fields.headline: Zimbabwe tour hits new crisis
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe 159 &165 Kent 487-8 dec Kent won by an innings and 163 runs
fields.body:
The tourists' sad capitulation inside three days was overshadowed yesterday by renewed fears for the rest of their stay. When asked whether the tour was in jeopardy, the Zimbabwe captain Andy Flower could only muster "I hope not".

"I think the guys need a day off, not just cricketing-wise," Flower added, rejecting any notion of net practice today after Zimbabwe's innings defeat. "There are a few other matters on people's minds."

While resisting the urge to use this as an alibi, he conceded that "matters of a non-cricketing nature" had worked against his players' concentration, but refused to elaborate as to whether he was referring to the grave political situation back home.

Speaking from Harare, the president of the Zimbabwe Cricket Union Peter Chingoka said: "As things stand there is no chance of the tour being called off. If there is a problem we will obviously talk to the players, but what is happening at home doesn't affect what's happening on the field."

An England and Wales Cricket Board spokesman played an equally straight bat: "At the moment we have no reason to believe that the tour will not continue as normal."

It is, of course, now too late for the ECB to find alternate opposition should the tour indeed be cancelled. The full ramifications should have been more thoroughly debated before the tourists arrived.

At least the sun was shining yesterday, but while the St Lawrence Ground bore some resemblance to the Harare Sports Club, the Zimbabweans' fortunes declined with pitiful rapidity. The crushing reversal 45 minutes after tea was inflicted by a depleted Kent team featuring three frontline bowlers with just four previous first-class outings between them.

While injuries to Heath Streak - unable to bat because of a swollen knee and now doubtful for the first test at Lord's on Thursday week - and Pommie Mbangwa (ankle) scarcely helped in the field, the Zimbabwe batsmen succumbed all too meekly.

The day began promisingly enough, Rahul Dravid failing to add to his overnight 182 before nicking Guy Whittall to slip in the fourth over, whereupon the rot resumed as Paul Nixon acquired his first 50 for his new county, adding 74 in 15 overs with the volcanic Matthew Fleming.

The dismay continued as soon as Grant Flower and Trevor Gripper went out to face three pre-prandial overs from David Masters and Min Patel. The skipper's brother edged Masters to Nixon for a duck and within an hour of the resumption half the side were back in the hutch.

Patel, who bowled unchanged thoughout, spun one viciously to elicit a caught-behind verdict against Gripper, who made no attempt to disguise his disapproval, but it was Masters who again took the eye and refused to let go.

In his first nine overs he claimed four for nine and he ended as the first Kent player since Ted Witherden in 1951 to take five wickets in an innings on his first-class debut, as well as securing the man of the match award.

webTitle: Vaughan injury puts Thorpe in the frame

fields.headline: Vaughan injury puts Thorpe in the frame
fields.trailText: Graham Thorpe, the Surrey left-hander snubbed when the central contracts were handed out by the England and Wales Cricket Board, will be hoping for a call from the England selectors now that a fractured finger is threatening to keep Michael Vaughan out of the first test in less than two weeks' time.
fields.body:
Graham Thorpe, the Surrey left-hander snubbed when the central contracts were handed out by the England and Wales Cricket Board, will be hoping for a call from the England selectors now that a fractured finger is threatening to keep Michael Vaughan out of the first test in less than two weeks' time.

Yorkshire's England batsman was hit on the hand on Thursday during the county championship match with Derbyshire and yesterday it was confirmed that he has broken the little finger near the knuckle on his left hand.

The injury will sideline him for up to three weeks and almost certainly rule him out of the first test against Zimbabwe which begins at Lord's on May 18, opening the door for Thorpe, who has not played for England since opting out of last winter's tour of South Africa.

This latest setback is a blow to Vaughan's chances of further establishing himself in the England team. It is the second hand injury he has suffered in the past six months. Having forced his way into the side for the first two tests against South Africa, he fractured a finger on his right hand during a provincial match in East London and did not reappear at the crease until the fourth test.

However, it was his innings of 69 which helped set up the dramatic and controversial win in the final test at Centurion and he is one of only 12 players who have been given central contracts.

Yesterday Vaughan admitted that it might be a severe setback. "The injury has come at a very bad time," he said, "but hopefully I'll be back playing in a month."

However, he must be seething. The opportunity is there for someone to take advantage of the weakest test team around and the injury puts a block on his progress.

Nick Knight made a double century for Warwickshire this week but Thorpe, a proven test performer albeit one who has underachieved over the past couple of years, would be the likeliest beneficiary from Vaughan's absence.

Yorkshire, meanwhile, carried too much firepower for Derbyshire, opening their First Division campaign with a victory yesterday at Headingley by an innings and 79 runs with a day to spare.

Derbyshire, 269 behind when they batted for a second time, were dismissed for 190, with England's Darren Gough and Craig White showing useful form to take three wickets each. Gough finished with three for 34 from 17 overs.

webTitle: Spirited Schofield keeps Leicestershire on the rack

fields.headline: Spirited Schofield keeps Leicestershire on the rack
fields.standfirst: Leicestershire 265 &155-6 Lancashire 488
fields.trailText: Leicestershire 265 &155-6 Lancashire 488
fields.body:
With Chris Lewis collecting newspaper payments for match-rigging allegations and Matthew Brimson offending Wisden by unzipping his fly in a team photograph, James Whitaker's move this summer from Leicestershire captain to chief executive could hardly have been more trying.

What will most concern Whitaker, though, is how his team fare now that his playing days are over. Early indications are not encouraging: failure to qualify for the quarter- finals of the Benson & Hedges Cup, and defeat beckoning here in the face of a determined Lancashire.

Leicestershire, consistent top-four finishers, might have imagined they could capably defend a first-innings total of 265. But the damage inflicted by Andrew Flintoff and Neil Fairbrother on the second day was continued yesterday by Chris Schofield, whose unbeaten 66, his best championship score, took Lancashire to a 223-run first-innings lead by half an hour after lunch.

In the face of that, Leicestershire's second innings was faint-hearted. In Darren Stevens and Trevor Ward they have two flyers at the top of the order, and both made quick exits against Greg Chapple with loose shots to square leg.

Darren Maddy's diligence might have been expected to make up for his team-mates' adventurousness, but he fretted 30 overs for his 18 before the leg-spinner Schofield switched to around the wicket after tea and had him caught at first slip.

Botched pull shots from Aftab Habib and Lewis left Leicestershire 155 for six at the close, still 68 behind, with only the captain Vince Wells organising much resistance.

webTitle: Inzamam lifts the clouds over Pakistan

fields.headline: Inzamam lifts the clouds over Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Pakistan 147-5 v West Indies
fields.trailText: Pakistan 147-5 v West Indies
fields.body:
The Pakistani batsmen, floundering at 26 for four in the first hour of the first test against West Indies at Bourda, Guyana, were probably wishing they could parlay the dark clouds of match-fixing allegations hovering over their heads into some weather-fixing which could have opened the even darker clouds hanging low over the ground all morning.

When it became obvious that the clouds simply would not turn into rain, Inzamam-ul-Haq set about fixing the Pakistani innings instead, as he has done every time he has gone to bat so far this tour. With a bit of help from Abdur Razzaq, the only other batsman to get into double figures, Inzamam took the score from 39 for five to 137 for five.

Cricket fans in Trinidad and Tobago were left wondering why a test match in so short a series (there are only two more tests, in Barbados and Antigua) should have been assigned to Guyana while Trinidad got only two one-day games and the first test against Zimbabwe.

While Trinidad is largely dry until June, rain in Guyana in May is almost a certainty. Additionally the Bourda Cricket Ground holds about 12,000 people; the Queen's Park Oval can accommodate easily twice that number. There is also a fairly large Muslim population in Trinidad that trans lates into local support for the touring team and a fantastic atmosphere. Even with a lunchtime score of 68 for five, the Bourda ground was nowhere near filled by teatime.

People from Trinidad and Tobago have two extra gripes. There is no Trinidadian in the team, which, for Trinis, is like salt-and-vinegar crisps without the salt and vinegar.

More than that, though, Trinidad's most famous son, Brian Lara, seems to be growing daily more un popular with his own West Indian crowd.

A man-in-the-street feature carried in yesterday's Stabroek News yielded half-a-dozen Guyanese who preferred not to see Lara return to the team at all, or only grudgingly as a batsman.

The perception seems to be widely held that Lara, in taking a break from cricket, abandoned the team; far from being given a shoulder to lean on, he is having a cold one turned to him.

fields.headline: County round-up
fields.trailText: Nottinghamshire are poised to win the Second Division match at Chelmsford despite dropping catches that, had they been held, would have seen off Essex a day early.
fields.body:
Nottinghamshire are poised to win the Second Division match at Chelmsford despite dropping catches that, had they been held, would have seen off Essex a day early.

With three wickets left, the hosts led by 118 thanks largely to Paul Grayson (47), dropped twice in the slips, and Stuart Law (55), missed by Usman Afzaal at mid-on.

 Matt Elliott, Australia's leading run-scorer in the 1997 test series in England, scored a century (117) at the first time of asking for Glamorgan. He and Steve James, unbeaten on 165, put on 203 for the first wicket to frustrate Warwickshire at Edgbaston.

 Devon Malcolm saved the follow-on for Northamptonshire at Lord's with a trademark inside-edge but Middlesex remain favourites to win.

fields.headline: Caddick steps into the breach
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 232 & 126 Somerset 319 & 40-1
Somerset win by nine wickets
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 232 & 126 Somerset 319 & 40-1

Somerset win by nine wickets
fields.body:
Andy Caddick responded magnificently to Somerset's injury crisis yesterday by returning figures of seven for 64 to lead them to victory by nine wickets and comfort those shrewd judges who had recognised them as a good each-way bet for the championship.

Somerset's victory was impressive. The positive captaincy of Jamie Cox and the confidence-building coaching of Dermot Reeve is bringing the best out of their players. They look in the mood to build on last season's success.

Caddick, who took 91 first-class wickets at 20.87 last year, was their main weapon but Somerset will not see a great deal of him this summer because of England duty, though he will play at Leicester on Thursday.

But the back-up seam looks good and the batting strong and deep. Crucially spirit abounds. Here they bowled out a disappointing Hampshire side for 126 in 57 overs with two of their frontline bowlers, Matt Bulbeck and Steffan Jones, injured and off the field.

Somerset, who had led by 87 on the first innings, knocked off the 40 they needed for victory in 10.1 overs.

Hampshire were without Adrian Aymes, Alan Mullally and Peter Hartley. But unless they improve, relegation is a real prospect. Their batting looks vulnerable and their captain Robin Smith, though still a fine player, is not the power he once was. Their solitary joy yesterday was Giles White's unbeaten 78.

White, the 15th Hampshire player to carry his bat, played Caddick with confidence, and hit seven fours over almost 3 hours. All he needed was some company.

Hampshire were 77 behind when they resumed on 10 without loss yesterday morning. Jason Laney was well caught at second slip and three overs later Will Kendall chopped Caddick on to his stumps.

Caddick, bending his back and full of hostility, proved too much for Smith, who was dropped in the gully on one and then well held at wide third slip without addition. Derek Kenway and John Stephenson followed cheaply and Hampshire were 67 for five at lunch.

After the interval Caddick sliced his way through the tail.

With a pair and a solitary wicket Shane Warne had a championship debut to forget. Within minutes of the end Warne marched out for a batting net. It was good to see.

fields.headline: Pakistan corruption report out soon
fields.trailText: The much-delayed judicial report on corruption in Pakistan cricket is expected to be published next week.
fields.body:
The much-delayed judicial report on corruption in Pakistan cricket is expected to be published next week.

The investigation into allegations that some Pakistan players had fixed matches began in 1998 and a report by Judge Malik Mohammad Qayyum was submitted to the national government in November. Qayyum said he had recommended life bans for some players.

A test series between Pakistan and West Indies began in Guyana yesterday and the Pakistan cricket board chairman Tauqir Zia said: "No date has been fixed but in all probability the report would be released immediately after the conclusion of the first test, some time next week.

"I would like the judge to be present so he can justify his punishments. I can't defend why one player has received stiff punishment while the other has been let off with a minor penalty."

Zia added that the decision by the International Cricket Council to impose life bans on players involved in match- fixing was not retroactive.

The Australian Cricket Board has also ruled out a review of the case involving Shane Warne and Mark Waugh, who were fined five years ago for providing weather and pitch information to bookmakers.

webTitle: When it's Provident to give in gracefully

fields.headline: When it's Provident to give in gracefully
fields.trailText: Mutuality was dealt a nasty blow this week when Friends Provident, one of the UK's biggest life insurers, surprised everyone by announcing plans to convert to a plc and pay windfalls likely to run into thousands of pounds to policyholders.
fields.body:
Mutuality was dealt a nasty blow this week when Friends Provident, one of the UK's biggest life insurers, surprised everyone by announcing plans to convert to a plc and pay windfalls likely to run into thousands of pounds to policyholders.

It was only a few days ago that the company came under attack from a group of carpetbaggers determined to force it to float on the stock market. However, Friends Prov says this is just a coincidence, and denies the speculators were responsible for its decision to ditch 168 years of mutuality. It says it came to the conclusion that mutuality was no longer the best way forward following several months of talks.

The company, founded by Quakers in 1832, is one of the leading lights in the world of ethical investment. It is highly regarded as a personal pensions provider, but has come in for some stick over poor returns on some of its endowment policies.

Applications for policies dated May 4 or later will not be eligible for windfalls. However, up until that date the company was still open to new members, with people able to buy a new Friends Provident savings plan for just £35 a month, or a lump-sum investment bond for £3,000.

Why is it demutualising?

The company says that being a plc will give it "greater financial flexibility" and enable it to compete more effectively in today's marketplace. It claims that demutualisation should spell double good news for policyholders: they will receive shares in the company and are also likely to benefit from improved investment performance.

So how much am I going to get?

Analysts suggest the company could float for around £4bn-£4.5bn. It had been assumed that only the 750,000 people holding "with-profits" policies - endowments, personal pensions and with-profits savings plans - would get windfalls, which would have meant average payouts of £5,000-plus.

But the company indicated this week it would also give around 1m non-with-profits policyholders payouts too, which means 1.7m people are set to benefit. If the money was dished out equally, that could mean windfalls averaging around £2,300-£2,700 per person.

But this isn't going to happen. The company has pretty much confirmed that the with-profits people will get the lion's share of the windfall cake, with smaller payouts going to the the rest. It will probably take a similar approach to Norwich Union, which gave non-with-profits policyholders windfalls worth around £500 when it floated in 1997, while the with-profits people all got at least double this.

I'm a policyholder with London & Manchester, the insurance company taken over by Friends Provident in 1998. Do I get a windfall?

I'm afraid not. That's because London & Manchester was a stock market quoted company when it was acquired by Friends Provident.

I'm a policyholder with UK Provident, a mutual insurer acquired by Friends Provident in the mid-80s.

You're in luck. Provided you are a qualifying member (precise details of who is and who isn't will be announced later), you will get a windfall.

I've bought a second-hand Friends Provident endowment policy.

Hmm, there doesn't seem to be a clear answer on this one. "Someone who buys a [second-hand endowment] policy is not a member and will not benefit from compensation for loss of membership," said one senior official. However, another spokesman said he could not rule out these people getting some form of payout. Watch this space...

So what happens now?

Friends Provident will be writing to policyholders next month to give more details of the proposed flotation. A special meeting to vote on the plans is likely around the middle of next year. At this, 75% of policyholders who vote must say yes to the company shedding its mutual status. If they say yes, flotation is set to take place "before the end of 2001". The earliest likely date is late summer/early autumn next year.

fields.headline: Staid and proud of it
fields.standfirst: Equitable Life may be seeking younger customers, but, says Tony Levene, it won't change
fields.trailText: Equitable Life may be seeking younger customers, but, says Tony Levene, it won't change.
fields.body:
This week we profile Equitable Life whose board faces a new challenge from a rebel policyholder.

Equitable Life - something to do with pension annuities and court cases?

Yes. But they also run investment funds which have nothing to do with arguments over guaranteed retirement benefits.

Don't they sell only to amiable old grandads?

You're thinking of the old "it's an Equitable Life, Henry" adverts. Those were full of self satisfaction. Now Equitable wants to sell to a younger generation.

How do they hope to do that?

With an appeal to twenty and thirty somethings. Equitable sponsors Frasier on Channel 4 so comfort and ease have been replaced by radio psychiatrist angst.

What do they offer other than pensions and TV comedies?

A mid-sized range of unit trusts.

Are they worth much?

Only around £500m - a mere drop in the Equitable's total £30bn ocean.

How many funds are there?

The Equitable counts 13, including Japan which it is launching this month.

Is that lucky?

The firm hopes so. It is trying to convince investors that it has thrown off allegations of sleepy fund management.

Which sectors are covered?

Most of the major areas, including Ethical and Footsie tracking. But there's no pure technology fund. It would be seen as too transient for a firm that's been around since 1762. And they've never bothered with a bond fund - the company thinks investors would be better off with one of its with-profits products.

Do customers like them?

Those that know about the firm love the lack of aggression from the sales force.

What's the view of independent financial advisers?

Nothing, nada, niente, zero and zilch. IFAs and the Equitable do not exist on the same planet.

Why's that?

The Equitable does not pay commission so it does not bother with IFAs. And the independent advisers don't bother with Equitable for the same reason.

Isn't not paying commission just a selling line?

Not here. It turns into lower charges and low entry levels. The annual management charge is 0.5% across the board with no extras such as custody. This compares with a more typical industry average of 1.5%, giving Equitable's long term investors a substantial uplift. And you can invest as little as a £250 lump sum or £40 per month.

Anything else?

The upfront charge is a standard 5%. But it falls to 4% at £10,000 and 3.5% at £50,000.

That's a tidy amount!

Not when your customers include many of Britain's best-heeled folk - it was apparently difficult to find high court judges to hear Equitable's annuity court cases who did not have a policy or two in the family.

How many fund managers?

Just 30 to manage the entire £30bn.

Do they have a star?

No. Personality cults are banned at Equitable.

What about style?

The emphasis is on teamwork, not taking big risks, and being as staid and conservative as they can. They hold a monthly meeting to check that all the trusts are singing from the same hymn sheet.

Does it work?

Increasingly so. The funds have crept up the performance tables In 1999, the average performance across the funds was 40% - better than most of their major competitors.

They're not into the winner picking thing. They've been around long enough to know that every fund has its day. But if pushed, they'll mention the Ethical Fund which was top of 182 in its sector over the past 12 months.

How did it manage that?

It had a heavy technology bias and was better at picking the winners.

Hi-tech? Surely not lastminute.com?

Afraid so. It bought into the lastminute offer at 380p and sold a few hours later at 500p. It's not a dot.com fan but it understands the laws of supply and demand.

What about the dogs?

High Income is not too appealing. Nor is the American fund. But while special situations was all about shrinking situations, over the last year or so, the fourth division relegation zone specialist has shot into the premier league.

How did they do that?

They got rid of the manager and hired another one.

Is there a website?

Try www.equitable.co.uk - you can buy an Isa online but also check out the latest Frasier gossip.

Is that the only unique selling proposition?

No. The Equitable line is "individual talent in formation, long term consistency and a guarantee of no white knuckle rides".

fields.headline: Tide turns for wet bikes
fields.trailText: A big damages award against Yamaha in the US may help British people injured in boating accidents - and particularly those involving wet bikes. Yamaha was ordered to pay $8.4m (£5.3m) dollars to David Cuenllas who was rendered paraplegic after being struck in the back by an out-of-control wet bike.
fields.body:
A big damages award against Yamaha in the US may help British people injured in boating accidents - and particularly those involving wet bikes. Yamaha was ordered to pay $8.4m (£5.3m) dollars to David Cuenllas who was rendered paraplegic after being struck in the back by an out-of-control wet bike.

These craft can steer only when the throttle is open. When an inexperienced user sees a hazard ahead, the instinct is to slow down, with potentially disastrous results. If the throttle is closed, the bike will continue in the same direction when the rider tries to turn it. It was this flaw which led to Cuenllas' accident at San Mateo near San Francisco.

Cuenllas sued both the other bike's rider and Yamaha. The jury decided that Yamaha was partly at fault. It is technically feasible to fit a device that overcomes this problem and Yamaha actually owns a patent on such a device. Cost constraints have prevented the company fitting it to production models. Although the jury took this into account, the award was, by American standards, relatively modest.

In 1996 an Alabama jury awarded $35m against Yamaha after a 12-year-old boy suffered brain damage when an all terrain vehicle flicked over.

Someone injured in similar circumstances in Britain would probably have a claim under the Consumer Protection Act 1987, though the damages would be far less. This provides that where a defective product causes injury, or substantial damage to property, the manufacturer or importer is liable. A product is defective if it "is not such as persons generally have a right to expect".

Surprisingly few cases have been brought under the Act, and while most have been by people injured by a product they were using themselves, the law is also intended to cover third party victims.

Yamaha insisted that the company does all it can to encourage responsible use of its products, saying: "The owners' handbook clearly sets out how to steer the craft. They certainly should never be used where there are swimmers."

No statistics are available for wet bike accidents, but the risks are such that 40 bills to regulate their use were passed by various American state legislatures in 1999. The US Coastguard is currently deciding whether to take action against manufacturers over the issue of their steering. In Britain, though, there is virtually no legal control.

The Cuenllas case may be of assistance to anyone injured here. While British courts are not bound by American precedents, the factual evidence could be highly persuasive. The more obvious claim will be against the person driving the boat - but that will be pointless unless they are wealthy enough to pay the damages or are insured. There is no legislation requiring boat owners in Britain to have third party insurance.

Local authorities do have the power to impose by-laws prohibiting boating without insurance - but it is not exercised consistently. The absence of mandatory insurance means many injured in boating accidents will be left with little remedy unless they can persuade a court that the manufacturer was also to blame.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

fields.headline: The engagement ring
fields.standfirst: Jessica McCallin looks at how shareholders are starting to put pressure on management
fields.trailText: Jessica McCallin looks at how shareholders are starting to put pressure on management.
fields.body:
Friends Provident this week slashed charges on its market-leading ethical funds amid growing evidence that ethical investing is taking off in the UK. Ethical funds account for a comparatively small percentage of the total investment market but the sector is growing at a phenomenal rate.

Since 1998 the amount invested in UK ethical trusts has jumped from £1.7bn to £2.8bn, a gain of 64%. In the US, where ethical investing is older and more established, it has risen from £334.8bn in 1997 to £947.5bn in 1999.

There are signs that the UK is starting to take its cue from the Americans in terms of the products that are available and the techniques used. The catchphrase in the US is engagement, where shareholders use their position as owners of a company to pressurise management into adopting more ethical practices.

On the other side of the Atlantic, some £683.5bn is controlled by investors who engage in shareholder advocacy by tabling resolutions at annual meetings or through direct dialogue. Research from the Social Investment Forum suggests the technique is popular, with the amount invested in shareholder engagement funds jumping from £53.2bn in 1997 to £167.7bn in 1999, making it the fastest growing sector of ethical investment.

Figures for the amount of money directed at engagement in the UK are difficult to pin down, but two leading campaigning organisations think shareholder action may be the way forward. Friends of the Earth has been talking to insurance companies about investments in oil, mining and logging companies, while Greenpeace was behind a recent BP Amoco shareholder resolution on Arctic exploration.

Ethical network, the UK Social Investment Forum, agrees that interest in shareholder engagement is growing, but says the work will be done by fund managers since most people buy shares through collective investments.

Nevertheless, shareholder engagement can have a significantly wider scope. It can be used by many of the so-called 'light green' ethical funds - those which may still invest in unreformed industries, but only those which are making the most effort to change their ways.

Engagement has its limitations, chief of which is the way you measure its success. Stephen Hine, head of research at the Ethical Investment Research Service expects more funds to get involved in shareholder engagement or at least claiming to do so. "But if funds say they will use engagement they must prove that their approach is working. This will be more difficult and investors should be aware of this."

webTitle: Hard-hit motorists get ton up warning

fields.headline: Hard-hit motorists get ton up warning
fields.standfirst: Jill Papworth reports on why premium rates are rising by 6% a quarter - and advises how to track down the cheapest deal
fields.trailText: Jill Papworth reports on why premium rates are rising by 6% a quarter - and advises how to track down the cheapest deal.
fields.body:
Latest figures from the AA show that the cost of car insurance policy has risen almost £100 in 12 months. The figures hammer home the need to shop around for the best deal.

The AA's quarterly index shows that the average comprehensive policy now costs £537 a year, £30 more than in January and £92 more than a year ago.

The 6% increase over the last quarter is not a one-off, but part of a continuing upward trend in rates prompted mainly by underwriting losses over the past five years.

"Insurance companies are forecasting a £1bn loss for 1999 and putting prices up by nearly 2% every month as a consequence," says Kerry Richardson, the AA's insurance managing director. "At the current rate of premium inflation, the cost of cover will have gone up by 26% at the end of 12 months."

The industry's continued losses, which stood at £1.4bn in 1998 and £1.1bn in 1997 - and the consequent rise in motor insurance premiums - are mainly the result of increased claims costs.

"Motor repair costs have gone up by 10% in the last year," says a spokesman for the Association of British Insurers (ABI).

The AA also cites the increased trend towards litigation following accidents, and new legislation which makes it easier for hospitals to reclaim the cost of treating accident victims which is expected to cost insurers up to £150m a year.

For every £1 taken in premiums, insurers are paying out £1.15 in claims, according to the AA. "Prices must increase if underwriters are to remain solvent and pay out claims in the future," says Mr Richardson.

Shopping around can cut the average £537 premium by 36% to a more palatable £346, though even these prices are rising every quarter. The "shoparound" premium is the average of the three lowest quoted by insurers in the survey.

"A lot of people don't bother to shop around," says the ABI. "They simply renew their existing policy each year and then have a moan about how much their premium has gone up. But it can definitely pay to shop around."

It's worth using a variety of routes to find the best quote. Try a good insurance broker or intermediary who can trawl a panel of major insurers to find you the best deal. If you have access to the internet, get online.

A good place to start is www.screentrade.co.uk. If you fill in one online form, it will search out the best quotes from a panel. Also check out the AA's own website, www.theaa.co.uk, which gets the best quote from a range of insurers and offers a 10% discount on premiums to internet buyers.

Compare these with quotes from a few direct insurers such as Direct Line, the largest provider of private motor insurance with 2.2m motor policyholders.

Finally, try going back to your existing insurer and asking if they can match the best quote you've found. One word of warning: if you find cover that is dramatically cheaper than other quotes received, do check that you are comparing like with like.

How to cut the cost of insurance

 The more people insured to drive a car, the higher the premiums. Adding a young person as a named driver to your policy can add 30% to the cost. CGU says that by switching from "any driver" to just policyholder and partner, you can save up to 15%.

 Limit your mileage. Some insurers offer a 10% discount if you drive less than 6,000 miles each year.

 Opt for a voluntary excess on top of the standard excess, typically £100. The AA offers up to 25% discount if you pay the first £150 of any claim while CGU gives £12 discount for a £50 voluntary excess and £24 off for a £100 excess.

 Fitting industry-approved security devices such as alarms and immobilisers, particularly to older cars which don't have them fitted as standard, can cut 10-20% off the cost.

 Consider driving a smaller or older car which costs less to insure than a new, racy model.

 Older drivers should seek out insurers which give up to 20% discount for over 50s.

 Tell your insurer if you can garage your car overnight. Some give discounts for this.

 Become a better driver. Newly-qualified drivers can get discounts by taking extra lessons under the Pass Plus scheme. Details on 0115 901 2633 or www.passplus.org.uk. Older drivers can obtain discounts from some brokers if they pass the advanced driving test.

 Switch from comprehensive to third-party cover - but only do this as a last resort, says the AA: "It may save money short term, but you may not be entitled to extras such as a courtesy car or legal assistance."

fields.headline: Glamour and poise
fields.trailText: La Bayadère The Lowry, Salford Quays ****
fields.body:
La Bayadère The Lowry, Salford Quays ****

When Petipa's ballet La Bayadère was premiered in 1877, the fake Indian splendour of its staging would have been all but out-glittered by the decor of the theatre - the Bolshoi in St. Petersburg - and by the competitive finery of its court audience.

Last night the location was, in contrast, Salford's new super-functional, robustly democratic theatre. Yet even if there was not a hint of ostentation in the Lowry's plain purple and aubergine auditorium, the performance was still an event. Not only did it mark the opening of a versatile lyric theatre with excellent sightlines and a huge stage (though an erratic acoustic), it also marked the first UK appearance in 16 years by the great Paris Opera Ballet.

Its Bayadère, first staged by Rudolph Nureyev in 1992, retains much of the leisurely extravagance of Petipa's original. Though the final scene of stormy retribution had been chopped there is a profligate cast of fakirs, temple dancers, warriors and even a fake elephant on wheels. It is so grandiose that, coupled with the very slow tempi of the Hallé orchestra, the staging occasionally appears to plod. But for fans deprived of the powered glamour and ineffable poise of the Parisian school, the dancing was the main point of the evening.

Last night's Solor was danced by the young Jean-Guillaume Bart (making his debut in the role). He performed with a wide-eyed hopefulness that belied vaulting technical assurance - contriving to make the smallest grace note gesture and the most powerful leap into equally eloquent.

Agnes Letestu as his beloved, Nikiya, also seemed to perform on an unbroken loop of movement, each step spooling into the next. At times her fluency looked almost bland, perhaps due to her unvarying expression of stricken seriousness. But Aurelie Dupont as the hatchet-hearted Gamzatti was a much sparkier performer: her dancing is of an imperious scale and control, but she performs with a deliciously cynical smile and malevolent energy.

The corps are the stars of Act 3, due to the nerve wrackingly exquisite symmetries of the Shades' choreography, performed with a proud collective authority that was by turn tender and austere.

Paris Opera Ballet is at the Lowry, Salford, until May 7. Box office: 0161-876 2000.

webTitle: Phoenix tells BMW it is in the money

fields.headline: Phoenix tells BMW it is in the money
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The Phoenix consortium yesterday claimed that it had secured financial backing for its bid for the Rover car company. A spokesman for the consortium led by former Rover chief executive John Towers said: "The backing is in place and BMW have been told."
fields.body:
The Phoenix consortium yesterday claimed that it had secured financial backing for its bid for the Rover car company. A spokesman for the consortium led by former Rover chief executive John Towers said: "The backing is in place and BMW have been told."

The question of how the consortium would finance its bid has been the main sticking point in its negotiations with BMW, which is determined to dispose of its loss-making Rover subsidiary. BMW exec utives will now have to decide whether the quality of the financial package justifies further negotiations.

The German company has threatened to close Rover unless a buyer can be found by the end of the month. Industry sources said it wanted a clear outline of a deal agreed before its annual meeting on May 16.

The consortium spokesman said that Mr Towers had given full details of the financial package to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary.

Mr Towers, accompanied by other members of the consortium and union officials, pre sented a detailed business plan for Rover to Mr Byers and DTI officials.

The spokesman would not name the financial backers or say how much was involved. However, industry sources said Phoenix hoped to get £500m from BMW to cover redundancy costs and raise £200m from institutions to cover Rover's running costs. The DTI said Mr Towers had not made a formal request for state aid.

fields.headline: Glorious barbarities
fields.trailText: Kirov Orchestra/Gergiev Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.body:
Kirov Orchestra/Gergiev Royal Festival Hall, London ****

"O hear the summons of the barbarian lyre," the Russian Symbolist Alexander Blok wrote in his 1918 poem The Scythians. The poem, with its queasy vision of Asiatic hordes terrorising Europe, was Blok's exultant response to the twin convulsions of war and revolution which had ripped apart the civilised veneer of the Tsarist empire.

The "barbarian lyre" had, however, been sounding for a while: in 1916 Prokofiev premiered his Scythian Suite in Petrograd; as early as 1913, Stravinsky had self-consciously explored "primitive" Russia in The Rite of Spring. Both sonic cataclysms were commissioned by Diaghilev (though the ballet from which the Scythian Suite was derived never made it to the stage). It seemed appropriate that the two works should kick off the South Bank's massive Diaghilev retrospective, with the Kirov Orchestra conducted by Valery Gergiev.

The Soviet authorities predictably gave The Rite of Spring a wide berth, so hearing it restored to the repertoire of one of Russia's finest orchestras was a treat. A couple of tentative brass entries apart, the playing was thrilling. Gergiev's interpretation is rivetting, though it has its flaws. This is no eruptive racket, but a carefully structured ritual proceeding with measured intensity. Part I is considerably more violent than Part II (it's usually the other way round).

Gergiev finds vestiges of Russian Orthodox liturgy in the block chords and bell-like sonorities of the Summoning of the Ancestors. The voltage sometimes drops, however. Where Stravinsky calms down a bit, Gergiev dawdles, though he teases out some sensual textures in the process. The ending, with a colossal pause before the final crunch, is mannered in the extreme.

The Scythian Suite has the reputation of being the loudest piece of music ever written, and there were certainly moments when you felt that the Festival Hall's roof might cave in. It is in the quieter passages, like the nocturne, where Gergiev (and Prokofiev) are actually more impressive. The orchestration here is lush - closer to Strauss's Salome than anything by Stravinsky - and the sound glittered with opalescent beauty.

Sandwiched in between this pair came Prokofiev's The Prodigal Son. Shorn of Balanchine's stupendous choreography, you become acutely aware that this is not so much a biblical parable as a portrait of the seductions and terrors of a very modernist city. You're also conscious, however, of the bitty, episodic nature of the music. The Prodigal Son may be one of Balanchine's greatest ballets, but it's not Prokofiev's best score.

fields.headline: Safeway warns the banks
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Safeway has waded in to the controversy over the cost of withdrawing money from cash machines by warning the banks which have machines in its stores that charging will not be tolerated.
fields.body:
Safeway has waded in to the controversy over the cost of withdrawing money from cash machines by warning the banks which have machines in its stores that charging will not be tolerated.

Simon Laffin, finance director of Safeway, said the supermarket chain was having "useful dialogues" the banks, including Royal Bank of Scotland, Abbey National and Barclays, about the policy over charging.

The move follows the decision by rival grocery group Tesco to banish 74 Barclays cash machines from its supermarkets, citing the bank's policy on charging. Barclays, however, insisted that it had to remove the machines - it will still have 125 in Tesco stores - because its had not tendered enough for the sites.

The issue of cash machine charging blew up last year when Barclays said it would introduce a £1 surcharge on rivals' customers using its machines, replacing a disloyalty fee which it had charged its own customers when they used non-Barclays machine.

That eventually prompted the industry to edge towards the surcharges which are to be introduced next year. Lloyds TSB has said it would set it set its surcharge through the Link cash machine network at 50p although its rivals were yet to make their charges clear.

Mr Laffin at Safeway said: "We are working very hard to make sure customers do not have to pay at ATMs [automated teller machines]."

He admitted that the banks and building societies did have to pay a "relatively small sum of money" to install the machines in or outside its stores.

The stance by some of the firms which provide locations for cash machines risked causing even further confusion about the charging structure for money withdrawals, one industry insider said.

The situation is already complicated and dogged by discrepancies. For instance, NatWest customers are charged a £1 disloyalty fee by their bank for using Royal Bank of Scotland machines, even though NatWest is now owned by Royal Bank. A spokesman for the bank said yesterday that there were no plans to change the policy, which was in line with the strategy of running the two brands separately after the takeover.

fields.headline: Standard Life on collision course
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Standard Life is on a collision course with rivals as it finalises its defence document against carpetbaggers who have forced a demutualisation vote.
fields.body:
Standard Life is on a collision course with rivals as it finalises its defence document against carpetbaggers who have forced a demutualisation vote.

The insurer, Europe's largest mutual, is to compare the performance of with-profits policies of Norwich Union, Clerical Medical, Scottish Amicable and Scottish Widows before and after their demutualisation.

It intends to show that Standard Life policies have performed better: for instance, the holder of a 25-year Norwich Union with-profits policy has lost out by 3.9% since the insurer voted to demutualise in April 1997, while a Standard Life policyholder saw a 7.5% improvement over the period.

Standard Life's defence document will be sent to policyholders to try to dissuade them from backing a demutualisation campaign led by Fred Woollard. The vote is on June 27.

The defence was criticised by independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet, who yes terday issued a report on what he describes as the "dirty war of disinformation" being waged by the by the mutual.

The report says legal safeguards will prevent any of Standard Life's 2.3m policyholders from being disadvantaged by demutualisation, largely because government-appointed actuaries and the Scottish Court of Sessions cannot approve a conversion if it leaves existing policyholders out of pocket.

Mr Cazalet also challenges Standard Life's assertion that many policyholders will receive payouts of £600 or less. He estimates the average windfall will be just over £6,000, with the vast majority of policyholders receiving between £3,000 and £10,000.

Standard Life's defence threatens to cause a major row with insurers which have demutualised Norwich Union chief actuary Geoff Shaw said: "The facts about payout figures they are using are correct, but the reasoning behind them has nothing to do with demutualisation."

fields.headline: Keeping pensions free from pollution
fields.standfirst: Jill Papworth looks at moves to bring in socially responsible investment policies for trustees and fund managers
fields.trailText: Is your company pension supporting polluters, arms manufacturers, cigarette makers or firms that experiment on animals? Now is the time to take action to ensure that it is invested ethically.
fields.body:
Is your company pension supporting polluters, arms manufacturers, cigarette makers or firms that experiment on animals? Now is the time to take action to ensure that it is invested ethically.

From July 3 this year, as a result of a regulation under the 1995 Pensions Act, trustees of occupational pension funds will have to state their ethical stance. They must declare in their statement of investment principles whether or not they have a socially responsible investment (SRI) policy and, if so, what it is. Local authority pension funds will be required to make a similar statement.

The declaration will explain "the extent (if at all) to which social, environmental or ethical considerations are taken into account in the selection, retention and realisation of investments".

This new rule will not compel pension trustees to invest in a socially responsible way. It will simply require them to disclose whether or not they do so. But indications so far are that it will encourage many pension funds to adopt some sort of SRI strategy.

A handful of the major pension funds have already announced a commitment to ethical investment ahead of the July 3 deadline.

For example, the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS) with assets of nearly £20bn and more than 153,000 members, is to strengthen its socially responsible policies.

"Today no properly run public company or fund manager should be unaware of the importance of public opinion and ethical issues," said Professor Sir Graeme Davies, the chairman.

The scheme is appointing new staff to monitor the ethical and environmental behaviour of the companies it invests in and to pursue a policy of more active engagement on these issues - making representations to those companies and using shareholder power to seek corporate policy changes.

The fund says that failure to adopt best practice on social, environmental or ethical issues by companies in which it invests may have an adverse financial impact on the value or the return on that investment

USS is also going to publish the names of all companies in which it has a shareholding on www.usshq.co.uk.

The trustees of the BT Pension Scheme, Britain's largest with about £29bn in assets, have also announced a commitment to ethical investment. This will instruct investment managers that when selecting shares they must consider the following: "a company run in the long-term interests of its share holders will need to manage effectively relationships with its employees, suppliers and customers, to behave ethically and to have regard for the environment and society as a whole".

The new policy will also ask fund managers to engage with the companies they invest in, using their rights as shareholders.

Penny Shepherd, executive director of the UK SocialInvestment Forum (UKSIF) says: "We are hearing that a lot of pension funds do want to respond positively to this new requirement. There is generally an interest in the principle that environmental issues in particular are one of a number of factors that affect investment performance."

But Ms Shepherd is not expecting large numbers of funds to start screening out stocks on ethical grounds.

The legal requirement for pension fund trustees to invest in the best interests of the beneficiaries - usually taken to mean best 'financial' interests - makes them wary of excluding stocks on purely moral grounds which may have adverse financial consequences.

Instead, trustees are tending to favour the engagement approach or are testing the ethical waters by placing a small portion of a fund's assets with specialist SRI investment managers.

A number of local authorities have taken this tack - including Nottingham County Council - which has placed £50m with Henderson Investors on a specifically environmental mandate.

Learn more about your pension investments

To encourage employees to make their pension schemes more ethical, Friends of the Earth offers a campaign pack, including a sample postcard which scheme members can send to their fund trustees. For details call FoE on 020 7490 1555.

EIRIS - the Ethical Investment Research Service - runs a campaign aimed at helping scheme members learn more about, and potentially influence, how their pension is invested.

It suggests contacting pensions scheme administrators or the chairman of the trustees, whose details should be in the annual report which all scheme members are entitled to receive.

Useful questions to ask include:

 Who are the fund managers for my pension?

 Have trustees considered ethical investment? Have they consulted fund managers and advisers? If so, what happened?

 Does my scheme have AVC (additional voluntary contributions) options? Is there an ethical AVC option?

 Is there an annual meeting at which members can question trustees and fund managers?

 Can I have a list of the companies my pension scheme invests in?

 Do members have a say in where their money is invested?

fields.headline: Pointers, but to where?
fields.standfirst: Serious doubts are being raised about the guides produced by independent financial advisers. Tony Levene warns against advice that's far from impartial
fields.trailText: Investors risk being misled by "guides" produced by independent financial adviser firms which offer neither independence nor advice, according to a Jobs & Money investigation this week.
fields.body:
Investors risk being misled by "guides" produced by independent financial adviser firms which offer neither independence nor advice, according to a Jobs & Money investigation this week. Savers are not told that the "independently-selected" unit trusts listed in discount ISA "guides" may have paid the broker anything up to £100,000 to gain inclusion.

Critics say the guides, often included in newspaper sections or sent through the post, make a mockery of independent advice with one top IFA saying the practice "stinks".

Nor is the public informed that some of the guides refuse to recommend funds which have not forked out, even though they may be the best choice for many investors. Other guides will list trusts which have not paid - but give them substantially less billing, reducing them to the equivalent of a bottom shelf brand in a supermarket.

And while it is a "pile them high, sell them cheap" sales method - most of these brokers discount all of the 5% upfront charge - the range on offer is narrow.

Unlike a supermarket which may have thousands of lines, "discount brokers" may offer as little as half a dozen funds. Last Sunday, Elson Associates, a Kent based IFA which calls itself 'one of the country's major investment discount houses' distributed millions of an Investing in Technology guide via a tabloid newspaper.

Described as a "complete" ISA guide, it featured just five out of the 23 small investor technology funds currently on offer in the UK. Big names such as M&G and SocGen Technology were excluded. The specific risk of investing in technology was relegated to small print while readers would be unaware of the recent fall in high tech shares which has knocked much of the gloss from performance, with some funds falling by 20% since their mid-March peak. Many of these guides are put together weeks before they are sent out. Elson director Graham Elson was not available for comment.

Brokers are legally obliged to disclose to you the commission paid to them by product providers. Indeed, the discount brokers' main selling point is that they pass back to you all or nearly all of the initial commission they receive. However, there are few rules preventing them from receiving income from product providers in other ways, such as payments for adverts that appear in the guides - provided the publishing operation does not make a profit, which would be banned under the FSA's indirect benefit rules.

The worry is that many investors will be lured into buying funds because they believe they have been independently selected yet the reality may be that the funds are only being pushed because the provider is paying large cheques to the broker.

Ian Beestin, of the ISA Shop, says: "The buying of places in the guides stinks. What is galling is how successful it is for them. We would have no integrity if we did the same."

Don Clark of Wolverhampton brokers Torquil Clark is also among these disturbed by this method. He says: "These are pseudo-guides and they're tacky. There is no real customer focus and limited or no after care. The potential for inexperienced investors to get it wrong is immense."

This week he wrote to eight investment houses. His letter suggests clients could be confused by guides which sell products that are easiest to move at any given time.

Richard Craven, of HCF Partnership, a guide producing IFA, confirms that companies pay for insertions. "We did our research, created a list of 15 and ran with six. If they didn't pay, we couldn't afford it so they wouldn't be in. But we don't profit directly from the publication - that's against FSA rules."

Craven concedes that he limits his choice to big companies with big marketing budgets. "We don't like small unit trust companies. We include what people want us to put in - the big selling widely publicised funds. The fund managers for this approach are those that people want to buy rather than those we would recommend if we were giving independent advice."

The IFAs who produce these guides can make easy money at little or no risk. The advertising fees pay for print-ing and distribution, leaving advisers with an annual commission flow, usually 0.5% of the value of your fund.

Julian Penniston at Willis Owen, the IFA which invented this method, told Jobs & Money the firm, which has 12 staff, was earning around £2m a year from 0.5% renewal commissions.

The Willis Owen guide has been criticised by other IFAs because it says "recommendations" - a word that most other discount brokers shy away from - and because the word "independent" appears on the cover when advice is coloured by financial considerations.

"It was my idea," Penniston says. "We've done six guides and while our biggest was entirely supported by adver-tisers, our latest will feature funds where our advertising deal was turned down. These funds will get less space while those that pay will get an advert plus all their details and key features. But I only approach trusts which are on a list drawn up by managing director John Owen."

Penniston claims that Willis Owen guides are produced with FSA approval but "most of the others have compliance errors. Some don't put in commission payments; some ignore the front end charge in calculating performance figures; they may cheat on graphs to make figures look more attractive and they leave out risk warnings."

Fund managers say they are consistently approached by brokers with deals which can cost them between £50,000 and £100,000.

"We'll stump up the cash if we think the guide will go to the right people and if there is no other competitive trust included. The payment is a guarantee of exclusivity. People believe their recommendation even though we have simply bought advertising space," says one.

CGU pays to have its monthly income fund put into guides even though, as Best Investment's Jason Hollands points out, it has lost Hugh Everitt, fund manager responsible for performance.

However, there are few rules preventing them from receiving income from product providers in other ways, such as payments for adverts that appear in the guides - provided the publishing operation does not make a profit, which would be banned under the FSA's indirect benefit rules. The worry is that many investors will be lured into buying funds because they believe they have been independently selected yet the reality may be that the funds are only being pushed because the provider is paying large cheques to the broker. Ian Beestin, of the ISA Shop, says: "The buying of places in the guides stinks. What is galling is how successful it is for them. We would have no integrity if we did the same." Don Clark of Wolverhampton brokers Torquil Clark is also among these disturbed by this method. He says: "These are pseudo-guides and they're tacky. There is no real customer focus and limited or no after care. The potential for inexperienced investors to get it wrong is immense." This week he wrote to eight investment houses. His letter suggests clients could be confused by guides which sell products that are easiest to move at any given time. Richard Craven, of HCF Partnership, a guide producing IFA, confirms that companies pay for insertions. "We did our research, created a list of 15 and ran with six. If they didn't pay, we couldn't afford it so they wouldn't be in. But we don't profit directly from the publication - that's against FSA rules." Craven concedes that he limits his choice to big companies with big marketing budgets. "We don't like small unit trust companies. We include what people want us to put in - the big selling widely publicised funds. The fund managers for this approach are those that people want to buy rather than those we would recommend if we were giving independent advice." The IFAs who produce these guides can make easy money at little or no risk. The advertising fees pay for print-ing and distribution, leaving advisers with an annual commission flow, usually 0.5% of the value of your fund. Julian Penniston at Willis Owen, the IFA which invented this method, told Jobs & Money the firm, which has 12 staff, was earning around £2m a year from 0.5% renewal commissions. The Willis Owen guide has been criticised by other IFAs because it says "recommendations" - a word that most other discount brokers shy away from - and because the word "independent" appears on the cover when advice is coloured by financial considerations. "It was my idea," Penniston says. "We've done six guides and while our biggest was entirely supported by adver-tisers, our latest will feature funds where our advertising deal was turned down. These funds will get less space while those that pay will get an advert plus all their details and key features. But I only approach trusts which are on a list drawn up by managing director John Owen." Penniston claims that Willis Owen guides are produced with FSA approval but "most of the others have compliance errors. Some don't put in commission payments; some ignore the front end charge in calculating performance figures; they may cheat on graphs to make figures look more attractive and they leave out risk warnings." Fund managers say they are consistently approached by brokers with deals which can cost them between £50,000 and £100,000. "We'll stump up the cash if we think the guide will go to the right people and if there is no other competitive trust included. The payment is a guarantee of exclusivity. People believe their recommendation even though we have simply bought advertising space," says one. CGU pays to have its monthly income fund put into guides even though, as Best Investment's Jason Hollands points out, it has lost Hugh Everitt, fund manager responsible for performance.

webTitle: Baffled buyers try to solve the price puzzle

fields.headline: Baffled buyers try to solve the price puzzle
fields.standfirst: Is the housing market soaring or set to sink as prospective purchasers put their dreams on hold? As lenders contradict each other, Rupert Jones and Jessica McCallin investigate the situation
fields.trailText: Is the housing market soaring or set to sink as prospective purchasers put their dreams on hold? As lenders contradict each other, Rupert Jones and Jessica McCallin investigate the situation
fields.body:
Britain's booming house market is defying all attempts to keep it in check. Or it is slowing down following the exceptional surges in London and the south-east during the last year? These conflicting views were presented to millions of bemused homeowners and buyers this week by two of Britain's biggest mortgage lenders.

According to the Nationwide, the price of an average house increased by £1,500 last month - £50 a day - to £80,893. The typical UK property is now worth 17.5% more than a year ago - the highest figure for more than a decade, and a rate of growth almost seven times the 2.6% headline general rate of inflation. In some parts of London, prices are up as much as 45% in a year. The society says the current rate of house price growth is "not sustainable", then predicts that there will be no let-up in the strength of the market for another few months at least.

By contrast, the Halifax reckons the market "is not as buoyant as a few months ago". It says prices rose last month, but by only 0.8%, compared with rises of well over 2% in December and January. It says the slowdown indicates that the four interest rate rises since the autumn are taking effect and reflects the fact that prices in many parts of London - the region that has led the upturn - have now breached the affordability ceiling for many would-be buyers. The price of a fairly average semi in a fairly average London borough is now £211,000. Based on standard mortgage criteria of three times income, you would need to be earning £70,000 to afford such a property.

Which lender is right? Well, the Nationwide's bullish view was backed by new figures showing that the amount of mortgage money lent by the major UK banks leapt by almost a third in March to £6.5bn, compared with under £5bn in February. There were 75,772 new loans approved for house purchase in March (this excludes remortgages, loans for home improvements and equity release schemes) - almost double January's total of 39,062.

However, the Halifax makes the point that in London, property values have risen so far, so fast in some areas that growing numbers of would-be buyers are being priced out of the market, and are either turning their attentions to less expensive areas or are waiting for the market to calm down.

This fits in with anecdotal evidence that ambitious sellers who put their homes on the market at sky-high prices, particularly in hot spot areas, are having to knock £10,000, £15,000 or even £20,000 off the asking price. Privately, some valuers say the market in London has already turned.

It's certainly fair to say that in London, the effects of the boom have trickled down into traditionally "cheaper" areas such as Newham and Lewisham to the extent that in terms of house price growth rates, they have now overtaken long standing star performers such as Islington and Kensington.

Figures from the Nationwide show that last summer, the annual rate of house price inflation in Newham was 16%, while in Sutton, to the south, it was just 8%. Over in ultra-hip Islington, the figure was 20%, while in Kensington and Chelsea it was an impressive 25%.

Fast-forward to the first three months of this year and the picture is very different: the annual house price growth figure for Newham has leapt to 31%, while in Sutton it has increased almost four-fold to 30%. However, Islington and Kensington and Chelsea have seen little or no acceleration: the figure for Islington is unchanged at 20%, and in Kensington and Chelsea it has only crept up slightly to 29%.

A straw poll of estate agents in some of London's hot spots showed that many would rebut the suggestion that things are slowing down. In Islington there is evidence that the market may be cooling, but the view is that this probably reflects people rushing to complete their purchases before the stamp duty increase announced in the March Budget took effect. The borough's estate agents say demand continues to outstrip supply.

Sellers in Fulham, south-west London, will be laughing all the way to the bank, with no one expecting prices to calm down and some agents saying increases of between 10% and 20% could still be possible this year. According to agents FPD Savills, prices in the area have increased 54.5% over the past year as buyers priced out of neighbouring Chelsea and Kensington looked to Fulham.

Mukhtar Quraishi, managing director of agent Harrington Lowndes, says: "Prices are still going up, though not as much as last year. People are more discerning now and are not willing to pay stupid prices."

Clapham is showing signs of slowing down. Agents say demand is still strong, especially around the Common, but prices will probably start to stabilise over the year. Maggie McKenna of John D Wood says: "Some buyers have been holding back, waiting to see what happens with interest rates and the stock market. They don't want to get burnt if prices start to fall." That said, entry level for flats is still over £100,000 and John D Wood recently sold a house in Clapham for £3m.

Signs are emerging that the price growth is rippling out to other regions. The region experiencing the biggest increase in house prices so far this year is the west Midlands, where the cost of the average home rose 5.1% to £78,806 over January 1-March 31, according to the Halifax.

Demand is not uniform throughout the area, with period family homes commanding a premium and modern terraces the lowest. And the possibility that the Rover car plant at Longbridge may close is putting people on edge. But Martin Greaves of Coventry estate agents Loveitts says: "Longbridge has yet to have an impact on house prices as people are hoping the plant will be rescued. The market has been very hectic since the new year and at times has resembled the 1988 rush."

The West Midlands average of £78,806 may be light years away from the absurd London prices, but it's still way out of the league of many thousands of poorly-paid public sector workers. For them, the Halifax's table of typical prices for semi-detached houses in 59 UK counties and areas, will make depressing reading. According to its figures, a nurse earning £14,800 a year, giving a mortgage of slightly over £44,000, would struggle to get a mortgage to buy a semi in even the UK's very cheapest areas. The lowest prices in the Halifax table were South Humberside (£45,700), South Yorkshire (£48,000) and North Humberside (£49,850).

Growing numbers of people are finding themselves priced out of the rental market, too. The London Research Centre found that the average weekly rent for a two-bedroom flat in London was £274 - more than £14,000 a year - and was as high as £399 in Westminster and £429 in Kensington and Chelsea. Yet the average rent for a similar property in Leeds was £65 a week. It's estimated that Londoners earn about 12% more than people in the rest of the UK, but that clearly doesn't come anywhere close to bridging this vast north-south divide.

It's worth pointing out that this is not the first time the Halifax and the Nationwide have clashed over house prices although both use similar methodologies. Something's clearly wrong somewhere, though, and it's a problem that needs prompt attention.

The two lenders have a duty to ensure their house price indices accurately reflect what is happening on the streets of Britain. Their data influences the life-changing decisions people are making every day about whether they should buy or sell a property, and the Bank of England's interest rate decisions are guided to no small degree by their findings.

How a change of area can change your fortunes

Mark Pavlika, 28, is an accountant earning £36,000 a year - but all that could buy him is a one-bedroom flat, not even towards the centre of London.

Instead, he bought a two-bedroom Victorian house in Edmonton in north London. He paid £86,000 late last year and believes it has already risen in value to more than £100,000. But his house search took more than a year and a half.

"I wanted to move to the Bounds Green area because I grew up there and my family and friends still live there.

"But when I finally did look in Edmonton, I was amazed by the quality of the houses and how much I could get for my money. It's not the trendiest place in London, but the more first time buyers that move here, the better it will get."

The prospect of a house price recession does not worry him as he is unlikely to move for the next 10 years. "I've been living here since November and my house is already worth £16,000 more than I paid for it, so from an investment point of view I'm very happy."

fields.headline: Infinite varieties
fields.trailText: CBSO/Oramo Symphony Hall, Birmingham ****
fields.body:
CBSO/Oramo Symphony Hall, Birmingham ****

No one has ever accused Sibelius of writing the same symphony over and over again. But it isn't until you hear two of the symphonies side by side that you realise how different they can be. Sibelius began his one- movement Seventh Symphony soon after finishing the four-movement Sixth; they are genuinely worlds apart.

It is rare to find a conductor who can be equally convincing in both works. Conductor Sakari Oramo did better than most. His reading of the Seventh Symphony was a triumph, without qualification. His Sixth was interesting and in places very beautiful, but in this symphony the success was patchy.

The first movement began very well. The strings' soaring polyphony - the nearest Sibelius ever came to imitating his idol Palestrina in orchestral terms - was almost vocal in its calm radiance. But later in the movement minute tempo changes undermined the sense of flowing current: the pace seemed forced, under pressure.

The hushed Nordic forest-scape in the second movement was full of mystery, but that was exceptional. When it works, there is something intimate and elusive about this symphony. Here a lot of it seemed a degree too forward, too obvious.

But the Seventh Symphony was magnificent: a vital, confident musical organism from first to last bar. Every tempo or modulation of tempo seemed absolutely right. The climaxes were elemental and the moments of quieter reflection just as rivetting. Oramo and the orchestra were also very persuasive in the four Interludes from Joonas Kokkonen's opera The Last Temptation, a piece which has been revered as a classic in Finland since its premiere in 1975 but is little known outside.

I am tempted to say that the Last Temptation music gets better the less Kokkonen tries to be up-to-date - the finest music is in the moving and frankly tonal hymn in the final Interlude. But critics once said very similar things about Prokofiev's First Violin Concerto, and what a classic that now seems.

Violinist Vadim Repin sounded completely at home in both the romantic-lyrical and the naughty boy-modernist music, and he shaped it all with great assurance.

webTitle: ECB chief reassures citizens over euro

fields.headline: ECB chief reassures citizens over euro
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: European central bank governor Wim Duisenberg yesterday sought to reassure worried savers and consumers that the tumbling euro would not ravage their nest eggs or stoke up the cost of living.
fields.body:
European central bank governor Wim Duisenberg yesterday sought to reassure worried savers and consumers that the tumbling euro would not ravage their nest eggs or stoke up the cost of living.

His unusual verbal intervention, combined with rumours that European central banks might be prepared to back it by buying euros on foreign exchanges, helped the shell-shocked currency stage a modest rally from Thursday's record lows, though it was unable to hold its best levels.

In what was described as an unprecedented statement Mr Duisenberg acknowledged that the fall in the euro, which has lost a quarter of its value against the dollar since its launch in January last year, was causing concern to citizens in the 11-nation euro-zone. "I understand their concerns since a persistently lower exchange rate might ultimately lead to higher prices in the shops," he said.

But he said the region was enjoying one of its longest periods of price stability for decades and, in a passage reminiscent of British prime minister Harold Wilson's "pound in your pocket" argument in 1967, he said: "This internal stability of the euro means people can be confident that their savings and pensions will keep their value over time."

He said the ECB was watching the exchange rate closely and -pointing to four interest rate rises since November - said it would do all it could to maintain price stability.

The euro has fallen from a launch value of $1.17 to as low of 88.40 cents against the dollar this week. Though it managed a modest initial rally to 90c, it then fell back later in the day to just over 89c.

Analysts were divided about the wisdom of Mr Duisenberg's speech. Eckhard Schulte at the Industrial Bank of Japan in Frankfurt criticised Mr Duisenberg's initiative. "It isn't sensible to heat up or dramatise the current atmosphere around the euro by making such a statement. The popular debate on the euro has been emotional and irrational and this statement is exactly what we do not need."

But Uwe Angenendt, chief economist at the BHF bank welcomed the ECB president's move. "Putting out a statement is certainly an unusual means of getting the point across but ECB policy is on the right path. Growth and inflation data in the coming months will improve so much that the euro has probably found its low."

Rumours that the ECB is preparing to mobilise its huge reserves in defence of the euro were rife in the foreign exchange market yesterday though there was no official comment.

"I have the feeling the ECB really is thinking about intervention, to give the market a strong hint that it won't accept a further depreciation of the euro," said HSBC Trinkhaus economist Frank Schröder. But he warned the tactic could backfire if the markets subsequently decided to test the ECB's determination.

The single currency's plight will be on the agenda at Monday's meeting of eurozone finance ministers, though German chancellor Helmut Schröder had affected unconcern. "I think it is appropriate to be relaxed. I am quite certain the euro is a strong currency," he said.

But Italian prime minister Giuliano Amato said there was a need for greater economic policy coordination and blamed international trade imbalances for the weakness of the single currency.

European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg yesterday:

The current development of the euro's exchange rate has given rise to questions from European citizens who are concerned about the value of their currency.

To them, I would like to say the following: I understand their concerns, since a persistently lower euro exchange rate might ultimately lead to higher prices in the shops. It may also undermine the perception of the euro as a stable currency. Therefore, we at the ECB monitor the euro exchange rate very closely.

Citizens should feel reassured by the fact that prices are currently stable in the euro area. Indeed, over the last decades there have been few periods in which prices have been stable for so long. This internal stability of the euro means that people can be confident that their savings and pensions will keep their value over time.

The ECB has, over the past six months, taken measures and increased interest rates four times. European citizens can be assured that the future of the euro is that of a strong currency, based on price stability and the strength of the European economy.

Prime minister Harold Wilson in November 1967 explaining the Labour government's decision to devalue the pound:

It would have been possible to ride out this present tide of foreign speculation against the pound by borrowing from central banks and governments ... In our view it would have been irresponsible to go on dealing with these successive waves of speculation by borrowing ... without tackling the root cause of the speculation.

From now the pound abroad is worth 14% or so less in terms of other currencies. It does not mean, of course, that the pound here in Britain, in your pocket or purse or in your bank has been devalued.

I have said that imports will cost more and this means higher prices over a period for some of our imports, including some of our basic foods.

It is vital that price rises are limited to those where increased import costs make this unavoidable. Our people will not tolerate traders who are not affected by import costs trying to cash in by unjustifiable price increases ...

It is just as vital that any prices that do go up are not used as an excuse for excessive wage demands.
