Citizens should feel reassured by the fact that prices are currently stable in the euro area. Indeed, over the last decades there have been few periods in which prices have been stable for so long. This internal stability of the euro means that people can be confident that their savings and pensions will keep their value over time. The ECB has, over the past six months, taken measures and increased interest rates four times. European citizens can be assured that the future of the euro is that of a strong currency, based on price stability and the strength of the European economy. Prime minister Harold Wilson in November 1967 explaining the Labour government's decision to devalue the pound: It would have been possible to ride out this present tide of foreign speculation against the pound by borrowing from central banks and governments ... In our view it would have been irresponsible to go on dealing with these successive waves of speculation by borrowing ... without tackling the root cause of the speculation. From now the pound abroad is worth 14% or so less in terms of other currencies. It does not mean, of course, that the pound here in Britain, in your pocket or purse or in your bank has been devalued. I have said that imports will cost more and this means higher prices over a period for some of our imports, including some of our basic foods. It is vital that price rises are limited to those where increased import costs make this unavoidable. Our people will not tolerate traders who are not affected by import costs trying to cash in by unjustifiable price increases ... It is just as vital that any prices that do go up are not used as an excuse for excessive wage demands.

fields.headline: Worthwhile ventures
fields.standfirst: The schemes started up to fund the new economy are showing results, writes Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: In face of the accelerating decline of the UK's manufacturing base, it will take something like alchemy to keep the economy on an even keel. The new economy can make up only a small part of the loss in employment and trade caused by continuing factory closures, but recent developments in the venture capital and enterprise investment field look promising.
fields.body:
In face of the accelerating decline of the UK's manufacturing base, it will take something like alchemy to keep the economy on an even keel. The new economy can make up only a small part of the loss in employment and trade caused by continuing factory closures, but recent developments in the venture capital and enterprise investment field look promising.

After two or three years of little progress, both venture capital trusts (VCTs) and enterprise investment schemes (EIS) are beginning to show rewards, at least on paper, for the investors large and small who took on the high risk of backing new funds and business start-ups - albeit encouraged by 20% income tax relief and capital gains tax deferment.

They contrast well with the abandoned business expansion schemes that gave better tax breaks but left thousands of investors with dismal returns.

The more recent EISs and VCTs have prospered on the back of the frenetic demand for companies that will make up the backbone of the new economy.

Although the first VCT and EIS investors still have until later this year to reap the tax concessions that depended on the investment being maintained for five years, new investments now qualify for relief after only three years.

EIS investment remains the riskiest because it is in single company operations. Yet those that have obtained a listing on one of the junior markets such as AIM have done surprisingly well. For example, investors in Tricorder Technology, a devel oper of 3D imaging systems, have seen the value of their holding multiply several times over. After the recent hi-tech market shakeout, the shares are down by half from their peak of over 200p but still two or three times the initial flotation price.

Mils Technology, which has developed a lighting safety strip for use in passenger liners in the event of fire, saw its shares double on the Ofex market, although in recent weeks they have slipped back.

Others have proved more disappointing. Avionic Services, a specialist in air traffic control and airport consultancy services, raised £1m on Ofex five months ago, but has seen its share price fall from the initial 50p to 38p.

The lesson may be that when dealing will be infrequent and the majority owners are retaining their stakes, it may be best to defer a listing for a year or two. UK Directory, a website and search engine, came onto Ofex in recent weeks but has slipped 40% below the 50p issue price during the turmoil in the dot.com sector.

Leisure companies such as pubs and hotels have been a particularly active field for EIS issues in recent months, but investment on a fairly long term basis is required and any gains will probably await disposal in a few years.

webTitle: It's all change for the new exchange

fields.headline: It's all change for the new exchange
fields.standfirst: What does the planned merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges mean for the small investor? Should we believe all the hype? Liz Stuart reports.
fields.trailText: What does the planned merger of the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges mean for the small investor? Should we believe all the hype? Liz Stuart reports.
fields.body:
Depending on who you listen to, this week's news that the London Stock Exchange is to merge with its Frankfurt counterpart is either a backdoor shove into the evil euro, or a great modernising leap forward which will streamline the whole sharetrading process along pan-European lines.

The news prompted the predictable flood of xenophobic jokes on website investor bulletin boards (und now, fur somezing completely different... ) as well as some genuine concerns about the safety of investing in the plunging euro. But what does the merger really mean for the private investor?

Is it good news?

It should lead to quick, efficient trading, says execution-only broker Charles Schwab.

Stockbroker Hargreaves Lansdown agrees: "In the long term it should be a good thing. It will make it easier for the more sophisticated investor to buy foreign stocks like Deutsche Telekom cheaply. At the moment we don't offer our clients this service as it is just too expensive to be worthwhile," says a spokesman.

What about costs?

As trading becomes more efficent, margins will narrow and brokerage costs will fall and this should be passed onto the consumer.

What about volatility? Will it make the stockmarket gyrate even more?

The merged market will be much more liquid than the current LSE and pundits say that volatility levels should not be affected either way.

Is it going to increase demand for shares?

The Association of Investment Trust Companies says that demand from Europe for cheap UK investment trusts may increase, which is good news for their shareholders. The extra demand should mean narrower discounts - so your shares will be worth more.

In future will share prices be quoted in euros?

Here lies the big question. The new exchange, to be called iX, will not force any company to list in euros and many companies will chose not to do so.

Building societies turned banks, for instance, have a very wide base of small shareholders in the UK and most of them will have little interest in listing in euros. But growing telecoms companies, for example, with plans for pan-European expansion, may prefer to list in euros rather than sterling. That will expose investors to a currency risk unless we join the single currency.

Prices of UK companies listed in newspapers will continue to be given in sterling at least until the new organisation is operational.

What will this mean if I only invest through unit trusts or Isas?

Collective investors will not see a big change, at least in the short term. Unit trusts will only convert to euro listing if their unit holders - that is, you - want to make the change. Even so, buying and selling in sterling will continue.

Alternative Investment Market (AIM) shares will not be affected.

Is this the death of stamp duty on share purchases?

Although news of the merger was widely leaked, many of the details have yet to be pinned down.

The most important of these is stamp duty. In the UK we pay duty of 0.5% on share purchases, but in Germany deals are not taxed.

Last year there were rumours that Gordon Brown was considering scrapping the duty, and this week's announcement will be another inducement to him.

Are other countries going to get involved?

The new organisation, iX - which will be based partly in London and partly in Frankfurt - plans to forge a link with the US technology market Nasdaq.

It is not yet clear just how this will work, but it should add to the number of shares available cheaply to UK investors. Exchanges in Milan and Madrid have already said they would like to get involved in iX.

What about trading hours? The Deutsche Börse has different opening times from the LSE.

Xetra, the computer system, or platform, on which the Frankfurt market trades, opens from 8.30am to 5pm German time, but from the beginning of June, trading will be extended into the evening until 8pm. It seems inevitable that the UK will move into line with this - and when the Nasdaq alliance happens, trading will operate round the clock.

Will this mean the end of the FTSE?

What also seems inevitable is the eventual end of the FTSE 100. The exchanges have yet to hammer out which indices will be used, but there have already been moves towards a wider benchmark for share prices in both markets.

So when will all this happen?

Nothing will happen just yet. As the Stock Exchange is keen to point out, the merger is "an agreement at high level" and, shareholder agreement pending, will not go through until the autumn. The effects will not be felt by most people for some time after that.

Does this mean no more days when you cannot trade because the stock exchange computer system has gone down?

Everyone hopes so; the German exchange's technology will be used.

fields.headline: Flintoff's gentle century
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 265
Lancashire 342-5
fields.trailText: It might have escaped attention with the indoor match-rigging marathon still in full swing but England's first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's is only a fortnight away. There is hardly enough time to mark a crease, let alone change a reputation, but Andrew Flintoff is bent upon trying.
fields.body:
It might have escaped attention with the indoor match-rigging marathon still in full swing but England's first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's is only a fortnight away. There is hardly enough time to mark a crease, let alone change a reputation, but Andrew Flintoff is bent upon trying.

Flintoff's hundred against Leicestershire yesterday was not the barnstorming affair that is readily associated with the most destructive England batsman in the land. It was the clearest indication yet, in a season already containing three previous half-centuries, that this is a batsman who intends to be taken seriously.

Bobby Simpson, Lancashire's Australian coach, has impressed upon Flintoff the need to play straighter and with power in reserve. To achieve that end, he promoted him to No3. The response was 119 in nearly four hours, a timespan which by his standards normally also houses a lengthy kip and several pints of good ale.

Simpson warned England against miscasting Flintoff, arguing that any intentions to bat him at No7, and thrust additional bowling responsibility upon him, are misguided. Better to push him up the order and give most emphasis to his hulking strokeplay.

"Flintoff is a batsman who bowls - rather than a bowler who bats - and for that reason it is imperative that he should bat at No4 or 5 for England," Simpson said. "He can easily handle the job. He is not only the most powerful batsman in the England side but also the most technically correct. His timing and strength is fantastic. It is only when he tries to knock the cover off the ball that he is vulnerable."

The restrained approach was never better emphasised than when he despatched Chris Lewis for two offside boundaries with the gentlest of forward pushes.

A winter fitness programme, developed by the former Great Britain rugby league full-back Steve Hampson, has been credited for Flintoff's robust health, even if suggestions in the Cricketers' Who's Who that he is only 13st 10lbs makes a weight-rigging controversy virtually inevitable.

There was the occasional uncertain moment against the short ball, a fumble by Lewis at mid-on when Flintoff was 43, and an inexplicable miss by Anil Kumble, at third man, when Flintoff top-edged a pull on 71. Lewis flung himself into the middle of the pitch in anguish, before springing to his feet to applaud Kumble's stab at it with the wisdom of a man who has had enough head-lines to be going along with.

A sprightly hundred from Neil Fairbrother enabled Lancashire to build a lead of 77 by the close. They had struggled against the new ball, with both Michael Atherton and John Crawley falling cheaply, and Sourav Ganguly got out wastefully with a reaching drive against Lewis.

fields.headline: Dravid catches Zimbabwe cold
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabweans 159
Kent 380-5
fields.trailText: Kent v Zimbabwe
fields.body:
Dravid versus Goliath? Hardly. As Rahul Dravid purred gracefully towards his maiden hundred for Kent - and beyond - like a puma on tranquillisers, it was hard to dispel the feeling that English lips are being smacked in anticipation of similarly facile pickings off the Zimbabweans.

Poorly as the tourists had batted, their attack, Heath Streak apart, boasted about as many teeth yesterday as Old Man Steptoe. There were mitigating circumstances. Guy Whittall and Streak himself are among five of the squad currently stricken with colds, while Mpumelelo "Pommie" Mbangwa was absent for much of the day with a dicky ankle.

Other matters, too, are inevitably preying on minds. "It's a very difficult situation," conceded their cheery avuncular manager Dan Stannard, making a rare reference to the political strife back home. "We talk about it every day. It's very difficult to concentrate."

Nor has the rather naive revelation by the captain, Andy Flower, that four of the squad hail from farming stock been greeted with unconfined glee by the white community. Nor, Stannard added ruefully if needlessly, was the weather helping; this was another day devised for the exclusive delectation of brass monkeys.

None of this, though, should detract overmuch from Dravid's consummate mastery, Alan Wells's crisp half-century, nor the promise of James Hockley, a strapping lad from Beckenham whose second first-class innings yielded 74 out of a fifth-wicket stand of 208 in 54 overs.

While Dravid was dissecting Neil Johnson's first over with the new ball, hitting four consecutive fours to herald an onslaught that sped him to his third fifty off 32 balls en route to an unbeaten 182 with 27 boundaries, it was hard to credit his winter struggles in Australia.

There Dravid averaged 15.50 in three tests, frozen, apparently, by the pace of Shane Lee and Glenn McGrath. Here, after being caressed to the boundary by a wafer-thin glance, Johnson grinned, partly out of admiration, partly impotence. He is unlikely to be the last to feel the backlash.

 England have cancelled their training camp, scheduled for Taunton on May 11, because of concern about the lack of competitive cricket in the rain-hit start to the season. The decision will allow England's contracted players to play one more county match before the squad assembles at Lord's on May 15, three days before the first test.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: An injury to Michael Vaughan spoiled a good day for him and for Yorkshire, adding to England's fitness worries for the first Test against Zimbabwe which is less than a fortnight away.
fields.body:
An injury to Michael Vaughan spoiled a good day for him and for Yorkshire, adding to England's fitness worries for the first Test against Zimbabwe which is less than a fortnight away.

Vaughan suffered a suspected broken little finger against Derbyshire at Headingley. After making a superb 155 in just under eight hours, he was surprised by a bouncer from Matthew Cassar which struck him on the left hand.

The initial view in the Yorkshire camp is that Vaughan had sustained a fracture near the knuckle of the little finger. Vaughan and Darren Lehmann (95) had inspired Yorkshire to 407 for four in reply to the visitors' 239.

 Durham, the First Division relegation favourites, annihilated the county champions Surrey inside three days at Chester-le-Street.

Surrey, set 317 to win, slumped from 41 without loss to 85 all out. Simon Brown and Neil Killeen took three wickets apiece.

Nicky Peng, the 17-year-old who made 98 and 23 for Durham, was afterwards described by Surrey's captain Adam Hollioake as "the best young player I've seen".

 In the Second Division at Edgbaston, Nick Knight struck the season's first double-century, a career-best 233, as Warwickshire declared on 551 for six against Glamorgan, who were 64 without loss at the close.

 Paul Johnson hit exactly 100 for Nottinghamshire at Chelmsford, where Essex were bowled out for 274. Darren Bicknell (59) helped the visitors to 240 for six.

 Owais Shah (76) lifted Middlesex to 427 for eight declared at Lord's. Northamp- tonshire struggled to 132 for five, Phil Tufnell taking two wickets in two balls.

fields.headline: Aussies conspire to thwart Warne
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 232 and 10-0
Somerset 319
fields.trailText: Hampshire v Somerset
fields.body:
Shane Warne must be thinking that county cricket would be something of a sinecure if only the place wasn't full of Australians.

He took his first championship wicket in only his third over here yesterday morning but then Somerset's Aussie pair, Jamie Cox and Peter Bowler, battered him into submission.

It was reminiscent of the recent Benson & Hedges Cup tie at Hove, where Warne bowled with some elan until Michael Bevan came in and won the match for Sussex with an undefeated half-century.

Yesterday he finished with the rather unflattering figures of 33-10-83-1. He also bowled a wide and a full toss that was slogged through midwicket for four by Rob Turner.

This was hardly Warne's most memorable day because his solitary wicket should not have been given by umpire Roy Palmer, who adjudged Piran Holloway caught behind by Derek Kenway. Holloway looked bemused and local TV pictures later confirmed that the batsman did not get a touch.

The conditions did not favour Warne. The chilly wind numbed his fingers and the flat pitch offered him little bounce or turn, although he might have attempted a little more variety.

Hampshire followers must be thoroughly fed up with Cox. In their final home match of last season they watched the Somerset captain score 216 and 129 not out. His 153 yesterday gave him a three-innings total of 498 and an average of 249.

Yesterday he played Warne expertly, concentrating on a forward defensive of exagger ated care before rocking quickly on to the back foot to cut anything short. He batted for some 6 hours and put on 119 in 45 overs with the English-born, Australian-raised Bowler and then 131 in 37 with Turner, both partners scoring 56.

When Simon Renshaw took the new ball he struck three times as Somerset lost their last five wickets for 36 runs. Their total of 319 still gave them a first-innings lead of 87. But they needed all of that because Matt Bulbeck (back) and Steffan Jones (hamstring) may not be able to bowl today.

fields.headline: Women crowded out
fields.trailText: The latest sport to assume the boast of being "the fastest growing sport in the country" is women's football. So where were all the spectators at the Women's FA Cup final?
fields.body:
It is tricky when we start talking about any form of minority these days, whether social, political or the small number of idiots blamed for the May Day riots. It is just as sensitive a word when applied to sport.

Realistically, any sport that is not football must be considered a minority interest in Britain at the moment but, when we consider the sports that provoke national fascination and debate, we must include cricket, rugby union, tennis, golf, motor and horse racing and, at a push, boxing.

For years others have been trying to progress from the staff canteen to the executive dining room with varying success, and all of them, bar none, have at some time professed to be the country's biggest growth sport.

Basketball has tried, but is dismissed as a sport for freaks, and ice hockey continues to give it a go but suffers because nobody can see the puck on television.

The latest sport to assume the boast of being "the fastest growing sport in the country" is women's football, with the number of women's clubs jumping from 80 to 3,600 in six years, and the chief executive of the Football Association acknowledging the likelihood of a professional women's league by 2003.

So why were there only 3,500 spectators at the Women's FA Cup final at Bramall Lane on Monday when Croydon beat Doncaster? And some Sky subscribers and Radio 5 Live listeners are asking why both networks bothered to broadcast live coverage of such a poorly attended event?

The organisers admit they had expected double that figure, to show a natural progression in popularity from a 6,500 gate last year and 5,000 in 1998, and they see it as a setback on the rocky road to justifying their expansion plans.

Since the FA assumed control of the women's game in 1993 it has pumped £2m into development, and Sport England will announce a further £10m investment in October. It insists that an improvement in standards of play with improved coaching will one day deliver an audience. But where from?

Many would say the men's game is bloated and over-hyped and in danger of becoming so elitist that only a handful of clubs will enjoy genuine broad appeal. And, with plans afoot to establish a veteran's football league for male players past their prime, can women seriously build a business on such a niche market?

It would seem foolhardy to write a business plan based on the growth of the women's game in the United States, where players command fat fees for exposing toned bodies in Playboy and where they are still glowing at that passionate 90,000 crowd who watched the United States beat China in Pasa-dena last year.

As we know, Americans are different. Their attitude to sport is less Neanderthal than our own. They accept change better and respond to skilful marketing. In Britain we like our contact sport to be fast, furious and sweaty, and the cynical football fraternity prefer their women to cut up the half-time oranges.

Even a senior female broadcaster said the other day that her "stomach churned at the thought of women running around trying desperately to control their wobbly bits".

The FA talks about altering this country's attitude as if it is as simple as a Groundforce garden makeover. No amount of financial muscle and honest endeavour will move the social goalposts.

This is not based on reasons of health or a perversion of womanhood; it is the simple economics of sport in this country. We believe we have a divine right to be brilliant at every sport. We have too much choice and the "minority sports" will stay just as they are, with a hardcore of support but picking up the crumbs from the main table.

Sensibly the FA's women's section will be tendering for a new television deal separately from the men's game and it is toying with the idea of playing its professional league during the summer.

With that plan it has a chance but, unless the men's game makes a complete hash of things over the next decade, women's football will be played by, and for, women.

As we know, Americans are different. Their attitude to sport is less Neanderthal than our own. They accept change better and respond to skilful marketing. In Britain we like our contact sport to be fast, furious and sweaty, and the cynical football fraternity prefer their women to cut up the half-time oranges. Even a senior female broadcaster said the other day that her "stomach churned at the thought of women running around trying desperately to control their wobbly bits". The FA talks about altering this country's attitude as if it is as simple as a Groundforce garden makeover. No amount of financial muscle and honest endeavour will move the social goalposts. This is not based on reasons of health or a perversion of womanhood; it is the simple economics of sport in this country. We believe we have a divine right to be brilliant at every sport. We have too much choice and the "minority sports" will stay just as they are, with a hardcore of support but picking up the crumbs from the main table. Sensibly the FA's women's section will be tendering for a new television deal separately from the men's game and it is toying with the idea of playing its professional league during the summer. With that plan it has a chance but, unless the men's game makes a complete hash of things over the next decade, women's football will be played by, and for, women.

webTitle: Royle and Gregory are handed new contracts

fields.headline: Royle and Gregory are handed new contracts
fields.trailText: Joe Royle's reward for guiding Manchester City away from the lowest point in the club's history will be a new contract this summer; and John Gregory has been given another three years as the Aston Villa manager after steering the club to their first FA Cup final for 43 years.
fields.body:
Joe Royle's reward for guiding Manchester City away from the lowest point in the club's history will be a new contract this summer; and John Gregory has been given another three years as the Aston Villa manager after steering the club to their first FA Cup final for 43 years.

The Manchester City manager has two years left on his current deal but the Maine Road hierarchy plan to draw up improved terms once the season has finished, regardless of whether the team reach the Premiership.

City are in their strongest financial position for years due to Sky's £5m input for a 9.9% stake, sponsorship deals and advance season-ticket sales in excess of £3m. Royle struck his current deal when City were heading towards a first-ever season in the third tier.

Gregory, meanwhile, has agreed to remain with Villa until 2003 in a deal worth £1m a year, double his previous rate. "I'm absolutely delighted," he said. "The Villa board have shown their faith in me and I'm happy that I have been given more time to add to the progress I feel we have made over the last two years. I am a much better manager now than the guy they gambled on and I hope I can prove that."

Gregory took over in February 1998 and after six successful months signed an improved deal which took him up to his predecessor Brian Little's £500,000-a-year wage level.

"The challenge now is to build on our progress," Gregory added. "The target has to be getting into the Champions League and I want Villa to have done that by the end of the contract."

It all represents a remarkable turn-around for Gregory, whose job looked to be on the line before Christmas. But after Villa's 2-1 FA Cup win against the "lucky losers" Darlington in the third round and West Ham's fielding of the ineligible Manny Omoyimni in the quarter-final of the League Cup, Villa have reached the FA Cup final and the League Cup semi-final and suffered only one league defeat, at Southampton.

 Manchester United will again face Real Madrid, who beat them in the Champions League quarter-finals, at a pre-season tournament in Germany also involving Bayern Munich and Milan.

webTitle: I come to heal wounds, not deepen them

fields.headline: I come to heal wounds, not deepen them
fields.standfirst: One day after his triumph in the London mayoral elections, Ken Livingstone tells of his intentions  for  the governance of London, and for his relationship with  the Labour party and central government
fields.trailText: One day after his triumph in the London mayoral elections, Ken Livingstone tells of his intentions  for  the governance of London, and for his relationship with  the Labour party and central government
fields.body:
On Thursday London made its choices clear in the largest single constituency election in British history. We are all bound by the outcome. Given that many of the issues affecting London are crucially affected by decisions taken centrally, and also that the capital naturally has a specific weight within the country, one of the new Mayor's most important priorities will be to create a constructive relationship with the government and Prime Minister.

Given the events in the Labour Party that led to the mayoral election I cannot but comment on these. But first must come the governmental aspect - the relations between the administration of London and the national government.

People have asked whether as Mayor I intend to collaborate with the government. The answer is a simple "yes". I am equally convinced that the government wants to collaborate with the Mayor and administration of London.

First, because they respect the democratic wishes of the people of London. Second, because the job of government is to ensure the best possible life for the citizens of the country, and in my case for the citizens of London.

I take the statements made by ministers of their decision to collaborate with London at face value, and look forward to working with them. Indeed within hours of moving into the Mayor's offices, consultations with government ministers had already begun.

My attitude to this Labour government remains what it has always been. Mrs Thatcher represented everything I oppose and detest - the damage she did to London, the culture she created of indifference to the most disadvantaged in society, and the way she rode roughshod over democratically expressed opposition. I believe her government did deep and lasting damage to London, which it is part of the Greater London Assembly's task to undo. I approached her government in that light.

This government is entirely different. I believe it is trying to strongly improve the lives of the citizens of our country. On some issues I have differences on how to achieve this. But we share common goals. This precludes any confrontational attitude.

To take London, it is sufficient merely to note that Mrs Thatcher abolished the democratically elected GLC, because Londoners dared to vote for candidates who disagreed with her, whereas Tony Blair's government recreated a strategic local authority for London, and devolved power to Scotland and Wales. It thereby gave them the right to elect representatives either to agree or disagree with the government. Despite all his criticism of me, it was Tony Blair's government that gave Londoners the right to elect either me or anyone else. It is impossible to take even a remotely similar approach to two such fundamentally different governments.

That determines my approach as Mayor. It does not mean that I will not, on occasion, disagree with the government if it affects London's interests. David Blunket's statement on television, implying that collaboration means abandoning the expression of disagreement with the government if disagreement exists, is not correct. How can the mayor not say that he believes that an overvalued exchange rate is deeply damaging to Ford's plant at Dagenham, which is crucial for the economy of London? A Mayor has no option but to comment on matters which deeply affect London. Indeed, devolution requires that central government adjust to the fact that regionally elected politicians will represent the wishes of their voters. In the case of London, this is clearly the case with transport policy and the London Underground.

I made clear at the beginning of my campaign that the election would be a referendum on the partial privatisation of the Tube. The great majority of Londoners cast their votes for candidates who rejected privatisation. They expect those views to be taken into account by government.

As regard issues that relate to the Labour Party, as opposed to government, it is obvious to all that the party suffered an electoral disaster in London on Thursday. The Labour candidate for Mayor was beaten into third place. The Conservatives out-polled Labour in the capital. Tragically, this was an entirely self-inflicted wound. If its selection ballot had not been outrageously manipulated, to the point where it was rigged, Labour would have won a victory in London that would have lifted its morale.

For the third time in succession, in Scotland, Wales and now London, those with a narrow sectarian conception of Labour have inflicted severe damage on the party. There are no policies that I expressed in my career in politics that are not part of the broad church of the Labour Party. This was proved by the fact that the prime minister was explicit that if I had overcome even the rigged ballot in London I would have been endorsed as Labour candidate and I was considered fit to represent the Labour Party in parliament. Such a broad church approach is indispensable. Actions such as those in London and Wales narrowed the basis of the party and imposed a defeat on it.

Some Labour MPs warned that a dirty election campaign would simply compound the damage. They were ignored. I want to put what was said in the election campaign behind us. But one thing went so far beyond the limits of acceptable debate that I cannot but put it on record and express my attitude on it. This was the attempt by the Labour campaign in a public advertisement to associate me with the desecration of the cenotaph. I have nothing but contempt for those who defiled the monument to those gave their lives for our liberty. That advertisment represented a low point in British political campaigning. It is clear that this negative campaigning approach inflicted huge damage on the Labour party in London.

London has voted. I am overwhelmed to have been given a mandate against the three most powerful party machines in Britain. But I would rather have become the mayor fighting alongside the many friends with whom I have spent thirty years in the Labour movement. I was forced to chose between accepting a selection mechanism that removed any democratic choice from London, and Labour in London, or allowing the electorate to judge.

But it was Labour's self-inflicted wound. Regardless of what anyone else does, I am going to conduct myself towards the Labour Party in such a way as to heal this wound, not deepen it.

fields.headline: London chooses Livingstone
fields.standfirst: Norris squeezes Dobson into third place
fields.trailText:
Ken Livingstone last night pulled off a spectacular comeback
                                                                when he was elected mayor of London, 14 years after Margaret
                                                                Thatcher abolished his former stronghold at the GLC and in the
                                                                teeth of equally impassioned opposition by her Labour
                                                                successor in Downing Street, Tony Blair.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone last night pulled off a spectacular comeback when he was elected mayor of London, 14 years after Margaret Thatcher abolished his former stronghold at the GLC and in the teeth of equally impassioned opposition by her Labour successor in Downing Street, Tony Blair.

He immediately offered to cooperate fully with the Blair government to make London a success and work for a Labour victory at the general election. But he coupled his conciliatory remarks with a blunt warning that yesterday's local council results across England were "very bad for Labour", a wake-up call for New Labour and a warning that Blair could not take the election for granted.

Mr Livingstone was on course to win early this morning after second preferences were distributed, with the free- thinking Tory candidate Stephen Norris coming second, and the Labour candidate Frank Dobson trailing third.

With the Tories easily meeting their benchmark gains of more than 500 seats in the local council polls, Labour showed undisguised relief at the Tory defeat in yesterday's Romsey byelection. The London minister Keith Hill even praised Labour supporters for switching to the Liberal Democrats in the byelection, saying it was the clearest way to send a message to William Hague, the Tory leader.

Turnout in the mayoral election was in the mid-30s, a blow to those who claimed the new "personality politics" would reinvigorate local democracy.

New electronic counting machines also severely delayed results with excuses ranging from excessive static to dust in the air and collapsing tables. Officials were also exasperated by the number of voters who misunderstood the new system.

Acknowledging that Mr Livingstone had won, the David Blunkett, the education secretary, urged him to stop attacking the Labour government, to stop being a victim and to start cooperating.

Mr Livingstone, who celebrated in a Thai restaurant, sent mixed messages promising to work for re-election for a Labour government before attacking Mr Blair's policies. "The news from all over the country is very bad for Labour," he told the BBC, and predicted that the prime minister would now have to "do more for pensioners, education and health".

The high pound was also hurting industry, he said before joining his victory celebration. "It's a quite wonderful feeling. I never thought I would be back in this sort of position," he said. His tone cheered his supporters - many of whom had defected from Labour to his independent bid - but dismayed ministers. They will be watching his every move to see if they are dealing with a Reformed Ken or the Red Ken of old.

With the first round of votes counted, Mr Livingstone's share of the vote was around 41%, according to preliminary findings of a BBC TV exit poll, not enough to win outright on what was a low turnout in the capital, barely 30%.

Mr Norris's 25% share left Mr Dobson in a humiliating third place, just ahead of Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat candidate. A Carlton TV poll confirmed Mr Norris's late, but inadequate, surge: Mr Livingstone on 46% to his rivals' 23%, 14% and 11% respectively.

BBC analysis suggested that 24% of Mr Livingstone's vote came from Tories, 33% from Lib Dems and a massive 46% from Labour voters, only 27% of whom backed Mr Dobson, who disappeared from public gaze last night.

Defending half the 3,300 seats in contention in 152 coun cils yesterday, Labour lost control of Oldham and other towns as the Lib Dems endured mixed fortunes. Labour voters seemed to be staying at home, much as party critics had feared. The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, was delighted. "We are picking up seats in areas where we have never picked up seats before," he said. But experts said the Tory campaign against asylum seekers had made only modest impact. Mr Dobson's running mate, Trevor Phillips, countered: "It's not exactly a government in difficulty."

Anticipating Mr Livingstone's victory Mr Blair, working on the peace process in Belfast, made arrangements to speak by telephone to the victor, a process that will enable him to avoid a photo handshake with the man he has repeatedly said will be a disaster for London and for Labour.

The prime minister also moved yesterday to placate Mr Dobson for the drubbing that has left the former health secretary feeling "bitter" at the way the Labour leadership and party machine mishandled his ill-starred campaign While voters were still going to the polls Mr Blair told the cabinet that their old colleague had behaved with "great dignity" during a difficult time. Labour is also concerned about recriminations when the inquest into the debacle starts today. It will be made far worse if, as some MPs claim, the deeply loyal Mr Dobson finally blows his top in interviews or a book.

Mr Dobson is said to blame Mr Blair's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, and a small coterie of Labour insiders for undermining him.

Mr Powell is believed to have been the chief advocate of running Mo Mowlam for the job - a plan she resisted until it was too late. Mr Dobson is also convinced that he could have beaten the former GLC leader fair and square in a one-member, one- vote election among party members in London - only to be tainted by the ill-judged imposition of an electoral college by party headquarters in Millbank and No 10 staff.

Many ministers and officials believe Mr Dobson's hunch is wrong and that a one-member, one-vote victory for Mr Livingstone would have created a far worse situation for them.

"Can you imagine the trouble if he'd made that Hitler remark as the official Labour candidate?" said one official.

Ministers confirmed there was no discussion in cabinet of what job Mr Dobson might be given, though party officials said: "He's a gifted man who can do jobs. He'll get one."

New electronic counting machines also severely delayed results with excuses ranging from excessive static to dust in the air and collapsing tables. Officials were also exasperated by the number of voters who misunderstood the new system. Acknowledging that Mr Livingstone had won, the David Blunkett, the education secretary, urged him to stop attacking the Labour government, to stop being a victim and to start cooperating. Mr Livingstone, who celebrated in a Thai restaurant, sent mixed messages promising to work for re-election for a Labour government before attacking Mr Blair's policies. "The news from all over the country is very bad for Labour," he told the BBC, and predicted that the prime minister would now have to "do more for pensioners, education and health". The high pound was also hurting industry, he said before joining his victory celebration. "It's a quite wonderful feeling. I never thought I would be back in this sort of position," he said. His tone cheered his supporters - many of whom had defected from Labour to his independent bid - but dismayed ministers. They will be watching his every move to see if they are dealing with a Reformed Ken or the Red Ken of old. With the first round of votes counted, Mr Livingstone's share of the vote was around 41%, according to preliminary findings of a BBC TV exit poll, not enough to win outright on what was a low turnout in the capital, barely 30%. Mr Norris's 25% share left Mr Dobson in a humiliating third place, just ahead of Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat candidate. A Carlton TV poll confirmed Mr Norris's late, but inadequate, surge: Mr Livingstone on 46% to his rivals' 23%, 14% and 11% respectively. BBC analysis suggested that 24% of Mr Livingstone's vote came from Tories, 33% from Lib Dems and a massive 46% from Labour voters, only 27% of whom backed Mr Dobson, who disappeared from public gaze last night. Defending half the 3,300 seats in contention in 152 coun cils yesterday, Labour lost control of Oldham and other towns as the Lib Dems endured mixed fortunes. Labour voters seemed to be staying at home, much as party critics had feared. The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, was delighted. "We are picking up seats in areas where we have never picked up seats before," he said. But experts said the Tory campaign against asylum seekers had made only modest impact. Mr Dobson's running mate, Trevor Phillips, countered: "It's not exactly a government in difficulty." Anticipating Mr Livingstone's victory Mr Blair, working on the peace process in Belfast, made arrangements to speak by telephone to the victor, a process that will enable him to avoid a photo handshake with the man he has repeatedly said will be a disaster for London and for Labour. The prime minister also moved yesterday to placate Mr Dobson for the drubbing that has left the former health secretary feeling "bitter" at the way the Labour leadership and party machine mishandled his ill-starred campaign While voters were still going to the polls Mr Blair told the cabinet that their old colleague had behaved with "great dignity" during a difficult time. Labour is also concerned about recriminations when the inquest into the debacle starts today. It will be made far worse if, as some MPs claim, the deeply loyal Mr Dobson finally blows his top in interviews or a book. Mr Dobson is said to blame Mr Blair's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, and a small coterie of Labour insiders for undermining him. Mr Powell is believed to have been the chief advocate of running Mo Mowlam for the job - a plan she resisted until it was too late. Mr Dobson is also convinced that he could have beaten the former GLC leader fair and square in a one-member, one- vote election among party members in London - only to be tainted by the ill-judged imposition of an electoral college by party headquarters in Millbank and No 10 staff. Many ministers and officials believe Mr Dobson's hunch is wrong and that a one-member, one-vote victory for Mr Livingstone would have created a far worse situation for them. "Can you imagine the trouble if he'd made that Hitler remark as the official Labour candidate?" said one official. Ministers confirmed there was no discussion in cabinet of what job Mr Dobson might be given, though party officials said: "He's a gifted man who can do jobs. He'll get one."

webTitle: Blair names Lords panel to vet 'cronies'

fields.headline: Blair names Lords panel to vet 'cronies'
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair chose local election day, when most politicians and the media were focused on last minute manoeuvres among candidates, to reveal his plans to rebut charges that his half-reformed House of Lords will be packed with "Tony's cronies".
fields.body:
Tony Blair chose local election day, when most politicians and the media were focused on last minute manoeuvres among candidates, to reveal his plans to rebut charges that his half-reformed House of Lords will be packed with "Tony's cronies".

Lord Stevenson of Coddenham - chairman of the Pearson publishing giant and the Halifax plc and a veteran of many official quangos - will also chair the interim House of Lords appointment commis sion. Lord Stevenson, 54, a crossbench peer with Labour connections, was picked after an open recruitment process conducted by the accountants, PWC.

His eminence did not stop Tory peers and MPs complaining that the new panel is a "smokescreen" which will still allow Mr Blair to decide the balance between parties, the total size of the Lords and to appoint the people who will help Lord Stevenson do the appointing - pending further reform of the upper house.

Over the years Lord Stevenson has employed both Peter Mandelson and his aide, Benjamin Wegg-Prosser. Andrew Tyrie, the Tory MP for Chichester, said: "Lord Stevenson is too close to the Blair presidency for comfort."

To square the gender and regional pressures to make the Lords more represenative of Britain, the independent members chosen yesterday were Angela Sarkis, chief executive of the Church Urban Fund; Dame Deirdre Hine, previously chief medical officer at the Welsh Office and chairman of the NHS's new commission for health improvement; and Ms Felicity Huston. She is chairman of the Northern Ireland consumer committee for electricity and deputy chairman of the General Consumer Council of Northern Ireland. Both William Hague and Charles Kennedy were said to be "content" with the appointments.

The newcomers will join the three party political members of the existing vetting panel: Lord Hurd, the ex-foreign secretary, Lady Dean, the former TUC stalwart; and the Lib Dem peer, Lord Dholakia.

With their "diverse range of personal backgrounds, they will be well qualified to take forward the process of appointing non-political peers to the House of Lords on a more open and transparent basis and to take on responsibility for vetting all nominations for peerages", Mr Blair said.

But the Tory leader in the Lords, Lord Strathclyde, replied in a statement: "Everyone apart from Tony Blair recognises the need to rein in patronage. This new appointments commission is not the answer. It is nothing more than a smokescreen behind which he can continue to wield the key powers of patronage."

fields.headline: Björk 'eats blouse' in movie protest
fields.trailText: Björk has vowed to never again make a movie after repeatedly rowing with director Lars Von Trier on the set of her debut flick Dancer in the Dark
fields.body:
Björk has vowed to never again make a movie after repeatedly rowing with director Lars Von Trier on the set of her debut flick Dancer in the Dark. Online music magazine Q reports that relations were so strained on set that Björk reportedly ripped up a blouse she didn't want to wear in a scene and even ate shreds of it before storming off the set.

A production executive on the movie told the Daily Mail, "When two strong personalities get together there are bound to be clashes." But sources on the film say the rift goes deeper than that. However, both Dogme founder Von Trier and the singer are apparently happy with the film. Björk's manager said. "They're not the best of friends, but they're both very happy with the end result."

fields.headline: clickmango.com
fields.trailText: AppleMac. Orange. clickmango.com. What is it with techno-forward companies and fruity names, I wonder? No doubt when they finally get around to inventing dinky robots to do the cooking and write thank-you notes and answer the door, they'll be called MyKiwi or GuavaHelp.
fields.body:
AppleMac. Orange. clickmango.com. What is it with techno-forward companies and fruity names, I wonder? No doubt when they finally get around to inventing dinky robots to do the cooking and write thank-you notes and answer the door, they'll be called MyKiwi or GuavaHelp. Anyway. Back to clickmango.com: more than a pretty name, this is one of our new favourite websites. It's gorgeous to look at, which is a treat after the headache-inducing ugliness of most of the internet, and because it's all about natural health and beauty, it's kinda good for you too.

Most specialist-interest sites turn out to be merely online shopping portals with token window-dressing, so it's nice to see that clickmango.com has genuine content in the form of an online family natural health encyclopaedia, advice, newsletters and an email response service from experts including natural health consultant Michael van Straten, holistic beauty therapist Bharti Vyas, medical correspondent Thomas Stuttaford, holistic vet Richard Allport and aromatherapist Lotte Rose. Joanna Lumley is also on board as a guest reviewer (this month: lymphatic drainage massage).

Natural health and beauty can be a teensy bit dreary - all that brushing yourself with dry twigs and drinking tea made from weeds - but this site is livened up with caricatures of Joanna and The Experts, as well as lots of jolly pink and green cyber-mangos. And then, of course, you can shop (they've got to pay La Lumley, after all). Liz Earle's gorgeous skincare products, plant-rich hair goodies from Phytologie, Neal's Yard Remedies and Seven Seas health supplements are all available to buy online. Tasty.

webTitle: Disney internet channel to screen British teenagers' film

fields.headline: Disney internet channel to screen British teenagers' film
fields.trailText: The Daily Mail reports that two British teenagers, cousins Gus Harris-Reid and Arran Vidal-Hall have beaten more than 1,500 hopefuls in a competition to write a screenplay which will be turned into a film screened on the internet.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail reports that two British teenagers, cousins Gus Harris-Reid and Arran Vidal-Hall have beaten more than 1,500 hopefuls in a competition to write a screenplay which will be turned into a film screened on the internet.

Their idea, called The Jake of Diamonds will be turned by Disney into a 15-minute cartoon. It tells the story of homeless teenager Mitch who is accused of stealing a car, and whose friend Jake sets out to prove his innocence.

Neither of the 13-year-old boys watch television (their families don't own one), nor do they attend conventional school - they are among the 60,000 British children who are educated at home. Said Gus, "I learn a lot just by living. I go on the internet occasionally to find things out."

Their winning story will be screened on the Disney channel website in October.

fields.headline: It's a local thing
fields.standfirst: Council elections are still fought on local issues and Hague can't count on the results for next year, says regional affairs correspondent Peter Hetherington
fields.trailText: Council elections are still fought on local issues and Hague can't count on the results for next year, says regional affairs correspondent Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
With almost 600 Tory council seat gains, and the capture of 15 local authorities, William Hague could momentarily sidestep the party's humiliation at Romsey by proclaiming a "spectacular victory" over Labour today.

Labour suffered its worst election defeat since 1992: losing over 560 council seats and 15 town halls as Tories regained some of their traditional ground lost at the height of John Major's unpopularity.

But while there were plenty of warning signs for Tony Blair, with many of his party's traditional supporters preferring to stay at home rather than support their local Labour council, the results of this year's contest were patchy.

On balance Labour fared badly, losing control of big boroughs like Portsmouth, Southampton, and Oldham, while the Tories picked up Torbay, Eastbourne, gained an overall majority at Southend, while making advances in the party's old southern heartlands - after playing the asylum card for all it as worth.

From the West Midlands, where the "Longbridge factor" clearly worked against Labour, to the Pennine towns of Yorkshire and Lancashire, Tories made steady progress. The former leader of Birmingham City Council, Sir Richard Knowles, was even ousted from his seat after 24 years, while Labour lost Worcester and Tories gained an overall majority in nearby Solihull.

But in truth the Conservatives, who lost all their MPs in Scotland and Wales at the last general election, can no longer claim to be the party of England - let alone Britain. In most northern citadels, they have little or no representation, while the Liberal Democrats now provide the main opposition to Labour. While taking Oldham, they strengthened their control of Liverpool, and Sheffield, while helping to topple Labour in Hartlepool - Peter Mandelson's constituency - and threatening the old political order in a string of other towns and cities.

On yesterday's showing, with a miserably low turnout - around 70% of electors stayed at home - and with many fewer seats contested this year than last (3,337 compared with 13,301) it is clearly dangerous to use this contest as a way of judging the outcome of the general election.

For a start, the turnout will be higher in many of Labour's core areas, although party strategists are clearly worried that the "armchair rebellion" could become endemic. Secondly, whatever the national exhortations from parties, people seem to be voting on local issues - quite happy it seems in some areas to support the Lib Dems locally and Labour nationally. Thirdly, voters are also drawing a distinction between their local Labour council and the government.

But another factor is now entering the local equation: single issue politics. In Wyre Forest, for instance, candidates fighting under the "health concern" label in support of a local hospital's fight against downgrading gained eight seats - giving them almost half the councillors on the authority.

Parish politics, in short, are not dead.

fields.headline: Great byelection shocks
fields.trailText:
1935
Labour won Liverpool Wavertree on a 30% swing following intervention of Randolph Churchill as an Independent Conservative.
fields.body:
1935
Labour won Liverpool Wavertree on a 30% swing following intervention of Randolph Churchill as an Independent Conservative.

1958
Mark Bonham-Carter gave the Liberals their first by-election gain since 1929 when he won Torrington, Devon, from Tories with a 219 majority. It was a bad year for Conservatives, who lost Rochdale to Labour, coming third.

1962
Liberal Eric Lubbock, now Lord Avebury, took Orpington off the Tories on a 26.8% swing.

1966
Gwynfor Evans gave Plaid Cymru its first seat when he took Carmarthen from Labour on an 18% swing.

1967
Mrs Winifred Ewing snatched a seat for the Scottish National Party, when she turned a 16,576 Labour majority at Hamilton into a 1,799 nationalist one. She polled 46% in a constituency previously uncontested by her party.

1968
Tories chalked up a 21.1 % swing to take Dudley from Labour.

1969
Liberals captured Ladywood, their first Birmingham seat for 83 years, from Labour on a 32% swing. The two years from November 2 1967 to Oct 30 1969 brought Labour its worst by-election run. The party lost 10 seats during that time and the swing against it was never less than 10%.

1972
Liberals overturned a 12,696 Conservative majority to win Sutton and Cheam on a 32.6% swing.

1973
Dick Taverne won Lincoln for the Democratic Labour party, standing against the official Labour candidate and polling 58.2%. At Ripon Liberal David Austick gained the seat on a 25.3% swing while Clement Freud polled 38.3% to win the Isle of Ely for the party - which had not fought the constituency in the 1970 general election. The SNP's Margo MacDonald gained Glasgow Govan from Labour on a 26.7% swing.

1976
Tories gained Walsall North on a 22.5% swing after the imprisonment of the Labour MP, former minister John Stonehouse.

1977
The Conservatives toppled Labour in its Ashfield mining stronghold on a 20.8% swing.

1979
David Alton turned a Labour majority of 6,171 in Liverpool Edge Hill into a Liberal lead of 8,133, achieving a 32.4% swing.

1981
Shirley Williams, a Social Democratic Party founder member, won Crosby from Tories on a 25.5% swing for the Liberal/SDP Alliance. Liberal Bill Pitt ousted Tories at Croydon North West on a 24.2% swing.

1982
But in the last days of the Falklandas War it was Tories' turn to win when they took Mitcham and Morden off former Labour MP Bruce Douglas-Mann who had defected to the SDP, resigned his seat and stood again, pushing Labour into third place. There was a net 10.6% swing from Labour to Tories on what was the last occasion the Government party gained an Opposition seat at a by-election.

1983
Liberal Simon Hughes gained the highest swing since the war - 44.2% - when he won Bermondsey from Labour.

1988
Jim Sillars grabbed Glasgow Govan for the SNP on a 33.1% swing from Labour, emulating the victory in the same area of his wife Margo MacDonald 14 years before.

1989
Labour's John Smith took the Vale of Glamorgan from the Tories on a 12.4% switch - giving the party its most dramatic by-election win for more than half a century.

1990
The "safe" Conservative seat of Mid-Staffordshire was won by Labour with a 21.33% swing. Liberal Democrats ended a run of disappointing performances when they captured Eastbourne from the Tories on a 20% switch.

1991
Liberal Democrats captured Ribble Valley, among the top 15 Tory strongholds, by notching up a 24.7% swing after a campaign dominated by the poll tax. Labour also triumphed two months later winning Monmouth from the Tories on a 12.6% move. Key issue here was the National Health Service.

1993
The first by-election of the new parliament saw Liberal Democrats capture Newbury from Tories with 22,055 majority on a 28.4% swing. This was followed by the Christchurch contest which brought the biggest recorded swing against a Government - 35.4% from Conservative to Liberal Democrats.

1994
Tories were forced into third place at Eastleigh, where they were defending a 17,702 majority. Liberal Democrats gained the seat on a 21.4% swing with a 9,239 majority over Labour. The year ended with Labour scoring its biggest swing for nearly half a century, 29.1%, to take Dudley West from Tories.

1995
Conservatives were forced into third place by Labour as the SNP took Perth and Kinross off them on an 11.5% swing. Just over a month later they also tumbled to third position as Liberal Democrats took Littleborough and Saddleworth off them on an 11.6% swing.

1996
Tories went down to Labour in another landslide at Staffordshire South East where the votes movement was 22.2%.

1997
With the General Election less than two months away, Conservatives lost to Labour at Wirral South on a 17.2% swing. Tories failed to win a single by-election between William Hague's victory at Richmond, Yorks in 1989 and their win in their first contest of the new 1997 Parliament at Uxbridge. But this success was short-lived when Liberal Democrat Mark Oaten won the Winchester poll, a re-run after the general election result was declared void, with a 21,556 majority on a 19.8% swing.

fields.headline: Terrapin terror
fields.standfirst: Reptile invasion, missing cones, a one-tank wonder and a taste of the exotic
fields.trailText: Reptile invasion, missing cones, a one-tank wonder and a taste of the exotic
fields.body:
A ninja should be for ever
It might be one of the most beautiful areas of the British Isles, but beneath Cumbria's glorious scenery lurks a terrible secret - terrapins! Hundreds of terrapins, it appears, are each year abandoned in Cumbria, with devastating effects on the wildlife. "It's a huge problem," said John Thorpe of the British Chelonia Society. "Everyone was buying them in the 1980s at the height of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle craze. Now that they're big, old and smelly, however, owners don't want them any more." Quite aside from the cruelty to the animals, many of which die in the wild, the release of terrapins is endangering indigenous species. "They'll eat anything that moves," said one expert. "A really big one can attack a duckling. They also carry salmonella." Local zoos and wildlife centres are at bursting point, and authorities are urgently seeking terrapin foster parents. "I'm thinking of taking a hundred or so for my garden," said one local man. "If you set them in concrete they make a really fabulous crazy paving." Carlisle News and Star

Coneheads
While Cumbria is suffering from an excess of terrapins, Northamptonshire is experiencing a quite different problem - a dearth of traffic cones. Police throughout the county are struggling to make do with an ever-decreasing supply and, desperate to boost stocks, have recently issued an amnesty to anyone them. "We're at crisis point," said a spokesman. "There are only a few cones left in Kettering, and none whatsoever in Corby. We've lost hundreds over the years." In some cases the cones have been lent to people who have forgotten to return them, in others they have been stolen. Those in possession can return them throughout May, however, with no questions asked. "After that," said the spokesman, "we're going to get tough." Not everyone, however, is prepared to co-operate. "I can understand their problem," said one Corby resident, "but what the police have to understand is that for many of us there's a genetic imperative to go out on Saturday night, get pissed and dance naked in the middle of the road with a traffic cone on our head. It's about each side trying to accommodate the other." Northamptonshire Evening Telegraph

He Skoda go
Not only does Lincolnshire produce Britain's most succulent sausages, but also, if David Wilson of Bracebridge Heath is anything to go by, its most fuel-conscious drivers. Last year Dr Wilson, 65, drove his Skoda Octavia 847 miles from Land's End to John O'Groats on a single tank of diesel, averaging 37.8mph to ensure maximum fuel efficiency. Now he is about to repeat the journey. This time, however, when he reaches John O'Groats, he will turn round and head back south in an attempt to break the 1,000 mile barrier. Dr Wilson has been in training for several weeks, and reckons he will be able to increase his average speed to 50mph, getting almost 70 miles to the gallon from his Skoda's 13.5 gallon tank. He claims to be "cautiously optimistic" about reaching his target, although he still has some way to go to beat Audi driver Stewart Bladon, who in 1992 covered 1,338 miles on a single tank of fuel. "Skodas are particularly good for fuel conservation," said one car expert. "Their engines are very economical, and of course a lot of the time they're broken down so you can't use any petrol even if you want to." Lincolnshire Echo

Something rotten
Whatever else you might say about them, thieves in Bamber Bridge certainly have a taste for the exotic. They proved it this week when they raided a butchers depot on the outskirts of the Lancashire town, getting away with £15,000 of ostrich steaks, crocodile tails and tandoori chicken drumsticks. The meat was stolen from NUPAC International Butchers, and police are concerned that if it is not stored properly it could go off. "We're not just talking a few hamburgers here," a spokesman said, "and if it starts going rotten it's not going to be very pleasant." Police are pleading for anyone with information to come forward as soon as possible. "Maybe someone has come to your door trying to sell you meat," the spokesman said. "Or perhaps you've just noticed your neighbour having a lot of barbecues lately." Lancashire Evening Post

Letter of the Week
I felt I had to write, and hope that the gentleman I am writing about reads the Herald and will feel suitably ashamed.
I recently made a brief shopping trip into town. The weather was awful. After having made the few purchases I needed I came out of Debenhams and the heavens just opened, so, needless to say, up went the umbrella. All I had left to get was some wrapping paper, so I made a dash into the card shop.
Knowing I would only be a few minutes I only half put down my umbrella, saw the paper and went straight to the cash desk.
Whilst I was waiting to pay I glanced up and noticed a man looking straight at me holding what looked like my umbrella, but the penny didn't drop - that is, until I went to put it up as I left the shop and could not find it. Obviously it had slipped from my grasp while I was getting my money out of my purse, and this man had picked it up.
If the gentleman concerned ( incidentally, a senior citizen) would like to send a stamped addressed envelope, I will send him the umbrella cover.
Ms P Powell
The Plymouth Evening Herald

webTitle: The good, the bad and the Cuddly

fields.headline: The good, the bad and the Cuddly
fields.standfirst: Voters have taken full advantage of the new choices available in Tony Blair's political supermarket and the various parties have both triumphed and suffered as a result, explains Guardian political editor Michael White
fields.trailText: Voters have taken full advantage of the new choices available in Tony Blair's political supermarket and the various parties have both triumphed and suffered as a result, explains Guardian political editor Michael White
fields.body:
When politicians appear on TV after an election they usually find some way of telling viewers how good the result was for their party. Last night's triple-election drama was a rare example of the voters both rewarding and punishing the three main parties.

As today's headlines underlined, Labour suffered worst: more than 500 seats down in the local council elections and the expelled dissident, Ken Livingstone, triumphantly vindicated in his quest to run London for the second time, 14 years after Margaret Thatcher expelled him from County Hall.

But fate was kind to Mr Blair in one respect. Victory for the Liberal Democrats in the Romsey byelection, a seat previously held by the Tories, helped to take the shine off what William Hague would otherwise have presented as an unalloyed success .

With a turnout of 60 per cent, twice as high as the night's other elections, this was a damaging defeat for Mr Hague, barely 12 months away from the expected general election. It showed that crude tactics on law and order or asylum seekers could be confronted and beaten back.

Even more importantly, it showed that the electorate, who squeezed Labour's vote dry to give the Lib Dems a 12 per cent swing, now understands tactical voting . As in 1997, voters are using it to punish the Conservatives. That is not to say that the Tories did not do well in recapturing old strongholds like Torbay from the Lib Dems or that Labour did not suffer the indignity of seeing Oldham fall to the Lib Dems and Hartlepool - Peter Mandelson's base - slip from its grasp.

But the Tory gains were mainly heartlands gains, in the smaller cities and towns of England, recapturing loyalties lost in the Major era. It was good, but not good enough to give Mr Hague much hope of victory in 2001. What it did do was consolidate his leadership over a still-fractious party. Tony Blair will not mind that.

What Ken Livingstone will do next is by far the most fascinating question. A new type of electioneering has been unleashed; populist, personal and de-aligned.

London voters were offered four votes and a substantial choice of parties and people to back, and many seem to have taken full advantage of the new choices available in Tony Blair's political supermarket.

This may not have been what Mr Blair had in mind when he talked, in 1997, about the new politics of choice, cooperation and consensus. But change is difficult to control, as the devolved Wales and Scotland have shown. Mr Livingstone has a few crucial weeks to show he means to live by the new rules, to cooperate with other parties - including his own former party, Labour. Downing Street will be monitoring his actions and his rhetoric, keen to avoid blame if things relapse into acrimony.

But 'Cuddly' Ken is also a deft politician who has learned some tricks from Blair. He may not have the electoral mandate he hoped for but he won against formidable odds and wants to make a success of what is probably his last chance.

The clutch of smaller parties who did better than expected in the GLA elections - assorted Greens, Lib Dems, Christian socialists and - yes - the BNP - show what opportunities are there for the taking.

One Labour official quipped that Ken and the Labour party were like the proverbial "dog and the lamp post." Will Ken pee on it every morning or are we at the beginning of a new era ?

fields.headline: No more centralisation
fields.standfirst: Tribune editor Mark Seddon on the lesson for Labour
fields.trailText: Friday, 9.15am: Tribune editor Mark Seddon on the lesson for Labour
fields.body:
The proposition is strangely surreal. Ken Livingstone's election as London Mayor is being presented as a "blow to Labour and a blow to Tony Blair".

In essentially Labour voting London, the electorate has abandoned the official candidate, Frank Dobson and plumped instead for the seriously unofficial, and serial off-message candidate. The winner - Ken Livingstone - would have been the official Labour candidate had Tony Blair sanctioned a fair internal ballot of members. Had he done so, the government's mid-term blues might have been banished this morning.

The import of a hybrid system of directly-elected mayors from the United States may have failed in its first objective - to raise the game of local politicians and blow away public apathy.

Yet it has succeeded, beyond all expectations, in further elevating personality over policy. What Labour party supporters cannot understand is why two personalities in particular - Blair and Livingstone - could not find some way of accommodating each other. The onus is now on the prime minister to do just that.

He could yet give Labour a second chance in the capital. Certainly he should obey his instincts and not continue a pointless feud for which he has already been punished. Ken Livingstone should be readmitted into the Labour Party.

Despite the fact that there were, in effect, two Labour candidates for mayor, it is the prime minister's good fortune to wake up this morning and discover that Steven Norris has not been elected mayor. It is also a mark of just how divorced the national press is from its metropolitan readers that its near uniform hostility to Ken Livingstone had such little impact on their voting intention.

The London Labour party, and the many thousands who cast their votes for Livingstone hope and expect that he is admitted back into the party at the earliest opportunity. Next week the annual conference of the Fire Brigades Union will debate a motion which many of its members intend putting to Labour's autumn conference; a demand that his membership card is returned.

Similar pressure is likely to feed through the other trade unions whose members voted so heavily for him. There will be renewed pressure, too, to ensure that the party leadership never repeats horrendous own goals, first in Wales, now in London, by ensuring that one member, one vote is always used for internal elections. It is now obvious that Jim Fitzpatrick, the current chairman of the London Labour party, who helped engineer the original electoral college fix against Livingstone, is in an untenable position.

He should resign in order to allow the London Labour party to elect a chairman who will respect their democratic rights.

Elsewhere in the country, a distinctly patchy night for the government led to a premature Tory triumphalism, that still seems unlikely to much boost William Hague's chances at the next election. He has managed to become ever more shrill, playing the race card while ramping up law and order. Hague is in danger of becoming the Captain Mainwaring of British politics.

Fortunately there is a limit to this constituency. For Labour and Tony Blair the message is crystal clear: it is time to stop aping aspects of Conservatism and begin to act more like a Labour prime minister. Margaret Thatcher once famously told a Conservative Party conference "You turn if you want - but this lady is not for turning." Her intransigence led to two recessions, social division and unemployment not seen since the 1930s.

Her hubris eventually destroyed her. We live in less apocalyptic times, but the results from around the country do suggest a far greater degree of voter apathy and volatility. They do demand a series of policy changes and a major rethink in direction so that fighting inequality, increasing support for public services and manufacturing industry become top priorities. And if the government is serious about tackling voter apathy and can be sure of getting Labour voters out at the polls, the twenty-year trend towards greater centralisation needs to be thrown into sharp reverse.
