fields.headline: Macca: You have your say
fields.trailText: Yesterday Football Unlimited argued that Steve McManaman could be England's saviour during Euro 2000 - providing Kevin Keegan has the guts to hand him the free role his talent deserves.
fields.body:
Yesterday Football Unlimited argued that Steve McManaman could be England's saviour during Euro 2000 - providing Kevin Keegan has the guts to hand him the free role his talent deserves.

That's not exactly a view that's doing the rounds at the moment. Those in the David Mellor brigade would never let McManaman near an England shirt again, while even those who followed our article (like Martin Samuel of the Daily Express and Football 365) have hedged their bets and recommended that Macca should simply be a squad player this summer.

But the message to Keegan from most Football Unlimited readers is clear. Stop thinking of Steve McManaman as a floppy-haired England failure, stop sticking him on the left-wing - and give him, at last, a starting position that can do his immense ability justice.

Here is a short selection of the letters we have received:

I was happy to hear a journalist finally singing the praises of one of England's brightest young stars. In recent times he has been the subject of considerable unjustifiable criticism from so called 'journalists' who chose to jump on the band wagon of the 'pub critic' who judged MacManaman on several poor performances for England (when he was forced to play in an unaccustomed wing-back role) rather than years of consistent years at Liverpool.

During his time at the Merseyside club he did, week in, week out, perform to the highest level in both effort and skill, it would therefore be ultimately detrimental to the chances of the England side if he was not given his chance at Euro 2000 to show off his unique ability.

Keep up the good work! Daniel Inglis

The argument for Macca to be in the England side has been going on between me and the rest of the English speaking world for the last year or so now. Thank you for being the first person to support my view.

The tabloids seem to have it in for him every time that he plays for England, (probably because they can't get to him in Spain) and that has done much to shape the public's perception. All I heard for the early part of the season was what a disaster his first few games for Real were, even though no-one had actually seen him play. However, despite the fact that when he is out of the side we do not have anyone who can beat his man, (see the dross produced in the Belgium and Sweden games) he remains a Waddle-esque figure at international level, too good to leave out, but too 'inconsistent' to accommodate.

This despite the fact that he has only found his international feet in the Euro 96 side where positive attacking play was preferred to a rigid and 'set in stone' formation and he was allowed to go out and express himself.

Anyway, sorry for wasting your time with this rant, it's just been nice being smug for the last fortnight.

Cheers, Lee Burman

Couldn't agree with you more about McManaman's ability to lift England to another level. As an ex-pat Scot now living in Canada I saw what he could do while attending the Euro 96 Scotland-England match and having seen him many times this season do his stuff for Real Madrid.

Why is there any deliberation on Keegan's part and who are the potential replacements should he be left out of the final squad? Doesn't the fact that he is the only player of UK origin currently playing - and playing well - for one of the top teams on the continent say enough about his ability?

Derek Mercer

I liked your feature on Macca for England. The one doubt I have is that he plays that well because he is in a team of brilliant players who really enjoy playing the game.

This is not quite the same as playing for England.

Bests, Ray Hudson

Exactly right. Two facts:

1. McManaman has been nothing short of brilliant in Champions League recently. At times against Hollywood [Bayern Munich], he seemed to be toying with what we've come to think a disciplined side, using speed and guile to create enormous patchs of ground.

2. Beckham disappeared in this same competition. After the verdict was known, Beckham turned in a decent second half against Real, but what was the point of that?

Both, obviously, need to be in the side. But there is a lesson: Big-time players must elevate their play in big time situations - and that's what McManaman has done.

Nice piece, Matt Schofield

The only anti-McManaman letter we've received was the following.

All Macca can do is go on mazy runs. If he can't get a go at goal then he can't take the run anywhere, he can't cross!! Give Becks the free role and his Laser accurate passes will be put to brilliant use especially with Andy Cole up front.

Kieran McNamara, Liverpool supporter (who would love to have those two in the ranks!)

What do you think? Should McManaman be given a free role? Or should he even be in the squad? Email the.boss@theguardian.com with your view.

fields.headline: The jeans team
fields.standfirst: Denim is huge news for spring. The shops are bursting with it. So it should be easy to find the perfect pair of jeans, whatever your shape or size, right? To find out, we gave five volunteers £70 each and challenged them to find a piece of denim heaven
fields.trailText: Denim is huge news for spring. The shops are bursting with it. So it should be easy to find the perfect pair of jeans, whatever your shape or size, right? To find out, we gave five volunteers £70 each and challenged them to find a piece of denim heaven
fields.body:
Gemma Harrison, 32, trading executive

As I am 6ft tall, I have previously had to resort to buying men's jeans - this time I was determined to try for a pair of women's. I started off in Evans and tried four pairs in various lengths and fits. Unfortunately none was quite long enough or they were baggy around the hips - obviously made for a more rounded person!

Next stop was Principles, where I tried two pairs of jeans, without luck, then leafed through the shelves of well-known brands to attempt to find a larger size. I did try one pair of black Levi's 501s - again I found they weren't the right cut for me, so I thought I'd just take a glance at the men's department and picked up a pair of Calvin Kleins and Levi's 501s. The young lad in attendance looked a bit astounded when I asked to try them on, but graciously allowed me to use the fitting room, even though I offered to go across to the ladies' department. Success at last: the 501s came up tops and I even have a little bit of extra length if I want to wear heels or they shrink a bit.

I was still embarrassed, though, at buying men's jeans. In future, to spare my blushes, I'll go back to ordering from my home shopping catalogue where I can try them on in the comfort of my own home.

Bonnie Gilmore, 23, video operatorSince most British women fall below 5ft 4in, you'd think it would be easy to find a pair of jeans for someone size six and 5ft 1in. Think again, girlfriend. Ten lunchtimes and as many shops as you can name, my quest for a new pair of jeans was failing miserably.

Forgetting about length because that's always an issue, I concentrate on the fit around waist, hips and crotch. Once upon a time, urban streetwear suited me perfectly: baggy, baggy, baggy. But after one night in Earl jeans (my favourite Christmas present yet), baggy Carhartts lost their appeal. So here I was, back in the land of straight jeans but unable to find a suitable high street pair that fitted. You name it, I tried it - and ended up with old man's baggy crotch or big saggy bum.

With Gap, French Connection and Diesel having failed me, all roads led to Levi's. Seduced by the ad campaign, "twisted jeans" were my first choice, but I was disappointed again - and in another pair of grandad's trousers. The helpful assistant suggested I try on six different styles. The winner was the classic dark denim 501s, style 535. These fulfilled every criteria: fitting well at waist, hips and crotch, straight-legged, slim-fitted and versatile. Suitable for work or Sunday football, fine with trainers and high-heeled boots.

John Beament, 50, managing director

My mission to buy a pair of jeans started at a well-known department store in Knightsbridge. As I was browsing, I came across a pair of designer jeans which, at £65, seemed a good buy, until I looked in the mirror and realised I was 30 years too old for them and they had 10 pockets too many for me.

Next stop was Gap where I tried on two pairs, both priced at a reasonable £42. The first pair, Boot Fit, were too tight, the second, Vintage Cut, too baggy. The designer had got it wrong for the shape of my body.

From Gap I went to Harringtons and picked pairs of Gant and Paul Smith denims, both priced at £69. Though both were good quality, they looked better on the shelf than they did on me. At this point, I was seriously considering resorting to a pair of the Levi's 501s I have always bought in the past, but I decided my last visit would be to Ikon in Guildford where I tried on several Armani and Boss jeans. The Boss Arkansas dark blue denims were just what I wanted and I went home happy, having spent £70 on a pair of jeans I really like.

Ritchie Parrott, 31, admin assistant

It's a cliché that gay men love to go clothes shopping: as a fat gay man, I can honestly say I don't. For me, the dreaded event happens only when my clothes have buttons dropping off and holes where there shouldn't be holes. Finding something that fits is not always easy, but I'm on a mission: to find jeans for summer that can be worn at work or play.

My options are limited, but I'm hopeful. I check a couple of high street chain stores and M&S - no luck. Then on to the fat man's shopping mecca, High and Mighty in London's Tottenham Court Road. They're quite trendy, a little bit pricey, but worth it for the joy of knowing you are going to get what you need. The staff were quick to assist, even when measuring my ever neglected waistline. When the jeans I liked weren't available in my size, they offered - without any fuss - to phone another branch, which was a nice touch.

The jeans ranged from Pierre Cardin at £119 to the affordable Easy range at around £49. I chose a pair of beige carpenter jeans that fell into the latter category. Job done and dusted within the hour - perhaps it's not as hard I thought. And if you want to make it even easier, shop from home at www.highandmighty.co.uk

Lyndsay Austin, 42, solicitor

I've worn jeans since my 70s student days when denims other than Levi's attracted howls of derision. A long leg is a must and I prefer a tightish fit but not breathing isn't an option. I began my quest at Allders in Woking. Nostalgia cooled after a pathetic struggle to fasten Wrangler's "70s cut" button flares. On to Next, where the stretch Classics protruded strangely around my knees. At TK Max (the designer seconds store), the Pepe Nicole jeans were too short and balloon-like. Elbowing aside the male shoppers, I tried a pair of men's DKNY long blue zip denims (past season). Slightly low-rise, they fastened after a satisfyingly brief struggle. The length was excellent, the fit snug but not life-threatening. Best so far.

My street cred improving, I hit Levi's and tried their Engineered Jeans. The fit was fantastic but (call me old-fashioned) I like my side seams at the sides, though the customised embroidery option was fun. The low-rise Gap Boy Fits, meanwhile, were too short and pleated around the derriere, and at Betty Barclay, the only jeans within budget were stretchy and comfortable but girlie and high-waisted. So it was back to TK Max for my almost perfect men's DKNY jeans - a bargain at £24.99.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Decleor tan
fields.trailText: The rehabilitation of self-tanning products from shameful butt of Tango jokes to status beauty purchase has brought sighs of relief from the less melanin-endowed among us (who were, of course, using it all along, just keeping quiet about it). So if you're still turning your pasty nose up, get with the programme and saunter into summer with honey-legged abandon rather than spending every lunchtime lying prone in the park on the off chance of getting a few freckles. Even better, get tanned professionally: a 90-minute treatment in a Decleor salon not only gives the optimum golden glow but leaves your skin smoother than chocolate mousse (presumably because the nice lady exfoliates your skin for over half an hour rather than the six seconds most of us manage). What a ridiculous waste of time and money, I hear you tut, and you're absolutely right, of course. Lovely, though.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  eye gloss
fields.trailText: Fashionable girls are very, very shiny these days. Boring old face powder has been sidelined so ruthlessly by lip shine, face highlighter and cheek shimmer that one can't help wondering whether a squirt of Mr Sheen and a vigorous rub with a chamois leather might not have a similar effect to the latest designer make-up. The newest arrival, eye gloss, seems possibly a step too far - do you really want to pay over a tenner to have shiny eyes? - but it is currently gracing the chicest lids. Eye gloss is not the easiest of products to use: it collects in creases, makes mascara run and gives eyelids a gummy texture that turns every blink into a languorous lash-fluttering affair which can be a little misleading. Shiny eyelids are, apparently, tremendously alluring - a little Vaseline above the lashes was to the 50s what body glitter was to the 90s. You have been warned: prepare yourself for a smear campaign.

fields.headline: Scooter loopy
fields.standfirst: Want to look stylish on the streets this summer?  Damon Syson  explains how
fields.trailText: With summer rapidly approaching, picking the right wheels on which to arrive at the pub on a balmy evening is becoming a matter of some urgency for the incurably hip. Standing outside the Bricklayers Arms in "London's fashionable Shoreditch" recently, I had the good fortune to witness this phenomenon taken to new extremes. As we nursed our pints and coveted each other's trainers, a small tank roared round the corner and pulled up outside the boozer.
fields.body:
With summer rapidly approaching, picking the right wheels on which to arrive at the pub on a balmy evening is becoming a matter of some urgency for the incurably hip. Standing outside the Bricklayers Arms in "London's fashionable Shoreditch" recently, I had the good fortune to witness this phenomenon taken to new extremes. As we nursed our pints and coveted each other's trainers, a small tank roared round the corner and pulled up outside the boozer. Everyone gawped. Some even clapped. Of course, this being Shoreditch, by the time the driver emerged from the top of his camouflaged vehicle (wearing goggles), most of the punters had returned to their customary torpor. Perhaps Tank Boy was a regular sight round those parts, though I prefer to think that at this particular pub, the sight of Elvis Presley and John Lennon enjoying a pint would barely raise a yawn.

Either way, it was a dramatic arrival. But for those who prefer a slightly less Schwarzenegger-esque entrance, summer 2000's must-have mode of transport is the Micro, a Swiss-designed scooter (that's "scooter" as in the kind you used to push along with one foot when you were a kid) that's fast becoming as much of an essential design item as the Philippe Starck lemon squeezer.

The Micro is so gloriously silly, it was bound to be embraced by the fashion crowd. The craze first took off in - you guessed it - Japan, where it is rapidly overtaking Pokemon as the fad du jour, with sales currently topping 50,000 per week. Micros first arrived in this country last October, initially in "cult" outlets: skate shops, The Conran Shop (Terry's a big fan) and Paul Smith. This summer, now that they're available in large retailers nationwide (and already selling at a rate of 4,000 per week), they will soon be a regular sight on urban streets. You may have already spotted a few brave Micro-naut pioneers. The only golden rule is always to ride alone. Two people on them look like something out of the Red Hand Gang.

On a smooth surface, Micros travel at a fair clip (pressing down on the back mudguard acts as a brake) and are a lot of fun. However, riders need to be ultra vigilant on your average British pavement, as even the smallest bump carries the risk of, at best humiliation, at worst auto-castration. Retailing at around £120, they are not cheap, but their USP lies in the fact that they are incredibly light and can be folded up, in about 15 seconds, to a size small enough to fit in your backpack. Thus you can ride one to the pub, chin six pints and not kill yourself trying to ride it home.

To get an idea of the broad appeal of the Micro, you need only consider the disparate celebrities who have fallen for its charms. Norman Wisdom uses one to bomb around when he's in London. Jack Dee recently purchased one. Rappers Cypress Hill borrowed a fleet of them for one of their videos, Robbie Williams is a devotee and - the ultimate stamp of cool - Jude Law and Sadie Frost own one, which they ride around in the living room of their Primrose Hill abode. And you don't get much hipper than that.

According to Dax Warner of Blue Room, one of the first skate shops to stock the Micro, even businessmen are being seduced by the scooter's speedy commuting potential. "We had a 60-year-old barrister come in the other day," Warner says. "He bought a Micro, unfolded it and scooted off to a meeting in his three-piece suit."

But what if scooting doesn't grab you? Well, it's still vitally important to recognise which of the current crop of urban transportation fads will win you admiring glances as you pull up outside your local gastro-pub. Roller blades, for example, are fashion hara-kiri, while roller-skates are perenially cool (but only if you wear leg-warmers and can funk dance on them). Similarly, skateboards are a wise choice (for adults) only if you can travel insouciantly with your weight on your back foot and herald your arrival by pulling a massive "ollie" - risky, even for experts. Snake-boards are a rare sight these days due to being frankly impossible to use. And long-boards are just too much of a drag to carry when you're fighting to get to the bar.

And what if you prefer to pedal rather than push? Mountain bikes, let's face it, are just too sensible and while the BMX has clung to a certain cachet, it is still essentially a kid's bike. The only cycle for an adult to be seen on is the Cruiser, the BMX's older brother, equipped with larger (24in) wheels so you don't look like an utter fool when you're pedalling.

Mopeds and vespas, too, are starting to look a bit declassé. Instead, why not take it back to l'ancien ecole with that paradigm of French peasant chic, the SoleX. Created in the 40s, it's a black sit-up-and-beg bicycle with a two-stroke engine attached to the front wheel. A top speed of 23mph may not sound impressive until you consider average speed for a car in London is 11mph. And you can't be arguing with 200 miles to the gallon.

So the message is, assuming you can't get your hands on a tank, go lo-fi this summer with a Micro. As for next summer, who knows how we'll be rocking up to the pub. Maybe someone will see fit to reinvent the Space Hopper. Or perhaps it's finally time to dust off that Sinclair C5.

Blue Room is at 12a Fouberts Pl, London W1, 020-7434 0627. For Micro stockists, contact Citybug, 0118973 6222, www.citybug.com. For SoleX stockists, tel 020-7795 0175.

fields.headline: Livingstone to 'heal and unite'
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone and Tony Blair both pledged today to put their differences behind them and work together for London after Mr Livingstone became London's first elected mayor, winning 776,427 votes against the Conservative Steven Norris's 564,137 after second preference votes were counted.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone and Tony Blair both pledged today to put their differences behind them and work together for London after Mr Livingstone became London's first elected mayor, winning 776,427 votes against the Conservative Steven Norris's 564,137 after second preference votes were counted.

On a turnout of 33.6%, the Labour candidate Frank Dobson finished third, only slightly ahead of Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat.

Mr Livingstone and Tony Blair promised to heal the divisions between them but they cautioned each other to use their power responsibly.

At a 3pm press conference, Mr Livingstone urged assembly members not to replicate the sterile politics of Westminster. "Members should leave the caucus and the whip at the door and vote for what is best for London.

"I strongly welcome the statements by government ministers about their intention to cooperate with me and we are moving towards a meeting with the prime minister."

He said he would work with Downing Street to solve London's transport problems but added: "The government also has to co-operate with London. Electors voted against the privatisation of the tube and the government should respect the voters' views. I can't believe this government which has taken such a drubbing at the polls believes that Londoners want to see the tube broken up."

Mr Livingstone, referring to the demonstrations in the capital on May Day during which graffitti was daubed on the cenotaph, said that those behaving in that way would "find this mayor distinctly uncuddly".

He added: "My intention is to heal my wound with the Labour Party. The job of the mayor is to unite all parties in this city."

Mr Livingstone was declared mayor just after noon and began his victory speech by saying: "As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted 14 years ago... I want an all-embracing administration that will speak with one voice on behalf of London.

"I hope after reflection my fellow candidates will want to help me in that work and hope they will join me in that administration.

"I believe in regional government. The government that is best is the government that is best for the people.

"I pledge to heal the division between myself and the Labour party and I hope the Blair government is elected for a second term."

The new mayor paid tribute to Mr Dobson, saying: "He has borne a terrible brunt of odium that should have been reserved for people behind the scenes."

Earlier, Tony Blair said that he would work with the new mayor, though he cautioned that Mr Livingstone must use his power responsibly and made it plain that there was no love lost between them.

"It is important that we do everything we can to see that this works for London and Londoners. Ken also has a responsibility to make this work. I have not changed my views on Ken, but that has to be in the past. Ken also has a responsibility to make this work. The mayor has real power. We've got to make sure we play our part as the government in making this work."

Mr Dobson, who gave no response to Mr Livingstone's invitation to join his London administration, said after the result: "As a democrat, I respect the votes of the people of London. Personally, I'm deeply disappointed not to become mayor. It's a job I would have loved to have done.

"It was not always easy. I believe our message was right, but we found it difficult to get that message across.

"I hope not too many people will feel that I have let them down.

"I have enjoyed the campaigning and I don't regret the decision to stand. I said what I thought, not what I thought people wanted to hear. I continue to believe that in a democracy we have to tell the people the truth whether it turns out to be popular or not."

After a count of second preference votes, Mr Livingstone won the endorsement of 12 of London's 14 constituencies, with the Tories victorious only in West Central and Bexley and Bromley.

fields.headline: Virgin vixens - a field guide
fields.standfirst: Confused by the current crop of teenage warblers? You won't be with Caroline Sullivan's handy tips
fields.trailText: Confused by the current crop of teenage warblers? You won't be with Caroline Sullivan's handy tips
fields.body:
Complaining about the state of the singles chart is a traditional British sport, but right now it really does seem to be poised at the edge of the eternal abyss of darkness. Boyzone clones ordinaire Westlife have made history by debuting their first five records at number one. Two-step garage, a colourless dance-music virus, has colonised the Top 10. And every week brings "the new Britney Spears", as if the old one weren't already the most derivative thing since Noel Gallagher happened across the Beatles.

How much more of this can the music business dish out before it implodes in a purifying ritual that sweeps away everyone who sees music as a quick route to fame and/or has ever been to stage school? That means you, Spears, on both counts. And your erstwhile Mickey Mouse Club compadre, Christina Aguilera. And the English version of you, Billie, who is relaunched this month as the more grown-up Billie Piper. It also means the "virgin Britney", Jessica Simpson, whose claim to fame is her vow not to have sex till she's married, and Mandy Moore, who seems to have no distinguishing characteristics whatsoever.

Sixteen-year-old Floridian Moore's first album, imaginatively titled I Wanna Be With You, is released next week, and is so lacklustre that even trade mag Music Week can only bring itself to say: "Too much like what might be expected, with few surprises." Needless to say, it has already sold a million in America.

Nevertheless, Moore, who's also "the global face of Neutrogena", is already making inroads here, hitting the Top 10 with the single Candy, erroneously described by her record label as "fresh and exhilarating". Well, it might be exhilarating to under-10s and to paedophiles who recently voted Spears the "girl you'd most like to see in a porn movie", but there's little of interest to anyone else.

Yet there will probably be no stopping her. Like the other Britclones, she looks enough like Spears to be her sister - and she plays up her adolescent cuteness with chilling purposefulness. If Prince William ever tires of Britney (who's starring in a C4 cartoon to mark his 18th birthday), he can move on to Moore, or any of her cookie-cutter sistren, and never spot the join. Just as boy bands defined 1999, this will be the year of the plastic teenage nymphette. Keep telling yourself "It's only a movie... it's only a movie..."

Britney Spears

Biog 18, from Louisiana, former Mickey Mouse Club child star. 20 million albums sold, biggest hit: Baby One More Time.

Looks like Every top-shelf fantasy of teenage nubility.

Would Prince William fancy her? He's said to have her posters on bedroom wall - she's returning the favour by buying a house near Highgrove.

Fashion don'ts Suspiciously large chest that seemed to sprout overnight, which she attributes to teenage growth spurt.

Redeeming qualities Evidence of sense of humour - her first boyfriend was called Reg.

Lyrical insights "You think I'm in love/ That I'm sent from above/ I'm not that innocent".

Has she no shame? What little clothing she still wears has to be glued to her skin to keep it in place.

Billie Piper

Biog 17, Swindon, TV ads, 500,000 albums, Because We Want To.

Looks like Top Shop meets Ibiza Uncovered.
Would Prince William fancy her? At least she wouldn't constantly squeal, "Ooh, say that again!"
Fashion don'ts Cynically ditched schoolgirl image for potentially more lucrative sex-bomb look.
Redeeming qualities British, so probably not completely suffused with sense of own importance.
Lyrical insights "Why ya gotta play that music so loud?/ Because we want to".
Has she no shame? Shattered thousands of girlish hearts by choosing to date Rich from Five.

Jessica Simpson

Biog 19, Dallas, child singer. First album just out, Sweet Kisses.
Looks like S Club 7's bubbly American cousin.
Would Prince William fancy her? Could learn about snogging together.
Fashion don'ts Partial to baby pink and pastel blue.
Redeeming qualities Unlikely to end up in ruinous tryst with Puff Daddy.
Lyrical insights "Left your desperate spell on me/ Say you feel it, too".
Has she no shame? Goes out with member of grunty US boy band 98 Degrees.

Mandy Moore

Biog 16, Florida, did ads and voiceovers. One million albums, Candy.
Looks like Midwestern mallrat with Zoe Ball highlights.
Would Prince William fancy her? Might be attracted by discount on skincare products.
Fashion don'ts Lacks the nous to realise that blond highlights and boob tubes make her look exactly like other four.
Redeeming qualitites Flawless complexion by Neutrogena.
Lyrical insights "Your love's sweet as candy/ I'll be forever yours/ Love, Mandy".
Has she no shame? Is threatening to co-write her next album.

Christina Aguilera

Biog 19, Pennsylvania, was a Mousketeer with Britney. Eight million albums, Genie in a Bottle.
Looks like Krystle-from-Dynasty's over-ripe daughter.
Would Prince William fancy her? He might be cowed by her matronly bosom.
Fashion don'ts Donatella Versace hair doesn't match half-Spanish complexion.
Redeeming qualities Possesses some actual talent, which was rewarded with a Grammy.
Lyrical insights "I'm a genie in a bottle, baby/ Rub me the right way".
Has she no shame? Looks more like a Vegas chorus girl every month...

fields.headline: Trial by jury
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw previews the Cannes film festival, which opens next Wednesday
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw previews the Cannes film festival, which opens next Wednesday
fields.body:
The first Cannes film festival of the century - an inexorably expanding event with 1,397 new films assessed for entry, up 23% from last year, and 23 selected for official competition - will certainly have a perceptibly newer, more gleaming showcase. Another new venue has been built, the 300-seat Salle Luis Buñuel, for special events and retrospectives, to add to its other theatres, the Lumière, the Debussy and the Bazin.

Also, Cannes is to junk its traditional simultaneous English translation through uncomfortable headsets, where no subtitled print was available. The official festival website calls it a "barbarity" and has now replaced it with electronic subtitles everywhere - but the interpreters' attempts at acting will be greatly missed, particularly their doggedly earnest moans and groans for sex scenes.

Otherwise, among the impossibly vast line-up, there is something familiar about the Cannes 2000 selection. In competition, Joel and Ethan Coen are back with O Brother, Where Art Thou?, a knockabout comedy starring George Clooney and John Turturro whose title alludes to the Preston Sturges classic, Sullivan's Travels. Ang Lee is out of competition with his action movie Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, and Lars Von Trier, a man whose career has been validated almost every step of the way at Cannes, is there with Dancer in the Dark, ostensibly a musical drama starring Björk and Catherine Deneuve.

Cannes has a way of amplifying to a deafening scale the mistakes and flip-flops of a director's career, and something about the Björk/Deneuve/musical combination may be enough to make his admirers uneasy. Neil LaBute, whose In the Company of Men was one of the most sensational films of the 90s, is in competition with Nurse Betty, a funky-looking Couplandesque tale about a waitress in love with a soap-opera doctor, starring Renee "Bridget Jones" Zellweger. The estimable Ken Loach's new film at Cannes is Bread and Roses.

In spite of these Anglophone directors, however, the flavour of this year's festival is distinctly Eastern and Middle-Eastern, something partly attributable to the continuing reluctance of US studios to submit their expensive babies to the festival's unpredictable, unspinnable brawl. (Lots more US projects are in fact out of competition, such as Stephen Hopkins's Under Suspicion, Darren Aronofsky's Requiem for a Dream, and John Waters' Hollywood spoof, Cecil B Demented.)

Maybe the most awe-inspiring Cannes debut this year is that of 20-year-old Iranian director Samira Makhmalbaf, with Blackboards, about a group of teachers fleeing bomb-wrecked Iranian Kurdistan looking for someone, anyone to teach. From the Far East, likely candidates are Wong Kar-Wai's enigmatic Untitled (formerly called In the Mood for Love), about a Hong Kong newspaper editor's clandestine affair, and Edward Yang's Yi Yi, an involved family drama set in Shanghai.

Despite this emphasis, there is not much Far or Middle-Eastern representation on the jury, which has a rather middlebrow flavour: chaired by Luc Besson, it features a lot of thesps, including our own Jeremy Irons and Kristin Scott Thomas. Perhaps they will smile on sturdily furnished costume and period extravaganzas like James Ivory's reading of Henry James's The Golden Bowl, or Arnaud Desplechin's Esther Kahn, an English-language movie about an East End Jewish woman in the 19th century who finds fulfilment in the theatre.

A mouth-watering choice in the alternative Un Certain Regard section of the festival is Kristian Levring's The King Is Alive (aka Dogme 4), about an impromptu production of King Lear in the African desert. Filmed in accordance with the Dogme Group's vow of chastity, it features an international cast including Romane Bohringer, Jennifer Jason Leigh and Janet McTeer.

It is in the Directors Fortnight strand that the New Brits are largely featured. Stephen Daldry's Dancer, Mark Herman's Purely Belter, and Simon Cellan-Jones's Some Voices are flying the flag for the British revival, though there is not quite the same credulity about celluloid Cool Britannia this year, and Chris Smith may not be putting in an owlish appearance on the Croisette. (But the British efforts here look a safer bet than Honest, another jocose Brit-gangster pic, out of competition, directed by ex-Eurythmic and Paradise Syndrome survivor Dave Stewart, and starring All Saints. The portents are not great.)

It may be that just as last year the Directors Fortnight gave us The Blair Witch Project, it will spawn a left-field indie smash hit again in 2000, and contenders could be Karim Dridi's much-fancied Cuba Feliz, or Karyn Kusama's women's boxing picture, Girlfight. We shall see.

fields.headline: What Livingstone does now
fields.standfirst: Guardian correspondent Seumas Milne on the new mayor's plans for London
fields.trailText: Guardian correspondent Seumas Milne on the new mayor's plans for London.
fields.body:
People would be "quite surprised", Ken Livingstone declared in characteristic style after voting for himself yesterday, to discover that his election as mayor would not mean London "disappearing into a great cavernous anarchistic hole".

Expect to hear plenty more of this kind of talk over the next few days. Cross-party inclusivity is already Livingstone's theme of the hour.

The man who once terrorised the suburbs as Red Ken may have just secured the largest ever electoral victory by a candidate to the left of Labour. But the former Greater London council leader has no intention of scaring off bits of the coalition he assembled for his electoral comeback.

While New Labour, the Tories and their media friends have been vying to brand him a threat to jobs and public order, the Brent East MP has been busy wooing London business organisations and the police.

Now he will offer the hand of cooperation to the government, the newly-elected Greater London authority members and the London boroughs.

Armed with his new powers of patronage and Tony Blair's pledge not to seek confrontation with the mayor - at least this side of the general election - getting his way with the GLA should not prove an insuperable task.

But for all Livingstone's studied magnanimity, there are some bottom-line issues his closest advisers insist are not negotiable, foremost of which is opposition to the partial sell-off of the London Underground.

Speculation that Livingstone is planning a graceful climbdown on this issue is wrong, one insists. "We have no technical powers to block them, but Ken regards this election as having been a referendum on tube privatisation and we're looking to stop the PPP".

At his victory party on Thursday night, Livingstone signalled that the greening of London would be a central theme of his administration.

Given his modest powers, the new mayor will have a full-time job trying to squeeze cash out of the government and his campaign for central government to stop "kicking London" is likely to be relentless.
fields.bodyText: People would be "quite surprised", Ken Livingstone declared in characteristic style after voting for himself yesterday, to discover that his election as mayor would not mean London "disappearing into a great cavernous anarchistic hole". Expect to hear plenty more of this kind of talk over the next few days. Cross-party inclusivity is already Livingstone's theme of the hour. The man who once terrorised the suburbs as Red Ken may have just secured the largest ever electoral victory by a candidate to the left of Labour. But the former Greater London council leader has no intention of scaring off bits of the coalition he assembled for his electoral comeback. webTitle: Police followed Palestine link, Lockerbie trial told

fields.headline: Police followed Palestine link, Lockerbie trial told
fields.trailText: Scottish police investigating the Lockerbie disaster flew to Rome and Germany within days of the bombing to study similar atrocities involving a Palestinian group, the Lockerbie trial in Holland was told today.
fields.body:
Scottish police investigating the Lockerbie disaster flew to Rome and Germany within days of the bombing to study similar atrocities involving a Palestinian group, the Lockerbie trial in Holland was told today.

Retired detective chief inspector Gordon Ferrie said that the tragedy was treated as a murder inquiry from the day after it happened. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine General Command (PFLPGC) quickly became the "focus of attention" because of arrests of some of its members in Germany only two months before Pan Am 103 exploded over Lockerbie.

They included a man known as Marwan Kreeshat, a technical expert who had been jailed for 18 years in his absence for his part in placing a bomb in a record player on an El Al flight from Rome to Tel Aviv in 1972.

He had been arrested by the Germans in October 1988, the court was told, but released in December, before the Lockerbie bombing later the same month.

About ten senior officers from the Lockerbie inquiry spent weeks at the German headquarters of the BKA, the German equivalent of the FBI, the court heard.

The two Libyans accused of the bombing, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, deny charges of murder and conspiracy to murder, and they have lodged special defences in which they incriminate, among others, members of the PFLPGC.

Under cross-examination Mr Ferrie confirmed he had been sent to Rome twice to study the El Al incident, in which two British women had been befriended by three men - including Marwan Kreeshat - and persuaded to take a record player on board the plane. They did not know it contained a bomb.

El Al security measures ensured the record player went into the bomb-proof luggage hold, instead of in the passenger cabin. Fortunately, although the device exploded at about 13,000ft and blew a hole in the passenger floor, the plane landed back at Rome safely.

Mr Ferrie brought back to Lockerbie some of the Italian evidence in the case, including part of an altimeter which had been used in the bomb's trigger. Questioned by Richard Keen QC, representing Fhimah, Mr Ferrie confirmed that in Rome he had discovered that Kreeshat had been involved in other incidents "using improvised explosive devices", including the bombing of a plane using a Toshiba radio cassette recorder modified to act as a bomb.

The Lockerbie trial indictment accuses Megrahi and Fhimah of placing an "improvised explosive device" concealed inside a Toshiba radio cassette recorder on board an Air Malta flight to Frankfurt labelled for onward connection to New-York bound Pan Am Flight 103 at Heathrow.

Asked if Kreeshat was believed to be "an agent of a Middle Eastern intelligence service", Mr Ferrie replied: "I can't answer to that."

Re-examined by Alan Turnbull QC, prosecuting, Mr Ferrie was asked: "There came a stage when the inquiry led officers in a direction other than the PFLP, weren't there?" Mr Ferrie agreed.

However, when he then asked Mr Ferrie what the eventual result of the police inquiry was, defence lawyers objected that it was hearsay evidence, because Mr Ferrie had later been moved to other work.

Questioned by Mr Keen for Fhimah, Mr McLean insisted that, although FBI and CIA agents from America were swiftly on the scene of the disaster, all evidence found was "religiously and meticulously" logged, including items recovered by the CIA.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Machine fault delays mayor vote count

fields.headline: Machine fault delays mayor vote count
fields.trailText: The London mayor result was delayed by more than five hours today because of a fault with the vote counting machines.
fields.body:
The London mayor result was delayed by more than five hours today because of a fault with the vote counting machines.

Politicians, journalists and the public were kept waiting until after midday in the Queen Elizabeth Hall on the South Bank, central London, as Britain's first election using electronic counters ground to a halt.

The machines automatically scan unfolded ballot papers and, when working, can register two-and-a-half votes a second. Using the manual method, vote counting would have taken until Sunday due to the multiple choice nature of the ballot papers.

Delays began when a fault was found on the vote tellers in the Enfield and Haringey constituency.

At first the problems were blamed on dust. Greater London returning officer Rob Hughes said shortly before 4am that the result would not be announced until 9am "at the earliest". He said "static" from dust on some of the coverings on the tables had caused problems with the electronic vote counters at Enfield, adding: "There is nothing wrong with the counting machines or the computers. They have just got bunged up."

Other counts were hit by large numbers of incorrectly completed papers and delays in getting ballot boxes to the counting centres.

Mr Hughes said: "This is a brand new system of voting and a brand new system of counting. It isn't surprising we have had a few problems."

fields.headline: Honeymoon by Amy Jenkins
fields.standfirst:
(Flame, £10), digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: This Life author mixes Bridget Jones and Private Lives without the wit, edge and style of either. And with Bridget Jones, that's quite some achievement.
fields.body:
We were driving around central London, the girls and me, in this fuck-off white stretch limo. Well, you've got to do something on your hen night.

"Let's play a game, Honey," said Della. "How about the Love Of Your Life?"

Della isn't given to endearments, by the way. Honey is my name. Short for Honeymoon because that's where I was conceived. I've got a sister Ven, short for Venice, too...

"If we must," I replied. So I told them about Alex. We'd met in a restaurant. Talk about electricity, it was like being plugged into the national grid. We both dumped our partners and went back to his place.

"And then..." the girls chorused.

"Nothing," I continued. "We stayed up all night chatting and I drove him to Heathrow the next morning to catch his flight to America and I never heard from him again."

"Not a letter or phone call?"

"Nah. I guess I just wasn't thin enough." The Enuff Monster gets me every time. Deep down I know I'm not fat and ugly, but the Monster always makes me doubt myself. Maybe it's because my parents were killed in an air crash when I was a child.

Even so, seven years on, scarcely a week has gone by when I haven't thought about Alex. Wondering if he was the ONE.

"OHMYGOD, you're serious," shrieked Della. "We mustn't tell Ed."

I'd met Ed when I was looking for a landscape gardener for Mac, my employer. Mac's something in the film biz: he tried to sexually assault me once, but after we talked it through, I sort of stayed on and became his PA.

Ed's a nice bloke, but he's not my type. I never really fancied him, but we became friends after he helped me through the death of Princess Diana. And now we're getting married.

The Big Day went OK, except we missed our honeymoon flight to Mexico as I had some work to do for Mac. Which is how we ended up in New York instead. Ed was furious with me so I went out on the balcony for a breather. And who was on the other balcony? Alex.

"What are you doing here?" I asked.

"I'm on honeymoon," he said, evenly.

Talk about coincidences. It could have been straight out of a Noël Coward play. In fact, it was.

Which is why we eloped to Mexico in a helicopter. We fell into each others' lives. The sex was great but Alex never wanted to talk. And he flirted with the scuba trainer. A commitment problem?

I came to miss Ed, the man who was such a doormat that he'd put up with any amount of shit and keep coming back for more. Even to Mexico.

"I'm back," I said, "and I've brought The Love of My Life."

"OHMYGOD," screamed Della and Ven. And in walked Ed.

And if you really are pressed, the digested read, digested: This Life author mixes Bridget Jones and Private Lives without the wit, edge and style of either. And with Bridget Jones, that's quite some achievement.

fields.headline: What will Ken do now?
fields.standfirst: London's newly elected mayor, Ken Livingstone, may have triumphed over the Labour political machine but he will have to work with his former party if he is to achieve anything in office, writes John Carvel
fields.trailText: In his heart Ken Livingstone will feel vindicated this morning, elated that the people of London have given him victory against the machine politicians. But in his head he knows he must now sit down to work with those politicians if he is to achieve anything in the new office of London mayor.
fields.body:
In his heart Ken Livingstone will feel vindicated this morning, elated that the people of London have given him victory against the machine politicians. But in his head he knows he must now sit down to work with those politicians if he is to achieve anything in the new office of London mayor.

Over the next few days he may give conflicting signals, as the balance between heart and head settles down. His strategy is to be inclusive. He will offer jobs to rivals from the main political parties. He feels that Frank Dobson, the defeated Labour candidate, would make an excellent head of the campaign he intends to launch against poverty in London. Steven Norris and Susan Kramer, the Conservative and Liberal Democrat candidates will be offered places on Transport for London.

Although it is highly improbable that they will accept, Livingstone's desire to be inclusive is genuine. He will be a leader without a following on the Greater London Assembly. He will not be able to do anything significant without the co-operation of GLA members, London borough leaders and Labour ministers in Whitehall.

His head will be telling him to moderate his words and deeds to achieve that objective. The clearest demonstration of that will be to seek out a Labour GLA member as his deputy mayor. If Tony Blair tries to block that, the problems of starting this new public office will be blamed on Downing Street.

But Livingstone was not elected for being all head and no heart. He would not be human if he did not feel triumphant after his personal victory. Margaret Thatcher stopped Londoners voting him out of office by abolishing the GLC. Tony Blair tried to stop them voting him in as a Labour mayor.

Will his triumph lead to triumphalism? At his victory party in the Silks and Spices wine bar in the City, he promised his adoring followers that he would never betray them. In television interviews he warned the prime minister that the local election results across England were a wake-up call for the government. There were even gentle digs about the lessons that Gordon Brown, the chancellor, needs to learn.

Can Livingstone manage to woo Labour and take pot shots at them at the same time? He is older and wiser than when he started at the GLC. But this will be a difficult trick to pull off. Both sides may take a while to work out the relationship.

 John Carvel is the author of Turn Again Livingstone

fields.headline: London's thumbs-down to the mayor
fields.standfirst:
Labour's misconceived reform has failed to capture public interest, says John Redwood, Conservative MP for Wokingham
View from the left: Tribune's Mark Seddon
fields.trailText: Labour's misconceived reform has failed to capture public interest, says John Redwood, Conservative MP for Wokingham
fields.body:
The London electorate have made up their minds about the mayoralty. Two-thirds of them have so little interest in the post that they did not bother to vote. Many of those were against the whole idea. Some do not think the new mayor will have enough power to make a real difference. It's a huge slap in the face for Labour, who have been telling us that elected mayors would grab the interest and the votes of the electors.

As Margaret Beckett herself admitted, this election has shown no great popular demand for an elected mayor.

The news got worse for Labour when we saw how the minority who did bother to vote had granted their favours. Many former Labour voters and even Labour party members cocked a snook at their party leadership and voted for rebel Ken. Some Conservatives joined them, finding irresistible the prospect of a struggle between old and new Labour to be played out in the metropolitan media over the next year or so.

The vote for the mayor is a one-off. It tells us next to nothing about how a general election might go. But given Tony Blair's well-publicised antagonism to Ken Livingstone, the result is a nightmare for him, not for the other party leaders.

The votes for the assembly tell us rather more about the political mood of London in the run-up to the general election. It shows a Conservative recovery is well under way, with victory in places like Ealing and Merton. Few commentators or pollsters were predicting that the Conservatives would have a bigger share of the popular vote than Labour, but this is what has happened.

Both the main parties will be hoping that come a general election under first past the post, fewer people will vote for minor parties than did in the assembly contest. The Greens claimed that a vote for them would not be wasted, given the availability of top-up seats for the assembly. They will not have this argument come a general election when more people are going to want to express a clear preference between the two main parties.

The biggest winner by far is Ken Livingstone. He has taken on his party establishment and won. He has managed to live down his dubious political past and a series of extraordinary gaffes during the election. We must conclude that Londoners have a sense of humour and are placing a heavy bet that whilst the mayor will have the power to embarrass the government, he will not have enough power to wreck London.

webTitle: Lib Dems snatch Romsey from Tories

fields.headline: Lib Dems snatch Romsey from Tories
fields.standfirst:
Audio from the count
Read Lucy Ward's report from Romsey
Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats have dramatically won the Romsey byelection, taking what was once a Tory safe seat in the party's Hampshire heartlands with a majority of 3,311.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats have dramatically won the Romsey byelection, taking what was once a Tory safe seat in the party's Hampshire heartlands with a majority of 3,311.

Liberal Democrat Sandra Gidley won 19,571 votes on a 12.56% swing, beating Old Etonian Conservative candidate Tim Palmer into second place and overturning a Tory majority of 8,585 amassed at the 1997 general election by Michael Colvin, whose death in a fire at his home prompted yesterday's poll.

The shock 4am result took the gloss off the Conservative party's gains in the local elections across England, with the Liberal Democrats appearing to benefit from a tactical switch by Labour voters. The Labour candidate, Andrew Howard, trailed home in third place with just 1,451 votes, losing his deposit.

"This is an absolutely sensational result for the Liberal Democrats," said Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy. "William Hague's leadership and his election strategy have been shattered. This is a fantastic launch pad for the general election."

In her victory address, Ms Gidley told Mr Kennedy: "This has been your success as well as mine." The result vindicates the Lib Dems' local campaigning effort, in which they swamped the constituency with activists and MPs from Westminster. It is also a welcome boost to Mr Kennedy's leadership, under whom the Liberal Democrats made modest gains in yesterday's local elections.

The byelection result ranks with some of the greatest upsets of recent times, including the Lib Dems' capture of Ribble Valley on a 24.7% swing from the Tories and Newbury with a 28.4% swing from the Tories in 1993. This was followed by the Christchurch contest which brought the biggest recorded swing against a government - 35.4% from Conservative to Liberal Democrats.

fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone today became London's first elected mayor, winning 776,427 votes against the Conservative Steven Norris's 564,137 after second preference votes were counted.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone today became London's first elected mayor, winning 776,427 votes against the Conservative Steven Norris's 564,137 after second preference votes were counted.

On a turnout of 33.6%, the Labour candidate Frank Dobson finished third, only slightly ahead of Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat.

Mr Livingstone began his victory speech by saying: "As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted 14 years ago... I want an all-embracing administration that will speak with one voice on behalf of London.

"I hope after reflection my fellow candidates will want to help me in that work and hope they will join me in that administration.

"I believe in regional government. The government that is best is the government that is best for the people.

"I pledge to heal the division between myself and the Labour party and I hope the Blair government is elected for a second term."

The new mayor paid tribute to Mr Dobson, saying: "He has borne a terrible brunt of odium that should have been reserved for people behind the scenes."

Earlier, Tony Blair said that he would work with the new mayor, though he cautioned that Mr Livingstone must use his power responsibly and made it plain that there was no love lost between them.

"It is important that we do everything we can to see that this works for London and Londoners. Ken also has a responsibility to make this work. I have not changed my views on Ken, but that has to be in the past. Ken also has a responsibility to make this work. The mayor has real power. We've got to make sure we play our part as the government in making this work."

Mr Dobson, who gave no response to Mr Livingstone's invitation to join his London administration, said after the result: "As a democrat, I respect the votes of the people of London. Personally, I'm deeply disappointed not to become mayor. It's a job I would have loved to have done.

"It was not always easy. I believe our message was right, but we found it difficult to get that message across.

"I hope not too many people will feel that I have let them down.

"I have enjoyed the campaigning and I don't regret the decision to stand. I said what I thought, not what I thought people wanted to hear. I continue to believe that in a democracy we have to tell the people the truth whether it turns out to be popular or not."

After a count of second preference votes, Mr Livingstone won the endorsement of 12 of London's 14 constituencies, with the Tories victorious only in West Central and Bexley and Bromley.

Results

Bexley and Bromley: Norris win.

London South West: Livingstone win.

Brent and Harrow: Livingstone win.

Croydon and Sutton: Livingstone win.

Greenwich and Lewisham: Livingstone win.

Ealing and Hillingdon: Livingstone win.

London North East: Livingstone win.

Havering and Redbridge: Livingstone win.

Enfield and Haringey: Livingstone win.

Barnet and Camden: Livingstone win.

Merton and Wandsworth: Livingstone win.

Lambeth and Southwark: Livingstone win.

West Central: Norris win.

City and East: Livingstone win.

The final result was announced at 12.20pm after many delays caused by malfunctioning computers.

The hi-tech optical-reading counting machine introduced for the first time at this election crashed a few hours after polls closed in Enfield.

"We have tested these machines to destruction," returning officer Robert Hughes said. "It is only an embarrassment if we fail to solve it but we can. The only way that there would fail to be a result today would be if we had a total computer failure and had to do the count by hand. If that happened we would be looking at a result in a week's time."

"People have four possible votes and without this computer system not only would it take five days to count, it would take more staff."

webTitle: Rennard's foxing of the Romsey Tories

fields.headline: Rennard's foxing of the Romsey Tories
fields.standfirst:
Liberals are smiling after a sensational win in a true-blue heartland, writes Lucy Ward, political correspondent
Audio report from the count
fields.trailText: Liberals are smiling after a sensational win in a true-blue heartland, writes Lucy Ward, political correspondent
fields.body:
It is the morning after the long night before in the Hampshire town of Romsey, and the statue of Palmerston dominating the market square appears to have a most unstatesmanlike grin on his face. The great Liberal prime minister might well celebrate: his party's successor has just pulled off a sensational byelection coup in what all but a handful of Liberal Democrat strategists believed was an unassailable true blue heartland.

The day after the Conservatives picked up hundreds of seats in local elections around the country, the Romsey parliamentary seat made vacant by the death of old school Tory Michael Colvin has bucked the trend by returning Lib Dem Sandra Gidley with a resounding 3,311 majority.

Confirmation of the 12.6 per cent swing from the Tories to the Lib Dems came shortly after 4am today following an exceptionally sluggish count. Initial cautious Conservative optimism turned to gloom over the evening, with the mobile phone of one Tory aide ringing dolefully to the Mission Impossible theme tune.

Meanwhile Lib Dem campaigns supremo Lord Rennard, credited by his party with spotting the seat's winnability and far outpacing a somewhat complacent Conservative campaign, saw his dream confirmed as the night wore on. The party has emphasised Mrs Gidley's local credentials as a Romsey pharmacist and former town mayor, and fought on "big issues" including health, education, pensions and rural post office closures to tap in to voters' concerns.

It appears many Tories, unimpressed with the tweed-jacketed Old Etonian Tim Palmer who lives and farms outside the constituency in Dorset, stayed at home, while significant numbers of Labour supporters voted tactically, leaving Labour's Andrew Howard to lose his deposit.

Party leader Charles Kennedy, in Romsey this morning to bask in the sunshine and the matching warmth of a Lib Dem parliamentary gain, claimed the result underlined the failure of his Tory counterpart's recent hardline statements on asylum and law and order.

While William Hague might be able to secure victories in low turn-out elections including local and European polls by appealing to the concerns of a rightwing core vote, he met defeat where the turnout was relatively high, as in Romsey, Mr Kennedy said today. He told a press conference: "This is a triumph for the politics of hope over the politics of fear and the politics of wanting to unite communities rather than the politics of wanting to divide the country and communities within the country."

The "resonance" of Romsey allowed the party to go into the next general election confident of more votes and more seats, said Mr Kennedy, whose own new and occasionally faltering leadership is strongly shored up by the result.

The Lib Dems' Lord Rennard, meanwhile, smiling happily beneath the Palmerston statue this morning, has only one concern. Bookmakers, awed by his uncanny talent as the Lib Dem "mystic Meg" of byelection results, will no longer accept any political bets he tries to place.

webTitle: And now for the rest of the country

fields.headline: And now for the rest of the country
fields.standfirst: Directly elected mayors are set to become a feature throughout Britain, writes Martin Wainwright
fields.trailText: The London mayoral race has been played almost entirely for entertainment in the English regions, to the extent that a dead newt found in a swimming pool belonging to a Leeds worthy was taken as an omen of disaster for Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
The London mayoral race has been played almost entirely for entertainment in the English regions, to the extent that a dead newt found in a swimming pool belonging to a Leeds worthy was taken as an omen of disaster for Ken Livingstone.

Like most such superstitions, it proved wildly wrong. And so will predictions that the farcical tone of the capital's battle is bound to kill the idea of mayors elsewhere in the country. Far from it. Prepare for another great jamboree of voting in November.

Mayor enthusiasts have had a saucer, rather than a dishful, of cold water poured on their heads by the events of last night. Here are the debits: the dismal turnout has quashed bright-eyed hopes that the electorate would be more inclined to turn out for a single, powerful figure than for largely anonymous members of local councils. And it is disappointing that the sophistication and extra choice provided by the preferential voting system pioneered in London failed to appeal, and that the various excellent ideas for making polling easier had only modest effects.

The proof of Livingstone's pudding remains an unknown quantity, though probably not for very long. Substance will take time, but the great showman is likely to press ahead rapidly with catchy ideas on public transport, possible car bans in the centre of London and a summery programme of metropolitan fun.

The important credits are these: the structure for elected mayors is increasingly in place in town halls, as more and more councils trade in the old committee system for a local cabinet monitored by backbenchers. Although clad in parliamentary language, the apparatus is more akin to the Greater London assembly elected last night, and it comes with a mayor-shaped hole just waiting to be filled.

That is what the government wanted. And the fact that Tony Blair is a keen mayorista (in spite of the Livingstone debacle) is the second and much more powerful force. Reluctant councillors are being whispered to fiercely: like it or lump it, No 10 wants it. Best to find some solid and knowledgeable citizen before bandwagons roll for a local and possibly apolitical superstar.

The actual trigger is even more potent; it needs only a petition signed by 5% of any council's electorate to trigger the required local referendum on whether to have a mayor. Several authorities will reach this point in the next few months: watch out for several London boroughs including Lewisham, and a range of big authorities in the Midlands.

The northern cities, which showed most interest in the mayoral system early on, are also in the picture, though their councils are notably unenthusiastic about the probable surrender of power which having a mayor will entail. Although Leeds remains officially chilly about the idea, the council's new randomly-chosen Citizens' Advisory Panel has taken a fancy to having a mayor and supporters within groups such as the Chamber of Commerce and the two universities are gaining ground.

Don't, however, get too excited about the chances of Sir Alex Ferguson and his ilk donning ermine. The wizard of Manchester United doesn't live in the city and Old Trafford isn't in Manchester either (without getting into the tedium of north western civic boundaries, it's well inside the neighbouring authority, Trafford). We rough non-metropolitans are more likely to stick with our local versions of poor, outsmarted Dobbo, visiting Ken's capital for our occasional moments of glitzy fun.

fields.headline: Even Tory voters like 'Red Ken'
fields.standfirst:
Londoners make their mark in first mayoral election

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: May 4 2000: On this day Ken Livingstone was elected mayor of London. This is how the Guardian reported the news.
fields.body:
Although Ken Livingstone's opinion poll rating inevitably slumped from the 68% high recorded by ICM on March 6, the day he left the Labour party to run as an independent mayoral candidate, the surveys repeatedly showed that he attracted an unprecedented level of support from all parts of the political spectrum.

As a BBC/ICM poll published last night again confirmed, those who backed Livingstone were not doing so primarily because they "wanted to give Tony Blair a kick", or because they thought he had been treated unfairly by Labour, but because they said they saw him as the "best champion for London".

Despite the repeated disclosures about his personal finances that undermined his "bloke in the pub" image, the political rows over his claims that capitalism kills more people each year than Hitler, and his apparent support for the City of London rioters last June, the polls continued to show that Labour, Liberal Democrat and Conservative voters were not going to peel away in large enough numbers to send Livingstone into a dive in the ratings in the final days of the campaign.

Indeed, his level of support never dipped below the bedrock 49% of first preference votes he recorded in last November's Guardian/ICM poll. Even then, it was clear that Frank Dobson, as the official Labour candidate, was in danger of being pushed into a humiliating third place and left out of any second-round run-off if Livingstone failed to secure outright victory on the first count.

But perhaps it is the breadth of cross-party support that is most remarkable about Livingstone's campaign and which may contain the clearest guide to his future conduct as mayor of London. For, completely contrary to the class warrior image that the hard left likes to portray, Livingstone has actually managed to straddle the class divide in London more effectively than Dobson or Norris ever achieved.

As the last Evening Standard/ICM poll published on April 27 showed, Livingstone had the support of London's middle classes with 57% of ABC1 voters - the professional and managerial classes - and took the lion's share, 44%, of support of the C2DEs - the manual workers and those living on state benefits.

Intriguingly, this presents him with the very New Labour dilemma, if he wants to be re-elected in four years, of how to retain his radicalism without turning London's middle classes, many of them Tory voters, against him.

The key may lie in the finding of the ICM poll for last night's BBC election programme, Vote 2000, that 89% of those who voted for Livingstone thought he would be best at standing up for London. Interestingly this poll also found that only 45% of those voting believed that the mayor should decide how improvements to the tube should be funded - the prime issue in the campaign - and 32% were happy to see the government determine the issue.

The same survey show that the voters are split over Livingstone's ambition to be allowed back into the Labour party: 38% want to see him readmitted while 34% believe he should be kept out. Similarly, a significant minority - 32% - believe Tony Blair had every right to campaign against Livingstone but 53% disagree with this view.

As for Dobson, his opinion poll ratings barely moved throughout the campaign. Despite his mid-campaign rebranding as "Frank" he found himself in a dogfight with Norris for the privilege of occupying a very poor second place. The ratings have wandered between 22% and 14%.

It seems that the real lesson from the polls might be that the public in London made up their minds when the battle for the Labour nomination took place, long before the official launch of the campaign in March.

fields.headline: Fear of the five planets
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about potential cosmic catastrophes on the net
fields.trailText: 1. Did you look into the sky at 9 o'clock this morning? If you did, you may have seen something peculiar.
fields.body:
1. Did you look into the sky at 9 o'clock this morning? If you did, you may have seen something peculiar.

2. A rare planetary alignment was taking place. The earth and moon were on one side of the sun and five planets - Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn - were strung out on the other.

3. In hindsight, we can be reasonably sure the human race has avoided a cosmic catastrophe.

4. The main fear was that seven celestial bodies lined up on one side of the earth would exert a tremendous gravitational pull.

5. Doomsayers had long predicted that the world would be torn apart today by tidal waves and earthquakes.

6. Fear of the five planets dated back to at least 300BC, and despite all we have learned about the mechanics of the solar system since then, the ancient superstition remained.

7. But some astronomists have issued similar warnings before and been mistaken. In 1982 it was predicted that Los Angeles would be destroyed by the Jupiter effect.

8. This time around astrologer Jonathan Cainer promised that the five planets conjunction "had the power to unleash energies, options and possibilities which people have long dreamed of yet never been able to reach."

9. Many scientists believed nothing would happen as a result of this particular planetary alignment. Even Venus (our nearest planet) exerts a gravitational force just one 500,000th of that of the Moon. Mars has about as much pull as a football.

10. With any luck, though, the rare conjunction (the like of which the world has not seen since 1962) will have a positive effect on the weather.

fields.headline: ISP clue to 'love bug' creator
fields.trailText: The prime suspect behind the "love bug" virus that wreaked havoc on computer systems worldwide is a 23-year-old from a middle class suburb in Manila in the Philippines, according to a Manila internet company.
fields.body:
The prime suspect behind the "love bug" virus that wreaked havoc on computer systems worldwide is a 23-year-old from a middle class suburb in Manila in the Philippines, according to a Manila internet company.

The Manila internet service provider (ISP) said the virus appeared to have first spread from two of its email addresses, prompting the Federal Bureau of Investigation to approach the National Bureau of Investigation, its counterpart in the Philippines, to investigate.

"What happened is the author of the virus used two email addresses through Supernet - spyder@super.net.ph and mailme@super.net.ph," Jose Carlotta, chief operating officer of Access Net Inc, a Manila internet company said. Access Net is the owner of Supernet, a prepaid ISP.

"We suspect the guy who is the owner of the account is 23 years old, from Pandacan and a male," he added. Pandacan is a middle-class suburb in Manila. Mr Carlotta said the clues to the identity of the hacker had been gleaned from information supposedly provided in online chat rooms, but there was no way of knowing if it was true. The two email addresses had been linked to prepaid access accounts so it was not immediately possible to zero in on the owner, he added.

"He's been very crafty," Mr Carlotta said of the hacker. "He's been very able to move around the network, the various ISPs, and he's been very hard to locate. "He's been using a lot of hacked accounts, so what happened is... he illegally gets the user name and passwords and he uses those accounts for his own purposes."

He said it was possible, albeit unlikely, that the hacker was in another city or country. Toby Ayre, a technical consultant for SKYInternet, another local ISP, said it appeared the same hacker had tried to break into their systems and that they had blacklisted the local Manila telephone number he was using.

"We have provided the NBI, the FBI, and Interpol with all of the audit trails for every transaction that involves this virus and they're using that information," he said.

The "love bug" is being called the fastest-moving and most widespread computer virus ever seen, affecting computer systems worldwide. It infected tens of millions of computers, not only spreading by email like last year's Melissa virus, but through instant messaging systems that let people chat in real time on the net. In the latest case, the original virus appears in emails as "ILOVEYOU", enticing users to open the message, only to paralyse their e-mail systems. One of its variants uses the phrase "fw: joke" in the subject line.

Another has a subject line that reads "Susitikim shi vakara kavas puodukui...", which is Lithuanian for "Let's meet this evening for coffee...". Lithuanian officials said on Friday they would investigate possible local origins of the virus. Although the bug apparently did originate in Manila, computer networks in the Philippines were not much affected.

Other notable viruses

 Melissa. Described as a typical macro virus with an unusual "payload", Melissa, when opened, attempted to e-mail itself to up to 50 other people. Melissa infected about a million computers and caused £50m of damage. David Smith, a 31-year-old computer programmer from Newark, New Jersey, was responsible for Melissa.

 Back Orifice 2000. A cunning programme written by a group called The Cult of the Dead Cow. It allows people to take remote control of Windows machines and was released summer in Las Vegas at Def Con, the seventh annual convention for virus writers and hackers from around the world. Mainly aimed at system administrators.

 W32/Mypics. Similar to Melissa. It arrived via email with the message: "Here's some pictures for you!" and contains the file pics4you.exe, which, once opened, will point a user's home page in the internet explorer browser to an adult pornography site.

 W95, alias Chernobyl and CIH.Spacefiller. Chernobyl is a very destructive virus that destroys data. It infects 32-bit Windows 95/98/NT files but is only capable of functioning under Windows 95/98. When an infected program on a Windows 95/98 machine is run, it becomes resident in the computer's memory. An infected system, therefore, must be rebooted from a clean system disk before scanning with an anti-virus product.

 XM.Laroux, alias ExcelMacro/Laroux, Excel.Laroux, and Laroux. This virus is the first working Excel macro virus found in general circulation. The macros are stored in a hidden datasheet named "laroux." When an infected spreadsheet is opened, the Check_Files macro copies the worksheet with the virus code into a spreadsheet file stored in the Excel startup directory. This enables the infection of all other spreadsheets opened or created on the infected system in the future.

fields.bodyText: The prime suspect behind the "love bug" virus that wreaked havoc on computer systems worldwide is a 23-year-old from a middle class suburb in Manila in the Philippines, according to a Manila internet company. The Manila internet service provider (ISP) said the virus appeared to have first spread from two of its email addresses, prompting the Federal Bureau of Investigation to approach the National Bureau of Investigation, its counterpart in the Philippines, to investigate. "What happened is the author of the virus used two email addresses through Supernet - spyder@super.net.ph and mailme@super.net.ph," Jose Carlotta, chief operating officer of Access Net Inc, a Manila internet company said. Access Net is the owner of Supernet, a prepaid ISP. "We suspect the guy who is the owner of the account is 23 years old, from Pandacan and a male," he added. Pandacan is a middle-class suburb in Manila. Mr Carlotta said the clues to the identity of the hacker had been gleaned from information supposedly provided in online chat rooms, but there was no way of knowing if it was true. The two email addresses had been linked to prepaid access accounts so it was not immediately possible to zero in on the owner, he added. "He's been very crafty," Mr Carlotta said of the hacker. "He's been very able to move around the network, the various ISPs, and he's been very hard to locate. "He's been using a lot of hacked accounts, so what happened is... he illegally gets the user name and passwords and he uses those accounts for his own purposes." He said it was possible, albeit unlikely, that the hacker was in another city or country. Toby Ayre, a technical consultant for SKYInternet, another local ISP, said it appeared the same hacker had tried to break into their systems and that they had blacklisted the local Manila telephone number he was using. "We have provided the NBI, the FBI, and Interpol with all of the audit trails for every transaction that involves this virus and they're using that information," he said. The "love bug" is being called the fastest-moving and most widespread computer virus ever seen, affecting computer systems worldwide. It infected tens of millions of computers, not only spreading by email like last year's Melissa virus, but through instant messaging systems that let people chat in real time on the net. In the latest case, the original virus appears in emails as "ILOVEYOU", enticing users to open the message, only to paralyse their e-mail systems. One of its variants uses the phrase "fw: joke" in the subject line. Another has a subject line that reads "Susitikim shi vakara kavas puodukui...", which is Lithuanian for "Let's meet this evening for coffee...". Lithuanian officials said on Friday they would investigate possible local origins of the virus. Although the bug apparently did originate in Manila, computer networks in the Philippines were not much affected. Other notable viruses  Melissa. Described as a typical macro virus with an unusual "payload", Melissa, when opened, attempted to e-mail itself to up to 50 other people.
