webTitle: Is the search for Anakin finally over?

fields.headline: Is the search for Anakin finally over?
fields.trailText: The internet is awash with rumours that George Lucas has finally cast his Anakin for Star Wars Episode II
fields.body:
The internet is awash with rumours that George Lucas has finally cast his Anakin for Star Wars Episode II. Word has it that the actor who won the day in screen tests conducted last weekend is a blond unknown with little experience - exactly the type of actor that Lucas has apparently said he was looking for all along.

According to Variety columnist Michael Fleming, 19-year-old fledgling actor Hayden Christensen will play the adolescent who goes on to father Luke Skywalker in the next Star Wars film.

The actor who portrays the teenage Anakin - whose personal journey takes him from wide-eyed Jedi trainee to scarred evildoer - will join the current cast of Natalie Portman, Ewan McGregor, and Samuel L. Jackson, all veterans from Episode I.

According to Harry Knowles of Ain't it cool news, the casting of Christen is confirmed, as is Ryan Phillippe as Bail Organa.

Similarly, Star Wars fan site www.theforce.net reports that Christensen signed the Anakin contract yesterday, and will be appearing in both Episode Two and Episode Three.

 Check the Star Wars official site for the final word.

webTitle: Works by Louise Bourgeois at Tate Modern

fields.headline: Works by Louise Bourgeois at Tate Modern
fields.trailText: They are not the kind of things normal 89-year-olds while away their twilight years on, but then the artist Louise Bourgeois is not your average octogenarian.
fields.body:
They are not the kind of things normal 89-year-olds while away their twilight years on, but then the artist Louise Bourgeois is not your average octogenarian.

Three 30ft steel towers, each topped with a swivel mirror, and a 20ft spider, entitled Maman - all built by the sparrow-like artist - were unveiled yesterday in the cavernous turbine hall of the new Tate Modern gallery in south London.

French-born Bourgeois, considered by many to be the world's greatest living woman artist, could not be there to see the awe that her creations inspired. Hugely eccentric, she rarely leaves her New York home, where she breakfasts on jam after her live-in assistant irons her copy of the New York Times.

The four sculptures to celebrate the £134m Tate Modern, which will be formally opened by the Queen next week, are called the Unilever Series, after their multinational sponsor.

They are the largest works that Bourgeois has produced.

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.trailText: The Times: 'Other cities should not make the same mistakes as London'
fields.body:
The Times: 'Other cities should not make the same mistakes as London'

This is not, it can be safely assumed, the result that Tony Blair had in mind when he bravely introduced this experiment... If Mr Livingstone is as reckless when in office as he can be when interviewed, then the Government might feel obliged to claw back what authority has been conceded to him.... It remains to be seen whether Londoners will live to enjoy or endure their collective decision. It is to be hoped that other cities will take up the challenge, but, perhaps, in a less entertaining fashion than the capital.'

The Sun: 'Oh no, they've elected Kenny!'

'Stand by for Nightmare on Livingstone Street... This is the biggest protest vote so far against New Labour. The maverick in exile has given Labour's exalted party machine a bloody nose. The Prime Minister should stop and think about his party's arrogance in tampering with the constitution then trying to fix the vote in their favour. Livingstone is the first of a dozen or so elected mayors. Many of them will be from the Livingstone mould - fully paid-up members of the awkward squad. Is this good for democracy, as the PM has always told us, or will it have a destabilising effect? We won't know for several years. And by then it could be too late.'

Daily Telegraph: 'Did Tony vote Tory?'

'Only Steve Norris, we were repeatedly told, could stop Ken Livingstone in the London Mayoral election. And, curiously enough, Tony Blair refused to say yesterday whom he cast his second preference vote for in the poll. Did he become the first serving Labour Prime Minister to vote Tory?'

David Aaaronovitch in The Independent:'We need the new politics'

'Ken has a mandate, mostly, to walk around being Kenlike. That is, to try and really be what most people already believe he is - open, attractive, candid and clear. Londoners like his tolerance and what they perceive as his inclusiveness. His willingness to talk to all and any party about posts and roles in his mayoral government has smacked of the new politics that we were once promised. Many London people that I know felt that it was liberating to be able to split their ballots yesterday, and vote for up to four different parties, including the Kennists.'

The New York Times (requires registration: 'Londoners pick a maverick populist'

'With a cheeky sense of humour and a tart tongue and nasal Londoner twang to convey it, Mr Livingstone built up a popular fondness that allowed him to survive several campaign gaffes... Though the job has the greatest popular mandate of any elected position in Britain, and offers Mr Livingstone the public visibility that he thrives on, the powers of the office itself over London's 7.2 million residents are limited.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Spielberg and Dreamworks face lawsuit over Small Soldiers, Miramax co-chairs sign up for seven more years, Directors Guild welcome internet movies, and Cate Blanchett on the casting couch
fields.body:
 A filmmaker who claims that Steven Spielberg stole the plot of his award-winning short film to make 1998's Small Soldiers is suing the director, his DreamWorks SKG studio and Universal Pictures for copyright infringement. Gregory Grant, who says Spielberg and his Amblin Entertainment production company considered turning his short film Ode to G.I. Joe, into a feature before turning it down and making Small Soldiers instead, is seeking unspecified damages. DreamWorks refused to comment.

 Harvey and Bob Weinstein have extended their agreement to co-chair Miramax Films for Disney for seven more years. "Harvey and Bob are creative geniuses," Disney chairman and CEO Michael Eisner said. "Their love of film is matched by
their deep understanding of the filmmaking process. The result has been an amazing variety of original and high-quality content for our studios." Among Miramax's many successes are Shakespeare in Love, Good Will Hunting, and Cider House Rules.

 The Directors Guild of America is seeking to encourage its members to become involved in the production of movies made for the internet. Last month the DGA approved new guidelines for directors making films for the internet and the DGA's Warren Adler, expressing enthusiasm for the new technology, said, "Like films with sound, internet features could have a vast future. And Hollywood doesn't want to stop the flow of progress; it just wants to make sure it's going along for the ride." See our report on the world's first internet movie

 If you're among the many X-Men watchers, you can check out Entertainment Weekly's photo gallery of the cast versus their comic counterparts here

Casting couch

 Cate Blanchett is in talks to star in a new film by Run Lola Run director Tom Tykwer. The film, called Heaven, could be the first in a trilogy by the late Krzysztof Kieslowski.

 Gary Oldman's involvement in Hannibal has been officially confirmed.

webTitle: England captains just not up to it

fields.headline: England captains just not up to it
fields.standfirst: Every weekend we publish a column by a wisden.com reader. Email your opinions, musings and rants to beamer@guardian.co.uk. Don't forget to include a daytime telephone number
fields.trailText: So, Dav Whatmore is setting Sri Lanka alight once more and Bob Woolmer is back at Edgbaston. For Team England, on the other hand, Grey Graveney is reappointed to compete with Zimbabwe for the wooden spoon of world cricket.
fields.body:
So, Dav Whatmore is setting Sri Lanka alight once more and Bob Woolmer is back at Edgbaston. For Team England, on the other hand, Grey Graveney is reappointed to compete with Zimbabwe for the wooden spoon of world cricket.

Why do the ECB hierarchy continue on this road of perversity and persist with an elite group of professional losers? Can the answer be that if they had the courage to dispense with men such as Mike Atherton, Alec Stewart, Nasser Hussain and co, they themselves would also fall upon the sword?

When Lord MacLaurin was in charge of Tesco, he would have had no time for sentiment when it came to putting an ailing branch or department to rights: doubtless he would have applied the hatchet to everybody associated with defeat and its consequent bad morale. But now he is the top man at the ECB, why is he being so lenient with our cricketers?

Atherton was appointed with barely any qualification and greedily hung on to the job for a record number of Tests when anyone with half an ounce of management and motivational know-how could see his ineptness. "Nice century Michael, have the captaincy" seemed to be the only science applied in selecting a leader who took England from bad to worse.

Years earlier, Ossie Wheatley fired Mike Gatting from the captaincy - an action from which the national side has never recovered. A succession of ill-qualified figureheads followed: the biggest joke was undoubtedly when Alec Stewart was given another go at being captain - despite having been our first leader to lose a Test in Sri Lanka. Could we really have been that desperate to make the second appointment? In doing so the ECB paved the way for a plethora of insults from the selectors in the direction of Mark Ramprakash, Matthew Maynard and others.

Now we have Nasser Hussain, another founder member of the Professional Losers Association. He kept the disgraceful momentum going with defeat against New Zealand. Then, in South Africa, he shrewdly inserted the opposition and restricted them to only 450! We soon saw the real benefit of such astute tactical thinking: he wanted to play to the strengths of our batsmen, i.e. the knack of trying to save a match under pressure, as taught by Atherton on the previous tour of South Africa!

The law of averages suggests that every leader, however useless, will have some moments of success simply through being there - even Atherton did - but what incentive is there for some of the now not-so-young prodigies to stay in the game when their paths are blocked by this elite of mediocrity?

fields.headline: The saviour of county cricket?
fields.trailText: To the casual observer it might have seemed peculiar that nearly 6,000 spectators sat patiently at The Oval a couple of weeks ago awaiting the 5pm start of a supremely artificial 10-over thrash. The reason Hampshire's encounter with Surrey was enough to keep bums on wet seats was the presence of one name in the visiting team's line-up: a man who eventually took 2-6 in his allotted two-over spell, and won the match. The man was Shane Warne.
fields.body:
To the casual observer it might have seemed peculiar that nearly 6,000 spectators sat patiently at The Oval a couple of weeks ago awaiting the 5pm start of a supremely artificial 10-over thrash. The reason Hampshire's encounter with Surrey was enough to keep bums on wet seats was the presence of one name in the visiting team's line-up: a man who eventually took 2-6 in his allotted two-over spell, and won the match. The man was Shane Warne.

Hampshire's games are becoming little more than Warne Roadshows. The car park at Southampton's ground was closed a full 90 minutes ahead of the start of his home debut, last Monday's Norwich Union second division match with Warwickshire, as a near-capacity crowd of around 3,000 gathered to see the fruits of Hampshire's chequebook. Replica Warne shirts soon sold out, and never can pre-match warm-ups have been so closely scrutinised. At a time when solemn discussions between men in suits dominate the cricket agenda, Warne's arrival puts the spotlight back on to the county game. His presence makes looking at the county scores fashionable again: how many wickets did Warne get?

The Benson and Hedges Cup may have been relit this season, but the qualifying round became a bit of a drag, as the majority of fixtures were curtailed by inclement weather. But Hampshire survived and on Tuesday they travel to Cardiff to meet Glamorgan for a place in the semi-finals. This comes shortly after the current four-day game against Somerset at the County Ground and Sunday's National League match against Middlesex at Lord's.

According to Warne, it this exhausting nature of the English fixture list that is to blame for the national team's recurring failure. In Australia, state squads prepare for matches weeks ahead with fitness routines, net sessions, recovery programmes, mental sessions with psychiatrists and in-depth notes on every member of the opposition.

The worry is that Warne will find the thought of countless stints of turning his arm over at the Northlands Road End to be too small-fry given his Test haul of 366 Test wickets. Despite facing county opposition on two Ashes tours, Warne has never experienced a full county season.

In the quest for silverware, this shouldn't be a problem. Hampshire's last trophy came eight years ago but now, in Warne and Alan Mullally, they are the only county side to boast two of the world's top ten one-day bowlers (as rated by PriceWaterhouseCoopers). With their blend of youth and experience, the feeling on the south coast is that further honours may not be far away.

Clearly Warne's appearances will be restricted, but he is an influential figure whether or not he is in the thick of things. The Times noted that, during Monday's game, Warne shouted "C'mon Hampshire, we're on top," even though Warwickshire were going well at 98 for two off 23 overs. Soon after it was 98 for four: both batsmen dismissed, probably distracted by Warne's encouragement.

Warne was recently elected as one of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century, an elite list upon which he admitted he never expected to see his name. Such modesty at last challenged the ingrained image of Warne that many British fans had: that of an arrogant, brash, over-opinionated lout. Speaking on BBC TV's On Side programme, Warne attempted to explain his perceived shortcomings, particularly his decidedly mixed relationship with the media.

"No one teaches you how to be a role model; how to conduct yourself all the time. I was only 21 when I started out and I liked a beer and a good time as much as anyone else did at that age. Sometimes I crossed the line and went over the top," he said. Warne seems to be a more balanced, mature man than when he first hit these shores. "The other thing that has changed my outlook," he said in an interview reprinted in the current Wisden Cricket Monthly "is turning 30, having a family [and] two kids." He's grown up at last: good news for an English game which is short on role models at the moment. Ironic as it sounds, borrowing Warne for a few months will be a great boost for English cricket.

Tim Dykes is a Journalism, Film and Broadcasting student at Cardiff University. His home town is Southampton.

webTitle: 'Now we're all casuals, hired and fired at will'

fields.headline: 'Now we're all casuals, hired and fired at will'
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm talks to Ken Loach, the sole British contender for the Palme d'Or
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm talks to Ken Loach, the sole British contender for the Palme d'Or
fields.body:
The sight and sound of dinner-jacketed members of the Cannes bourgeoisie rising to their feet and applauding Ken Loach after the evening performance of one of his films is always one of the slightly incongruous high spots of the festival. The ovation in 1995 for Land and Freedom, his Spanish civil war epic, lasted nearly 10 minutes.

This time round he has Bread and Roses in competition - the sole British entry and the first film he has made anywhere near LA, which he calls "the most horrible city in the world". And it is to be hoped that what happened to him after the stunning reception of Land and Freedom doesn't occur again. He was called back to Cannes on the final day of the festival with the promise of a prize from the international jury. He was actually seated on the plane with his producer when a further call told him not to bother.

Ever since then, Loach has viewed the festival with a somewhat sceptical eye. He hates the fuss anyway and doesn't look forward to the endless interviews he is always subjected to there, often by people who haven't seen the film. But he may well be luckier with Bread and Roses, particularly if Luc Besson's jury, on which there are several strong Loach supporters, rises to the occasion. The film, by all accounts, is likely to.

The title is taken from an old slogan used during a strike of immigrant workers: "We want bread [decent wages] and roses too [respect]." The film, made in LA but definitely not in Hollywood, is about the Mexican and Salvadorean janitors who sluice out office buildings there.

"We thought it was a pretty interesting subject," says Loach, "because the picture you get of LA from the film industry is about wealth and conspicuous consumption - the American Dream come true. But there is this parallel world of people from Central America who come in illegally, who do the worst jobs and, because they are without papers, are very easy to exploit.

"Our story is pretty simple. It's about a girl who crosses the border illegally and joins her sister as a janitor. It's about what happens to them, their relationship as sisters and their work. We found casting difficult at first because there are a lot of Hispanic actresses in LA, but the fact of being so near to Hollywood means they inevitably start to fit the mould that the industry expects. The corners seemed to be knocked off them. Obviously where you live affects who you become. So we went to Mexico and found a nice girl [Pilar Padilla] there."

Loach admits that in other respects, too, he was in a tricky situation. The film is about unions as well as the girls' lives, and he is a staunch supporter. But in LA, unlike Britain, where there are only two unions to deal with when making a film, there are four or five. Everybody eventually did a deal with this impecunious British film-maker despite the fact that his total budget was pretty hilarious to them at around $5m.

The most difficult, however, were the drivers. There is only one for most Loach films. Everything and everyone else goes in the minibus. Here they insisted on 10 drivers for eight vehicles, and the drivers had to have separate lavatories. "There we were, filming in LA where every building has a toilet and we had to have portable lavatories so that the drivers could go for a pee next to the minibus cars rather than across the road.

Each corporation tries to build the tallest tower. It's horrible, and so are the lives of those who service them. It's not exactly a romantic film, but I hope it brings these people to life, and I hope it's entertaining too."

But once you've got that right, it's simple. You treat everybody the same.

"The trick is to appear both arbitrary and casual. To make people think the story is just unfolding totally naturally and by the end show them something that makes a kind of sense about the people you're talking about. Everybody making the film has to share that feeling, and the moment you or the audience sees a nice bit of camerawork or direction, you know you've failed."

As far as Bread and Roses is concerned, he hopes it explores something you seldom see on film - what happened to work. "We used to have jobs that lasted for life. Now we don't. We're all casuals, hired and fired at will. It's made a big difference to our psyches, and that difference is never discussed. It ought to be."

webTitle: Two men released from bail in Lawrence murder case

fields.headline: Two men released from bail in Lawrence murder case
fields.trailText: Police hunting the killers of teenager Stephen Lawrence today said they had released from bail two men arrested in connection with the racist murder.
fields.body:
Police hunting the killers of teenager Stephen Lawrence today said they had released from bail two men arrested in connection with the racist murder.

The pair, who were not charged with any offence, had been due to answer to police bail today.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "We have released them from the terms of their bail. But we reserve the right, as is routine with any suspect, to re-interview them in the future should the need arise."

The men, who were held on March 21, would have been informed of the decision through the normal channels, either by letter or through their solicitors, she said.

The men - one was arrested in Scotland and the other in London - were questioned by detectives in March and bailed to return to a south London police station.

A third man arrested in London on March 22 is still on bail to return to police on May 9.

The three men are not believed to have been among the five original suspects in the case.

Stephen Lawrence, an 18-year-old A-level student, was stabbed in an unprovoked attack by a gang of white youths at a bus stop in Eltham, south east London, in April, 1993.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.body:
Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Cantina Italia , 19 Canonbury Lane, London N1. Tel: 020-7226 9791.

Surprising numbers of people ignore the glitzier restaurants along Upper Street to find their way here (Denise Van Outen is a fan, but you're more likely to be noshing alongside less high-profile Islingtonites). Visitors are rewarded with smiles from friendly, unhurried staff. But if you're coming for a quick bite, you'll have to resist the temptation of a leisurely meal. Those who don't settle in for an hour or two aren't penalised, though, as the takeaway menu offers the same, unmistakably Italian, dishes. Chef Francesco Scala's pasta and risotti are expertly done, and those with larger appetites would be advised to choose one of the stomach-challenging pizzas. A cheap eat, too.

Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Pasha , 301 Upper Street, London N1. Tel: 020-7226 1454.

Elegant Turkish restaurant. Moves with Ottoman calm and measured pace and proffers a brilliant lunch bargain in the form of mixed meze, some hot some cold, yours for a princely £4.95. Now there's meze and there's meze. Pasha's are fresh, light, clean flavoured, precisely spiced or freshly herbed. What you get may depend on the mood of the kitchen, but there'll be the usual standbys, hummus and taramasalata and the great aubergine dish imam bayildi carried out with eye-opening excellence. A heap of tabbouleh, something with aubergines, a borek or two, maybe a delicate kofte, some grilled hellim cheese and chicken in walnut sauce. Sunday lunch is a bargain, too, £8.95 for two courses, £10.95 for three.

On the menu: oyster sauce

What is it? A staple of Chinese cooking available in bottles. From Canton originally.

And, tell me truthfully, does it contain oysters? It does.

Oh my god! And water, salt, cornflower and caramel colouring.

That's better. So what's it used for? Originally to add a dash of exotic flavour to those distinctly non-Chinese dishes, chop suey and chow mein. These days it's a general purpose gunk to add to meat, fish, noodles or veg. Very tasty.

But those oysters!
Food on the net

www.wwrecipes.com

An odd one, this. On the one hand, it's a straightforward recipe service, sending out daily emails which, over the course of a week, make up a gourmet meal. On the other, it's an often bizarre foodie community, with the personal musings of recipe creator "The Chef" popping up alongside directions on how to stuff an Argentinian flank steak.

Pros: Assumes you know your way around the kitchen and are able to track down unusual ingredients. A few weeks' worth of emails amounts to quite a repertoire of dishes.

Cons: Serious recipes, but some might find the "zany" humour of The Chef rather perplexing.

Charges: It's free.

fields.headline: World's first internet movie premieres
fields.trailText: The first feature film developed and produced exclusively for the internet had its premiere last night
fields.body:
The first feature film developed and produced exclusively for the internet had its premiere last night.

Quantum, which cost $3m to produce, and $3.95 to download, stars Stephen Dorff (Blade), Fay Masterson (Eyes Wide Shut) and John Cleese, in an alternate-reality love story. Dorff plays a bewildered quantum physicist, Paul, who's caught in a blurred reality following a chance encounter with his frustrated flame, Mia, played by Masterson. It is directed by Eugenio Zanetti, the Oscar-winning designer who created the house in The Haunting.

Quantum producer Stephen Simon says the big-name cast was lured to his project because of the chance to try something new. "Everyone loved the idea of being first," says Simon, whose production company, Metafilmics, also produced What Dreams May Come. "We kind of felt like the people who made The Jazz Singer, and we had a sense of being pioneers."

The movie plays like a collage of hallucinations, cut with hundreds of digital effects aimed to burst off the computer screen. Simon says the effects and quick-cut editing techniques were designed specifically with the net in mind. When characters are thinking, a computer toolbar pops up to signify their brains. And when Dorff senses danger, a pesky Windows alert sign flashes onto the screen.

Reviewing the film, Associated Press writer David Germain said that while the music-video-type editing makes the visual effects appear "reasonably impressive" on the computer screen, the film itself amounts to "little more than a collage of impressionistic images stitched together by a loose plot."

Germain added: "If the internet is going to become a new outlet for first-run films, the requirement is the same as it is for television and movie theatres: If you want an audience, tell a good story."

Despite the hype, Quantum suggests that the internet isn't quite ready to supplant the cinema yet. The movie takes 15 minutes to download on high-speed modems; while users with slower connections will have to endure a four-hour-plus wait. Furthermore, the $3.95 required to 'buy' the half-hour movie might deter many users.

Meanwhile this morning, the site gives an error on an attempt to preview the movie, and it appears that it can only be downloaded with Internet Explorer as your browser. The future it seems is not quite with us yet.

 Quantum is available for downloading for $3.95 at www.sightsound.com

fields.headline: Reaction to the vote
fields.trailText:
"It's a quite wonderful feeling. I never thought I would be back in this sort of position."
Ken Livingstone
fields.body:
"It's a quite wonderful feeling. I never thought I would be back in this sort of position."
Ken Livingstone

"Let's say to Ken: 'Congratulations, if you've won. Let's work together'."
David Blunkett, education and employment secretary

"We have run a good campaign, we've framed the issues and it looks as though we might hold the balance of power in the London assembly."
Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat candidate

"I am comfortable with the fact that Ken is there. I genuinely wish him well. I have never doubted him personally but he has a big task on his hands."
Steven Norris, Conservative, candidate

"We do not want to spend the next six months fighting the battles of the last six months. All of this is yesterday's battle. Tomorrow we have to sit down and work out how we make this assembly open and democratic and work for London and how we work with the new mayor."
Trevor Phillips, Frank Dobson's running mate

"The prime minister wanted business people and others from the community to offer themselves as candidates, and I did that and managed to bring together a vast range of diverse groups. That has been a very encouraging development which I want to build on. We are looking at elections in other cities for mayor and assemblies - life goes after May 4."
Ram Gidoomal, Christian Peoples' Alliance candidate

"Obviously it is a disappointing result for Labour. We had a lot of faith in Frank - he is a genuine, decent man, but obviously has not won and that is disappointing."
Jim Fitzpatrick MP, London Labour Party head.

"The onus and responsibility on everyone is to work together for the good of London. I am certain that we will hope for a constructive and responsible attitude from the Assembly and Mayor. Party rules exclude those who stand against official candidates resuming Labour Party membership but time will tell."
Margaret Beckett, Labour leader of the House of Commons

"I will have no problems working with Mr Livingstone. What he and I do together is obviously vital to the City of London and vital for Londoners."
Lord Mayor of London, Clive Martin

"If the Archangel Gabriel had stood with the name Winston Churchill, Ken would still have won. The way Labour handled the selection of its candidate pretty well handed it to him on a plate."
Lord Archer (who resigned as Tory candidate to make way for Steven Norris)

webTitle: 'I was never scared of the elephants in my garden'

fields.headline: 'I was never scared of the elephants in my garden'
fields.standfirst:
Kuki Gallmann’s tale of her turbulent years in Africa was an international bestseller. As the film of her life is released, she tells Hadley Freeman how Hollywood - and Kim Basinger - got it wrong
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Kuki Gallmann’s tale of her turbulent years in Africa was an international bestseller. As the film of her life is released, she tells Hadley Freeman how Hollywood - and Kim Basinger - got it wrong
fields.body:
"I myself would have been curious to meet the person I was to interpret," says the heavily accented, slightly indignant voice at the end of the telephone line. "Kim Basinger has given her own interpretation of me, and it's definitely not me. I was never afraid when Paolo went off hunting. I've certainly never been afraid of the elephants in my garden."

Kuki Gallmann, widow, mother, internationally acclaimed author and conservationist, is not very happy. I Dreamed of Africa, the film adaptation of her autobiography, opens today in the US and she is quickly discovering the pitfalls of handing over your life to Hollywood.

"I know, times change and things change. But this is a year 2000 depiction of my life in the 1970s," she says.

It is easy to understand why Hollywood was attracted to Gallmann's life, despite her initial (and, apparently, unresolved) reluctance to see "all that drama up on screen". Born just outside of Venice in 1943, Kuki (her name is pronounced "cookie") moved to Kenya with her husband Paolo and son Emanuele in 1972. They bought a ranch in the Laikipia region and revelled in their new, exotic life. Shark fishing, buffalo hunting and flying around the continent in private planes became part of their daily life, a far cry from the claustrophobic grey gloom of a Venetian winter.

But eight years later, Paolo was killed in a car crash on his way to pick up a cradle for his and Kuki's soon-to-be-born daughter, Sveva. Three years later Emanuele, then aged 17, died in Kuki's arms after he was bitten by one of his pet snakes.

At this point, most people would probably have packed up and gone home, leaving with nothing but sad memories of their African adventure. Gallmann, however, stayed put. Determined "to make something positive out of the tragedy", in 1983 she established the Gallmann Memorial Foundation - in memory of her husband and son - dedicated to conservation and anti-poaching programmes, research into the use of the region's medicinal plants and promotion and sponsorship of the education of Kenyans.

When she is not working at the foundation in Kenya, she flies around the world, raising international aid for it. It took her agent and myself almost a week to track her down, chasing her by telephone and email from New York to Toronto to London to Kenya.

In the three parts of her autobiography - I Dreamed of Africa, African Nights and Night of the Lions - Gallmann manages to write about her life and achievements without slipping into sanctimonious smugness or overwrought sentimentality. She describes Africa without romanticising it or resorting to scenes of alien quaintness - this isn't Out of Africa meets A Year in Provence. And although she didn't learn English until she was an adult (self-taught from Victorian novels "about governesses and paupers") her books are beautifully, elegantly written, enlivened with wonderful details of her life in Africa: the smell of elephants, the sound of a leopard's cough, the feel of the desert dust after the rain.

Although Gallmann stresses that her main aim in writing the books (and giving her consent to the film) was to present a side of Africa not often seen on television, she admits that there was, inevitably, a cathartic aspect as well: "Some people - I've never done it - go to a psychoanalyst, lie on a couch and tell a stranger their problems. That's what happens, isn't it? Well, since I was a little girl, the white page has been my psychoanalysis."

Through her books she looks "for clues for solving the absurd puzzle"; trying to find a logical progression leading up to her senseless losses.

I Dreamed of Africa is punctuated by terrible tragedies - crippling car accidents, the death of friends and friends' children. It is as if Gallmann, in retrospect, sees her life as a series of disasters, preparing her (and the reader) for her greatest tragedy - the loss of her husband and son.

Take romance, loss, rejuvenation and a clear plot, chuck in some stunning vistas and a sweeping soundtrack, plus a politically correct eco-message: hey presto, you have Hollywood magic. Or so thought the 15 or so producers who approached Gallmann as soon as her first book was published. Initially, she was unwilling to hand over her life into "unknown hands", but in the end she signed away the rights to her book to Stanley R Jaffe, already a producer of two films that deal with a lone female struggling against the odds - The Accused and Fatal Attraction.

Although Gallmann enthuses about Jaffe and the director Hugh Hudson (who made Chariots of Fire), she had her doubts. She questioned why most of the film was shot outside of Kenya, and felt there was a "lack of magic" on screen between Basinger and Vincent Perez, who plays Paolo. She feels happier after having seen the movie at the New York premiere last week ("Not a dry eye in the house!"), but still has her reservations. "It is difficult to concentrate a life down to two hours. The film is a rendition of the book, and the book is a rendition of my life, so I knew it would not be the same."

But Gallmann's main concern was Basinger. Despite Basinger's praise for Gallmann as "an individual with dreams and the fortitude to pursue them", the actress seems to have decided to treat Kuki Gallmann as a fictional character: not once, to Gallmann's chagrin, did Basinger arrange to meet her character's real-life counterpart. "The director, the producers and the scriptwriter all spent time with me in Laikipia. The only person who didn't come was Kim. Perhaps she felt a little insecure, and she had her own ideas about her interpretation of me.

"You know," she hastily adds, "I'm not an actor, I don't know anything about actors. The only time I see movies is when I'm on an airplane, so I don't know how actors approach these things. Kim is good with the script she was given. But, you know, we're very different people: she's an actress in the US, I live in the bush."

So what about the film itself? "Well, I'm not really the ideal audience. The ideal audience member has never met me, never been to Africa, never read my books. For that person, they will be hit by the film, no doubt about that."

But now that Gallmann is back home in Laikipia, she has more important things on her mind: she is finishing off two more books, there's the day-to-day running of her 100,000 acre ranch, not to mention preparations for the wedding of Sveva, now 20 and studying at Oxford. But it is her charitable foundation that remains Gallmann's primary concern. Just before we hang up she asks me: "Have you been to Kenya yet?"

webTitle: The role of the London mayor

fields.headline: The role of the London mayor
fields.standfirst: As Ken Livingstone prepares to take office, we explain the newly elected mayor's powers and responsibilities
fields.trailText: What's the mayor's first job in office?
fields.body:
What's the mayor's first job in office?

Before anything else, the mayor must appoint a deputy from the Greater London Authority (GLA). The deputy will act as an adviser and stand-in, and, like the mayor, will have a seat on the newly created Metropolitan Police Authority. Other appointments will also have to made, including a cabinet of experts, who the mayor can appoint to a range of new public bodies in the city. The job creation doesn't stop there: the mayor's office - led by a chief of staff - will act as an in-house think-tank.

Does the mayor get to spend money on anything other than salaries?

The Greater London Assembly Act (1999) which established London's devolved government, gives the GLA power over public expenditure for the capital's police service, the fire brigade, transport system and economic development. The mayor will draw up a budget for providing those services, and submit it to the GLA for approval. Last year, those services cost £3.3 billion.

So if the GLA gives it the OK, the mayor can spend whatever he wants on whatever he feels like?

Not quite. Much of the money the mayor is allowed to spend will come from central government, with strings attached. Whichever government department allocates money to London will have a veto over how it is spent.

So what can the mayor do about, say, transport?

Quite a lot. As part of the shake-up of London's government, a new body governing all transport will be created by merging London Transport, the Traffic Director of London and the parts of the Highways Agency and the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions which deal with the capital. The result will be Transport for London, and the mayor will not only chair the body, he will also appoint its members. Transport for London will have overall responsibility for all transport in the capital, and it may promote legislation in parliament if it wishes. Perhaps its most obvious power is the ability to decide public transport fares. The mayor will, ultimately, have the power to introduce road tolls and special parking fees, although not immediately upon taking office.

And the police?

Once again, a lot of the mayor's power lies in making appointments. In all, 12 out of the 23 members of the Metropolitan Police Authority will be appointed by the mayor. The authority itself is a new creation, taking away the home secretary's direct supervision of the Met. The mayor's budget also determines funding for the police in London. It must, however, exceed a minimum level set by the Home Office, or the home secretary can rule that London will be inadequately policed, and force the mayor to allocate the police more money from the budget. The mayor also appoints and oversees the new London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority

What about the economy?

The principle change will be the creation of the London Development Agency, which will take over central government's responsibility for distributing inward investment to London, and economic regeneration grants. Once again, however, much of the funding will be earmarked grants that can only be spent as central government departments dictate. The mayor will also take on responsibility for wider strategic planning, developing a "Spatial Development Strategy", which will deal with economic development, urban regeneration and housing issues.

Anything else?

The other principle area of the mayor's power is over environmental and cultural matters. On the environment, the mayor is obliged to implement strategies to deal with ambient noise and rubbish, as well as safeguarding air quality and biodiversity. Once during every four-year term, the mayor will publish a "global" report on the state of the environment in London. In the cultural sphere, the mayor will direct city-wide action on the arts, sport and tourism: the bid to host the Olympic Games is a prime example. And yet again, there are jobs to be given out. The Cultural Strategy Group for London, appointed by the mayor, will advise the GLA on culture.

So is it fair to say that the mayor's powers have been exaggerated by all the attention the election has generated?

A little, but it's worth remembering that the mayor's influence extends beyond his legally bestowed powers. As the elected representative of more than eight million people, whoever lands the job will have a greater public mandate than any other politician in Britain. As the chief spokesperson for the capital, the mayor's voice will be very hard to ignore, even for cabinet ministers who, technically, have far more power over London.

webTitle: Greed appeal fails to lift American Psycho

fields.headline: Greed appeal fails to lift American Psycho
fields.trailText: Although it scared up a huge audience for The Blair Witch Project, internet marketing seems to have failed American Psycho
fields.body:
Although it scared up a huge audience for The Blair Witch Project, internet marketing seems to have failed American Psycho. Distributor Lions Gate pumped $50,000 into an online stockmarket game designed to drum up business. 'Make a killing with American Psycho' invited players to invest in movies, actors or musicians using fake Hollywood dollars.

Players were given an opportunity to share in the box-office revenues with the promise of real cash for every imaginary American Psycho share they purchased, should the film hit the $20m mark.

But the highly touted and controversial movie has made only $12m since its release three weeks ago, falling far below box-office expectations.

Lions Gate co-president Tom Ortenberg said nonetheless he considered the net promotion a success. "The aim was to gain exposure and awareness for the picture, and we did that," he said. "Lions Gate will make a tidy profit on the picture."

fields.headline: Second 'love bug' threatens computers
fields.standfirst: Love bug virus creates worldwide chaos
fields.trailText: A new strain of the virus that yesterday attacked computer systems across the world has emerged.
fields.body:
A new strain of the virus that yesterday attacked computer systems across the world has emerged.

'Love bug 2' is again email based, this time in the form of an email with a joke attachment.

Experts believe the new variant has been devised by a "copycat" programmer using the ILOVEYOU virus as a model. Love Bug 2 works in the same way, rapidly multiplying by sending itself to all those listed in a user's email address book.

The email uses the comparatively common subject header: "fwd: Joke".

It contains no text but an attachment called "very funny.vbs", which, if downloaded, triggers the damaging virus.

Graham Cluley, of the anti-virus programming firm Sophos, said the new variant would not be knocked out by the antidote developed yesterday to deal with the love bug, which took the form of a message telling recipients: "Kindly check the attached love letter from me!"

Mr Cluley said: "It is a copycat virus written by somebody who has taken the existing bug and altered it in such a way that anti-virus products do not recognise it.

"It is quite possible the new variant was not written by the original programmer because the original source code was contained in the virus and that was sent to millions of people. Any of those people could have taken it and used it as the basis for launching the new virus."

A cure for the new strain has now been developed.

fields.headline: Apathy wins the day
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown looks at how the low turnout affects the results
fields.trailText: Derek Brown looks at how the low turnout affects the results
fields.body:
The winners are crowing over their triumph, and the losers are scornfully dismissing any suggestion of defeat. It was ever thus in electoral politics where the outcome, however cut and dried, tends to lie in the eye of the beholder.

To Labour, the loss of more than 500 council seats is "containable". For the Tories, the loss of the Romsey byelection to the Liberal Democrats is less important than Labour's loss of its deposit.

But the bombast and special pleading cannot conceal the most significant figure to emerge from Thursday's welter of polling: two thirds of the electorate couldn't be bothered to take part.

Even in the London mayoral election, the most publicised contest in recent political history, the turnout was a dismal 35%. Elsewhere in England, it averaged rather less. In one district, electors were so indifferent that only 14% cast their votes.

The abysmal turnout badly undermines the efforts of psephologists to extrapolate the likely outcome of the next general election. The council results are also skewed by the fact that Labour was defending a swathe of seats captured in 1996, when Conservative fortunes were at their lowest ebb.

In that context, the Labour loss of 546 seats and the Tory gain of 542 merely returns the two big parties to a more natural balance in their respective heartlands. As a pointer to national voting intentions, the swing is no more significant than the LibDem's ostensible triumph in capturing 28% of the popular vote - just two percentage points behind Labour.

webTitle: The best Andy Kaufmann scene: Man on the Moon

fields.headline: The best Andy Kaufmann scene: Man on the Moon
fields.trailText: A black screen behind him, Andy Kaufman (Jim Carrey) steps before the camera. A nervous smile plays around his lips. In a strange, indeterminate foreign accent, he speaks straight to camera.
fields.body:
A black screen behind him, Andy Kaufman (Jim Carrey) steps before the camera. A nervous smile plays around his lips. In a strange, indeterminate foreign accent, he speaks straight to camera.

"Hello. I am Andy. Welcome to my movie."

His expression suddenly changes to one of irritation.

"I hoped the story of my life would be nice - but it turned out terrible!"

He becomes agitated.

"It is all LIES! Things are all mixed up, real people I knew play different people. What a mess! So I broke into Universal and cut out the junk. Now it's much shorter."

He hesitates.

"In fact, this is the end of the movie. Thanks for coming! Bye!"

Andy places the needle on a record beside him. Bombastic, emotive music starts to swell. The closing credits roll. Andy smiles awkwardly. Finally, the credits end. Leaning into camera, he whispers, his accent now everyday American.

"OK! Now just my friends are left. I wanted to get rid of those other people. They would have laughed in the wrong places. I was kidding about the movie, it's actually pretty good. It shows everything, from me as a little boy until my death."

He clasps his hand over his mouth.

"Oops! I wasn't supposed to talk about that."

He grins in embarrassment.

"We better just begin..."

See also: The Andy Kaufman Midnight Special, I'm From Hollywood, My Breakfast With Blassie

Don't see also: Heartbeeps

Pointless trivia: Andy Kaufman was a devotee of Transcendental Meditation throughout his adult life, claiming it enabled him to improve his performances.

webTitle: Oscar winner Mendes to direct unknown's play

fields.headline: Oscar winner Mendes to direct unknown's play
fields.trailText: Sam Mendes shocked the world of theatre last night by revealing that the first play he is to direct since winning an Oscar will be by an unknown author.
fields.body:
Sam Mendes shocked the world of theatre last night by revealing that the first play he is to direct since winning an Oscar will be by an unknown author.

After his American Beauty triumph, the British director took Hollywood by surprise by saying that he was dying to return to the Donmar Warehouse, a small London theatre he had put on the map with his Tony Award-winning production of Cabaret and of The Blue Room starring Nicole Kidman.

Now Mendes has ditched his plans to direct Twelfth Night in favour of a drama called To The Green Fields Beyond, which is set in a tank on the western front during the first world war, and written by the relatively obscure Nick Whitby.

"Shakespeare can wait," Mendes said last night.

"You have to take advantage of a good and exciting new play like this. It is not every day they land on your desk. One of the benefits of running a theatre is that you can change the programme when you need to."

A spokeswoman for the Donmar said Twelfth Night would be staged next year instead, although casting had actually begun before the change of plan.

"Sam read To The Green Fields Beyond and went 'Wow!' said the spokeswoman.

"He really loved it, so he thought 'what the hell!' It is a fascinating piece, and it's a very unusual subject."

The play revolves around a multiracial crew of a tank during the Somme offensive in September 1916. The generals hoped that the new weapon would turn around the war, stuck in a battle of attrition, by being able to break through the German lines.

But most of the tanks broke down with mechanical failures on their first outing at the Somme, long before they got in sight of German trenches, and failed to break the stalemate.

In contrast to army tradition, the new tank corps recruited from all corners of the British empire, and moreover its tank commanders were "ordinary blokes" rather than officers.

Whitby, in his early thirties, has written comedy for TV but is best known for a play, Dirty Dishes, that has been a hit in Germany.

Mendes, 34, said last month that he was happy to direct one play a year until the right film script came along: "There are not as many of them out there as you think."

He has formed his own film company, called Donmar, backed by the DreamWorks studio, and even persuaded its boss, Steven Spielberg, to donate money to the theatre.

The head of Miramax, Harvey Weinstein, is also keen to secure Mendes' services, and is investing in the Donmar production of Tom Stoppard's The Real Thing on Broadway.

fields.headline: Mission: Impossible 2
fields.trailText: Mission: Impossible 2
fields.body:
The Impossible dream

At first, just a humble seven-year US TV series starting in 1966 about a covert operations unit with Steven Hill, Peter Graves and Barbara Bain as (lest we forget) Cinnamon Carter. In plot terms, it was Mission Quite Tricky, but execs decided Mission: Impossible sounded more ratings grabby and the colon stuck. The first M:I movie was 1968's entirely colon-free and largely budget-free Mission Impossible vs The Mob.

The much more Impossible dream

Brian De Palma hired Tom Cruise and flew a helicopter through the Channel Tunnel for his 1996 movie. Big screen, big bucks, big explosions, big colon, big waste of Emmanuelle Béart.

The really Impossible dream

The inevitable Mission Impossible: 2 is already in the can, directed by John Woo. But the impossible bit this time is that Paramount has decided it wants a PG-13 rating in the US to protect its $180m investment and the MPAA has already issued a provisional R (for restricted).

As any viewer of The Killer, Hard Boiled or Face/Off will agree, Woo is a strictly adult action man. Quentin Tarantino said of Woo (to an executive who said "I suppose Woo can direct action scenes") "Sure and Michelangelo can paint ceilings." Cue more cuts and blood-letting than Woo is used to. Even Cinnamon would find this one impossible. Warning: this column will self-destruct in your memory bank in five seconds.

fields.headline: Katrin Cartlidge
fields.trailText: What was your first film?
fields.body:
What was your first film?

The Red Balloon, a French film made for children by Albert Lamorisse. I loved it because it captured all the fears, hopes and dreams of being a child. I was inconsolable for three days afterwards.

What's your favourite film?

Andrei Rublev for the part that deals with the bell-maker's son. It's the most extraordinary metaphor for faith and creativity. Any creative person who's ever bullshitted to anybody and then had to make that bullshit a reality, will identify with that story.

What's the last film you walked out of?

None, but I really wanted to walk out of Independence Day. I saw it at the Empire, Leicester Square, and the audience's reaction was mindless and murderous. I had a panic attack.

Most erotic movie moment?

In Urga, a film about the Mongolian steppes, the husband and wife peel and share a hard-boiled egg after an argument, which is incredibly erotic. And when I was 13 I saw Peter Sellers as Inspector Clouseau. There's a scene where he's scrabbling round on all fours in a bath room. A busty bint comes in wearing nothing but a fur coat and he ends up with his nose in her belly button. These two dishy teenage boys sitting behind me were so vocal in their lust that I found it a huge turn-on.

When did you last snog someone in the cinema?

I always give my boyfriend a great big kiss before a film starts. The last time was last week when we went to see Tim Robbins's Cradle Will Rock. I remember having my fingers sucked years ago while watching The Color of Money.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

Talking, rustling, eating and crunching.

Favourite snatch of dialogue?

I have a terrible memory for dialogue but I remember so clearly what Johnny says in Naked. Louise asks him how he got his black eye. His reply is, "The sky fell in on me and a cloud caught me across the cheek", which I absolutely love. It's poignant because he's evading answering the question and yet it's so true, metaphorically.

Which actor would you most like to be?

Gary Oldman, Dan Day-Lewis and Tim Roth. They've all been rightly appreciated for their tremendous versatility and ability to transform, instead of being rushed into obscurity for those same qualities, which often happens to their female counterparts.

Which actress?

Bibi Andersson, Ellen Burstyn and Jeanne Moreau for their intellect, sexuality, sense of humour, ability to grow old with gusto, and for the wonderful directors they've worked with. I'd like to be a combination of all three.

When did you last hide under your seat?

In Lodge Kerrigan's first film, Clean, Shaven, the lead character thinks there's a transmitter under his fingernail and proceeds to try to uproot his nail to get at it.

When did you last cry?

When I saw the Bill Douglas trilogy in a very rare screening. It's an autobiographical film about a poverty-stricken existence in Scotland in the 50s. It's phenomenally brilliant and very moving.

Was Claire Dolan the most gruelling role you've played?

Because my character doesn't have the luxury of breaking down, all the feelings had to be held inside. That extreme concentration made it very lonely. And Claire is the only character who appears all through the film, so it was hard to build up relationships with other actors.

How did you cope with the sex scenes?

The film is trying to deal with the psychology of intimate sex without it being titillatory. The director is really inside the woman's head, which is an extraordinary feat.

fields.headline: Sobbing in the stalls
fields.trailText: I can't talk freely or openly about the new Natalie Portman movie, Where the Heart Is, without first coming clean about my nasty, dirty little secret. And no, it isn't what you're thinking.
fields.body:
I can't talk freely or openly about the new Natalie Portman movie, Where the Heart Is, without first coming clean about my nasty, dirty little secret. And no, it isn't what you're thinking.

I'm aware that a healthy proportion of the male movie-going audience (better make that unhealthy) has been waiting for Hollywood's teenage princess to grow up in much the same way that Karl Malden "waited" for Carroll Baker in Baby Doll. That's to say, doubled up and made demented by paroxysms of guilt-soaked lust.

Not me. I'd be happy if Portman stayed innocent and sweet forever. (Take me where the big girls play). I'm glad she routinely turns down movies and scripts containing nude scenes and deflowerings, and I dread the day she starts swearing and baring 'em.

No, Where the Heart Is forces me to admit that I have a serious problem with that genre of movies commonly dismissed as "Chick Flicks". I just can't get enough of them. It's a habit I just can't kick. "Weepie", "Women's Picture", "Chick Flick" - call them what you like, but whenever a movie appears that looks like it'll require three hankies, I'm there front and centre, clutching my tear-stained Kleenex like the biggest Jessie in the 48 states.

And I mean literally front and centre: Row five, right where the curtain splits, to make sure that no one can hear me snuffling or see me reaching for the huge pile of napkins I've appropriated from the concession stand in the lobby.

For weepies I always head for one of the multiplexes in nearby Glendale (Mildred Pierce country), and make sure I hit the weekday Twilight show between five and seven. It's usually jammed with little old ladies just back from the nearby malls, loaded down with shopping bags, who are too nervous to drive during the LA rush-hour and want nothing more than a nice rest until the traffic fades.

I'm sure they think it's awfully cute that a grown man is blubbing his face off up at the front. I've had many a nice chat in the lobby with venerable old dears who can't believe that a heterosexual male in his thirties was the person howling his way through Meryl Streep's death scene in One True Thing or the last 10 minutes of Magnolia.

Well, call me a big softie. I don't care. Being a cry-baby has its advantages, especially if you take a date. Most women in America are stunned if a man suggests going to see something romantic. They're used to the kind of mouth-breathing yahoo frat-boys who drag their dates to see the new Steven Seagal action-atrocity instead of My Best Friend's Wedding (not a film I had much time for, but no matter).

But once the lights go down and that first silvery tear flows down my cheek, I often feel a hand slipping under my arm and a head suddenly resting on my shoulder. Then I find myself repressing a lascivious chuckle (" 'ere we go!") even as I grope in the dark for more hankies.

To be honest, though, I think the age of the great weepie is far behind us. The genre belongs to the pre-ironic era, before Method acting, before the 1960s, before the onset of universal cynicism about girly stuff like true romance and endless love.

Sometime in the mid-1950s, the producer Ross Hunter and Douglas Sirk, his favourite director (and mine), were putting the final touches to the script of one of their magnificent melodramas when Hunter lurched to his feet, stabbed the page with a pencil and cried, "Douglas, I want 500 handkerchiefs to come out right here!" And come the premiere, I'll bet that linen flapped like a million surrenders.

I wish movie producers were like that today, but obviously they aren't. I just know that if push came to shove I'd trade in both Godfathers and most Martin Scorsese movies for just five minutes of All That Heaven Allows or Written on the Wind. Or Mildred Pierce, The Enchanted Cottage, or Letter From an Unknown Woman.

These days though, a three-hankie movie is more likely to mean Cherry Cheeks 3 or Buttman's Backdoor to Buttsville, Part Six. Plus *a change... The last zone of creative endeavour unsullied by irony is, of course, country music, so it's in that milieu that one finds today's equivalent of the old Women's Picture: country music biopics like Coal Miner's Daughter and Sweet Dreams, or indomitable Southern gal stories like Places in The Heart or (ak!) Steel Magnolias.

Where The Heart is fits snugly into that tradition. Billie Letts's novel is the kind of supermarket best-seller that I'll never bring myself to read (I'll bet it gives The Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood a run for its money), but which makes excellent raw material for the big screen.

Natalie plays 15-year-old Novalee Nation, literally barefoot and pregnant as she leaves her trailer park home for California. She's dumped by her worthless boyfriend outside a Wal-Mart in Oklahoma, and ends up hiding out at night in the store for two months until she gives birth to a child the tabloids instantly dub "the Wal-Mart baby". Thereafter she's warmly enclosed in the bosom of this rag-tag little town, as if she and her baby were gifts fallen from the sky.

Her best friend is Lexie Coop (Ashley Judd), whose life, despite her innate wisdom and strength, is all about getting knocked up and knocked around by a series of worthless boyfriends. Novalee is taken in by Alcoholics Anonymous member Sister Husband, whose pre-prandial prayers usually culminate with the imprecation, "and please lord, forgive the fornicatin' that took place on this here dinner table this very afternoon".

The next five years of Novalee's life are a sucession of thunderstorms and tornadoes, good men and bad, crazy Christians, weddings and babies (Judd pops them out like a baseball pitching machine), deaths and funerals, tragedy and triumph. Oh, and tears and laughter. It's as if screenwriters Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel (kings of the superslick crowd-pleaser) have adapted Loretta Lynn's The Pill, Dolly Parton's Just Because I'm a Woman and George 'n' Tammy's divorce album The Battle.

Natalie holds the film together like a country-fried version of Phoebe Caulfield, the wise little sister in The Catcher in the Rye, sweet as a butterfly, sharp as a tack. Praise the Lord, and pass the Kleenex.

Thereafter she's warmly enclosed in the bosom of this rag-tag little town, as if she and her baby were gifts fallen from the sky. Her best friend is Lexie Coop (Ashley Judd), whose life, despite her innate wisdom and strength, is all about getting knocked up and knocked around by a series of worthless boyfriends. Novalee is taken in by Alcoholics Anonymous member Sister Husband, whose pre-prandial prayers usually culminate with the imprecation, "and please lord, forgive the fornicatin' that took place on this here dinner table this very afternoon". The next five years of Novalee's life are a sucession of thunderstorms and tornadoes, good men and bad, crazy Christians, weddings and babies (Judd pops them out like a baseball pitching machine), deaths and funerals, tragedy and triumph. Oh, and tears and laughter. It's as if screenwriters Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel (kings of the superslick crowd-pleaser) have adapted Loretta Lynn's The Pill, Dolly Parton's Just Because I'm a Woman and George 'n' Tammy's divorce album The Battle. Natalie holds the film together like a country-fried version of Phoebe Caulfield, the wise little sister in The Catcher in the Rye, sweet as a butterfly, sharp as a tack. Praise the Lord, and pass the Kleenex.

fields.headline: Box office isn't everything
fields.standfirst: The Film Council is hoping to reinvigorate British cinema. Jonathan Romney offers some advice
fields.trailText: The Film Council is hoping to reinvigorate British cinema. Jonathan Romney offers some advice
fields.body:
Two years ago, announcing the opening of a British film office in Los Angeles, culture secretary Chris Smith announced he wanted to "send a big message to Hollywood that we are not a quaint suburb but a big block on High Street Tinseltown". If Hollywood hasn't got the message yet, then no doubt it soon will. Britain's new Film Council has promised that it will be "shameless" in doing deals with Hollywood studios, and that it will go for the multiplex jugular. Chief executive John Woodward announced earlier this week that the Council will concentrate on "films that can really play in cinemas on a Friday night."

Films that people want to see - well, why not? Nearly every article written about Lottery funding over the last two years has featured a list of egregious box-office flops, not to mention films that never even got released. With the Council's emphasis on commercial prospects, we're less likely to have to groan through lame-duck projects such as Food of Love, Keep the Aspidistra Flying and The Secret Laughter of Women. The Council's money - roughly half of its £22m to go on commercial films, plus £4.2m for co-productions - will be well spent if it helps build "a sustainable industry that can stand on its own feet," as board member Duncan Kenworthy put it.

But a really healthy British cinema - one that can hold its own with the rest of the world, not just with Hollywood - will depend just as much on the £5m going into the New Cinema Fund, which will back more adventurous and experimental work. The Council's chairman Alan Parker has spent years eating his famous promise to leave the country if Peter Greenaway ever made another film; this week, on Radio 4's Front Row, he admitted that the Film Council would indeed be looking for the new Greenaways.

This can only be good news. For better or worse, we already have our mainstream, our geezer-gangster thrillers and glorified sitcom romps. What we don't have is an art-cinema sector in which the best talents can be nurtured. The Council is offering all the right rhetoric: the New Cinema Fund will support "creativity and innovation... personal vision... experiment." It will look for new names, as well as supporting "established talent working outside the mainstream." But, one independent producer commented, "I can't see the word 'risk' in that manifesto."

Without a commitment to risk, or a willingness to nurture artistic risk-takers, you can't have a real cutting edge: at present, independent experimental directors, producers and writers stagger on from project to project, always hoping the bank manager won't pounce. Under this government, it's become tougher to experiment in film, and for all New Labour's celebration of young talent in art, music and fashion, the government has made an exception of cinema, constantly promoting it as an industry while neglecting its status as an art form.

In June, the NFT in London is running a retrospective of the Alternative British Cinema - "alternative" simply meaning any type of film-making bold enough to stray outside commercial paths. The season's extremely wide menu gathers together Peter Greenaway, Derek Jarman, Terence Davies, the Brothers Quay and Lynne Ramsay, as well as relatively mainstream, and eminently marketable, independents such as Peter Mullan and Shane Meadows. The season proves that left-field needn't mean recondite: but it highlights films that could never have been made if box-office had been the main criterion.

Besides, if the Council is taking its commercial cue from Hollywood, it should remember that even there, the rules are changing. It shouldn't look to the safe old Hollywood of the mid-90s, but to the Hollywood that's prepared to get involved in films such as Boys Don't Cry, Being John Malkovich, Fight Club and Magnolia - all of them the sort of idiosyncratic, high-risk ventures that have rarely stood a chance of getting made in Britain.

As well as making mainstream fare, Britain should capitalise on the success (either at the box-office or on the festival circuit) of smaller films that invent their own rules, such as Ratcatcher, Beautiful People and Under the Skin. Films like this show the world that British cinema has vision and conviction, even if it's often clueless at marketing them.

Yes, let's get those cinemas full on Friday night, but let's remember that there are different cinemas and different audiences. Britain will always produce new Ridley Scotts and Guy Ritchies (and new Alan Parkers, for that matter). But it's a riskier and, right now, more urgent business to nurture the new Peter Greenaway, or Derek Jarman, or Lynne Ramsay, and to encourage the disenfranchised art-house constituency that's out there just waiting to have its imagination captured again. We can set up shop on High Street Tinseltown, by all means, but it won't mean a thing unless we're selling our very own range of coffees, and not just ersatz Starbucks.

fields.headline: In the jungle of cities
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney talks to director Lodge Kerrigan about Claire Dolan, his film about a prostitute
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney talks to director Lodge Kerrigan about Claire Dolan, his film about a prostitute
fields.body:
American director Lodge Kerrigan made his second feature Claire Dolan over two years ago. It gets a limited British release, but for a while was in danger of being the film that time forgot. Critics at Cannes in 1998, squeezing it into a five-a-day schedule, took a deep breath, found Kerrigan's film "distant and removed" - the usual epithets - and quickly filed it away as a noble failure. Kerrigan, ensconced in his Brooklyn apartment gives a booming Jolly Green Giant laugh, and points out that, like most films, Claire Dolan benefits from a little time and attention.

"I remember running into a British critic in Cannes who was up till 3.30 in the morning and was going to see an Angelopoulous film at 9am the next day. I thought, that's not really the best state to see a lyrical, slow-moving film. I think it's a responsibility of the critic to commit to giving a film the proper attention. If a film-maker takes a year, two years of his life to make a film, is it too much to ask that a critic can actually watch it without a hangover?"

Viewed again in the cold light of sobriety, Claire Dolan is a powerful piece of work. It's the story of a young woman, played by Katrin Cartlidge, living in New York and trying to find her way out of prostitution. It's also a film about cities, architecture and glass: from the opening credits, Kerrigan and cinematographer Teodoro Maniaci sheet the screen with abstract swathes of geometrically-patterned windows.

Claire Dolan is entirely unvoyeuristic, although it's very much an essay on voyeurism and urban living. "In my old apartment," Kerrigan says, "I could look across the courtyard into the lives of maybe 15 other people - families, couples, whatever. You have a choice - you can either close your blinds and shut out the world, or you can emotionally shut down to some degree and just not care that people can see into your life. Claire, when she's turning all these tricks, is doing them in front of other hotel buildings where hundreds of people could be watching her do that."

Claire Dolan may have confounded some critics because, despite its sometimes explicit matter-of-factness about a prostitute's routine, it doesn't offer any easy exposures. "If you go to a strip club," says Kerrigan, "there's usually one guy who's absolutely convinced the stripper is stripping for him - that regardless of the other people in the room, there's this more personal intimate relationship. In films that deal with prostitution, the audience actually expects that - they're put in this position where the prostitute opens up and reveals something to them. It's very titillating in that regard, and this film totally rejects that."

Because of these preconceptions, Kerrigan complains, "few critics have talked about what the film is really about, which is a woman struggling to change her life. Certain male critics have just discussed whether they find Katrin Cartlidge attractive or seductive enough, like they're looking for a Bardot."

Certainly, any preconceptions about Cartlidge as an actress, based on her full-on, rather caricatural edge in Mike Leigh's films, are overturned in Claire Dolan. Her performance is all the more commanding for its absolute restraint, thick with the discomfort of half-glimpsed emotions under a tightly-reined surface.

"The emotions are very internal," Kerrigan says. "I don't like to rely on dialogue and exposition to tell a tremendous amount of the story. There are other interesting ways that people communicate." Kerrigan so wholeheartedly rejects the usual certainties of film storytelling that it's not always easy to tell exactly what's happening in Claire Dolan, and what the characters' relationships really are. "Connect-the-dots is just trivial. I prefer films where the audience have to figure it out for themselves - it's more like life. I've never understood why it all has to be crystal clear."

This oblique attitude to narrative and style must make it harder for Kerrigan to find financing? "Yeah - so?" Claire Dolan was financed by French company MK2, after American funding fell through. This doesn't strictly make Kerrigan a French film-maker, but he certainly has more in common with the strategies of European art cinema than with the commercial level-headedness that defines even the American independent fringe these days.

If you want to make tougher, more oblique films, Kerrigan says, then you just have to be financially disciplined. "It's my responsibility as a film-maker to make sure the investors make their investment back. If you're unsure whether your film will break even, you should reduce your budget. My films are not audience-friendly, they're not date movies - but they have made money."

Kerrigan learned cash management the hard way. His first feature, Clean, Shaven from 1994 - "an amateur film", he calls it - cost $60,000 and took three years to make. "I'd shoot a little, run out of money, go shoot some more, and it was everything I love about film-making. I couldn't believe it when it was over - 'Isn't there anything else I have to do?' "

Anyone who saw Clean, Shaven won't easily forget the way that the sound design and rough, tarnished look gave you the feeling of spying on the schizophrenic hero from inside his head. The film was the result of Kerrigan's extensive research, both on paper and at New York's Bellevue mental hospital. "I wanted an audience to see what it might feel like to be schizophrenic. Everything in it is related to something which is medically known. People affected by mental illness are the least able to defend themselves in a political arena so hopefully, on some level, it made a difference and made people question their prejudices."

Kerrigan seems to have a leisurely approach to getting films made. He doesn't like sending his scripts out - "Very few people know how to read screenplays" - and Claire Dolan only reached its financier via French director Jacques Audiard, whom Kerrigan had met at a writing workshop. He also got Katrin Cartlidge for the lead simply because he happened to meet her, and likes to give his scripts to actors to look at, because they're good at sifting out inconsistencies. We may have to wait some time for a third feature: in between university teaching stints, Kerrigan has been planning two architectural documentaries and several feature ideas. The ones most likely to get made are a Blow-Up-style investigation of infanticide, and a political drama about campaign finance abuse.

Even though he's likely to make a bigger-scale feature next, Kerrigan is champing at the bit to go micro-budget again. "I'm interested in digital video but not for the standard reasons. I want to use a lot of hidden cameras - have a crew of two, three people maximum and have actors interact in live environments, instead of trying to control reality. Like - art-direct it, get actors, extras, props, everyone in costumes, rehearse it?" Kerrigan lets out a booming laugh, incredulously. "That's almost like doing a period piece!"
