webTitle: Stanley told Steven: 'You'd be the best guy to direct this film'

fields.headline: Stanley told Steven: 'You'd be the best guy to direct this film'
fields.standfirst: Kubrick, Spielberg and the AI project
fields.trailText: Kubrick, Spielberg and the AI project
fields.body:
Never a man to do things by halves, and rarely a man to tell anyone else what he was doing, Stanley Kubrick fuelled Hollywood's rumour mill to a greater extent than any other director. Even his death last year did little to reduce the steady flow of fantastic tales about his future projects, and top of the list has been the sci-fi epic, AI. Kubrick had nurtured this project for more than 20 years, and it was announced as his next project several times. But ultimately, it outlived him.

Last year, the AI saga took a new turn when it was announced that Steven Spielberg had decided to direct the film, with a release planned for summer 2001. With no known direct connection between the two directors, the news came as something of a surprise, but they were close associates, and their film careers were bizarrely intertwined.

Had it not been for Spielberg, in fact, Kubrick's film legacy might have taken an entirely different shape. "They are both great writers but they have different handwriting," says Jan Harlan, Kubrick's brother-in-law and long-standing executive producer. "They are similar in their intellect. They are both very fast and very, very bright." As unofficial earthly representative of Kubrick, a close friend for more than 40 years and the sole link between Spielberg's AI and Kubrick's, Harlan is in the perfect position to clear up decades of speculation surrounding the director.

"He and Spielberg spoke all the time," he continues. "I have six or seven years' worth of correspondence between them over AI, which I recently passed over to Spielberg along with over 1,000 drawings." Harlan has recently read Spielberg's new script and is very enthusiastic about it. He has seen the initial models and designs ("mind-bogglingly wonderful", "huge teams of people"), and though he is still sworn to secrecy on the details, he confirms that Haley Joel Osment (the boy from The Sixth Sense) and Jude Law are both on board.

AI (short for Artificial Intelligence) is an adaptation of a 1969 short story by Brian Aldiss called Super-Toys Last All Summer Long, to which Kubrick bought the rights in 1983. Set in a flooded futuristic world, the story is like a robot version of Pinocchio, centring on an android boy with human emotions. "Stanley took that idea and projected it into the future, not only the child but the society as well," Harlan explains. "He always liked to tackle new things and a really fantastic fairy tale was something he hadn't done yet."

Spielberg's own fantastic sci-fi fairytale, ET, had been released the year before, and it had an influence on Kubrick in the same way that 2001: A Space Odyssey had influenced Spielberg to make Close Encounters of the Third Kind. At the same time as AI, however, there were two other stories Kubrick had been grooming for development for decades: Eyes Wide Shut, to which he had bought the film rights in 1972, and a second world war project called The Aryan Papers. These three projects were intensively developed, then put on the back burner for the rest of Kubrick's life.

After an initial bout of work on AI with Aldiss in the early 70s, it was shelved, partly in response to Star Wars. So The Aryan Papers was the frontrunner after Kubrick finished Full Metal Jacket in 1987. "Kubrick always wanted to do a film on the Holocaust, but he never got a good script," says Harlan. He had tried to commission an original screenplay from the novelist Isaac Bashevis Singer (who turned it down on the grounds that he knew nothing about the Holocaust), before settling on an adaptation of the novel Wartime Lies, by Lewis Begley.

"We were very committed to do this film," Harlan recalls. "We had done enormous amounts of research and preparation, but there came a point when he and Warner boss Terry Semel decided it would be better to do AI first. It had to do with Schindler's List," he said. "It was such a good film and so successful, and Stanley's film would have come out about a year later. He'd already had this experience with Full Metal Jacket, which came out the year after Platoon, and that hurt us, there's no question about it." So in 1995, The Aryan Papers was abandoned and Kubrick returned to AI.

Aldiss contributed sporadically, and other writers were brought in, including another British sci-fi writer, Ian Watson, and novelist Sara Maitland. By this stage, the internet community had discovered the project, and rumours started to fly on a daily basis, fuelled by Kubrick's secrecy and refusal to communicate with the press. There was the rumour, for example, that AI had begun production in the early 90s, and that Kubrick was shooting Joseph Mazzello (one of the child actors from Jurassic Park) for four weeks at a time every couple of years. "Total nonsense," Harlan replies, "although we did test Joseph and he was put on a contract, but then he didn't do the film."

What about the rumoured involvement of Chris Cunningham, futuristic video director for the likes of Madonna, Björk and Aphex Twin and part-time robot designer? "We did try to build remote control machines and stuff like that. We tried to construct a little boy with a movable rubber face to see whether we could make it look appealing. But it was a total failure, it looked awful."

How much of the footage had already been shot before he died? "We did some test shots from a helicopter of oil rigs in the North sea. We wanted to see the sea during really bad weather. That was all. Spielberg is basically starting from zero." Or there is the rumour that Kubrick was already working on effects shots with Industrial Light & Magic, but stopped everything when he saw ILM's computer-generated dinosaurs for Spielberg's Jurassic Park. "There's a grain of truth in that, yes, because he was really astonished by Jurassic Park and AI needs that kind of stuff even more. So he said, 'The longer we wait, the better'."

Thus AI was put on the back burner again, and Eyes Wide Shut became Kubrick's final film. Like AI, it had been in Kubrick's possession since the 70s, and had been worked and reworked from Schnitzler's source material. "He was stuck on it for 20 years. He didn't know how to end it," Harlan remembers. "At one point, about 15 years ago, he was totally high for a week. He said, 'I have a brilliant idea: I'll do it in New York and I'll have Woody Allen playing the lead. It makes total sense!' Of course, Woody told me he never heard anything about it."

Harlan maintains that Kubrick would certainly have returned to AI after Eyes Wide Shut. "He had no intention of dying, I assure you. But at one point, Stanley actually said to Spielberg: 'You would be the best guy to direct this film, I'll be the producer.' I can't tell you whether he would have directed it himself or given it to Spielberg. That was still very much a possibility."

Having crossed Kubrick's path so often, having influenced, obstructed and ultimately earned his respect, Spielberg now finds himself in an entirely new relationship to Kubrick, as his officially approved successor. It is a shift that Harlan and the rest of the Kubrick estate seem entirely satisfied with. "There's really no one else who could have done it apart from Spielberg. I'm more than happy about it; I'm ecstatic. It's exactly what Stanley would have wanted. Well, second best to living."

As unofficial earthly representative of Kubrick, a close friend for more than 40 years and the sole link between Spielberg's AI and Kubrick's, Harlan is in the perfect position to clear up decades of speculation surrounding the director. "He and Spielberg spoke all the time," he continues. "I have six or seven years' worth of correspondence between them over AI, which I recently passed over to Spielberg along with over 1,000 drawings." Harlan has recently read Spielberg's new script and is very enthusiastic about it. He has seen the initial models and designs ("mind-bogglingly wonderful", "huge teams of people"), and though he is still sworn to secrecy on the details, he confirms that Haley Joel Osment (the boy from The Sixth Sense) and Jude Law are both on board. AI (short for Artificial Intelligence) is an adaptation of a 1969 short story by Brian Aldiss called Super-Toys Last All Summer Long, to which Kubrick bought the rights in 1983. Set in a flooded futuristic world, the story is like a robot version of Pinocchio, centring on an android boy with human emotions. "Stanley took that idea and projected it into the future, not only the child but the society as well," Harlan explains. "He always liked to tackle new things and a really fantastic fairy tale was something he hadn't done yet." Spielberg's own fantastic sci-fi fairytale, ET, had been released the year before, and it had an influence on Kubrick in the same way that 2001: A Space Odyssey had influenced Spielberg to make Close Encounters of the Third Kind. At the same time as AI, however, there were two other stories Kubrick had been grooming for development for decades: Eyes Wide Shut, to which he had bought the film rights in 1972, and a second world war project called The Aryan Papers. These three projects were intensively developed, then put on the back burner for the rest of Kubrick's life. After an initial bout of work on AI with Aldiss in the early 70s, it was shelved, partly in response to Star Wars. So The Aryan Papers was the frontrunner after Kubrick finished Full Metal Jacket in 1987. "Kubrick always wanted to do a film on the Holocaust, but he never got a good script," says Harlan. He had tried to commission an original screenplay from the novelist Isaac Bashevis Singer (who turned it down on the grounds that he knew nothing about the Holocaust), before settling on an adaptation of the novel Wartime Lies, by Lewis Begley. "We were very committed to do this film," Harlan recalls. "We had done enormous amounts of research and preparation, but there came a point when he and Warner boss Terry Semel decided it would be better to do AI first. It had to do with Schindler's List," he said. "It was such a good film and so successful, and Stanley's film would have come out about a year later. He'd already had this experience with Full Metal Jacket, which came out the year after Platoon, and that hurt us, there's no question about it." So in 1995, The Aryan Papers was abandoned and Kubrick returned to AI. Aldiss contributed sporadically, and other writers were brought in, including another British sci-fi writer, Ian Watson, and novelist Sara Maitland. By this stage, the internet community had discovered the project, and rumours started to fly on a daily basis, fuelled by Kubrick's secrecy and refusal to communicate with the press. There was the rumour, for example, that AI had begun production in the early 90s, and that Kubrick was shooting Joseph Mazzello (one of the child actors from Jurassic Park) for four weeks at a time every couple of years. "Total nonsense," Harlan replies, "although we did test Joseph and he was put on a contract, but then he didn't do the film." What about the rumoured involvement of Chris Cunningham, futuristic video director for the likes of Madonna, Björk and Aphex Twin and part-time robot designer? "We did try to build remote control machines and stuff like that. We tried to construct a little boy with a movable rubber face to see whether we could make it look appealing. But it was a total failure, it looked awful." How much of the footage had already been shot before he died? "We did some test shots from a helicopter of oil rigs in the North sea. We wanted to see the sea during really bad weather. That was all. Spielberg is basically starting from zero." Or there is the rumour that Kubrick was already working on effects shots with Industrial Light & Magic, but stopped everything when he saw ILM's computer-generated dinosaurs for Spielberg's Jurassic Park. "There's a grain of truth in that, yes, because he was really astonished by Jurassic Park and AI needs that kind of stuff even more. So he said, 'The longer we wait, the better'." Thus AI was put on the back burner again, and Eyes Wide Shut became Kubrick's final film. Like AI, it had been in Kubrick's possession since the 70s, and had been worked and reworked from Schnitzler's source material. "He was stuck on it for 20 years. He didn't know how to end it," Harlan remembers. "At one point, about 15 years ago, he was totally high for a week. He said, 'I have a brilliant idea: I'll do it in New York and I'll have Woody Allen playing the lead. It makes total sense!' Of course, Woody told me he never heard anything about it." Harlan maintains that Kubrick would certainly have returned to AI after Eyes Wide Shut. "He had no intention of dying, I assure you. But at one point, Stanley actually said to Spielberg: 'You would be the best guy to direct this film, I'll be the producer.' I can't tell you whether he would have directed it himself or given it to Spielberg. That was still very much a possibility." Having crossed Kubrick's path so often, having influenced, obstructed and ultimately earned his respect, Spielberg now finds himself in an entirely new relationship to Kubrick, as his officially approved successor. It is a shift that Harlan and the rest of the Kubrick estate seem entirely satisfied with. "There's really no one else who could have done it apart from Spielberg. I'm more than happy about it; I'm ecstatic. It's exactly what Stanley would have wanted. Well, second best to living."

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Fight Club | The Blade | Brokedown Palace | Detroit Rock City
fields.trailText: Fight Club | The Blade | Brokedown Palace | Detroit Rock City
fields.body:
Fight Club
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 18
*****

An outrageous, witty broadside against consumerism and a handbook in applied anarchy, Fight Club is more radical than smashing up McDonald's; it also treats its audience with exceptional intelligence, is bursting with ideas and has fun with concepts like "time", "taste", "Nietzsche" and "knuckle sandwich".

It acts as a critique of Hollywood too, by reminding you just how little you expect from studio product in terms of making you think about life and how much they pander to the lowest common denominator. And, what I like best, it does all this in a nonchalant, offhand way as if insomnia, faking testicular cancer, vibrating luggage, subliminal pornography in family cartoons and "selling rich women their own fat asses back to them" were everyday subject matter.

This reflects enormous credit on everyone: director David Fincher bleaches out the colour and light as usual - but, by his standards, there is a light touch here; Brad Pitt's best previous role was Fincher's Seven, this tops it; Edward Norton is riveting as usual, a terrific, manic lead; Helena Bonham Carter is convincingly disgraceful in the sort of role you'd expect to go to screen slut queens like Rose McGowan or Juliette Lewis. And there's Meat Loaf as you've never seen him before.

Fight Club is sly as a fox. It hits you in the ribs and never lets you settle. It has tremendous narrative drive, but it never goes where you think it will and you never quite know how you got to where you are. It bears hardly any relation to mainstream cinema but has some connection to jam, Delicatessen and Face/Off.

It has one major flaw too: a plot twist that works against everything that came before and slightly spoils the last half-hour (that's in Chuck Pahlaniuk's book as well as all those ideas). But nobody's perfect. Set against that an inspired soundtrack with apposite use of Tom Waits and The Pixies and a brilliant conclusion. It's tops for after-dinner chat too: "The condom is the glass slipper of our generation": discuss.

The Blade
Retail (£12.99/ £13.99) and DVD (£19.99)
Hong Kong Classics Cert 18
***

Hong Kong action in the grand style with Tsui Hark's thoroughly cinematic epic. The camerawork makes the action stand out, but frenzied scenes are mixed with poetic moments. Yin and yang are balanced with a female voiceover from Ling, who sets two men against each other in the foundry ("I could give her my sword any time" is a very untypical subtitle). Our hero loses an arm in saving her but turns himself into a one-armed whirling dervish of vengeance against the bandits. You soon forget the plot but the visuals stick like a dream.

Brokedown Palace
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 12
**

A familiar tale of two innocents abroad who wind up in a Thai jail after drugs are found in their luggage. As the contrasting friends, Claire Danes and Kate Beckinsale are very watchable, but the film suffers the usual US bias - Yank Bill Pullman comes to the rescue while the locals are as deceitful as the Australian who tricked the girls - and succumbs to an unlikely tearjerker ending. Among the horrors in a cockroach-infested jail is Amanda de Cadenet's "cockney" accent. By George, I don't think she's got it. One to forget in director Jonathan Kaplan's bad girls CV.

Detroit Rock City
Rental
New Line Cert 15
*

Subtle as a six-inch flare with a vomit-stained paisley insert, this comedy takes us to Cobo Hall, Detroit, 1978, mecca for a thousand Spinal Tap-esque bands. Four kids from Cleveland are determined to see their heroes, KISS, there and, like, their parents don't want them to go. Phew, that's the plot taken care of. KISS is the band that made the Ramones look like Einstein and this amiable clunker makes their Rock 'n' Roll High School look like... something you'd rather be watching. The soundtrack disinters 70s horrors Ted Nugent, Styx and Nazareth. Aaargh!

fields.headline: Man On The Moon
fields.standfirst: Jim Carrey stars in a respectful tribute to America's oddest stand-up comedian. But Peter Bradshaw   finds it solemnly one-paced
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Carrey plays Kaufman the same throughout, in good times and bad, with no growth and no progression... Milos Forman opts for a very easy, cloying sentimentality to close his film about a difficult, bloody-minded comedian
fields.body:
Films about great comics have a similar problem to films about (fictional) painters. You can show the painter being brilliant and drunk in a cafe, or brilliant and angry with agent or gallery-owner, or brilliant and inspired in his atèlier. But sooner or later the camera has to peep, however cursorily, at what is actually on the canvas, and risk all that assumed brilliance looking a bit thin. The problem arises with the short and troubled life of Andy Kaufman, the subject of Man On The Moon. A volatile stand-up-comedian-cum-situationist-hoaxer, Kaufman is now remembered here, if at all, for his squeaky-voiced Latka in the early 80s TV show Taxi.

But he was also a cult figure in the US for his anarchic performances on Saturday Night Live, Letterman, Johnny Carson and playing live on the lucrative college circuit or in Vegas as his alter ego, the appalling lounge singer Tony Clifton. Jim Carrey, in a solemn and conspicuous act of ancestor worship, plays Kaufman, and Milos Forman directs: a return to his familiar themes of madness and creative inspiration. But we never get much more than a few seconds' continuous showing of Kaufman's act, his "comedy canvas", and maybe that is as it should be.

The film does an efficient sleight-of-hand job of suggesting comic genius: Kaufman dying on stage at the Improv club; cut to shot of audience looking baffled and irritated; cut to shot of Kaufman ploughing on; cut to audience smiling, shrugging, starting to laugh. And afterwards,Kaufman's agent George Shapiro (Danny DeVito) chuckles prescriptively: "You're insane! But you might also be brilliant!" QED.

Man On The Moon cannot risk attempting to be funny on its own account; it has to establish a complementary tone of respectful, bittersweet drama as a showcase for the implied comic genius. And considering how profoundly conservative American network television was and is, it is remarkable how far Kaufman was allowed to go: mad stunts on air, attacking and humiliating the audience, "a single-minded pursuit of anarchy" from which he appears never to have been spiritually seduced by a parallel career in a top-rated middle-of-the-road network TV show. (Judd Hirsch and most of the original cast of Taxi appear in the film, unsmilingly enduring once again the trial of looking like pedestrian schmucks compared to Kaufman's mercurial talent, but not DeVito, who has interestingly promoted himself out of the Taxi cast to play someone in on the gag.) But this wild and crazy guy died from lung cancer at the age of 35, a career move which took him into the realm of legend and away from playing, say, the silver-haired lead in Father of the Bride 2.

What could and should have been interesting about Andy Kaufman's life is how he reacted to failure: he had hardly reached the top when public and fellow artists alike wearied of being his straight man, and turned against him. He was getting a bad press and was voted off Saturday Night Live in a viewers' phone poll that Kaufman clearly believed he would win: a rare stunt of which he was not in control.

But Carrey plays Kaufman the same throughout, in good times and bad, with no growth and no progression, with the same blinking, moon-faced detachment, a sort of halfway-house between Kaufman's weird, deadpan live act and an assumed professional backstage reserve. One of the most incredible things about Kaufman is his self-appointed position as World Inter-Gender Wrestling Champion, challenging women, quite genuinely, to wrestle him.

At the time, this was considered the nadir of jarring unfunniness: the very quintessence of being on the comedic skids. But now, in its magnificent lack of taste, it looks like an inspired take on the sex wars: with Kaufman as a cross between Norman Mailer and Bobby Riggs. It is a pity that Forman didn't expand this gloriously offensive part of Kaufman's career. And it only hints at the final irony: when Kaufman had to tell his family he was dying of cancer, his furious sister contemptuously suspected him of staging the ultimate, bad-taste stunt. In real life, Kaufman claimed to have met Elvis Presley by smuggling himself into the kitchen of the Las Vegas Hilton. This meeting is not dramatised on screen: perhaps because that might overload the Troubled Genius quotient.

But in his final scene, Forman hints at an Elvis-style resurrection for Andy, suggesting that he might actually have faked his death after all. Well, let's assume Andy Kaufman is up in Valhalla with John Belushi, while Robin Williams, Chevy Chase, Dan Aykroyd and Eddie Murphy labour in the world of mediocrity below, what is the point of Kaufman's career?

The family is shown to be upset at what they suspect is Andy's Ultimate Cancer Put-On, but the next thing we know they have come to terms with it, and uncomplicatedly embrace Andy's career in its tragic final act: a tear-jerking final concert in Carnegie Hall: a very tame ending for his comedy guerrilla, like Che Guevera joining the Liberal Democrats. Milos Forman opts for a very easy, cloying sentimentality to close his film about a difficult, bloody-minded comedian.

webTitle: Ministers offer congratulations through gritted teeth

fields.headline: Ministers offer congratulations through gritted teeth
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Labour ministers moved quickly last night to accept Ken Livingstone's victory, as they congratulated their former parliamentary colleague hours after deriding his campaign.
fields.body:
Labour ministers moved quickly last night to accept Ken Livingstone's victory, as they congratulated their former parliamentary colleague hours after deriding his campaign.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, was first to congratulate the former GLC leader. Through gritted teeth, he told BBC1's election special: "Let's say to Ken: 'Congratulations, if you've won. Let's work together.' "

Other ministers indicated that they were prepared to live with Mr Livingstone as long as he did not use his power base to attack the government.

"It is a two-way street," said the leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett.

Trevor Phillips, who stood as Frank Dobson's deputy, insisted that Labour would soon recover from the setback. "It isn't exactly a government in trouble," he said. "Of course we are disappointed. Of course we are going to learn lessons. The next time we have to be more transparent, more open about the way we do our selection."

Stephen Pound, the Labour MP who decided to throw his weight behind Mr Dobson after voicing support for Mr Livingstone, thought the result would inevitably spell trouble. "I have known Ken for many years and the usual corollary of knowing Ken is that I don't particularly like him," Mr Pound said. "He is the ultimate non-team player."

Diane Abbott, the Labour leftwinger who has criticised the Labour party's handling of the Livingstone affair, said she had voted first for Mr Dobson but had shown her support for the former GLC leader by voting for him with her second preference vote. She said: "The personal attacks played very badly."

Labour sources, who have spent months pondering a Livingstone victory, were dismayed at having to deal with a man they see as a natural oppositionist. One Millbank source said: "Ken and the government is like a dog and a lamppost. He just can't resist it."

Labour will reel out a series of sophisticated excuses for Mr Livingstone's victories over the weekend. Nick Raynsford, the London minister who briefly put his name forward as the Labour candidate for mayor, came up with the most ingenuous excuse last night. He said the result was the fault of Margaret Thatcher, for abolishing the GLC in 1986 without a vote. Londoners had been deprived of their democratic vote in the 1980s and they were now throwing their weight behind the man who was in charge at the time.

Steve Norris, the Tory who beat Mr Dobson into second place, said Mr Livingstone's expected failure to win more 50% first preference votes meant he would be restricted.

Mr Norris said: "London was asked to choose between action and politics and on current evidence it seems to have given Ken Livingstone merely a conditional mandate - if this trend continues he will be on probation as London's mayor. I am delighted to have reached out to Londoners who would never previously considered voting Conservative."

Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat candidate, said her campaign had attracted many new supporters to her party: "We have run a good campaign, we've framed the issues and it looks as though we might hold the balance of power in the London assembly."

Mr Livingstone said he was delighted to be in power in London after his enforced absence of 14 years. "It is a quite wonderful feeling. I never thought I would be back."

He said it was now time to "draw a line in the sand" after the election and promised to "establish a system of government that sets a model for the rest of Britain as we move towards directly elected mayors."

fields.headline: Byelection stuns Tories
fields.trailText:
William Hague's Tories suffered a crushing defeat in the Romsey byelection early today, as the Liberal Democrats overturned a
   Tory majority of more than 8,000 to snatch the traditionally true blue seat.
fields.body:
William Hague's Tories suffered a crushing defeat in the Romsey byelection early today, as the Liberal Democrats overturned a Tory majority of more than 8,000 to snatch the traditionally true blue seat.

In a stunning political upset, the Lib Dems' Sandra Gidley captured 19,571 votes to Tory Tim Palmer's 16,260, a majority of 3,311. The Labour candidate Andrew Howard lost his deposit with 1,451 votes.

In a sometimes bitter contest, marked by rows over Mr Hague's asylum policies, the swing was 12.5% from the Lib Dems to the Tories. It represents one of the few occasions of the past 100 years when the opposition party has lost a seat in a byelection.

The loss of the once-safe Hampshire seat, made vacant when old-school Tory Michael Colvin died in a fire at his home last February, is a devastating blow both for the Tories and for Mr Hague's leadership.

Ms Gidley said: "This is a sensational result. We have reminded people of what the Conservatives did in the 18 years that they were in government. People having been reminded are not ready to forgive."

The Romsey result took the gloss off an otherwise encouraging night for Tories as the party achieved its best local election results in nearly a decade, far outstripping Mr Hague's expectations.

Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy was jubilant: "By giving William Hague's Conservative party a bloody nose in Romsey we are proving definitively that his far-right saloon-bar politics are not fooling the country's voters."

The Tory campaign chief, John Hayes, said: "Clearly, as often in byelections, this is a freak result. The Labour party's result has completely collapsed and the Lib Dems have benefited accordingly."

Victory for the Lib Dems came after a hyperactive campaign, which saw the party flood hundreds of activists into the seat. The Tories got off to a slower start and failed to motivate more than their core support to visit the polling booths.

The Lib Dems' success relied significantly on wooing tactical Labour voters anxious to keep out the Tories, and on attracting disaffected former supporters of both other parties. They tempted switchers by stressing the local credentials of their candidate.

In the local elections Labour was toppled from power in heartland areas including Oldham and Hartlepool. The Tories also won back Eastbourne, which they last controlled in 1988, and the former Tory bastions of Southend-on-Sea and Stratford-on-Avon, which the party lost in 1994.

A Labour inquest was launched after the Tories won back symbolically important councils such as Solihull, the first time they will have controlled a metropolitan district council since 1995.

fields.headline: Livingstone stares victory in the face
fields.standfirst:
But the full result is not due until 10am
London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Final polls put Ken Livingstone firmly on course to fulfil his long-held ambition to return to London government as the new directly elected mayor of London.
fields.body:
Final polls put Ken Livingstone firmly on course to fulfil his long-held ambition to return to London government as the new directly elected mayor of London.

A Mori poll pointed to a victory for the former leader of the Greater London Council. It showed Mr Livingstone coming first with 46% of the votes after first preference votes, Conservative candidate Steven Norris following in second place with 23%, Labour's Frank Dobson third on 14%, and the Liberal Democrat's Susan Kramer on 11%.

In the second round, it predicted Mr Livingstone would claim 21%, and Mr Norris 15% - making Mr Livingstone the clear winner on 67% overall.

"It is a quite wonderful feeling. I never thought I would be back," the former leader of the GLC said, although he cautioned that the polls were "a bit generous".

Both the Labour and Conservative parties have privately conceded that Mr Livingstone, who narrowly lost the official Labour nomination to Frank Dobson, would win this ballot.

But a series of computer failures with the new electronic system of counting the votes is set to delay the full, formal announcement of Mr Livingstone's victory until 10am.

Dust in the air caused by table coverings clogged up the computers at the count in Enfield, north London, forcing returning officer Rob Hughes to announce that the official result will not be made until mid-morning at the earliest.

"This is a brand new system, a brand new system of voting and a brand new system of counting. It isn't surprising we have had a few problems," he said.

Despite enduring what he called an "absolutely vile campaign from start to finish", Mr Livingstone was in a conciliatory mood before heading home from the Westminster counting centre shortly after 2am.

The former Labour MP said it was now time to "draw a line in the sand" and promised to "establish a system of government that sets a model for the rest of Britain as we move towards directly elected mayors."

With government ministers also offering words of reconciliation, Mr Livingstone, who was expelled last month for running against Mr Dobson, said he would apply to rejoin the Labour party.

Education and employment secretary David Blunkett, a fierce critic of Mr Livingstone, said: "Let's say to Ken: Congratulations, if you've won. Let's work together.'" Leader of the Commons Margaret Beckett also told reporters that relations between Downing Street and Mr Livingstone were "a two-way street".

Meanwhile, Mr Norris said he was still "not discounting the prospect of victory", but admitted he would not be staying up for the result.

"Whatever will have happened, we will have done a very good job in the election. I am very proud of my team. I think they are just fantastic and I don't think anybody doubts that we really caught up huge ground."

"We are going to be a massive new influence in London politics," Mr Johnson said, although the rumour that Mr Livingstone could make him his deputy appeared confounded by Mr Livingstone's comment yesterday that his deputy would be someone with previous experience of government.

fields.headline: Local triumph for Tories
fields.standfirst: Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservative party made considerable gains throughout the country in yesterday's local elections, in contrast to Labour's worst performance in years.
fields.body:
The Conservative party made considerable gains throughout the country in yesterday's local elections, in contrast to Labour's worst performance in years.

The latest results show the Conservatives securing 533 seats and gaining the upper hand in 16 new councils, including the symbolic seat of Solihull - the first time they will have controlled a metropolitan district council since 1995.

The Tory success in the West Midlands, where the battle for the survival of Rover is being fought, will lead to comments that the government is being penalised for the possible job losses at the Longbridge plant, even though the Longbridge ward in Birmingham city council was held by Labour.

The Tories made a particularly strong show in the south-west, taking control of Torbay and Plymouth, comfortably overshooting their initial target of 400 seats, the number they were aiming to regain at this stage in the electoral cycle, when the opposition traditionally does well at the expense of the government.

Labour meanwhile lost 13 councils and 546 seats, including Bradford, Oldham, Worcester, Portsmouth, Hartlepool, Walsall and Chorley.

BBC polling predicted that in the local elections, the Tories would win 37% of the vote, Labour 30% and the Liberal Democrats 28%. That would represent a 10% swing from Labour to the Conservatives since the general election.

The Liberal Democrats gained one council and 10 seats in the 3,360 seats which were being contested in 153 towns across Britain.

It looked like an increasingly bad night for Labour, facing a likely Ken Livingstone victory in the London mayoral vote and a poor showing in the Romsey byelection, where as little as 4% of the votes have been predicted to go to Tony Blair's party.

The scale of the losses will alarm the government, despite Labour being resigned to losing a significant number of the seats it won in 1996 at the height of John Major's unpopularity.

One Labour source said: "Overall, we are losing hundreds of seats, but it's in a containable range. The Tories are failing to show any breakthrough."

Another Labour spokesman said the party's performance in the local elections had been hampered by a "very, very low turnout".

Despite several authorities experimenting with new voting systems to encourage higher turnout, including longer opening hours and electronic voting, it appeared many voters had stayed away from the polling booths.

The national average turnout for local elections is usually around 30%, but in one inner city ward in Liverpool just 11% of those entitled to vote turned out, while at nearby St Helens, the figure was just over 16% in four wards.

fields.headline: Tories take key councils
fields.trailText: The Conservatives showed the first signs of a real recovery early today when they swept back into power in a series of local councils across England, achieving their best local election results in nearly a decade - far outstripping William Hague's hopes of 400-plus gains.
fields.body:
The Conservatives showed the first signs of a real recovery early today when they swept back into power in a series of local councils across England, achieving their best local election results in nearly a decade - far outstripping William Hague's hopes of 400-plus gains.

Labour ministers were forced to admit that they had failed to inspire their core voters as the party was toppled from power in heartland areas, including Oldham and Peter Mandelson's base in Hartlepool.

A Labour inquest was launched after the Tories won back symbolically important councils such as Solihull, the first time they will have controlled a metropolitan district council since 1995. The Tory success in the West Midlands will fuel fears that the government is being punished over the threat of job losses at the Longbridge Rover plant, though Longbridge ward in Birmingham city council was held by Labour.

The Tories also won back Eastbourne, which they last controlled in 1988, and the former Tory bastions of Southend-on-Sea and Stratford-on-Avon, which the party lost in 1994.

The party also won Rossendale from Labour, which the Tories last controlled in 1986, Portsmouth, which they have not controlled since 1990, Great Yarmouth and Hyndburn, both of which they last controlled in 1986, and the former Tory bastion of Torbay, which they lost in 1990.

A BBC poll predicted that the Tories would win 37% of the overall vote in the local elections, with Labour on 30% and the Liberal Democrats on 28%. This would represent a 10% swing from Labour to the Conservatives since the 1997 general election and give the Tories around 400 gains.

The Tories were delighted with the results. A spokesman said: "These results show that there is strong public support for William Hague's recent speeches on asylum seekers and on crime.

"They are also a huge rebuff to the government which is failing to deliver and is out of touch with the electorate."

Despite the Conservatives' joy, party strategists will know that last night's results do not yet represent enough of an impact to challenge Labour at a general election.

The Tories were bound to do well last night because Labour is defending seats it won in 1996, which was at the height of John Major's unpopularity.

Labour had been braced for mid-term setbacks. The home secretary, Jack Straw, admitted that it was "worrying" that Labour's traditional supporters appeared to be staying at home and blamed the feebleness of Mr Hague's opposition.

Labour officials called the losses "containable" but some MPs predicted that it would delay the coming general election.

webTitle: Tories back on the map after heartland wins

fields.headline: Tories back on the map after heartland wins
fields.standfirst: Symbolic successes as Torbay, Eastbourne and Solihull are recaptured
fields.trailText: William Hague always knew he would do well in yesterday's local council elections after the Tory meltdown in the mid-1990s, when Labour captured seats across the country in Conservative heartlands.
fields.body:
William Hague always knew he would do well in yesterday's local council elections after the Tory meltdown in the mid-1990s, when Labour captured seats across the country in Conservative heartlands.

But the Tory leader was delighted by the size of his gains, estimated to be more than 400, which independent electoral experts described as a strong showing.

The Conservatives have at last regained councils, such as Torbay and Eastbourne, in what were once their heartland areas. Their success in Solihull also has great symbolic significance as the Tories win back control of their first metropolitan district council since 1995.

One of the Tories' strongest results came in Torbay, the one council in the West Country that Mr Hague was determined to win back. The Tories lost control of the 36-seat council in 1990 and suffered the humiliation of holding just five seats in the mid-990s.

But last night they gained 19 seats, to secure 32 of the 36 seats. The Liberal Democrats, who hold the local parliamentary seat by a mere 12 seats, will be horrified after they lost 14 seats, taking them down to just four seats.

Richard Cumming, Torbay's new Tory leader, said during the campaign that the Tories had to do well in Torbay to show that they were back on the electoral map. He said last night that his strong performance, after Mr Hague made two trips to Devon coastal resort during the campaign, shows that the Tory leader's controversial speeches over the past month have paid off.

Tory strategists were also relieved to have won back Solihull in the West Midlands, suggesting that fears over the job losses at Longbridge may be translating into votes. The Tories needed two gains to win back the council, but they managed to win back four seats. Conservatives last controlled the council in 1991 after ruling it continuously from the 1970s.

The other symbolic wins for the Tories include:

 Eastbourne, which the Tories have not controlled since the late 1980s. Conservatives gained three seats on the council to win 18 seats on the council to the Lib Dems' 12. The two parties have been tied at 15 seats each.

 Stratford-on-Avon, which the Tories lost in 1994. The Tories gained four seats to win 28 seats on the council to 18 for the Lib Dems. The council has been under no overall control since the mid-1990s.

 Rossendale, which the Tories lost back in 1986. The Tories gained nine seats, with Labour losing nine, making it one of the few councils with councillors from only the two main parties.

 Amber Valley, which the Tories lost in 1991. The Conservatives were particularly pleased with the result in the Derbyshire council where they won 21 seats, with Labour losing 20 seats. The result will be bad news for the two Labour MPs whose seats are in the council boundaries.

 Cherwell, which the Tories lost in 1995. The Tories gained seven seats, with Labour losing six.

 Great Yarmouth, which the Tories lost in 1986. They gained seven seats, with Labour losing seven and overall control of the council. The result will please the Tories because independent polling experts predicted that Labour would hold the council.

 Hyndburn, which the Tories lost in 1986. The Tories won eight seats, with Labour losing the same number. The Tories will also be delighted by the result in the Lancashire council because the result was predicted as a dead heat.

Before the Tories get too carried away with last night's results, wiser heads will remind the party that they are still a long way from challenging Labour at the general election. The Conservatives were bound to do well last night because Labour was defending seats in areas it was surprised to win in the mid-1990s, when the Tories plummeted to an all-time low.

But the poor Labour showing will encourage the Tories. Labour lost control of the symbolically important Basildon council. When the Tories won the parliamentary seat at the 1992 general election, John Major knew he was back on course for victory.

Lab lost Basildon to no overall control after losing three seats, with the Tories gaining seven. This delighted the Tories because pollsters predicted that Labour would hold on to the council, which it won in 1996.

The results will also worry Peter Mandelson, who saw his local council of Hartlepool fall from Labour hands into no overall control after two decades of control. Labour had been expected to hold onto the council. Russel Hart, the Labour leader, said before the election: "I don't think we will lose control, but I'd be foolhardy if I suggested we will not lose any seats."

All sides were depressed by the low turnout. But Labour officials took some comfort from the experiment with early voting - where pilot schemes allowed people to vote days in advance in places including supermarkets.

Counting machines in the London constituency of Enfield and Haringey were blighted by technical problems which might delay the official announcement of mayor, Labour sources said.

Experiments with electronic counting were not confined to London. It was also being used for the first time in Bury, Salford, and the Hertfordshire districts of Broxbourne and Three Rivers.

DRS, a manufacturer of data recognition technology, specialises in electronic scanning of ballot papers. The company processes more than 10m British exam papers each year.

Latest estimates suggested that the London count would take between seven and 10 hours, depending on the turn- out, and that the need for re-counts should be eliminated.

One electoral official predicted: "I am sure it will work. The machines are incredibly accurate. They are more accurate than human beings, but rather slow." And any folded papers would still have to be dealt with by hand.

He went on: "Obviously the government was determined to go for something which sounded modern. But in reality we could have got a much quicker count by hand.

"This is an interim, evolutionary stage. You really want electronic voting and counting in one. Then it will be worth doing."

webTitle: Europe defence force will need 180,000 troops

fields.headline: Europe defence force will need 180,000 troops
fields.standfirst: Germany faces pressure to contribute despite cuts
fields.trailText: Up to 180,000 troops will be needed if the European Union is to establish a credible defence capability, the Europe minister, Keith Vaz, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Up to 180,000 troops will be needed if the European Union is to establish a credible defence capability, the Europe minister, Keith Vaz, said yesterday.

The EU is planning a conference this year at which member states will be expected to make radical and expensive commitments to a new European expeditionary force capable of imposing peace in trouble spots such as the Balkans.

The force, agreed in principle at the Helsinki EU summit, is due to be in place by June 2003.

The "capabilities pledging conference", initially proposed by the British, is seen as the only way in which to pressurise some EU nations into making the commitments necessary to create a force intended to be 60,000 strong and capable of going into the field for a year.

Under questioning by Lord Inge, former chief of the British defence staff, Mr Vaz conceded that a force 60,000 strong at a single time may require an overall fighting pool of 180,000 troops.

Mr Vaz told a hearing of the Lords EU select committee: "Distinguished military people have put to me the 3-1 ratio. Soldiers have to rest and eat. They are human beings."

British defence chiefs are not publicly naming the countries they fear will not properly contribute to the EU defence force, but the Foreign Office is alarmed that Germany is already spending less than 2% of gross domestic product on defence and Chancellor Schröder is now imposing defence cuts.

Mr Vaz said: "It is not for a British minister of Europe to tell Germany what to spend, but it is right to remind all countries what they have signed up to at Helsinki."

He also accepted Lord Inge's assertion that serious gaps existed in Europe's capability, including heavy lift, communications and intelligence.

Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary general, and Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, have also been disturbed by the scale of defence cuts envisaged in Germany.

General Klaus Naumann, the chairman of the Nato military committee until last year, told the Lords hearing that Germany could contribute a two-brigade division, but the recent German defence budget was "absolutely insuffi cient to meet the requirements of Helsinki".

The capabilities conference will produce a "headline catalogue" setting out the force's needs for different scenarios, including crisis management, conflict resolution and peacekeeping.

Ministers said this week they envisage the capabilities conference as a series of negotiating sessions in which individual nations make offers of troops, shortfalls are identified and member states are then "required" to remedy the shortfall. Each country's proposed contribution would then be collectively agreed.

The Helsinki summit in December agreed to set up a corps, or 15 brigades, by June 2003 capable of carrying out a range of tasks, including peace enforcement.

Ministers are aware that the Conservatives in the run-up to next year's likely general election will represent the plan as a commitment to a full-time standing Euro army, which will in the long term undermine Nato and decouple the US from Europe.

Most EU capitals accept that they were acutely embarrassed by their reliance on the the US for the Nato-led operation in Kosovo.

Ministers are aware that the Conservatives in the run-up to next year's likely general election will represent the plan as a commitment to a full-time standing Euro army, which will in the long term undermine Nato and decouple the US from Europe. Most EU capitals accept that they were acutely embarrassed by their reliance on the the US for the Nato-led operation in Kosovo.

webTitle: Heavenly alignment excites astrologers, but no one else

fields.headline: Heavenly alignment excites astrologers, but no one else
fields.trailText: To astrologers it is the event of the century - until the next one, anyway. But you won't see it, you won't feel it, and, as far as astronomers are concerned, it is no more than a scientific curiosity.
fields.body:
To astrologers it is the event of the century - until the next one, anyway. But you won't see it, you won't feel it, and, as far as astronomers are concerned, it is no more than a scientific curiosity.

At shortly after 8am today, all seven classical bodies of the solar system - Venus, Jupiter, Mars, Saturn, Mercury, the sun and the moon - will be in an alignment with earth tighter than any seen since 1962.

The sun will prevent anyone from seeing the alignment, but if they could they would see the planets and the moon bunched across the sky only 25 degrees apart.

"These coincidences do happen from time to time," said Roderick Willstrop of the Institute of Astronomy in Cambridge. "The physical effects are negligible."

In the past, doomsaying writers have exploited planetary alignments to gull bookbuyers with warnings of earthquakes or icecap upheavals caused by the combined gravitational force of the sun, the moon and the planets.

The dull reality is that the sun itself exerts on our world half the tidal force of the moon - the main influence on our tides - while the next most influential planet, Venus, exerts less than one hundred thousandth of that.

For all his inability to stop the tide coming in, King Canute exerted more gravitational power over the waves than Mars does when it is at its closest.

This still leaves the field clear for the astrologers. Jonathan Cainer, the stargazer in the Daily Express, took a double-page spread in the tabloid yesterday to gush predictions linked to "the most important astrological event for 1,500 years".

With the uncanny prescience that has made him rich, he summed up the significance of the alignment thus: "Watch the news carefully during the next few weeks. Expect several stories that make you sit up and take notice."

webTitle: Sharp rise in convictions a blow to pro-cannabis lobby

fields.headline: Sharp rise in convictions a blow to pro-cannabis lobby
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The number of people convicted for cannabis possession has more than doubled in the past six years to over 40,000 a year, according to new Home Office figures which deal a bodyblow to the idea that the police are taking a more lenient approach to soft drugs.
fields.body:
The number of people convicted for cannabis possession has more than doubled in the past six years to over 40,000 a year, according to new Home Office figures which deal a bodyblow to the idea that the police are taking a more lenient approach to soft drugs.

This evidence of the increasingly tough enforcement of the drug laws in Britain coincides with a decision by the country's chief constables to start introducing drug testing for police officers for alcohol and illegal substances.

New guidelines will recommend drug testing initially for new recruits and then for those in specialist squads such as firearms units.

Although primarily designed as a welfare policy, those who fail to take the tests or test positive for illegal drugs will face disciplinary action.

The Home Office figures published yesterday confirm conventional wisdom that there has been a sharp rise in the number of occasions that the police let off with a caution somebody found in possession of cannabis. But they explode the myth that this has been accompanied by a rapid decline in criminal prosecution for cannabis possession.

The number of people con victed for cannabis possession rose in England and Wales from 26,600 in 1996 to 40,199 in 1998. During the same period the numbers of people arrested for cannabis possession and released with a caution rose from 38,000 to 48,000.

Drugs law reform campaigners last night were dismayed by the official figures.

The influential Police Foundation report published last month called for the depenalisation of cannabis possession so that prosecution in the courts would become the exception rather than the rule.

Figures giving a breakdown for 1998 show that more than 60% of those arrested for all drug offences in Gloucestershire and Cleveland were released with a caution, compared with fewer than 30% of those arrested for the same offence in West Yorkshire, Thames Valley and Durham.

On Merseyside and in the Thames Valley drug offenders were much more likely to be convicted and fined.

In Durham, 25% of convicted drug offenders are sent to prison, in South Yorkshire 15% and in Humberside 14%. Jail is least likely to be the outcome for cannabis smokers arrested in Surrey (4%) and Gloucestershire (3%).

In London, where the bulk of drug offenders are arrested, 61% are cautioned, 22% fined and 5% imprisoned.

A Home Office spokesman said it was difficult to explain the sharp increase in both convictions and cautioning by the police for cannabis possession in the last two years but that it could reflect a growth in the numbers using cannabis or a tougher enforcement regime.

Drug law reform campaigners put the blame on police guidelines, issued three years ago, designed to reduce the amount of repeat cautioning of offenders.

Danny Kushlick of the drugs campaign Transform said: "These figures show that decriminalisation is as far away as ever."

webTitle: They were just watching This is Your Life. Then a fireball rained down from the sky

fields.headline: They were just watching This is Your Life. Then a fireball rained down from the sky
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: Terror, a fireball like a nuclear explosion and bodies littering the streets of Lockerbie were described yesterday on the second day of the trial of two Libyan men accused of the bombing.
fields.byline: Gerard Seenan  and  Ian Black in Camp Zeist
fields.body:
Terror, a fireball like a nuclear explosion and bodies littering the streets of Lockerbie were described yesterday on the second day of the trial of two Libyan men accused of the bombing.

Witnesses to the December 1988 disaster told the Scottish court at Camp Zeist in the Netherlands of a screeching roar before a firebomb lit up the sky and burning debris rained down. Within minutes, they were stepping over parts of the stricken plane and trying to cover up corpses on the ground.

"It looked like an atomic bomb," said Ian Wood, 37, from Lockerbie, recalling the fierce heat and blast as part of the aircraft exploded, sending a ball of fire high into the night sky.

Much of the horror came through the very ordinariness of the events that were interrupted as the Jumbo came down. Many witnesses said they had been watching This is Your Life on television moments before the disaster.

Jasmine Bell, a social worker, said she had been delivering Christmas food parcels to the Borders town at around 7pm when she first heard the noise of the falling plane. Mrs Bell, 53, shaking as she gave evidence, said her brother shouted: "It's a plane, get down." She looked up and, at about roof height, a piece of shiny grey metal debris she thought was a small plane hurtled past. Almost immediately, pockets of fire began to break out in front of her and she backed away toward her brother's home.

"I ducked down and my brother had dived into the garage. Within seconds there was fire just raining down. It's the only way I can describe it.

"There was fire all around me, there were burning objects and the fire was falling down from the sky and as it landed on the ground I was stepping backwards to avoid the fire. I stepped back and back until my back was against the wall of the house and I couldn't go any further.

"The fire was still coming down and I thought I was going to be burned."

Outside, a couple carrying two small children were looking for help and Mrs Bell, accompanied by her teenage son, went to their aid. "My son looked down and said, 'What is that mum?' and my first reaction was it's OK it's just meat, and then I registered it wasn't meat," she said.

"Everything was burning - the driveway, the lawn, the hedges, the rooftops."

She said she and her brother went into the street and had to jump over small "campfires" everywhere.

Many houses were on fire and they went along the street to help people and get them out of their burning homes.

Later she stumbled over an object that she later realised was part of a human body. "I recalled seeing in my brother's garden and he had put white cloths around. There were parts of bodies and he had covered them."

Roland Stevenson, a retired engineer from Dumfries, described the "thunderous black mass" that fell from the sky. He said he had shouted to people to run for cover as debris from the aircraft - including an entire wing - rained down. It started as the noise of thunder, he said, then developed into an orange fireball hurtling towards Sherwood Crescent.

Mr Stevenson, 65, said he was at the town's railway station to meet his daughter. He waited in his car listening to the radio. Her train had arrived. Then he heard a noise. "My first thought was that the train was over-revving its engines. It got progressively louder and became thunderous. I got out of the car.

"I saw an object coming from the north. It was a black mass showing some form of lights. A small flame. Enough for me to see the dark shape and the passage of the object. It was coming down on what I would call a glide path, at a shallow angle."

Then he told of seeing an entire wing, without engines, plummeting from the sky. "The whole of the wing was descending vertically straight down. I could see it wing tip to wing tip, a clean wing, silhouetted against the clouds from the town lights. A rolling ball of fire was descending rapidly from the sky.

"In the ball of flame I could see objects descending, black objects hurtling down towards the Sherwood Crescent end of the town. After the wing had crashed down I saw a door panel which came shimmering down in the night sky, silver, very clearly visible."

There were other objects too, said Mr Stevenson. "They were possibly seat sections. They were coming down very rapidly."

As objects rained down his daughter emerged from the station. "I told her to get back under cover. People came out of the nearby public house. I shouted to them to get under cover because there were objects falling from the sky."

Kevin Anderson, 35, a plasterer from Tundergarth, three miles from Lockerbie, told the court how the plane's cockpit came down in the field opposite his house. He thought the explosion was "atomic, like you see on the telly".

But the reality of the situation struck Mr Anderson immediately when he noticed, among the chaos, that what appeared to be the nose of a plane, decapitated from the fuselage, had landed around 100 yards from his house. Mr Anderson said he took a torch and went to investigate - and had his worst fears confirmed.

"I looked inside the cockpit with the torch," he said. "There were bodies lying around the cockpit. I went to get my father-in-law from his house about 100 yards up the road. We went over to the cockpit to see if anyone was alive. I had a torch. We looked inside the cockpit. I could see the pilot."

Stewart Kirkpatrick, who found the body of a young woman a few feet from his front doorstep, said he had suffered from alopecia and psychological problems since the accident. He said it had taken years for normal life to return to Lockerbie. "I do my best just not think about it," he told the court.

He described how he rescued an elderly neighbour whose house had been almost destroyed by debris from the plane.

He and his family were in their home in Rosebank Crescent when they heard a loud noise and went outside to see a "great big fireball" shooting up into the air. Mr Kirkpatrick told the court he heard screaming from Ella Ramsden's house and dashed to the scene.

Wreckage had landed right on top of the house, destroying everything but her kitchen - the room Mrs Ramsden, 70, happened to be in.

Mr Kirkpatrick said: "The rest had all fallen down and rubble was up to the height of her windowsill. I broke the kitchen window but she wouldn't come out without her dog so I lifted it out though the window and handed it to someone. Then I lifted her out."

He told how he later saw Mrs Ramsden's house on the television news. "It was quite hard to believe she was in the kitchen, the only place that was whole. She was a very lucky lady."

Robert Peacock, 63, heard a thunderous noise and watched the plane spewing burning fuel from his home at Hightay, six miles away. Asked where it was heading, he replied: "Straight for Lockerbie."

All 259 passengers and crew on the flight died instantly. Eleven residents of the town were also killed. Two Libyans, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, deny charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and breaching the Aviation Security Act.

By the second day of the trial, expected to last for over a year, there was already a feeling of routine at Camp Zeist, a former US airbase declared Scottish territory for the duration. There was less bustle and a smaller media presence than on Wednesday. But the trial is progressing much more quickly than anticipated and defence counsel were forced to apologise when the court finished early because they did not have enough witnesses to call.

There was a hint that the trial would give families and observers a chance to hear the many theories surrounding the case. During his cross-examination of Geoffrey Carpenter, 56, the first police officer on the scene, William Taylor QC, counsel for al-Megrahi, asked about FBI officers, one named Al Hendershott, appearing quickly on the scene.

Horror

Mr Carpenter, now retired, said he first noticed something was seriously wrong on the night when his windows began shaking and his doors vibrating. In a matter of minutes, the full horror of the situation was apparent and he began trying to organise what resources he could find.

"I utilised off-duty police officers to evacuate the areas in case of another explosion," he said. "There was a council officer and I asked him if he would open the town hall, church halls and so on." Under cross-examination, he admitted that it had been impossible - with wreckage stretching from Lockerbie in the west to the North Sea in the east - to seal off the scene of the accident properly.

He said journalists were in Lockerbie within hours and the FBI also became involved very quickly, bringing sophisticated modern equipment with them, including digital cameras.

There was a further reminder of how much devastation the bombing wrought on the small town. William Pattie, 53, told the court that his sister-in-law and her husband were among the 11 people who died in Sherwood Crescent when a large part of the plane landed there.

"Their house was blown up. The bungalow just vanished in the crater. I went to see if I could find them, but about half a mile from Sherwood Crescent you couldn't get closer because of the heat. You couldn't see where the house had been for the flames."

The two suspects, dressed yesterday in western clothes, looked on impassively in the witness box throughout. The trial continues today.

fields.headline: Judge reignites self defence row
fields.standfirst: Builder's use of baseball bat to defend home was 'reasonable'
fields.trailText: A judge yesterday reignited the debate over the law on self-defence by asserting that a householder who repeatedly beat a burglar with a metal baseball bat had been using "reasonable force".
fields.body:
A judge yesterday reignited the debate over the law on self-defence by asserting that a householder who repeatedly beat a burglar with a metal baseball bat had been using "reasonable force".

David Summers, 21, a drug addict, suffered a broken wrist, fractured elbow, cracked ribs and a cracked skull. He had broken into the Peterborough home of Lee Gapper, 20, and his lodger George Goodayle, 21, both self-employed builders.

Sentencing Summers to a year in jail for burglary, Judge Hugh Mayor QC said: "They used reasonable force. I am making no allowance for reduction in sentence for any hurt you may have received in a failed attempt of a citizen to arrest you.

"You brought that on yourself and I have no sympathy for those who receive hurt while committing a crime. It is a very serious offence," he told Peterborough crown court.

Summers was arrested minutes after fleeing the house and complained to police that his potential burglary victims had assaulted him.

Mr Gapper and Mr Goodayle were arrested by Cambridgeshire police and held for 12 hours. The crown prosecution service decided not to bring charges against them.

Last week the Tory leader, William Hague, said the law on self-defence should be changed to give greater protection to people who were forced to defend their homes against intruders. He was accused of trying to exploit pub lic outrage at the murder conviction of the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin, who shot dead a teenage burglar.

A Conservative party spokesman said of the Peterborough case yesterday: "In this case the law appears to have operated in a commonsense and reasonable way.

"Our concern has been that one can't always be confident that in cases of this kind the law is on the side of householders using reasonable force in defence of themselves and their property."

Mr Gapper said after the case: "I was told if anything happened to the intruder I could be looking at manslaughter. I was petrified at the time.

"I think it was a disgrace what happened to Tony Martin. It means he is being made out to be a criminal."

Mr Gapper said he kept a baseball bat by his bedside for self-defence. "I think 90% of England has something to use to defend themselves, but I never thought I would use that bat. I acted out of fear. I'm no angel, but I'm not violent.

"I was in bed when I heard this banging on the window downstairs at around 10am. At first I didn't know what it was, then I heard the door being smashed in. I woke George and said I thought someone was in the house and raced downstairs.

"At first, all I could see was the shadow of this man, but as he turned to face me he lifted his arms above his head and I saw he had a spanner in his hand.

"I was face to face with him for a split second before he ran past me and I just hit out. I thought he could have hit me. I hit him first in the back of the head and then twice about his body."

Mr Goodayle said he grabbed the intruder and punched him three to four times: "He deserved what he got."

Mr Gapper added: "I could feel my adrenalin take over my body.

"I could have killed him. Afterwards, I was still shaking, but chased him barefoot out of the house into the street in the rain and people were just standing, watching me."

The court heard that Summers had committed the burglary to fund his drug habit.

Asked after the case if he would attack a burglar in his home again, Mr Gapper said: "If I had no choice, if my life was in danger, I guess I would do anything. No, I don't regret what I did."

A Conservative party spokesman said of the Peterborough case yesterday: "In this case the law appears to have operated in a commonsense and reasonable way. "Our concern has been that one can't always be confident that in cases of this kind the law is on the side of householders using reasonable force in defence of themselves and their property." Mr Gapper said after the case: "I was told if anything happened to the intruder I could be looking at manslaughter. I was petrified at the time. "I think it was a disgrace what happened to Tony Martin. It means he is being made out to be a criminal." Mr Gapper said he kept a baseball bat by his bedside for self-defence. "I think 90% of England has something to use to defend themselves, but I never thought I would use that bat. I acted out of fear. I'm no angel, but I'm not violent. "I was in bed when I heard this banging on the window downstairs at around 10am. At first I didn't know what it was, then I heard the door being smashed in. I woke George and said I thought someone was in the house and raced downstairs. "At first, all I could see was the shadow of this man, but as he turned to face me he lifted his arms above his head and I saw he had a spanner in his hand. "I was face to face with him for a split second before he ran past me and I just hit out. I thought he could have hit me. I hit him first in the back of the head and then twice about his body." Mr Goodayle said he grabbed the intruder and punched him three to four times: "He deserved what he got." Mr Gapper added: "I could feel my adrenalin take over my body. "I could have killed him. Afterwards, I was still shaking, but chased him barefoot out of the house into the street in the rain and people were just standing, watching me." The court heard that Summers had committed the burglary to fund his drug habit. Asked after the case if he would attack a burglar in his home again, Mr Gapper said: "If I had no choice, if my life was in danger, I guess I would do anything. No, I don't regret what I did."

fields.headline: Knutsford shares suspended
fields.trailText: Knutsford shares were suspended yesterday after the high-profile bid vehicle announced it was in talks to buy a privately owned investor relations business partly owned by one of its own directors.
fields.body:
Knutsford shares were suspended yesterday after the high-profile bid vehicle announced it was in talks to buy a privately owned investor relations business partly owned by one of its own directors.

The company said it was negotiating to buy World Investor Link (WIL), a US-based business which specialises in providing investors, free of charge, with the annual reports of public companies.

The deal is expected to value WIL at around £60m and the shares are likely to remain sus pended until completion of the purchase.

Knutsford director Nigel Wray owns around 6% of WIL, with an option to take his holding to 11%.

The deal is likely to be financed through a mixture of cash and new shares, and Mr Wray is expected to use Knutsford shares for his stake.

Mr Wray, along with former Asda boss Archie Norman, property entrepreneur Nick Leslau and Richer Sounds millionaire Julian Richer bought into Knutsford last year amid a rush of publicity, saying they were going to use it as a vehi cle for buying an undervalued retailer. The shares, which were then valued at less than 10p, jumped to 250p.

But the promotion of Mr Norman - who is also a Conservative MP - to the shadow cabinet and an aborted bid to buy conglomerate-cum-venture capital group Wassall forced Knutsford to switch its focus to e-commerce.

WIL has a database of 1.2m customers, and Knutsford is likely to look to exploit them by offering online information on flotations and other, similar opportunities.

Its existing customers include the Financial Times, the Wall Street Journal and the Investors Chronicle.

The shares were down 1p at 80p when they were suspended.

WIL also owns a small stake in Stockcube, the financial forecasting specialist planning a flotation and run by a team which includes Mr Wray and Tim Horlick, husband of "superwoman" Nicola.

The flotation, scheduled for next month on the Alternative Investment Market at 25p a share, will value Stockcube at £24m and raise £3m for expansion and development.

webTitle: Lego language: how piles of jargon bury English

fields.headline: Lego language: how piles of jargon bury English
fields.trailText: The Commons held its monthly festival of jargon yesterday. I've nothing against jargon; we all use it in our various trades. If a plumber talks about a "washer", instead of a funny little round rubber thingy that fits inside a tap, we don't accuse him of mangling the language.
fields.body:
The Commons held its monthly festival of jargon yesterday. I've nothing against jargon; we all use it in our various trades. If a plumber talks about a "washer", instead of a funny little round rubber thingy that fits inside a tap, we don't accuse him of mangling the language.

But education questions is something quite different. Here is a world in which few of the words used resemble the vocabulary of any normal person.

There are "new job retention pilots", "sure start programmes", "age diversity codes", "better regulation taskforces" and endless "roll-outs".

At education questions, no one ever says, "we need more trained workers". Instead, they say "we must address the skills gap". ("Dear skills gap, may I make so bold.")

No minister could bear to say, "we're doing three things to tackle this"; instead they announce, as someone did yesterday, a "three-pronged integrated strategy".

Nobody challenges this because anyone who is interested enough to turn up to the Commons on local government election day knows exactly what it means.

So when David Blunkett says: "All teachers at point 9 will be able to access the £2,000 uplift, and access the fast-track procedure to be able to access these new thresholds," they all nod wisely, or else claim to be enraged - not by the minister's language but by what they surmise he might be trying to say.

Jargon is like Lego: start fixing it together and you soon have something sturdily built but quite impossible to recognise.

Estelle Morris was answering a question about the standard spending assess ment for primary school pupils. "We are doing our best within the freeze on the SSA's," said Ms Morris, adding moments later, "on top of which we can build fair, transparent extra money."

I think this means something like: "We will find a way of giving more money in an equal sort of way, while letting people know how we decide." But who can say?

They love to borrow jargon from modern management-speak, and have a special love for buzzy words such as "delivery", "best practice" and "excellence".

So Tessa Jowell announced, "we are putting in place the job search programmes which have already had considerable success at the pilot stage, offering practical help, and are delivering people into the jobs which are there," making people sound like so many sacks of coal being delivered down a chute.

There was one curious and somewhat disturbing incident. On Wednesday, the Speaker seemed to forget Mr Michael Fabricant's name and began to address him as "Mr Pa..." "Fabricant!" he reminded her. "Ominous! That was very off-putting!"

George Foulkes, the aid minister, said waspishly that he shouldn't worry. Perhaps the Speaker just didn't read the Guardian sketch. (Actually, I believe she sometimes does.)

Yesterday he got his revenge. In a question about jobs for people aged 50 and over, he confessed that he was about to fall into that category. (Ironic cries of "No, no, impossible! Surely not!")

Mickey supported the rights of older people, including "grey-haired sketch writers," he said, waving an order paper in my direction, then giving me a "no hard feelings" type of wink.

I felt doubly hurt. The response was mild, given what I've said about him, but to have your hair criticised by Fabricant! The shame will haunt me for years.

And there was a time when a Tory MP for the shires would no more have winked at a hack than worn white socks with a dinner jacket.
