fields.headline: Questing for liberals
fields.standfirst:
Hague is determined to do battle with them. It's time New Labour gave him something to aim at

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Today William Hague will be crowing: his party was always bound to make some gains, but he thinks he's found the road to power. In an eve-of-poll interview for the Daily Mail yesterday he was confident that he has finally found his winning issues - race and crime.
fields.body:
Today William Hague will be crowing: his party was always bound to make some gains, but he thinks he's found the road to power. In an eve-of-poll interview for the Daily Mail yesterday he was confident that he has finally found his winning issues - race and crime. Defiantly he announced: "It's time the liberal establishment were taken on. I am determined never to be browbeaten by them." Girding his loins, buckling on his rusty armour, he's off to battle. But tilting at the liberal establishment, he'll find his target is no more than a windmill of his mind. For the liberal establishment is no more.

What exactly does William Hague mean by it? Ask Tory central office and they wax fierce. It's everywhere, under every bed, in every crevice. Liberals always had the upper hand, said one spokesman and this list followed: the judiciary, senior police officers, town halls, social services, academia, education, "Whitehall, obviously" and definitely the media, not just broadcasting, "BBC of course" but they even control the print. What paranoia! Murdoch owns 41% of all print readership, with Conrad Black and Lord Rothermere in charge of most of the rest.

Looking for a cooler head, I asked Two-Brains David Willetts, Tory thinker, where this liberal establishment still lurks. He added the church to the list - the Church of England, the "nationalised" church, he called it, not the evangelicals who are definitely not liberal. He named the cadre of quango-serving business men. At the BBC, he named Jeremy Paxman and Melvyn Bragg. It's pervasive, he said, and quoted a Radio 4 programme yesterday on gay families, accusing it of promoting gay parenthood as normal. As for academia, he accused social researchers of following a liberal agenda and liberal historians - Linda Colley in particular - of undermining traditional self-images of what it is to be British.

So what qualifies someone as a liberal? He pulled out his copy of Edmund Burke who wrote: "Many of our [conservative] men of speculation instead of exploding general prejudices employ their sagacity to discover the latent wisdom which prevails in them. If they find what they seek, and they seldom fail, they think it is more wise to continue the prejudice with the reason involved than to cast away prejudice and leave nothing but naked reason." So conservatives find latent wisdom in old prejudices while liberals seek truth by naked reason. What liberal would want to disagree? Maybe that explains William Hague's recent attempts to stoke up prejudice wherever he can against asylum seekers, Gypsies and fellow Europeans, while hymning the praises of gun-toting home owners.

But paranoia apart, where is this liberal establishment? Does it exist? Whatever the virtues and successes of this government, it would be hard to call it liberal. Labour has always been riven between its liberal and illiberal instincts. In the past, its illiberal wing wore the workerist cloth cap of reactionary, chapel-bred sexual puritanism. It was full of little England patriotism, little-woman-in-the-home sexism and law-and-order authoritarianism. Labour's backbone had few liberal bones in its body. (Look at how the old Labour peers, including Callaghan, voted against lowering the gay age of consent.) But they tolerated the liberals in the party and allowed them to campaign against hanging and censorship and for abortion, gay rights and race-relations laws.

New Labour is forged from neither of these traditions. Its trade-union roots are all but dead along with that old-fashioned conservatism, but the party's old liberalism has also been silenced for now. They have had to satisfy themselves with Labour's determined assault on poverty and heavy commitment to progressive social programmes instead. Jack Straw in riot gear stands ready to chase off anything from within too overtly liberal. In the fight to make Labour electable, he has been the bulwark defending the party's weak liberal flank. No one outflanks him on law and order, no one sticks a liberal label on his back.

So far it has driven the Tories to distraction. For as long as Straw stands there, no epithets like soft-on-crime, soft-on-cannabis, giving-away-national-secrets or betraying-our-boys-in-blue ever sticks to this government. Teflon on law and order, shockproof on official secrets, strong as on ox on defence, rock steady on income tax, tough on rioters, ferocious to asylum seekers; none of the usual Tory assaults make any headway against New Labour. Hague's lance glances off Straw's armour: bemusement will greet him if he tours about on his flat-bed truck warning voters of some scary new "liberal establishment" peril.

Labour is accused of selling its soul when it made this trade-off, coupling social progress to illiberalism in almost everything else. Others say Labour couldn't have been elected without it. What's still unknown is whether beneath the carapace of Tony Blair and even Jack Straw there beats a more liberal instinct than they yet dare show. And if so, will they ever dare?

Most MPs and ministers you meet are by nature - and in off-the-record opinion - far more liberal than the party's public face. Private response to the sensible Police Foundation report on decriminalising cannabis was almost wholly favourable. When will the true liberal nature of the Labour party break free?

As for the old liberal establishment, its passing happens to be marked this week in a memorial service for its great doyen and chronicler, the late Lord Annan. In his book Our Age, he recorded from the inside how the postwar liberal consensus, Butskellism, embraced a bien-pensant trust in progress, reform and, yes, the power of naked reason. Mighty royal commissions of the great and good deliberated and their deliberations were acted upon. Roy Jenkins was the quintessential liberal Home Secretary who saw in the major 60s reforms. But that world imploded in the chaos of the last days of Labour. What remained was blow-torched out of existence by Margaret Thatcher. She scorched liberals out of every establishment she could reach. It wasn't a strange death, but a sudden violent death for a liberal England that now looks archaic and essentially oligarchic.

So what's William Hague on about? Outside in the real world, liberal values on personal freedom have taken root beyond reversing: gays are accepted, "living in sin" and illegitimacy unknown concepts. This the Tories deplore, but can never reverse. The danger is that Hague is bent on taking the Haider route with his call to lock all asylum seekers into camps. If so, Labour will at last have to dare stand up for the less popular liberal values and face down the Mail and the Sun instead of vying with Hague for language to damn all "bogus" immigrants. In the end, Labour will have to emerge as a liberal force against the forces of conservatism.

webTitle: The Queen shares a joke with Lady Thatcher

fields.headline: The Queen shares a joke with Lady Thatcher
fields.standfirst: National Portrait Gallery
fields.trailText: There are days when being a monarch is the loneliest job in the world. Yesterday the Queen had to face two Margaret Thatchers - one a frighteningly large photograph, and the other the even more scary real life version.
fields.body:
There are days when being a monarch is the loneliest job in the world. Yesterday the Queen had to face two Margaret Thatchers - one a frighteningly large photograph, and the other the even more scary real life version.

The former prime minister was among the great and the good who posed in front of their likenesses for the opening of the National Portrait Gallery's new £16m Ondaatje wing. The two women, who had a famously prickly relationship, shared a joke but Lady Thatcher later declined to disclose what had made the Queen laugh. "I'm a diplomat," she said. The Queen dressed all in red while Mrs Thatcher stuck to her Tory blue.

Asked what she thought of the black and white photograph of her by Helmut Newton - who is better known for his nudes - Lady Thatcher said: "I've got quite used to it but you're never a good judge of your own portrait. It's a very contemplative mood that the photographer has caught."

She also spoke to the Queen about portraits displayed nearby of fellow former Tory prime ministers Sir Alec Douglas-Home and Harold Macmillan. "These were great thinkers," she said.

Sir Edward Heath and the former Tory deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine were kept at a discreet distance.

The Queen said she was pleased that a new Tudor Gallery had been created to display portraits of her predecessors, including the "Ditchley" painting of Queen Elizabeth I and a Holbein drawing of Henry VIII.

The startling new extension, which includes a rooftop restaurant with one of the most spectacular views in London, taking in Nelson's Column, Big Ben and the London Eye, was built with nearly £12m of lottery money. The rest came from private donors, including the philantropist, Christopher Ondaatje, after whom the new wing is named. The Canadian financier is a brother of the poet and novelist Michael Ondaatje, author of the English Patient, which was made into an Oscar-winning film.

Designed on five levels by architects Jeremy Dixon and Edward Jones, the wing is linked by a huge escalator. There is also an IT gallery where visitors can see 260,000 pictures and photographs.

fields.headline: Rural cancer sufferers 'more at risk'
fields.trailText: People who live in rural areas have a much lower chance of surviving cancer than city dwellers, and are up to four times more likely to die before the disease is even diagnosed, according to a report published yesterday.
fields.body:
People who live in rural areas have a much lower chance of surviving cancer than city dwellers, and are up to four times more likely to die before the disease is even diagnosed, according to a report published yesterday.

Results of a study of more than 60,000 people diagnosed with lung, breast, prostate, stomach, ovarian or colorectal cancer in rural and urban Scotland between 1991 and 1995 were published in the British Journal of Cancer.

Scientists focused on those people who were not diagnosed with the disease before they died from it.

The study, funded by the Cancer Research Campaign, showed that people with breast cancer in rural areas are three times more likely to die before diagnosis compared with urban patients.

Bowel cancer victims are twice as likely to die and stomach cancer patients are four times more likely to die before diagnosis if they live in the country.

webTitle: Big cut in legal aid work for QCs

fields.headline: Big cut in legal aid work for QCs
fields.standfirst: Clampdown on 'routine overmanning' in criminal cases will slash earnings and save Treasury millions
fields.trailText: Criminal defence QCs face a substantial drop in their workload under new rules which could oblige them to do some work at half their usual rates or go idle.
fields.body:
Criminal defence QCs face a substantial drop in their workload under new rules which could oblige them to do some work at half their usual rates or go idle.

The lord chancellor is pressing ahead with controversial plans to cut overmanning in criminal cases by limiting the number of cases in which legal aid will pay for two defence barristers or for a QC.

Under the regulations, which will be laid before parliament soon and come into force in September, "junior" barristers - those who have not attained QC rank, regardless of age - will be expected to do much of the defence work handled by QCs. And in many cases where QCs are allowed, they will have to work alone, without a supporting junior.

Judges will decide what level of counsel the case warrants, under guidelines designed to ensure that legal aid pays for a silk only in the most difficult and complex cases. Rape defendants, for example, are less likely to qualify for a QC.

The Bar Council and senior judges have wrung a number of concessions from Lord Irvine designed to give judges more discretion, but they will still be kept to strict guidelines. Yesterday the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, would only say: "The senior judiciary were very grateful that the lord chancellor felt able to make some concessions."

The bar's chairman, Jonathan Hirst QC, said that the changes had made "an enormous improvement" but there were "areas which we still think are too tight".

A senior QC who did not want to be named said: "It's the triumph of Treasury cost-cutting over the merits of arguments in favour of members of the public having the best possible representation in serious cases."

David Lock, minister in the lord chancellor's department, said: "It will be for the judges to apply the guidelines strictly. But we expect a very substantial change to the number of cases where two counsel are used and a substantial change to the number of cases where a QC is used. It will stop any routine overmanning."

Lord Irvine has told the Bar that if the move leaves QCs short of work there will be nothing to stop them taking cases for juniors' rates of pay. These tend to work out at around half the rates for QCs.

In a letter to Mr Hirst, Lord Irvine said: "A number of individuals have expressed concern about the consequential reduction in work available to QCs when my proposals are introduced.

"Whilst I do not accept that I have any duty to maintain a particular level of income for any group of practitioners or any duty to maintain a particular level of work, I do accept that QCs should not be prevented from undertaking work they are otherwise qualified to do."

He proposed to change the rules to make it clear that QCs may accept cases certified by the court as suitable for a junior "providing payment is on a junior basis and the QC does not look to the client to top up the payment". The move is expected to save millions of pounds, and is one prong of the lord chancellor's assault on the £300m legal aid bill for crown court cases.

Barristers, and particularly QCs, the most successful of whom can earn £300,000 to £400,000 a year from criminal legal aid, also face curbs on their pay rates. Lord Irvine proposes to bring prosecution and defence barristers' rates into line by cutting defence fees while prosecutors, traditionally paid less, have their rates increased.

Very high cost cases, mainly fraud, will be covered by contracts at specified hourly rates.

fields.headline: Dinosaurs claim Microsoft's technology wiz
fields.trailText: Nathan Myrhvold, the chief technology officer of Microsoft, has decided to spend more time digging for dinosaurs rather than return to the software company.
fields.body:
Nathan Myrhvold, the chief technology officer of Microsoft, has decided to spend more time digging for dinosaurs rather than return to the software company.

Mr Myrhvold said yesterday that he would not be returning to Microsoft once his year-long sabbatical comes to an end in July. His departure, although widely expected, comes as the company is finding it increasingly hard to retain staff in the wake of its legal difficulties and increased competition from internet start-ups.

Bob Young, the chief executive of Red Hat, a rival company that promotes Linux, the main competitor to Windows, said yesterday that, for the first time, a "huge number of junior Microsofties" were leaving the firm.

Mr Young indicated that such defections were having a more immediate effect on the company than the long-running anti-monopoly battle with the US government. "It was one of the things that used to intimidate me in the early days. All the best guys, who didn't really like Microsoft, went to work for them anyway because it was full of interesting people and they were guaranteed to make lots of money."

Microsoft moved to stem the defections last week when it issued more share options. Shares in Microsoft have fallen more than 40% since January.

Mr Myrhvold, who joined Microsoft in 1986, has made a fortune at the company. He is expected to continue to act as a close adviser to Bill Gates, the co-founder and chief software architect of Microsoft.

Next week, Microsoft is expected to ask for further hearings to discuss the justice department's demands that the company be broken into two.

fields.headline: Ulster leak shows London-Dublin split
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A leaked Northern Ireland Office document last night underlined the chasm between the British and Irish governments over saving the ailing Good Friday agreement as Tony Blair arrived at Hillsborough castle for critical talks with the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern.
fields.body:
A leaked Northern Ireland Office document last night underlined the chasm between the British and Irish governments over saving the ailing Good Friday agreement as Tony Blair arrived at Hillsborough castle for critical talks with the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern.

The secret paper, passed to a prominent pro-agreement Ulster Unionist, highlighted bitter disagreements between Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, and the Irish foreign affairs minister, Brian Cowen.

It suggested Mr Cowen was pro-republican, with no understanding of the difficulties faced by the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble.

Chris McGimpsey, the Belfast councillor handed the document, believed it was genuine. He was told it related to a meeting this week.

A senior civil servant who was present wrote: "Cowen's line appeared to be that, beyond the constitutional acceptance that Northern Ireland remained part of the UK, there should be no further evidence of Britishness in the governance of Northern Ireland.

"It was an argument presented with all the subtlety and open-mindedness that one would expect from a member of Sinn Fein."

The leak raised speculation that the Government was floating the idea of a brief reprieve for the name of the RUC.

That would boost Mr Trimble with his sceptical Ulster Unionist Council in selling a return to devolution with Sinn Fein without prior IRA decommissioning.

Mr McGimpsey, whose brother Michael was an Ulster Unionist minister in the short-lived power-sharing executive, said: "It gives some indication of the extremely green and intransigent position the Irish government is taking.

"There is obviously not a fraction of an inch difference between the Irish government and Sinn Fein."

Disagreements between the governments have been bubbling under since Mr Mandelson signalled a return to direct rule on February 11.

Mr Blair and Mr Ahern were last night meeting the fringe parties, including Alliance, the Women's Coalition, the Progressive Unionist Party and the Ulster Democratic Party. They will meet Sinn Fein, Ulster Unionists and the SDLP today.

They are desperate for a breakthrough before May 22, the deadline in the agreement by which all parties were to use their best efforts to achieve the complete decommissioning of all paramilitary weapons.

The governments are working on a plan to extend the timetable for decommissioning. It would also redefine decommissioning as "putting weapons beyond use", a dilution which would require legislative changes to the remit of General John de Chastelain's decommissioning body.

It would involve a sequence of statements. The most important would be from the IRA about its future intentions.

There there is still no indication whether that is on the cards. And, if it is, it is unclear whether it will be enough for Mr Trimble to persuade his increasingly doubtful party to back a return to Stormont.

webTitle: Whitbread gives strong hint about quitting brewing

fields.headline: Whitbread gives strong hint about quitting brewing
fields.trailText: Whitbread's chief executive, David Thomas, has given his clearest signal yet that the company is preparing to sell its brewing operations, which produce Stella Artois, Heineken and Boddingtons.
fields.body:
Whitbread's chief executive, David Thomas, has given his clearest signal yet that the company is preparing to sell its brewing operations, which produce Stella Artois, Heineken and Boddingtons.

Reporting a 7.1% increase in annual profits to £391m, Mr Thomas said: "The UK and European brewing industry is going through a great deal of consolidation. That could well create an opportunity for us to add value for Whitbread shareholders. If such an opportunity arises, I firmly intend to take it up."

He refused to comment on rumours that Whitbread had discussed selling its breweries to Interbrew, the Belgian owner of the Stella Artois brand. Whitbread produces lager under licence for Interbrew in the UK.

Whitbread's breweries in Wales, Manchester and Lancashire employ around 4,500 people. Surging sales of Stella helped lift the group's profits from beer production by 11% to £57.1m.

Mr Thomas wants to focus Whitbread on hotels and health clubs - where, he believes, growth prospects are greater.

The group's overall performance benefited from a stronger second half, during which profits rose 12%, against 3% in the first half. Average weekly sales in Whitbread pubs rose 6.4% during the year. The shares slipped 2p to 578p.

Mr Thomas admitted, however, that he had been disappointed with the performance of the group's restaurants division in recent years, where profits rose just 2.5%.

He has ordered a review of restaurant brands, with Café Rouge, Beefeater and Dome likely to come under close scrutiny. Whitbread said it was possible that one or more of its chains could be axed.

Mr Thomas defended Whitbread's strategy, blaming a plunge in the group's shares on the attraction of dot.com investments and disappointment at the group's failure to buy Allied Domecq's retail estate last year.

webTitle: US deal makes Galen a global force in women's health care

fields.headline: US deal makes Galen a global force in women's health care
fields.trailText: Galen Holdings, the Northern Ireland-based specialist in women's health care, is to become a world leader in feminine medicine by paying £190m for a US manufacturer of contraceptive pills.
fields.body:
Galen Holdings, the Northern Ireland-based specialist in women's health care, is to become a world leader in feminine medicine by paying £190m for a US manufacturer of contraceptive pills.

The all-paper acquisition of Warner Chilcott will bring on board Bill Gates as a shareholder. The Microsoft billionaire owns 11% of Warner, and will own 3% of Galen following the deal.

Galen has developed an intra-vaginal rubber ring which slowly releases hormone replacement therapy into the bodies of menopausal women. The product is due to be launched later this year, and the purchase of Warner Chilcott will provide a sales and marketing infrastructure in the US.

John King, Galen's chief executive, said: "Strategically, this is an extremely important move for us. It gives us the opportunity to commercialise our rings in the largest market in the world."

Warner Chilcott has 260 US sales staff. Its main products include vitamins for pregnant women, contraceptive pills and a cream version of hormone replacement therapy. The group was originally a spin-off from an Irish drugs company, Elan.

Galen is keen to undertake a big marketing campaign for its intra-vaginal rings. It believes the same technology could be used to release contraceptives, anti-infectives and hormones to increase sex drive.

Galen's shares have quadrupled since flotation four years ago and after this acquisition the group will be worth almost £1bn. Mr King and co-founder Allen McClay are among Northern Ireland's wealthiest businessmen, their 40% stake worth some £400m.

They will relinquish some control after the deal. Warner Chilcott's boss, Roger Boissoneault, is to become Galen's chief executive. Mr King will become executive chairman, with Mr McClay stepping up to non-executive president.

Galen's shares fell 50p to 562.5p. The company is issuing aroun 34m shares in the transaction. Galen will gain a listing on the US Nasdaq index.

webTitle: Labour's blame game as the inquest begins

fields.headline: Labour's blame game as the inquest begins
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair moved yesterday to placate Frank Dobson for the drubbing that has left the former health secretary feeling "bitter" at the way the Labour leadership and party machine mishandled his ill-starred campaign to become London's elected mayor.
fields.body:
Tony Blair moved yesterday to placate Frank Dobson for the drubbing that has left the former health secretary feeling "bitter" at the way the Labour leadership and party machine mishandled his ill-starred campaign to become London's elected mayor.

While voters were still going to the polls in 152 council elections and the byelection in Tory-held Romsey as well as in London, Mr Blair told the cabinet that their old colleague had behaved with "great dignity" during a difficult time.

First indications from a TV exit poll last night suggested that Ken Livingstone had failed to win the mayoralty outright by gaining more than 50% of first-preference votes and that the Tory candidate, Steve Norris, had pushed Mr Dobson into third place.

That prospect added to Labour anxiety about recriminations when the inquest into the debacle starts today. It will be made far worse if, as some MPs claim, the deeply loyal Mr Dobson finally blows his top in interviews or a book.

Mr Dobson, who fought an uphill struggle as official Labour candidate after Mr Livingstone claimed he had been cheated of the nomination, is said to blame Mr Blair's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, and a small coterie of Labour insiders for undermining him.

Mr Powell is believed to have been the chief advocate of running Mo Mowlam for the job - a plan she resisted until it was too late.

More controversially, Mr Dobson is also convinced that he could have beaten the former GLC leader fair and square in a one-member, one- vote election among party members in London - only to be tainted by the ill-judged imposition of an electoral college by party headquarters in Millbank and No 10 staff.

Many ministers and officials believe Mr Dobson's hunch is wrong and that a one-member, one-vote victory for Mr Livingstone would have created a far worse situation for them. "Can you imagine the trouble if he'd made that Hitler remark as the official Labour candidate?" said one official.

With ministers braced for significant losses among the 3,360 council seats at stake, as well as the psychological blow of Mr Livingstone's near-certain emergence as independent London mayor, the cabinet was warned that the results would be patchy, especially in areas such as the West Midlands where voters are angry about Longbridge.

Ministers confirmed there was no discussion in cabinet of what job Mr Dobson might be given, though party officials said: "He's a gifted man who can do jobs. He'll get one."

They remain adamant that Mr Dobson will not write a book or denounce them on TV or in print. But they admit: "Frank's problem is that he won't tell lies." That could be dangerous, as Peter Kilfoyle's resignation from the govern ment over the "heartlands" issue showed. Mr Dobson has already said: "I didn't use spin doctors, though spin doctors did use me."

One minister said: "This is a personal tragedy for Frank but it was not all his fault. Others played their part in the result." Labour is planning an inquest into its poor campaign but No 10 is anxious to keep it private to avoid public bloodletting.

Labour was already committed to a review of the selection of its candidates for European elections and the devolved assemblies. After submissions next month a report will be sent to the party conference in October, with an eye on the likely spring general election.

The inquiry will look into why a party famed for its organisation did so badly and appeared off its guard in the contest when in effect it had had three years' notice - albeit at a time when Northern Ireland and Kosovo dominated ministerial agendas.

"We need to learn whatever lessons there are not just for the general election but any elections for mayors in other cities," said a senior Labour backbencher. "We did not perform well and we know it."

Downing Street and Millbank appeared at odds why Mr Dobson did not perform well. The "blame game" is already under way with Margaret McDonagh, Labour's general secretary, facing criticism from No 10 for failing to persuade constituency activists to back Mr Dobson.

Some Millbank insiders claim No 10's political unit decided to impose an electoral college to select the party's standard bearer, handing Mr Livingstone an excuse to run as an independent. But others say they consulted each other on all key decisions and will share any credit or blame.

Downing Street in turn has complained it received poor intelligence after senior figures in the London party insisted Mr Livingstone would "bottle" a breakaway campaign.

webTitle: Friends reveal hand in secret poker game

fields.headline: Friends reveal hand in secret poker game
fields.standfirst: Carpetbaggers wrongfooted
fields.trailText: Carpetbaggers claimed another victory yesterday, but the truth is that they walked into the middle of a secret poker game at Friends Provident. The decision to ditch mutual status - according to the announcement - was taken some time ago.
fields.body:
Carpetbaggers claimed another victory yesterday, but the truth is that they walked into the middle of a secret poker game at Friends Provident. The decision to ditch mutual status - according to the announcement - was taken some time ago.

Friends management is clearly happy about walking over the mutual principles that guided the firm's Quaker founders - they are history, after all. They will find it more difficult to sidestep concerns among the small army of investors who in the last few years have bought into its market-leading ethical funds, comforted by the group's longstanding mutuality.

It may explain why Friends has chosen to parcel out so widely the cash benefits from demutualisation among its policyholders. Normally, only with- profits members, the true owners of a mutual society, receive a pay-out.

Friends has 750,000 of them, and they will all enjoy a windfall. But it is also extending the windfall to another 1m policyholders outside the with-profits fund, which will no doubt make it easier to attract support for conversion.

Standard Life must view Friends' embracing of demutualisation with horror. Its defence of mutuality, already battered by highly professional carpetbaggers, now faces collapse. Standard Life will be sending out 2.3m letters to members proclaiming the benefits of mutuality. Friends, the third largest mutual after Standard and Equitable Life, will be sending out nearly as many saying that the game is up for mutuality. Few people will need convincing that jam now - especially £5,000 worth - is better than a potentially higher policy payout in many years' time. If they feel any discomfort about voting for carpetbaggers, they now know they are voting with the approval of the Friends board.

Spirits will also be sinking at Equitable Life. It, too, has been battered by action groups angry about what they see as a refusal to pay out on annuity promises. If Equitable loses its appeal in the House of Lords in June, the writing may also be on the wall for the number two mutual.

There are lots of reasons to support mutuality. But the windfall driven steamroller is now so powerful that almost nobody can stand in its way. Mutuality supporters must feel like the Scottish undertaker in Dad's Army. "We're all doomed."

Brewer's angst

What is the point of Whitbread? The company has been suffering existential angst for some time and is yet to come up with a satisfactory answer.

The conglomerate's sprawling leisure businesses include Pizza Hut, Mariott Hotels, David Lloyd Leisure and Boddingtons. These are well known brands, but the group as a whole has underachieved. Perceptions have hardened that it is drifting aimlessly, tossed around at the whim of changing consumer habits.

Chief executive David Thomas declared yesterday that he was outlining his "strategy". The general reaction afterwards was that if you blinked, you missed it. In a nutshell, Mr Thomas's plan is to "operate in big, expanding markets". He claims Whitbread's unique skill is that it "understands the UK consumer at leisure". This takes in everything from operating a tennis court to building a chain of coffee bars and running a local pub.

The City wants more focus. Investors are frustrated with a mixed bag of figures from Whitbread each year, with the performance dragged down by whichever bit of the leisure market happens to be faring badly.

This year, the laggards were soft drinks and restaurants, and management is slowly lumbering around to tackle these areas. Mr Thomas has also indicated that the group's breweries are up for sale - a course of action which the City called for well over a year ago.

All this serves to support the view that Whitbread tends to plod along, reacting to trends as they materialise. Losing a bid battle with tiny rival Punch Taverns last year should have been a wake-up call. Instead Whitbread has lapsed back into denial, with Mr Thomas blaming the popularity of dot.coms for a halving of its share price in a year.

He will have to come up with something better than that.

The £15bn takeover of Marks & Spencer proved to be a fantasy; the £600m try-on with Wassall was thrown out by the institutions. But the investors who thought the foursome behind Knutsford were worth £1bn without a business to run have finally got a deal.

This one, to buy investor relations business World Investor Link, should not get away - if only because Knutsford director Nigel Wray already owns around 6% of WIL. What is more, the synergy of this acquisition is clear: WIL has a ready-made job explaining to Knutsford shareholders how stupid they have been to buy the stock.

webTitle: And now, some answers from the founders

fields.headline: And now, some answers from the founders
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com founders Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox answered some tough questions at the announcement of their interim results yesterday:
fields.body:
Lastminute.com founders Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox answered some tough questions at the announcement of their interim results yesterday:

Your losses are mounting. When will you break even?

BH: Analysts are looking for a reduction in costs next year and profitability towards the back end of 2003. Right now we are investing for growth. We're ahead of our own forecasts for the business and ahead of most of the analysts' forecasts.

You claim to have 1.4m subscribers but only 65,387 have bought goods from you. The conversion rate at which you turn subscribers into buyers appears to be stuck at around 5%-6%. Is your growth slowing?

BH: We're still growing incredibly quickly. In the last quarter UK conversion rates were less than 5%, now they are 6%. New markets are weighing down the average. It takes time to get the virtuous circle going.

Can Lastminute handle the competition that is likely to emerge? Airlines, for instance, could sell their own last minute tickets, and similar websites are already springing up.

BH: The competition has been misrepresented. Our business model is easy to replicate and we know of nobody who is well funded and trying to replicate it. We have the advantage of being the first mover, a known brand, 2,450 suppliers, top tier strategic partners, technology and £131m in the bank.

Do you feel the negative publicity about your float has damaged your brand?

BH: No; our brand grows stronger by the day and total transaction value since the float has continued to grow. On Wednesday 9,000 new subscribers signed up. We are the UK's second best known e-commerce site and national brand awareness has doubled in the last quarter to 46%.

Some analysts privately suggest that they would like to see more experienced business operators appointed to senior levels to see the company through its next stage of growth.

MLF: We're constantly reviewing the business. We're humble enough not to think we can build this firm on our own and have appointed a string of experienced people to senior positions.

E-commerce has been hit by the sell-off in tech stocks and sentiment in the US has turned against online retailers after suggestions that many may run out of money. How has that affected you?

BH: Many companies have been spending too much and missing their targets. It is disappointing for European e-commerce firms if they are not allowed to invest for growth. US firms like Priceline and Amazon have done exactly that, and are now turning into profitable companies. European firms must be allowed to spend for growth otherwise US firms will end up dominating over here. But the downturn is good news for companies like ours, which are well developed, and analysts believe that we have enough money in the bank to see us through to break even. In a tougher climate the cash we have will be worth more, making our marketing, sales and staff budgets go further.

How badly has the fall in your share price hit your ability to use your shares as acquisition currency?

BH: We can still use our shares as currency. This not just a Lastminute issue, it is a sector issue. We do not have any acquisition news to talk about at the moment but would be likely to look at companies in other geographies or firms with fantastic technology worth buying into."

The lock-in period preventing you from selling your Lastminute shares comes to an end some six months after the flotation. What is your long-term commitment to the business?

BH: We are incredibly confident about the long term future of the company - and are also committed to staying with it in the long term.

fields.headline: Dairy bidding hits £240m
fields.trailText: Scottish milk group Robert Wiseman snatched back the initiative in the battle to buy Unigate's dairies yesterday, by raising its bid £15m to £240m.
fields.body:
Scottish milk group Robert Wiseman snatched back the initiative in the battle to buy Unigate's dairies yesterday, by raising its bid £15m to £240m.

The increased offer trumped a £235m bid on the table from Dairy Crest, which was tipped last night to be preparing a further increase.

Whichever company wins the tussle will become one of Britain's largest milk and cheese groups. The businesses under the hammer include the St Ivel and Shape brands, whose product lines embrace Utterly Butterly, Golden Churn and Vitalite.

When asked whether he was confident of victory, Robert Wiseman's finance director, Bill Keane, said: "Who knows? All you can ever do is give it your best shot."

Based in East Kilbride, Robert Wiseman is a bulk supplier of milk to supermarkets, with a customer list including Asda, Safeway and Morrisons.

Already strong in Scotland and north-west England, the company is building a dairy in Droitwich to service the Midlands. It wants Unigate's operations as a platform for growth in London and the south-east.

If successful, Robert Wiseman's cash offer would mean a £140m hand-out to Unigate's investors at the rate of 61p a share.

Chairman Alan Wiseman said: "Wiseman has recognised the advantages of being able to offer a national service to the multiple retailers, most of whom have national coverage themselves."

After a hastily convened board meeting, Unigate said it expected to recommend Wiseman's offer "unless circumstances change".

A Unigate spokeswoman pointed out that bids for the business had doubled since Dairy Crest made an initial offer in February. "This is very good news for our shareholders."

Industry sources suggest that a victory for Dairy Crest would mean more job cuts because there would be more overlap between operations in the south.

Dairy Crest's products include Country Life butter, Clover and desserts such as Yoplait and Petits Filous.

Unigate's shares slipped 3p to 291p yesterday, while Robert Wiseman was un changed at 83.5p and Dairy Crest remained at 139p.

Unigate has opted to sell its dairy business to concentrate on prepared foods.

Consolidation has been gathering pace in the dairy sector. Smaller operators have struggled because of a long-term decline in consumption of milk. Many people have switched from daily doorstep deliveries to buying milk less frequently from supermarkets.

The industry has been further shaken by the disbanding of Milk Marque, the farmers' cooperative which heavily influenced pricing.

webTitle: Prickly  Agave shortage hurts Allied Domecq

fields.headline: Prickly  Agave shortage hurts Allied Domecq
fields.trailText: A chronic shortage in the supply of the agave, an obscure Mexican desert plant, is hampering Allied Domecq's attempts to achieve a recovery in profits.
fields.body:
A chronic shortage in the supply of the agave, an obscure Mexican desert plant, is hampering Allied Domecq's attempts to achieve a recovery in profits.

Starch from the centre of agave is the core ingredient of tequila. Allied Domecq makes Sauza, one of the world's top tequila brands.

After announcing a 16% increase in interim pre-tax profits to £210m yesterday, Allied Domecq warned that problems getting hold of the plant would be a key factor in slowing its earnings growth in the second half.

Chief executive Philip Bowman said the price of a kilo of agave had leapt from one peso (7p) to eight pesos since September. He blamed "the juxtaposition of explosive demand, a higher incidence of disease and a remarkably primitive agricultural system in Mexico".

To qualify for the name tequila, drinks must contain agave from a specific province of Mexico. Allied Domecq has begun planting its own supply and has urged the Mexican government to carry out an inventory of remaining crops. But because agave take at least five years to reach maturity, Allied believes the problem will impact profits for several years - possibly costing as much as £8m.

Mr Bowman said: "It's extremely frustrating - it's happened just as we were getting everything else back on track."

Allied's profits were driven by a 15% increase in the contribution from its four leading brands - Sauza, Beefeater, Kahlua and Ballantine's. Since his appointment last year, Mr Bowman has implemented sweeping changes in promotional activities.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.standfirst: Seagram
fields.trailText:
House prices start to cool
The boom in house prices is beginning to ease, suggesting the recent series of interest rate rises is taking effect, the Halifax survey said yesterday.
fields.body:
House prices start to cool
The boom in house prices is beginning to ease, suggesting the recent series of interest rate rises is taking effect, the Halifax survey said yesterday.

Figures from the Halifax showed prices up 0.8% in April and 14.2% ahead on the year, giving an average house price of £84,819.

The increase in April partly offset falls in February and March. Halifax said the figures over the past few months suggested the underlying pace of house price growth was easing, showing the risk of overheating was receding.

Most recent house purchase figures indicated the market was not as buoyant as a few months ago, the company said.

Seagrams denies spin offs
Seagram, the drinks and entertainment group, denied plans to spin off its spirits and wines business or to sell its film studio yesterday as it reported better than expected losses in the third quarter.

The company has been repeatedly linked with various large media groups since the merger of America Online and Time Warner was announced in January.

Edgar Bronfman Jr, chief executive, has admitted that the deal between AOL and the media company prompted a great deal of soul searching.

But he denied that the company was in discussions to sell its Universal Studio arm or was planning an initial public offering of its drinks group.

Royal & Sun profits dip
Royal & Sun Alliance Insurance reported a 4.8% fall in first quarter profits to £138m yesterday.

It said progress in turning around its underperforming UK general insurance book had been slower than some analysts had expected, but it was on track to meet its underwriting and capital return targets next year.

The insurer said its US acquisition last year of Orion Capital was performing better than expected, with cost savings likely to be double initial expectations.

Trinity Mirror posts growth
Sir Victor Blank, chairman of Trinity Mirror, yesterday said advertising revenues at the Mirror and Sunday Mirror had grown 5% in the first four months of the year.

Classified advertising increased 10% across the group's regional titles he added, suggesting that the mooted migration of classifieds to the internet is still premature.

Vanguard ends merger talks
Biotechnology company Vanguard Medica has terminated merger discussions with CeNes Pharmaceuticals.

Vanguard said a merger with CeNes would not realise appropriate value for Vanguard shareholders.

There has been market speculation in recent days that Vanguard may be in merger talks with parties other than CeNes.

webTitle: Keep homes secret, plead biotech chiefs

fields.headline: Keep homes secret, plead biotech chiefs
fields.trailText: Directors of Britain's biotechnology companies have asked for a relaxation in the law, to allow them to keep their home addresses secret from animal rights protesters.
fields.body:
Directors of Britain's biotechnology companies have asked for a relaxation in the law, to allow them to keep their home addresses secret from animal rights protesters.

The BioIndustry Association, which represents the industry, has written to the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, asking for an exemption in disclosure requirements in cases where there is a threat to life and property.

At present, the law requires all directors to list their addresses in accounts, which are available to the public at Companies House.

Drugs companies which test their products on animals are concerned at a sudden increase in the activity of protest groups targeting executives and shareholders.

A spokesman for the BioIndustry Association said: "There has been a resurgence in animal rights activism and certain of our members have received threats. There have been a lot of intimidatory-type phone calls."

She said the association was "not seeking a blanket change" but wanted dispensation where there was a genuine security risk.

A high-profile campaign against one testing company, Huntingdon Life Sciences, led to a fall in the share price as institutions bowed to pressure and sold their shares. Shareholders found demonstrators outside their homes.

Most companies prefer to keep quiet about their activities in animal testing, although nearly every drug development firm does carry out some such research.

Rolf Stahel, chief executive of Shire Pharmaceuticals, said his company did little in the field. He said he had been exposed to protesters some years ago while working for Wellcome.

"It was not a pleasant experience," he said. "Petrol bombs were thrown into private resi dences and surveillance equipment had to be installed in the houses of executives. We were advised that we should check our cars for bombs all the time."

He supports a relaxation in disclosure rules: "If you've gone through that kind of experience, you certainly don't want to expose your family to risks."

A different view was taken by Glyn Edwards, chief executive of the biotech firm Antisoma, which does test drugs on animals. He said he felt that the requirement for freedom of information overrode the danger from protesters, although he added: "As an individual, you do sometimes have fear for yourself and your family.

"None of us wants to harm animals but, if it comes down to finding out whether a drug can cure cancer, I think it's worth it."

A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry said the government was taking a fresh look at the laws. Previous reviews have concluded that the need for directors to be accountable to shareholders outweighed other factors.

The Association of the British Pharmaceuticals Industry, which represents large drugs groups, is backing calls for a change. Last week, the ABPI warned that attitudes towards animal testing could drive some firms abroad.

The British Union Against Vivisection said it would oppose widespread relaxation of the rules. "The general principle of public accountability of companies, and therefore directors and shareholders, remains important," a spokesman said.

fields.headline: British quizzing for launderers
fields.trailText: A team of investigators from Britain's national crime squad has flown to the United States to question the couple at the centre of the multi-billion dollar money laundering scandal involving the Bank of New York.
fields.body:
A team of investigators from Britain's national crime squad has flown to the United States to question the couple at the centre of the multi-billion dollar money laundering scandal involving the Bank of New York.

The squad hopes that information from Lucy Edwards, a former bank executive, and her husband, Peter Berlin, will provide material in ongoing investigations of individuals and companies still based in Britain.

Ms Edwards and Mr Berlin were living in London before flying to New York to plead guilty to money laundering charges two months ago. They were understood to have set up accounts at two British banks to receive illegal payoffs totalling $1.8m (£1.1m) as part of the $7bn money laundering scandal.

According to court papers filed in the US, the Russian-born couple used the names of three companies for these accounts: Highborough Services, Sandbrook Limited and Globestar Corporation.

The crime squad, which has refused to comment on the investigation or last month's interviews with Ms Edwards and Mr Berlin, is investigating whether any British laws were broken in the $7bn scam. Any possible legal action is likely to be some way off.

webTitle: Skyline sculpture Tower block unveiled for Liverpool's waterfront

fields.headline: Skyline sculpture Tower block unveiled for Liverpool's waterfront
fields.trailText: Southern developers yesterday nervously unveiled plans for a 40-storey, 500ft tower block standing over the Liverpool waterfront.
fields.body:
Southern developers yesterday nervously unveiled plans for a 40-storey, 500ft tower block standing over the Liverpool waterfront.

The £60m skyscraper will be one-and-a-third times the height of St Paul's cathedral. "We are from London," said Richard Miller, director of the developers Rumford Investments. "But we are showing confidence in Liverpool. We are bringing inward investment. Give us a chance before you slate the building."

Mr Miller may have had at the back of his mind a scheme announced two years ago to erect Europe's tallest building on the site of the Liverpool garden festival. It would have been more than 1,000ft high with a vertical theme park, an integrated ecosystem and a 30-storey waterfall. It has not been built.

Mr Miller's building was welcomed yesterday as a significant element in the economic revival of Liverpool, which now has more speculative development than its rival, Manchester.

"This is an ambitious, bold statement that comes at just the right time," said Christopher Gibaud, chief executive of the Mersey Partnership, the regional investment marketing agency.

The building, which the city's people will be invited to name, will rise on the site of Richmond House, which is to be demolished in September. The architects Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates describe it as a "cluster of slender stone towers that frame a steel and glass atrium. The height of each tower reflects the form on to the hill below, creating an elegant cascade dropping towards the river".

There will be 650,000 sq ft of space, an observation tower with views over the Mersey to Birkenhead and beyond, and glass lifts glid ing up a building that will provide "a dynamic signature for the skyline at night".

Simon Close, an associate partner of Kohn Pedersen Fox, said: "This is a chance for us to be involved in the regeneration of a famous city and to reinforce the skyline of a famous waterfront."

Mr Miller added: "We are open to suggestions. The building is functional but flexible ... it is a building for the future, not for now."

Mr Gibaud said the building was as potentially im portant to Liverpool as the decision by Ford to build the small Jaguar at Speke. "This comes when the city is producing its own master plan," he added. "The people behind it are serious players with a serious track record. This would have been inconceivable five years ago."

Locals and outsiders were aware of new optimism in the city. "What we want now is a real headliner, an investment that makes people sit up and take notice."

webTitle: BBC loses long-running trademark battle over Proms

fields.headline: BBC loses long-running trademark battle over Proms
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday lost a long-running battle to stop the organisers of an annual concert referring to it with the word Proms.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday lost a long-running battle to stop the organisers of an annual concert referring to it with the word Proms.

The European Group was given approval to use Cathcart Spring Proms as the title of a yearly show dedicated to a medical specialist who helped found Britain's original Promenade Concerts.

At a hearing at the trademarks registry in London, the presiding officer, Allan James, rejected the BBC's view that allowing the Royal Albert Hall concert to be called a prom would confuse the public. The BBC had argued that people would be led to think that the event was part of the traditional summer Proms season it has broadcast from the London venue since 1927.

Nicholas Kenyon, BBC Proms director, said: "The BBC is simply trying to protect the name of the Proms ... from possible confusion in the minds of the concert-going public with other similarly titled events.

"In this case the event is presented at the same venue as the BBC Proms season and has made unjustified connections with the season." Christopher Palmer-Jeffery, chairman of the European Group, said: "I'm delighted. It's a victory for common sense ... I think the BBC's reaction has been a waste of taxpayers' money."

The ear, nose and throat specialist George Cathcart provided initial financial backing for the Proms. Alarmed at the suffering performers experienced through loss of voice and more serious ailments, he worked to restore a safer, lower pitch of music and improve humidity in the concert venue.

webTitle: Inquiry launched into riot at youth jail

fields.headline: Inquiry launched into riot at youth jail
fields.trailText: An investigation was under way yesterday into the seizure of a wing by inmates at a young offenders' institution where conditions have been described as a moral outrage by the government's prison watchdog.
fields.body:
An investigation was under way yesterday into the seizure of a wing by inmates at a young offenders' institution where conditions have been described as a moral outrage by the government's prison watchdog.

Up to 70 prison officers in riot gear were needed to restore order at Portland in Dorset after a wing was occupied on Wednesday night.

It is believed the protest was started by inmates angry that they had been repeatedly denied free time out of their cells.

Portland, a former borstal, has been at the centre of allegations that warders assaulted inmates.

The prison service said that 26 inmates aged 15-21 were involved in the disturbances. They had erected barricades of furniture to keep officers at bay for eight hours.

The stand-off, which caused minor damage, ended after the barricades were stormed by a squad of officers in riot gear. No one was injured.

In March Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, branded as "wholly unacceptable" the treatment of young offenders at Portland and described conditions as a "moral outrage".

Last night the prison service admitted that six times in the past month free time out of cells - called association - had been cancelled because of staff shortages caused by sickness. The youths were also believed to be angered by delays in responding to their grievances.

The trouble started at 8.15pm on Wednesday after youths refused to return to their cells after association.

Prison service negotiators tried to talk the inmates into ending their protest, but after negotiations failed riot officers went in.

Warders from Winchester and Dorchester prisons were drafted in and at 4am broke through the barricades.

A prison service spokesman said that an internal investigation was under way into the causes of the disturbances: "There is no evidence of staff assaulting inmates."

The spokesman added that a number of inmates had been moved out of the jail after the disturbances. "A number of prisoners refused to go back to their cells. They used furniture to block themselves in and eventually we decided to break through and remove them by force.

"The prison officers all dealt with the situation extremely well. They are trained to do so but the fact that no one was injured and the situation was resolved is testament to their skills."

Juliet Lyon of the Prison Reform Trust described Portland, built in 1848, as "a Napoleonic fort on a cliff edge which is totally unsuited to hold young inmates".

She added: "It's very unusual for young people to protest in the way they have collectively. It must indicate that there are serious issues."

Frances Crook, of the Howard League for Penal Reform, said: "Any inquiry should have an independent element to discover if there were legitimate issues being raised by the young offenders."

She added: "That independent element should either be the inspector of prisons or someone else from outside."

More than 120 MPs have signed an early day motion calling for a judicial inquiry into the allegations of abuse since last year.

webTitle: NTL to go for mobile network by the back door

fields.headline: NTL to go for mobile network by the back door
fields.standfirst:
NTL
Vodaphone
One 2 One
fields.trailText: NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, which last week fell at the final hurdle in the government's auction of next-generation mobile phone licences, has revived plans to launch a "virtual" network.
fields.body:
NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, which last week fell at the final hurdle in the government's auction of next-generation mobile phone licences, has revived plans to launch a "virtual" network.

Chief executive Barclay Knapp indicated that talks were under way to buy airtime wholesale from another network, with Vodafone and Orange understood to be the likely candidates.

The discussions emerged as NTL finally started its digital television services, six months after they had been due to go live. Mr Knapp also said the cable company would seek a primary listing in Europe, which is likely to be on the London/Frankfurt exchange, next year.

NTL was the last of the bidders to pull out of the mobile auction after almost eight weeks of bidding and 150 gruelling rounds of competition. Canadian telecoms company TIW, backed by Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa, won the fifth licence with a £4.4bn bid.

NTL aims to follow the model set by Virgin Mobile which buys airtime from the One2One network. Mr Knapp said NTL had an imperative to press ahead with its own plans irrespective of its largest shareholder, France Telecom, which is expected to bid for Orange.

NTL's digital television service will initially be available in Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales, and will be available across the country by the third quarter. As well as additional TV channels, the services will include pay per view and full internet access through television sets.

The company has targeted 300,000 digital customers by the end of the year.

Mr Knapp conceded that the service had launched "a little late". He blamed delays on implementation of services such as billing systems.

He said: "If I had my time over and was able to launch six months earlier then sure I would have liked to. But this isn't a road race."

NTL trails by some distance BSkyB, which started its digital service in October 1998 and claims to have signed up 3m households.

Mr Knapp maintained that the delay had not damaged NTL. "We don't overlap that much with Sky," he said. "There is 80% of the market that wants a bit more TV but is attracted to the telephony deals. Sky is for the real TV addicts."

webTitle: Army set up farm occupations, says insider

fields.headline: Army set up farm occupations, says insider
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The occupation of hundreds of white-owned farms in Zimbabwe was organised by senior military officers, including the former commander of the notorious Fifth Brigade which carried out atrocities in Matabeleland in the mid-80s, according to senior sources in the ruling party.
fields.body:
The occupation of hundreds of white-owned farms in Zimbabwe was organised by senior military officers, including the former commander of the notorious Fifth Brigade which carried out atrocities in Matabeleland in the mid-80s, according to senior sources in the ruling party.

On Wednesday, President Robert Mugabe denied prior knowledge of the land seizures by self-styled "war veterans" and thousands of poor black people, although he said the government welcomed and supported the occupations.

But according to senior officials of the ruling Zanu-PF party, who are unhappy about the destabilising impact of the land crisis on Zimbabwe, the farm seizures were ordered by the party's politburo and coordinated by the military.

The revelations provide fresh evidence that the land occupations were organised at the highest levels and give the lie to President Mugabe's claim that the seizures were a spontaneous outburst by desperate landless blacks. Zanu-PF leaders hammered out the strategy at a meeting in February in the wake of the government's politically devastating defeat in the national referendum on constitutional reform.

"No one trusted the war veterans to organise it on the scale the leadership was thinking of," said one senior party source. "They thought the veterans would just loot the farm houses and go home so the army was brought in to make sure they got onto the farms and stayed there. So they called in the military men who know how to do these things. The soldiers were also a restraining force, to make sure it only went so far. They didn't want it getting out of hand."

The occupations were coordinated by General Perence Shiri and retired Brigadier Ben Matanga. Gen Shiri formerly commanded the Fifth Brigade, widely held responsible for the massacre of tens of thousands of people while putting down an uprising in Matabeleland between 1982 and 1987. Gen Shiri is now head of Zimbabwe's air force, which has been flying the war veterans' leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi, between farms in a helicopter.

The party officials say the military deployed at least 1,000 soldiers and air force personnel - and possibly twice that number - to lead the occupations. The troops were ordered to wear civilian clothes and some were issued with army weapons, including Kalashnikovs. But the officials deny there was any intention to kill despite the murder of two white farmers during the occupations.

The military also provided food and transport to move the "war veterans" and others between farms. The army worked in coordination with Zimbabwe's Central Intelligence Organisation, which actively recruited war veterans and other people to occupy land. Zanu-PF provided the cash to pay the veterans.

When the occupations first began three months ago, the farmers and their union noted the evident coordination of the land seizures across large parts of Zimbabwe. The army's involvement explains why there were so many young faces among supposed "veterans" of a war which ended 20 years ago, how armed groups were able to move around relatively swiftly, and why some were carrying guns only issued to the military and police.

The Zanu-PF official claimed the farm occupations were partly motivated by a genuine anger within the party at the open support given by some white farmers and businessmen to the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, which spearheaded the government's defeat in the referendum.

"You must not underestimate the anger at the farmers who support the MDC, so it was a logical step to make land the issue. Once that is decided, then of course the state will use all the means at its disposal," he said.

The army spokesman, Colonel Chancellor Diye, denied the military's involvement in the land occupations. "The ministry of defence wishes to reiterate that the Zimbabwe Defence Force is a professional force guided by the established roles and functions as provided for in the statutes and regulations," he said.

But the defence minister, Moven Mahachi, was more circumspect. "We don't oppose the invasions because the army also wants land and this has been brought to my attention but what we don't want is anarchy," he said.

Zimbabwe's military chiefs have barely bothered to hide their role in meetings with white farmers union leaders.

The head of Zimbabwe's army, Vitalis Zvinavashe, and the head of the Central Intelligence Organisation, retired colonel Happison Bonongwe, paid separate visits to the president of the Commercial Farmers Union, Tim Henwood, on consecutive days a month ago. The CFU represents almost all the 4,000 white farmers in Zimbabwe.

Each time the message was the same; that the farmers had made a "fatal mistake" in supporting the opposition and that unless they backed away from politics "retaliation will be massive", according to a source close to the meeting. Gen Shiri also met CFU officials to convey a similar message.

As the land crisis has worsened, Mr Mugabe has increasingly fallen back on military rhetoric to justify his government's backing for the land seizures and the political row it has sparked with Britain. He portrays the land issue as a continuation of the liberation war, and threatens to fight anyone who resists.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Struggling blue chips Blue Circle and British Airways did their best to drag down the main FTSE 100 index yesterday, but a strong set of results from Shell and the Royal Bank of Scotland managed to keep the market in positive territory.
fields.body:
Struggling blue chips Blue Circle and British Airways did their best to drag down the main FTSE 100 index yesterday, but a strong set of results from Shell and the Royal Bank of Scotland managed to keep the market in positive territory.

Strong profit reports and the Bank of England's decision to hold base rates at 6% helped the FTSE fight off fears in New York of an overheating US economy and the likelihood of a Greenspan inspired a rate rise.

That said leading shares ended a volatile session only modestly higher, and by the close, the FTSE 100 index had climbed 14.8 points to 6,199.6, well above an early low at 6,162.5, but back from a morning high at 6,231.4.

All the broader FTSE in dices were firmer, with the Techmark 100 index adding nearly 15 points to 3,722.29. Like the main index, the Techmark suffered a volatile session.

A welter of corporate results and news also directed early attention in the City.

Shell's big jump in income, albeit in the first quarter, pushed up its own shares 5.75p to 509.5p and dragged up BP Amoco 4.5p to 557p. Royal Bank saw its shares rise 17.5p to £10.11 after posting proforma interim pre-tax profits of £715m, up 35% year-on-year, and most other finance houses followed suit.

Rival Bank of Scotland , on a desperately downward path since its decision to bid against Royal Bank for NatWest, recovered 58p to 598.5p. Barclays saw its shares rise 15p to £16.67 and Lloyds TSB followed suit, edging up 7.5p to 654p.

Allied Domecq profit figures were less exciting, mainly it seems due to a lack of Tequila making cactus. Blue Circle also brought more negative sentiment when it slipped 11.5p to 411.25p as investors mulled its future in the wake of the collapse of the £3.65bn Lafarge bid. British Airways fell 16p to 313p after April traffic statistics failed to impress.

Some good gains from "quality" hi-tech and telecom stocks continued to provide some limited support for the wider market, with British investors using Nasdaq's tumble overnight as an opportunity to bargain hunt at the lower levels.

Baltimore Technologies remained in demand ahead of next week's first-quarter results, up 464p to 7,119p, while Freeserve added 11 at 399p, and Kingston Communications gained 22p at 793p.

Thus rebounded from yesterday's post-results falls, gaining 14.5p at 354.5p. Colt Telecom , recently tipped by Nomura, was also in demand - up 146p at £28.15 - helped by news of the launch of a new network in Germany.

Strong profit reports and the Bank of England's decision to hold base rates at 6% helped the FTSE fight off fears in New York of an overheating US economy and the likelihood of a Greenspan inspired a rate rise. That said leading shares ended a volatile session only modestly higher, and by the close, the FTSE 100 index had climbed 14.8 points to 6,199.6, well above an early low at 6,162.5, but back from a morning high at 6,231.4. All the broader FTSE in dices were firmer, with the Techmark 100 index adding nearly 15 points to 3,722.29. Like the main index, the Techmark suffered a volatile session. A welter of corporate results and news also directed early attention in the City. Shell's big jump in income, albeit in the first quarter, pushed up its own shares 5.75p to 509.5p and dragged up BP Amoco 4.5p to 557p. Royal Bank saw its shares rise 17.5p to £10.11 after posting proforma interim pre-tax profits of £715m, up 35% year-on-year, and most other finance houses followed suit. Rival Bank of Scotland , on a desperately downward path since its decision to bid against Royal Bank for NatWest, recovered 58p to 598.5p. Barclays saw its shares rise 15p to £16.67 and Lloyds TSB followed suit, edging up 7.5p to 654p. Allied Domecq profit figures were less exciting, mainly it seems due to a lack of Tequila making cactus. Blue Circle also brought more negative sentiment when it slipped 11.5p to 411.25p as investors mulled its future in the wake of the collapse of the £3.65bn Lafarge bid. British Airways fell 16p to 313p after April traffic statistics failed to impress. Some good gains from "quality" hi-tech and telecom stocks continued to provide some limited support for the wider market, with British investors using Nasdaq's tumble overnight as an opportunity to bargain hunt at the lower levels. Baltimore Technologies remained in demand ahead of next week's first-quarter results, up 464p to 7,119p, while Freeserve added 11 at 399p, and Kingston Communications gained 22p at 793p. Thus rebounded from yesterday's post-results falls, gaining 14.5p at 354.5p. Colt Telecom , recently tipped by Nomura, was also in demand - up 146p at £28.15 - helped by news of the launch of a new network in Germany.

fields.headline: Raúl Rettig
fields.standfirst: Lawyer who exposed the crimes of Pinochet's Chile
fields.trailText: Faced with old age, illness and declining powers as he entered his ninth decade, the controversial Chilean politician and lawyer Raúl Rettig had a strange, but perhaps understandable, wish: "Please, let someone assassinate me." It was a tribute to the esteem in which he was held in Chilean society that no one carried out his request. fields.body:
Faced with old age, illness and declining powers as he entered his ninth decade, the controversial Chilean politician and lawyer Raúl Rettig had a strange, but perhaps understandable, wish: "Please, let someone assassinate me." It was a tribute to the esteem in which he was held in Chilean society that no one carried out his request. Instead, Rettig, who produced a historic report into Chile's civilian dead during General Pinochet's rule, died of natural causes in Santiago, a few days short of his 91st birthday.

Although denied a violent end, Rettig had often flirted with danger; he fought a celebrated duel with Salvador Allende, and risked the wrath of his country's armed forces, first, when investigating human rights abuses, and, more recently, when he questioned Pinochet's version of history after the former dictator was arrested in London.

Rettig was born in the southern city of Temuco, admirably described in the memoirs of another famous Chilean born there in the early years of this century, Pablo Neruda. This shared origin helped the two men become firm friends, despite their political differences. While Neruda was a communist, who stood down in favour of Allende's presidential bid, Rettig had trained as a teacher and lawyer, and joined the Chilean centrist Radical party in his youth.

The party shared in various coalition governments in the late 1930s and 1940s, and Rettig was deputy interior and deputy foreign minister in successive administrations. He also became party chairman and, in 1949, was elected as a senator.

A powerful orator, his style was often more combative than his beliefs. In 1952, this led him into a heated argument with the then Socialist party senator Allende. Matters got so out of hand that Rettig challenged Allende to a duel, which was duly set for six o'clock the next morning. Both men turned up with their seconds, and both fired their guns, but, as in the best tradition, both aimed to miss.

The Radical party was over taken in popularity in the 1950s and 1960s by more outspoken parties, including the communists and Allende's socialists. Rettig and the Radicals did, however, support the Allende-led Popular Unity government in 1970, and as a reward for his services, Rettig was appointed ambassador to Brazil, serving there until 1973.

When Pinochet led the military coup in Chile in 1973, Rettig was forced back into private life, and he took up his legal practice again. In 1985, he was elected as president of the prestigious Colegio de Abogados (or lawyers' association), where he struggled to maintain the independence of the profession despite the difficulties of military rule.

In 1990, after Pinochet had given way to civilian government in Chile, the new president, Patricio Aylwin, asked Rettig to head an eight-strong team investigating the accusations of murder, torture and disappearance that had arisen during the country's 17 years of military rule.

Collecting the evidence took Rettig and his colleagues a full year. In March 1991, he presented the six volumes of the finished report - which immediately became known as the Rettig report - to an emotional president. Such was the solidity of the evidence that, on receiving it, Aylwin apologised to all Chileans for the crimes committed against them by the state.

It had been hoped that the report would serve as the basis for trials against the perpetrators of human rights crimes, but the Chilean supreme court, still dominated by nominees loyal to Pinochet, blocked the move. The truth the report set out to uncover thus never reached the Chilean courts.

This was, in part, what made Pinochet's arrest in London at the end of 1998 so important. A black period in Chilean history seemed to have been opened up again, with the possibility of redress that might lead to proper reconciliation.

Typically, Rettig made few comments during the prolonged legal battle over the former dictator's fate. But when the general wrote an open letter to Chileans saying that he had acted to save his country, and claiming that one third of the 2,000 or more victims of the violence had been members of the security forces, Rettig pointed to his report. He had established that those killed in the line of duty numbered only 132.

In the new climate prevalent in Chile as a result of the Pinochet affair in London, Rettig was approached last year to lead a second investigation into what had happened to all those who had disappeared during the Pinochet years. He declined, saying that he no longer had the strength; indeed, by this time, he could hardly walk.

Both Rettig's wives predeceased him. He leaves a daughter, Soledad. Three days of national mourning were ordered in Chile after his death.

Raúl Rettig, lawyer and politician, born May 26 1909; died April 30 2000
