webTitle: Love bug virus creates worldwide chaos

fields.headline: Love bug virus creates worldwide chaos
fields.trailText: A computer virus which exploits office workers' yearnings for love shut down computer systems from Hong Kong to the Houses of Parliament yesterday and caused untold millions of pounds worth of delays and damage to stored files across the world.
fields.body:
A computer virus which exploits office workers' yearnings for love shut down computer systems from Hong Kong to the Houses of Parliament yesterday and caused untold millions of pounds worth of delays and damage to stored files across the world.

The virus, nicknamed "the love bug" and "the killer from Manila" after its apparent Philippine origins, is carried in an email with the heading "ILOVEYOU".

The text of the message reads: "Kindly check the attached love letter from me!" A click on the attached file launches the virus, which promptly spreads by sending itself to everyone in the recipient's email address book, overloading email systems.

Once embedded in a host computer, the virus can download more dangerous software from a remote website, rename files and redirect internet browsers.

"It's a very effective virus. It's one of the most aggressive and nastiest I've ever seen," said Kieran Fitzsimmons of MessageLabs, which screens millions of company emails for viruses. "It manifests itself almost everywhere in the computer."

One tenth of the world's mail servers were down as a result of the love bug, he said.

Estimates suggested that between 10% and 30% of UK businesses were hit.

Among the firms and organisations affected in the UK yesterday were Microsoft, News International - publishers of the Times and the Sun - the BBC, a number of FTSE-100 companies and parliament.

In an announcement to the Commons, Margaret Beckett, leader of the House, said that the parliamentary email system had crashed. "I have to tell you that, sadly, this affectionate greeting contains a virus which has immobilised the house's internal communication system," she said.

At the UK arm of Reed International, publisher of trade magazines, IT engineers alerted staff with Tannoy announcements after the bug had already crippled their computer system.

"It completely wipes out your network," said Sarah Perkins of PC Pro magazine. "Ours is down and we're going to lose a day's business."

The virus spread west from Asia as offices opened and workers checked their emails. The only clue to its origins lies in the first few lines of the code which makes it work. They are headed: "I hate go to school." The next line identifies the author as "spyder" and the next refers to "Manila, Philippines".

Daphne Ghesquiere, a Dow Jones spokesman in Hong Kong, said: "It crashed all the computers. You get the message and the topic says ILOVEYOU, and I was among the stupid ones to open it. I got about five at one time and I was suspicious, but one was from Dow Jones Newswires, so I opened it."

Later Germany, France, Switzerland and the Low Countries were seriously affected.

IT specialists described the love bug as "a visual basic worm" far more dangerous and fast-spreading than the similar Melissa virus, which also replicated itself by email. Melissa infected about a million computers and caused £50m of damage.

ILOVEYOU is eight times bigger, sends itself to everyone in a recipient's address book instead of just the first 50 (and then deletes the address book), and, unlike Melissa, tampers with operating systems.

By yesterday afternoon MessageLabs had picked up 10,000 infected emails. The highest number in one day until now has been 700.

Last night another virus tracker, TrendMicro, was reporting more than 800,000 infected files around the world, the bulk of them in the US.

One expert said the love bug spread "like wild fire" in Britain after 11.30am.

"It's taking out computers right, left and centre," he said.

fields.headline: Freecom buys established software house
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freecom.net yesterday paid £31.9m for Systems Union a software business, in an attempt to distance itself from the "cash burn" model of conventional internet start-ups.
fields.body:
Freecom.net yesterday paid £31.9m for Systems Union a software business, in an attempt to distance itself from the "cash burn" model of conventional internet start-ups.

Michael Williams, Freecom chief executive, said the investment community was increasingly uneasy about the money being spent by start-ups to build their brands and customer bases.

The acquisition of Systems Union, he said, brought with it 18,000 customers and would help Freecom to move toward breakeven earlier than originally planned. Freecom provides e-commerce solutions for small and medium sized businesses.

"The Mad Hatter's tea party is over," Mr Williams said. "The City will not keep providing money to burn. Internet companies now have no choice and should use their paper to go and buy real companies with real customers. Last minute.com should bid for Thomson Travel.) "

Freecom has felt the disaffection of investors along with the rest of the sector and has seen its share price fall from 550p at the start of March to 227.5p yesterday.

The acquisition of Sun Systems was the second by Freecom in its relatively short life as a public company. In March the business acquired Oneview.net Oneview.net which also offered services to companies wanting to get online.

The Sun Systems deal provides the group with £73m of revenues although it made an operating loss of £752,000 last year. Mr Williams said the enlarged group would break even within 12-18 months.

The offer for Sun Systems was made up of 7.8m new Freecom shares and £7m in cash. Freecom said it would build a hosting business around Sun Systems' applications. The company is seeking a telecoms partner to provide bandwidth capacity.

webTitle: Who are you? What the Freeserve ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Freeserve ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: This shocking (and arguably exploitative) commercial features a model who has no legs. We see some characters fooling around on a catwalk, rehearsing for a show, then cut to a woman relaxing backstage. She's a model, and we see that she's lost the bottom half of her legs. We then see her all dressed up, running down the catwalk on curious metal posts, to rapturous applause. "It's a total feeling of accomplishment," she says, as the endline "be free. freeserve.com" comes up.
fields.body:
The ad: This shocking (and arguably exploitative) commercial features a model who has no legs. We see some characters fooling around on a catwalk, rehearsing for a show, then cut to a woman relaxing backstage. She's a model, and we see that she's lost the bottom half of her legs. We then see her all dressed up, running down the catwalk on curious metal posts, to rapturous applause. "It's a total feeling of accomplishment," she says, as the endline "be free. freeserve.com" comes up.

The jargon: The ad aims to demonstrate that freeserve - the UK's biggest internet service provider - "gives you the liberty to express yourself both on the internet and in life itself" by rejoicing in a top paraplegic model who isn't going to let her disability hold her back.

Personality: It might not be to everyone's taste, but the ad is a mass-market commercial, targeting all potential internet users in the UK. So you are basically anyone with a PC (apparently 30 per cent of the population has one). You are also most likely to be ABC1C2, and probably male (there's a 60/40 male skew among PC owners).

Financial status: Freeserve is, well, free, providing free access to the net. You only need to pay for your local call charges.

Telling lifestyle detail: You obviously don't have to be disabled, just someone with a computer who values their freedom (as well as, er, getting things for free).

Other relevant data: The model is Amy Mullins, now 24, who was handicapped at the age of one but who has managed to become a leading paraplegic athlete as well as a top model. The legs she uses in the ad are the ones she normally runs on, and they're modelled on a cheetah's. This is the first ad she's ever done.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Prince Valiant
fields.body:
Prince Valiant

(Anthony Hickox, 1997)

3pm, Sky Premier

A Euro-take on the American comic-strip hero that children will love. This is Arthurian romance done in a heady pop-video style, with gothic touches from horror-man Hickox and a dash of Braveheart in the battles, but nothing too gruesome. Stephen Moyer plays the lowly Camelot squire who becomes Prince Valiant, while Katherine Heigl is a very post-Leia princess and Edward Fox is King Arthur. But best of all is Joanna Lumley as scheming Morgan le Fey - see AbFab's Patsy get medieval!

Bullets Over Broadway

(Woody Allen, 1994)

9pm & 1am, UK Drama

John Cusack takes the role Allen coveted but was too old to play: a struggling writer given a Broadway spot by the mob on condition that his show stars gangster's moll Jennifer Tilly. But it's her bodyguard, Chazz Palminteri, who proves he's as good with a pen as he is with a gun. Vicious shotgun attack on theatrical types, with Dianne Wiest stealing the show as a grand Broadway dame.

Dead Man

(Jim Jarmusch, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

Weird, wonderful and bizarre Jarmusch western, full of deadpan humour and arresting imagery. Johnny Depp plays William Blake, a Cleveland clerk heading out to a new job in the wild west.Pursued by bounty hunters, he meets up with an Indian called Nobody (Gary Farmer), who's convinced he's the poet William Blake. Cast includes Robert Mitchum, Gabriel Byrne and Iggy Pop.

The Idiots

(Lars Von Trier, 1998)

12.20am, FilmFour

Von Trier's satire caused uproar at the Cannes festival two years ago, not so much because it was made under the purist Dogme regulations (natural lighting, handheld cameras, etc), but because of the content - it concerns a small group of people who pretend to be disabled. Moving beyond the limits of acceptable behaviour, they test society's values - and the patience of the audience. Demanding, funny, explicit, this is a flawed film, but more than just a sick joke.

fields.headline: Night of the living dead
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Tributes should be confined to the fortnight after a person's death. That way, there'd be none of the confusion engendered by No Alf Measures (BBC1), in which an impressive array of luvvies delivered eulogies to Warren Mitchell. A shocked nation duly bowed its head and reached for the tissues. But no sooner was the last nose wiped than Mr Mitchell himself took centre stage, alive and well and - as it turned out - a major contributor to the tribute.
fields.body:
Tributes should be confined to the fortnight after a person's death. That way, there'd be none of the confusion engendered by No Alf Measures (BBC1), in which an impressive array of luvvies delivered eulogies to Warren Mitchell. A shocked nation duly bowed its head and reached for the tissues. But no sooner was the last nose wiped than Mr Mitchell himself took centre stage, alive and well and - as it turned out - a major contributor to the tribute.

Perhaps those raised from the dead have a right to arrogance - or perhaps it's just actors - but there was little endearing in Mitchell's account of how Alf Garnett single-handedly reversed the policy of BBC Light Entertainment. Nor was it noble of him to parody Anthony Hopkins, in a smug anecdote designed to tell us who is the more dedicated actor.

The programme's purpose, if it had one, seemed to be an exorcism of past ghosts. A penitent Lawrence Marks and Maurice Gran, original writers of Til Death Us Do Part, were shown surrounded by wine bottles, as if they were slowly drinking themselves to death in a subterranean hide-out. They said they were embarrassed nowadays by Alf Garnett's racism. Mitchell, certainly no racist himself, pointed out that Alf was merely a parody. But before anyone could utter the words "Ali G", we were whisked away to the plush opera box of Sir Peter Hall, whose stentorian tones urged us to forget all about that nasty old sitcom and remember Mitchell's brilliant theatre performance in Death Of A Salesman. From the tantalising clips of this - and his 1995 performance as King Lear - it did indeed seem that 'orrible Alf repre sents just a fraction of the actor's talents. Screening these performances would surely have been the most fitting compliment - this bizarre pat on the back looked more like Mitchell's bid for a knighthood.

Perhaps David Starkey will also receive a regal tap on the shoulder for his enthusiastic life story of the first Queen Elizabeth (C4). It seems that the Tudor queen lived through more than one annus horribilis. Her dad's idea of compassion was to behead her mum with a sword instead of the customary blunt axe. After Henry VIII died of a burst leg, Elizabeth fell prey to the unnatural attentions of her step-father, Thomas Seymour. The graphic reconstructions - showing him sneaking into her bedchamber to tickle her, and making suggestive horseplay with his sword - were peculiar, and rather got in the way of the narrative. Nonetheless, Dr Starkey had unearthed some fascinating details, including early examples of the Queen's Latin homework, and a decidedly wobbly letter she penned while awaiting execution in the Tower. One wonders what treasures await next week - an exclusive glimpse of the first spud in England?

The march of science is endangering Britain's most beloved creature. The naturalist - once to be found whispering edgily next to a band of silver-backed gorillas, or snaring his beard in the branches of a gum tree - is soon to become a thing of the past. The fault lies with programmes like Predators (BBC1), which seem to think that flashy graphics and cyber-age camera-trickery are fair substitutes for an Attenborough or a Bellamy. Deafened by a backing track of hardcore techno, we were delivered five breakneck examples of nature's predators in action. These included a crocodile which, despite having a camera mounted upon its head, made a noble stab at biting some zebras. Meanwhile the action, freeze-framed and replayed beyond the point of decency, was "explained" by the narrator in terms which would leave the average research scientist scratching their head. Most dramatic of all, we were told, is the complex encounter between the eagle and the hare. We then saw this. For anyone who blinked, the clip was repeated - all nine-twenty-fifths of a second of it. This is not long enough for anything "dramatic" to unfold - not even on Neighbours.

"You're going to kiss me right in the middle of dinner?" Detective Sipowicz asked, as his baby son tried to comfort him after a hard day of busting perps ( NYPD Blue , C4). The best line in a dreary episode. Now that Sipowicz is playing the widowed Dad, expect lots of saccharine stuff more worthy of a Tom Hanks film - those after gritty realism would be better off watching Friends.

fields.headline: On the road
fields.standfirst: In the anonymous, enclosed space of a London taxi, all manner of fleeting dramas can unfold. At least that's the theory behind Black Cab, BBC2's series of short plays. But does it measure up to reality, asks taxi driver  Andrew Wallace
fields.trailText: In the anonymous, enclosed space of a London taxi, all manner of fleeting dramas can unfold. At least that's the theory behind Black Cab, BBC2's series of short plays. But does it measure up to reality, asks taxi driver Andrew Wallace
fields.body:
It's late and I'm in casualty at St Thomas's in London. Acting as translator for a young Italian with appalling English. Actually, "translator" is a bit strong, implying as it does some actual knowledge of Italian. More accurately, I am reducing. Summarising a complex tale of woe that has unravelled in the back of my cab since I picked him up in Kennington. He needs methadone for his friend, but does not want to risk shopping in Brixton. He needs it now. Is it really for him? No! It's for his friend. Of course the nurse says that she can't just give him methadone. There are procedures. He needs it now. And so it goes. A million stories in the city.

This is the premise for Black Cab, an innovative new series of 10-minute dramas shot in the back of a London taxi modified to create a mobile multi-camera studio; the theory being that intimate exchanges in a tight space make good theatre. The cab driver as confessor. Just the back of a head through a sliding door. You can tell him anything, safe in the knowledge you'll never see that person again. A private space where the rules of the outside world do not apply. Series creator Amelia Bullmore observes that talking to a cabbie is like therapy only much cheaper.

Bullmore herself has written three of the strongest stories, focusing on unremarkable people whose love lives have led them astray. Nothing too fantastic, just tightly scripted and tantalisingly brief snatches of human existence. The kind of conversations you could hear regularly in a cab. Busy Body opens the series, an amusing, well-acted tale of a cab driver who picks up a jogger with an unusual exercise programme. After the well-heeled jogger suffers the cabbie's barrage of questions, there is a moment of delightful fantasy in his response: "Would you mind not talking?" Not a socially acceptable reaction to intrusive chit-chat, but one many passengers must dream of saying. Of course, hardly anybody does. They suffer in silence. Unwilling to create an atmosphere in such a confined space.

For more talkative fares, there is the tip seat directly behind the driver and the intimacy of these conversations is well captured in Bullmore's second story, Marriage Guidance. The actors are only inches apart. As a dramatic device it is excellent, heightening the sense of the cab as confessional. In reality, a tip seat passenger is invisible to the driver in the rear view mirror. They become a disembodied voice in your car, often close enough to smell the expired alcohol.

The episodes that succeed are those where least is happening on the surface. No shouting, no blood, no RADA 'ooligans. A story like Work. Written by an ex-cabbie, it's authentic and restrained, the story of an ordinary person with an unusual job - a male escort. All the animals come out at night, and these are the kind of people - table dancers, the late-night crowd - who make the most intriguing fares.

With the films that fail, there appear to be two problems. Co-producer Jake Lushington says they sought a wide variety of stories, but "nothing unbelievable". Unfortunately, many of the episodes have the feel of stories shoehorned into categories. As a consequence, while not strictly unbelievable, a rather bogus air hangs around them. Fact can be stranger than fiction, but blood-spattered psychotics, abandoned children and implausibly generous American tourists handing out airline tickets are not the stuff of everyday life. The writers who have succeeded understand that colourful "characters" do not in themselves make for good drama.

The second difficulty with this project is that short films are tricky to both write and direct. The former EastEnders actress Susan Tully, who directed five episodes, observes that "The trick is not to skate over an important moment. You have to be absolutely aware of the significance of everything." But when Lushington says that the writers complained they couldn't fit a three-act story into 10 minutes, you can't help wondering why he didn't listen to them.

Many films, such as Lost and Found, begin well. A cabbie spins a hard luck story to boost his tip. Nice dialogue, beautifully acted by Phil Davies. Enough. Then, presumably in compliance with the immutable law of the three-act structure, the plot begins to flip-flop around in a manner which can only be described as nonsense. Passengers leap in and out of the cab. The driver leaps in and out of the cab. It's a small but telling point that the stories where the driver is rooted in his cab are superior to those where characters are on the move every time a new act is signalled.

As a rule of thumb, most drivers are highly resistant to leaving the cab for any reason. (The exception to this being, of course, the Holy Grail of all jobs - Heathrow. I have seen arthritic old drivers leaping gazelle-like from their cabs to load luggage before the hapless punter can change his mind.) In your cab you are unassailable. Inscrutable. Father confessor with the power to absolve sin and talk bollocks. Cabbies have an instinctive grasp that when you begin to get involved with passengers you have crossed a line. It's late and I'm in casualty . . .

Black Cab, from Monday 8 May, 10.20pm, BBC2

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: News that Telewest is talking to magazine publisher IPC about a possible acquisition brings heaps of exciting new television opportunities to mind.
fields.body:
News that Telewest is talking to magazine publisher IPC about a possible acquisition brings heaps of exciting new television opportunities to mind.

IPC is one of the country's biggest publishers of consumer magazines. It houses the likes of Loaded, Marie Claire, Woman's Own and the list-tastic TV Times. Cable company Telewest is in the process of merging with TV company Flextech which owns the Bravo, Trouble and UK Gold/Drama/Horizons/Style channels. It has its sights set on convergent media. What does this mean? Only that you'll be able to access the same media content on your mobile phone and PC as on your TV. Yippee!

A deal with IPC would, of course, give the Telewest/Flextech behemoth (they're looking for another name, not surprisingly) a great deal more lovely content to relay to us punters over the various media. Just think of that regular "poor but 'appy" story every month in Marie Claire - you know, the worthy feature at the front about (this month) "Cuban revolutionaries to child conscripts of Liberia - these brave female fighters". Now that would look great in all singing and dancing colour on your mobile or personal digital assistant. Wouldn't it? And what scope for the monthly Come Again - The Facts Of Life slot from Loaded? I can see that working as a regular email bulletin, brightening every dull day at the orifice.

Of course, TV Times offers perhaps the most possibilities. Imagine a world where you could skip from an audio-enhanced version of Donna Hay advising Zak to send Nellie packing (from the sets of Emmerdale) relayed over your hands-free phone to a Videoplus programme allowing you to record that night's episode via your TV Times software on your work PC. The only problem might be your boss, left wondering if you ever do any work at all. Time, if ever there was one, to make good that ambition to work in the media, where you can claim all this interactivity is simply "research".

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline:
No: 1630
 Doomsday
fields.trailText: Age: New.
fields.body:
Age: New.

Appearance: Catastrophic - tidal waves, tornados, earthquakes, plagues of locusts, cosmic chaos.

Crikey, I'd better get the washing in. What's happening? This morning sees the conjunction of the Sun, the Moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Saturn and Jupiter, all coming together in the constellation Taurus.

Is that bad? A situation of the utmost gravity.

Well it's rather pleasant here in Didsbury. No earthquakes?

No. Tornados?

A bit of a breeze. Cosmic chaos?

There's a traffic jam in the Wilmslow Road. Don't you wonder why?

Traffic light failure? Armageddon!

Are planetary alignments unusual? They occur about once a decade, but ones involving seven planets are very rare. Hence the panic.

What panic? Maybe it's passed Didsbury by, but Nebraska's nuclear shelters have been full for weeks.

When was the last seven-planet alignment? In 1962, in Aquarius, and look what happened then.

What? An earthquake in Iran, floods in Europe, the start of Beatlemania.

That was 1963. Didsbury, as usual, was behind the game.

I bet nothing happens. Read Jonathan Cainer, the Express's astronomically well-paid astrologer.

What does he say? "This cosmic alignment is here to shake us awake. Expect several stories that make you sit up and take notice."

Such as? Dot.com shares will tumble; computers will collapse; politicians will make wild excuses for abject electoral failure.

A normal day in Didsbury. I'm going out. Look out for the locusts.

Not to be confused with: The Jupiter Effect, astronomer John Gribbin's prediction that an alignment in 1982 would cause huge earthquakes. There were none.

Do say: Anything you like - no one's listening. The phone lines are down, the telly's blown up, and Manchester's been overwhelmed by a tsunami.

What's a tsunami? An anagram of "I am nuts".

webTitle: Does your daddy know you're here?

fields.headline: Does your daddy know you're here?
fields.standfirst: The news that a violent activist involved in the May Day riot was an Etonian shocked many. But not John Vidal, who knows a thing or two about public school rebellion. Expensive education and revolutionary urges have always gone hand in hand.
fields.trailText: The news that a violent activist involved in the May Day riot was an Etonian shocked many. But not John Vidal, who knows a thing or two about public school rebellion. Expensive education and revolutionary urges have always gone hand in hand.
fields.body:
The setting is lunch in a northern public school, circa 1968. One hundred boys in Foundation House - mostly the sons of landowners, industrialists, nuclear scientists and civil servants - have just queued for their weekly ration of marmalade, strawberry jam or lemon curd, supposed to last each one a week. Rule 423b, or perhaps just tradition, states that each of us must eat only his own food. But rebellion is brewing in the lower sixth. The conversation goes something like this:

Boy A: "This is stupid. Why don't we just pool everything? You can share mine, I can share yours. That way, we'll all have a choice."

Boy B: "But that's... that's communism."

Boy C: "Well it makes sense..."

Boy D: "Think where this could end..."

Boy A: "Exactly."

And so began the Battle of the Jams, a miniature revolution which was at first brutally repressed and eventually accepted by an ancient school that prided itself on physical prowess and arcane privileges, boasting more by-laws and rules than any government could conceive.

The revolution spread fast, from table to table and then house to house. The prefects, sensing correctly a threat to their power and an overthrow of the state, tried to stamp it out, picking on the weakest with punishment runs, and then on the ringleaders by cancelling privileges.

But they only drove the revolution underground. The housemaster publicly condemned the sharing of private goods - "the property of the school" - as subversive, a word few of us had ever heard before. Two of us - wrongly identified, as it happened - were thrashed, but within weeks, the ancient system of one man, one jam had crumbled.

And there it might have ended, if the jam wars had not coincided with a talk to the school given by one of the founders of Amnesty International, the French student revolt and intense classroom discussions about Sartre and existentialism. The combination of personal experience of repression, a growing awareness of human rights, and a philosophical system to bat our own ideas off was powerful stuff.

Within a year, the whole school system was being rejected. Why, we asked, should prefects be allowed to beat young boys? Why should they have fags - effectively, slaves - to cook, clean, iron and run errands for them? Why should we look at our feet when passing a senior boy, or wear shorts until the age of 18?

Within two years, under a barrage of criticism led by the boys and then their parents, the school had changed, and much of the social repression had been abolished. How many of those boys are still social reformers or questioners of the establishment I do not know - but I suspect that the answer is quite a few.

Public schools have always bred an anti-establishment view. No one is more qualified than a public schoolboy to recognise dictatorship, fascism, human rights abuse and inequality. If you separate bright children from their parents at a very young age, keep them in borstal-type conditions, and instil in them even a modicum of social awareness, you are bound to get not just a majority who toe the line, question nothing and further a class or economic system that only benefits them, but a smaller group who at some time in their lives will rebel intellectually, emotionally or physically.

Matthew MacDonald is one of the rebels. The 17-year-old's time at Eton College came to an abrupt end on Wednesday night after he was arrested near Trafalgar Square amid the violence that erupted during Monday's anti-capitalism demonstrations. "He submitted a letter saying that although he loves the school and very much appreciates the teaching, his political views don't allow him in conscience to continue at such a privileged institution," his father Theodore MacDonald, a professor at London's Brunel University, was quoted as saying. What Matthew did enjoy about Eton, an anonymous friend of his added, was that he could "destroy the Establishment from within."

MacDonald's arrest comes days after the acquittal of Lord Melchett (Eton, Cambridge), executive director of Greenpeace and GM crop trampler, and two weeks after the acquittal of Mark Brown (Radley, Goldsmith's College), 36-year-old grandson of the Dewhurst tycoon Sir Derek Vestey, who had been accused of helping to organise last November's City riots. Brown shares a trust fund valued at £2.7m - a clear £700,000 more than the estimated cost of the damage caused by the riot.

But the wilder shores of activism have always been tinged with bluer blood than might at first be supposed. The tradition of public school social reform is long, and the thread of money and privilege runs through almost every radical social movement Britain has known. Abolitionists, the first animal rights activists, many early campaigners for trade unionism, some of the first socialists, communists, suffrage campaigners and feminists, through to the human rights and anti-nuclear movements have all been led, or at least intellectually informed, by the sons and daughters of the rich.

Today's environment movement is in this respect no different, attracting numerous representatives of the financially or socially privileged classes. As well as Melchett and Brown, its leading lights include a host of former public schoolboys and girls: Jonathon (Lord) Porritt, the heir to a baronetcy, Sir Crispin Tickell, George Monbiot, the tribe of Goldsmiths, Gordon Roddick, the Marchioness of Worcester (who proposed setting up an eco-village on the family estate); Julia Stephenson, novelist, anti-fur campaigner and Mark Brown's sister, several of the early Earth-Firsters and, of course, Prince Charles himself. All, at one time or another, have been vilified and ridiculed in the press and the green movement for the role they play.

Their motives are complex. Some have reacted against the part their families have played in environmental destruction. Most understand that the environmental movement, if it is to succeed, must address the allied problems of poverty, development, capitalism and global injustice - and that they are therefore effectively fighting for the very people their families have so long ignored.

"Among the aristocrats there is a sense of stewardship, of noblesse oblige, of wanting to use your position for the general good," says Charles Secrett (Cranleigh), executive director of Friends of the Earth. "There is also for some of them a sort of guilt - they are so lucky, have so much, that they need to give more. For the landed aristocracy, there is also a feeling of stewardship towards the land." Many public schools have had vibrant environment groups, often encouraged by masters; Matthew MacDonald had founded a school society in tribute to another radical old Etonian, George Orwell. The destruction of Twyford Down - widely accepted to have been the catalyst for much of the direct action in the past seven years - was most actively opposed by young Wykehamists, whose own school, Winchester College, played its part by selling the land for the bypass to the government.

"All movements are started by the middle classes, the ones who read the newspapers and who have the time to take part - even Communism," says Teddy Goldsmith, veteran environmental activist and first editor of the Ecologist magazine, a post now filled by his nephew Zac. "But I've been in the environmental movement for 35 years and I have never seen anything like what is happening now: people from every walk of life, from all classes, are all joining together, because they see themselves as victims of the globalised economy, and they object to the fact that Mr Blair and Mr Clinton behave as if they are employees of a handful of global corporations."

None the less - as Matthew MacDonald is discovering - the life of the privileged activist can be particularly prone to philosophical contradictions. As Goldsmith once famously said: "Dear boy, the sort of revolution I want will put me up against the wall first."

fields.bodyText: The setting is lunch in a northern public school, circa 1968. One hundred boys in Foundation House - mostly the sons of landowners, industrialists, nuclear scientists and civil servants - have just queued for their weekly ration of marmalade, strawberry jam or lemon curd, supposed to last each one a week. Rule 423b, or perhaps just tradition, states that each of us must eat only his own food. But rebellion is brewing in the lower sixth. The conversation goes something like this: Boy A: "This is stupid. Why don't we just pool everything? You can share mine, I can share yours. That way, we'll all have a choice." Boy B: "But that's... that's communism." Boy C: "Well it makes sense..." Boy D: "Think where this could end..." Boy A: "Exactly." And so began the Battle of the Jams, a miniature revolution which was at first brutally repressed and eventually accepted by an ancient school that prided itself on physical prowess and arcane privileges, boasting more by-laws and rules than any government could conceive. The revolution spread fast, from table to table and then house to house. The prefects, sensing correctly a threat to their power and an overthrow of the state, tried to stamp it out, picking on the weakest with punishment runs, and then on the ringleaders by cancelling privileges. But they only drove the revolution underground. The housemaster publicly condemned the sharing of private goods - "the property of the school" - as subversive, a word few of us had ever heard before. Two of us - wrongly identified, as it happened - were thrashed, but within weeks, the ancient system of one man, one jam had crumbled. And there it might have ended, if the jam wars had not coincided with a talk to the school given by one of the founders of Amnesty International, the French student revolt and intense classroom discussions about Sartre and existentialism. The combination of personal experience of repression, a growing awareness of human rights, and a philosophical system to bat our own ideas off was powerful stuff. Within a year, the whole school system was being rejected. Why, we asked, should prefects be allowed to beat young boys? Why should they have fags - effectively, slaves - to cook, clean, iron and run errands for them? Why should we look at our feet when passing a senior boy, or wear shorts until the age of 18? Within two years, under a barrage of criticism led by the boys and then their parents, the school had changed, and much of the social repression had been abolished. How many of those boys are still social reformers or questioners of the establishment I do not know - but I suspect that the answer is quite a few. Public schools have always bred an anti-establishment view. No one is more qualified than a public schoolboy to recognise dictatorship, fascism, human rights abuse and inequality. If you separate bright children from their parents at a very young age, keep them in borstal-type conditions, and instil in them even a modicum of social awareness, you are bound to get not just a majority who toe the line, question nothing and further a class or economic system that only benefits them, but a smaller group who at some time in their lives will rebel intellectually, emotionally or physically. Matthew MacDonald is one of the rebels. The 17-year-old's time at Eton College came to an abrupt end on Wednesday night after he was arrested near Trafalgar Square amid the violence that erupted during Monday's anti-capitalism demonstrations. "He submitted a letter saying that although he loves the school and very much appreciates the teaching, his political views don't allow him in conscience to continue at such a privileged institution," his father Theodore MacDonald, a professor at London's Brunel University, was quoted as saying. What Matthew did enjoy about Eton, an anonymous friend of his added, was that he could "destroy the Establishment from within." MacDonald's arrest comes days after the acquittal of Lord Melchett (Eton, Cambridge), executive director of Greenpeace and GM crop trampler, and two weeks after the acquittal of Mark Brown (Radley, Goldsmith's College), 36-year-old grandson of the Dewhurst tycoon Sir Derek Vestey, who had been accused of helping to organise last November's City riots. Brown shares a trust fund valued at £2.7m - a clear £700,000 more than the estimated cost of the damage caused by the riot. But the wilder shores of activism have always been tinged with bluer blood than might at first be supposed. The tradition of public school social reform is long, and the thread of money and privilege runs through almost every radical social movement Britain has known. Abolitionists, the first animal rights activists, many early campaigners for trade unionism, some of the first socialists, communists, suffrage campaigners and feminists, through to the human rights and anti-nuclear movements have all been led, or at least intellectually informed, by the sons and daughters of the rich. Today's environment movement is in this respect no different, attracting numerous representatives of the financially or socially privileged classes. As well as Melchett and Brown, its leading lights include a host of former public schoolboys and girls: Jonathon (Lord) Porritt, the heir to a baronetcy, Sir Crispin Tickell, George Monbiot, the tribe of Goldsmiths, Gordon Roddick, the Marchioness of Worcester (who proposed setting up an eco-village on the family estate); Julia Stephenson, novelist, anti-fur campaigner and Mark Brown's sister, several of the early Earth-Firsters and, of course, Prince Charles himself. All, at one time or another, have been vilified and ridiculed in the press and the green movement for the role they play. Their motives are complex. Some have reacted against the part their families have played in environmental destruction. Most understand that the environmental movement, if it is to succeed, must address the allied problems of poverty, development, capitalism and global injustice - and that they are therefore effectively fighting for the very people their families have so long ignored. "Among the aristocrats there is a sense of stewardship, of noblesse oblige, of wanting to use your position for the general good," says Charles Secrett (Cranleigh), executive director of Friends of the Earth. "There is also for some of them a sort of guilt - they are so lucky, have so much, that they need to give more. For the landed aristocracy, there is also a feeling of stewardship towards the land." webTitle: Six die in Hizbullah rocket attacks on Israel

fields.headline: Six die in Hizbullah rocket attacks on Israel
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Hours after Ehud Barak's government confirmed it would test Star Wars laser defence system on its borders, Hizbullah guerrillas last night demonstrated the power of their rockets in a fiery assault on northern Israel.
fields.body:
Hours after Ehud Barak's government confirmed it would test Star Wars laser defence system on its borders, Hizbullah guerrillas last night demonstrated the power of their rockets in a fiery assault on northern Israel.

Israeli radio said at least six people were injured by some 40 Katyusha rockets, which fell on the northern town of Kiryat Shemona and border settlements for more than half an hour yesterday evening.

Hizbullah said the attack was in retaliation for Israeli strikes on its self-declared security zone in south Lebanon.

As darkness fell, thousands of people descended into underground bunkers in Kiryat Shemona and kibbutzes on the Lebanese border.

Israel's security cabinet was to meet late last night to discuss its response, Israeli television said, a move likely to lead to heavy bombing of south Lebanon.

Yesterday's attacks underscored the vulnerability of Israel's northern villages in advance of the planned troop withdrawal from Lebanon on July 7.

US officials announced earlier this week that the powerful laser-based defence system being developed jointly by both countries had hit stationary targets. It is to be tested against a moving Katyusha later this month, and then shipped to Israel for further testing and deployment.

The possible deployment of the laser represents a revival of the previously discredited Strategic Defence Initiative - or Star Wars - of the 1980s.

However, Israeli defence experts say the technology is unlikely to be in place for two years - leaving the villages of northern Israeli exposed to Hizbullah assaults.

Last night's attack was the deadliest assault on Israeli territory since last June. A spokesman for the Shi'ite Muslim militia said the attacks were in retaliation for the deaths of an 80-year-old Lebanese woman and her daughter, who were killed by Israeli artillery bombardment overnight on Wednesday.

fields.trailText: Clare Short, the secretary of state for international development, has asked us to say that contrary to the suggestion in a report, page 13, April 7, she is not blocking, nor is she in a position to block, Cuba's accession to the new EU-ACP convention. She says Cuba's accession would be warmly welcomed if it decided to bring itself within the terms of membership. She points out that all EU members agreed in 1998 there had to be substantial progress in Cuba's human rights record before it could join.

webTitle: Alchemy head gets £5m fee from BMW for Rover talks

fields.headline: Alchemy head gets £5m fee from BMW for Rover talks
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Jon Moulton, head of Alchemy Partners, is understood to have been receiving more than £100,000 a day from BMW for work on Alchemy's abortive bid to buy Rover.
fields.body:
Jon Moulton, head of Alchemy Partners, is understood to have been receiving more than £100,000 a day from BMW for work on Alchemy's abortive bid to buy Rover.

The highly unusual fee, which tops £5m, was arranged before the venture capitalist opened detailed talks with the German car manufacturer, which has now set an end-of-month deadline to dispose of the ailing car operation. Mr Moulton, who has blamed a series of complex legal hurdles imposed by BMW for the decision to end negotiations after six weeks, expects to make a profit after the detailed talks to buy Rover.

His shock decision to walk away from the deal last week has left 24,000 workers in the West Midlands facing redundancy and forced the German car manufacturer to open last-ditch talks with Phoenix, the consortium led by former Rover chief executive John Towers.

Mr Moulton last night continued to pour scorn on the ability of Phoenix to clinch a deal with BMW and made it clear that he expected the German car manufacturer to resume talks with him when the Phoenix negotiations collapse.

"Do not imagine we have gone away," Mr Moulton said.

Admitting that he had negotiated a "flat fee" with BMW before starting the talks in March, he refused to reveal the size of the payment or how it had been structured.

Most of the fee would be used to settle lawyers' fees and other costs associated with the bid.

Alchemy's plans for Rover were unpopular with workers in Longbridge as Mr Moulton had made it clear he would sack most of the 9,000 workers, abandoning high volume manufacturing.

The collapse of his negotiations opened the door for Phoenix, which has set up a shell company called Tech-tronic 2000 to run Rover. Workers and the government are more supportive of this deal. Mr Towers has pledged to continue mass production of cars at the site.

Mr Towers is poring over documentation provided by BMW about Rover but questions linger over how he will be able to finance the deal.

webTitle: Apartheid officer killed hundreds of prisoners

fields.headline: Apartheid officer killed hundreds of prisoners
fields.trailText: A former South African special forces officer yesterday described killing hundreds of black guerrillas and tossing their corpses from an aircraft into the Atlantic ocean, shedding light on one of the worst horrors committed by the apartheid regime.
fields.body:
A former South African special forces officer yesterday described killing hundreds of black guerrillas and tossing their corpses from an aircraft into the Atlantic ocean, shedding light on one of the worst horrors committed by the apartheid regime.

Sketchy reports had surfaced earlier of the murder of some 200 guerrillas who fought against South Africa's occupation of neighbouring Namibia, known as South West Africa until it won independence in 1990. Johan Theron's testimony crystalised the events of two decades ago.

Leaning forward in the witness stand in the Pretoria high court, Mr Theron told in a mild voice of flinging the corpses of his victims from a plane 3,700 metres (12,000ft) above the Atlantic and watching them plummet to the sea.

"The people had to be dead before I threw them into the sea," explained Mr Theron, a former special forces lieutenant colonel, to eliminate any chance that they would survive to implicate him.

Most were killed by an overdose of muscle relaxants supplied by Dr Wouter Basson, who ran apartheid South Africa's chemical and biological weapons programme, according to Mr Theron, who is appearing as a prosecution witness in Dr Basson's murder, conspiracy and fraud trial.

Mr Theron hopes to secure immunity from prosecution by testifying. He said he did not confess his crimes to the truth and reconciliation commission - which can grant amnesty - because he did not want to be "humiliated".

Mr Theron said that he and the commander of apartheid's special forces at the time, General Fritz Loots, had decided there were too many South West African People's Organisation guerrillas in prison camps and that they posed a "security risk".

The two decided to kill the PoWs, Mr Theron said. He conducted an aerial surveillance of the Atlantic coast off Namibia to see where best to dump the bodies without them being washed to shore, and felt that 100 miles offshore was suitable. South African paramilitary police then began delivering prisoners to him for execution in 1979, he said.

The first killing did not go as planned, he said on Wednesday. He fired a dart supposedly loaded with an overdose of tranquiliser to kill a prisoner, but the man did not go down.

"The prisoner started struggling with me. I put a plastic cuff around his neck and strangled him," he said. "I thought he would die quickly, but it took 15 minutes of kicking and wetting himself before he died. It was very traumatic."

After trying to perfect the executions with muscle relaxants that caused the victims to suffocate, Mr Theron said he was not satisfied because they were dying in agony. So future victims were given anaesthesia in cans of soft drink or beer before being injected.

"I cannot remember how many we killed, but there must have been hundreds," he told the court.

fields.headline: Assault teacher struck off
fields.trailText: A teacher convicted of assault for smacking his daughter is to be struck off the teachers' register by the General Teaching Council.
fields.body:
A teacher convicted of assault for smacking his daughter is to be struck off the teachers' register by the General Teaching Council.

The father of three from north Lanarkshire was ruled unfit to remain in the teaching profession by the GTC yesterday after a court convicted him of assaulting his daughter, aged 8, by smacking her bottom when she threw a tantrum in a dentist's waiting room.

The man, aged 49, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had denied that smacking the girl's bare bottom up to six times with his hand constituted an assault.

But he has admitted he lost his temper on Christmas Eve, 1998, at a Motherwell health centre where he had taken his daughter to have a tooth pulled. When she refused and threw a tantrum, her father put her across his knee, pulled down her trousers and knickers and smacked her.

The incident was spotted by a member of staff, who reported it to the police, who charged the father.

He was ordered to keep away from the family home over Christmas and was suspended from his £20,000 post at a north Lanarkshire primary school.

The man was admonished by the court and last autumn a children's panel hearing placed a year-long supervision order on all three children in the family. Since then, once a fortnight, social workers call at the house to check the children.

The case prompted a national debate on smacking and caused uproar among some family campaigners who believe in the right to physically chastise children.

In March the man was called to give evidence before a GTC disciplinary hearing. All teachers at state schools in Scotland must be registered with the council.

Yesterday the man's lawyer, Joe Beltrami, said his client was deeply shocked by the ruling and would be appealing to the high court in Edinburgh.

"There are a number of grounds for appeal and I'm very confident indeed. He will see his employers and we'll see what happens then."

Mr Beltrami said the 10-member GTC panel which heard the case did not give a reason for its decision.

The teacher, who was accompanied to yesterday's hearing by his wife and all three of their children, has repeatedly said that he was wrong to smack his child.

"I just lost it and deeply regret it," he has said. "What father hasn't smacked his kids then regretted it?"

Relatives of the family say the daughter is consumed with guilt at what has happened to her father. Since his suspension, the man has been working in a teaching resource library for his employers, North Lanarkshire council.

The council said yesterday it would consider the GTC ruling. It was a condition of contract that every teacher should be registered with the teaching council.

Tino Ferri, the NASUWT spokesman for Scotland, said: "I don't know why they have chosen to marry the school and non-school matter."

The teacher, who was accompanied to yesterday's hearing by his wife and all three of their children, has repeatedly said that he was wrong to smack his child. "I just lost it and deeply regret it," he has said. "What father hasn't smacked his kids then regretted it?" Relatives of the family say the daughter is consumed with guilt at what has happened to her father. Since his suspension, the man has been working in a teaching resource library for his employers, North Lanarkshire council. The council said yesterday it would consider the GTC ruling. It was a condition of contract that every teacher should be registered with the teaching council. Tino Ferri, the NASUWT spokesman for Scotland, said: "I don't know why they have chosen to marry the school and non-school matter."

fields.headline: Accused nurse's 'rescue attempt'
fields.trailText: A nurse charged with manslaughter and two counts of rape yesterday described how he attempted to save the woman he is accused of killing.
fields.body:
A nurse charged with manslaughter and two counts of rape yesterday described how he attempted to save the woman he is accused of killing.

Kevin Cobb was giving evidence at the Old Bailey. He denies killing colleague Susan Annis after drugging her with the intention of committing rape. Cobb, 38, also denies raping two other women after administering Midazolam, and drugging a third victim with the intention of raping her.

Henry Grunwald QC, opening the defence, said Cobb had no idea how the drug came to be in Ms Annis's system.

Cobb met Ms Annis, 31, at a residential paediatric care course at the Royal Brompton hospital, west London, in November 1996.

On the evening Ms Annis died the pair had shared a take-away meal and a few drinks in Cobb's room at the Royal Brompton nursing home. Cobb denied there had been any sexual attraction between the pair.

He said Miss Annis fell asleep on his bed around 10pm. He woke her up and she left for her room.

Around two hours later, Mr Cobb told the court, he went to check on her. When he opened the door he saw Ms Annis lying at the end of the bed, blue in the face and with vomit leaking from her mouth. Cobb said he then cleared her airways of vomit and administered first aid. Eventually an ambulance crew arrived.

Cobb was not charged with causing the death of Ms Annis until July 1999 after three other woman had come forward alleging that Cobb had injected them with Midazolam at St Peter's hospital, Chertsey, Surrey, where he was a staff nurse.

webTitle: Court told of gun mayhem in car chase

fields.headline: Court told of gun mayhem in car chase
fields.standfirst: Gun violence in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A woman was taken hostage and five people were cold-bloodedly shot and injured during a 50-mile car chase, Manchester crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman was taken hostage and five people were cold-bloodedly shot and injured during a 50-mile car chase, Manchester crown court heard yesterday.

A Kalashnikov AK-47 assault rifle and a Smith and Wesson pistol were fired repeatedly by two men wearing balaclavas as they attempted to shake off their police pursuers.

Alistair Webster QC, prosecuting, told the court the chase began with the chance discovery on the M6 last April by a plainclothes policeman of three men kitted out for armed robbery.

Yakub Adetoro, 30, of no fixed address, and Andrew Dennis, 24, of Failsworth, Greater Manchester, deny 24 joint charges including attempting to murder two police officers, a motorist and a cyclist, kidnap, causing GBH, hijacking two cars and using firearms to resist arrest. Adetoro also denies attempting to murder a lorry driver and threatening to kill a motorist. The two, along with Steven Dixon, 24, from Newton Heath, Manchester, are also accused of conspiring to commit armed robbery and carrying the Kalashnikov and two hand guns with intent to commit robbery.

The prosecution alleged that the three were equipped with a classic armed robber's kit of boiler suits, balaclavas and firearms, and that Adetoro was moreover wearing body armour.

They were spotted on a slip road of the M6 near Lancaster by an off duty officer. He followed Adetoro and Dennis in one car, and the high speed chase went on for 50 miles. Dixon, in another car, was apprehended separately.

During the pursuit, said Mr Webster, "Adetoro and Dennis graduated from firing at policemen to the kidnap of an innocent civilian and the cold blooded shooting of five civilians." After a motorway patrol had taken up the pursuit of Adetoro and Dennis, they pulled over on the hard shoulder. When PC David Bentley got out of his car, Adetoro put on a balaclava, produced a hand gun, and braced himself to fire. The officer dived for cover as one bullet shattered his car door window and other shots ricocheted off the ground and hit his leg.

The police car followed Adetoro and Dennis' car to the M61 and then into a side road near Bolton, where Adetoro fired two more shots. They then headed north towards Horwich where they stole a Ford Fiesta from Melanie Williams, who was sat in a queue at traffic lights.

"She was confronted by a man in a balaclava holding a firearm leaning into her car," said Mr Webster. "She was terrified. He threw the door open and pulled her from the car, threatening to shoot her if she didn't get out." Adetoro aimed the Kalashnikov at a lorry driver who tried to stop the Ford Fiesta, but it misfired.

They then headed towards Bolton and hijacked a BMW before taking a hostage, Amanda Ryan, 27. "Adetoro forced her into the car at gunpoint, then fired, at less than 30 yards, at the windscreen of a police Range Rover which had taken over the chase," said Mr Webster.

The BMW was pursued at speed through Bolton and Bury and towards Rochdale. Ms Ryan, cowering in the back of the car, heard Adetoro suggest to Dennis that they should shoot somebody.

Their first victim was Peter Hayles, a cable installer, shot in the leg as he worked on the main Bury to Rochdale road. A mile and a half later, they shot Saranath Chandra Senerath-Yapa, a community doctor, who was driving to work; the bullet fractured his arm.

Minutes later Martin McKay Smith, a crown prosecution service solicitor, was shot in the leg as he passed the BMW on his motorcycle. James Gallagher, 75, was shot in the leg at a bus stop, while two bullets missed another pensioner, James Jennings, also at a bus stop. Finally, David Hassall was shot in the back as he cycled to work in Rochdale.

Dennis then lost control of the BMW and hit a lamp post.

In a police interview, he said he did not realise it was the police chasing him. "He claimed to be unable to remember having shot any of the civilians," said Mr Webster. "He was adamant that he did not intend to kill anybody, and professed himself to be full of remorse that he was responsible for injuring anyone.

"He stated that he wore body armour because he had been living in fear, having had some dealings in drugs, which meant that people were after him." The trial continues.

fields.headline: Russian claims eye transplant first
fields.trailText: A Russian eye surgeon has made medical history by attempting the first "combined eye transplantation" in the world, taking a retina and cornea from a corpse to "assemble" a left eye in a woman who has been blind for 20 years.
fields.body:
A Russian eye surgeon has made medical history by attempting the first "combined eye transplantation" in the world, taking a retina and cornea from a corpse to "assemble" a left eye in a woman who has been blind for 20 years.

Following the controversial operation, Tamara Gorbacheva, 37, a former translator from Kiev in Ukraine, claims that partial sight has been restored and she can detect light and discern simple shapes.

News of the alleged breakthrough has been met with bewilderment and scepticism among eye experts in Moscow and London. But Professor Ernst Muldashev, head of the All-Russian Eye and Plastic Surgery Centre, who carried out the operation at a clinic he runs in Ufa, the capital of the Russian republic of Bashkortostan, insists he has accomplished something that orthodox ophthalmologists say is not possible.

"The eye is almost normal. The critics just say this can't happen," said Prof Muldashev.

Three months after the six-hour operation was carried out on January 28, Ms Gorbacheva is still undergoing tests at the Ufa clinic. "It was half past two in the morning, not long after the operation, that I could see light," she said.

Prof Muldashev said that after 20 years of blindness, a major problem for Ms Gorbacheva was that her brain was barely capable of deciphering the complex visual signals it was receiving.

Scepticism

Experts at London's Moorfields Eye Hospital, who declined to be named, cautioned that the claims were barely credible. One said that Ms Gorbacheva could be experiencing a "cerebral phenomenon where she perceives images and light in conditions of total blindness", a common occurrence among blind people who are desperate to see. "No one has ever transplanted a cornea and a retina together. If true, it would be an amazing development."

Zinaida Moroz, head of Moscow's cornea transplant and surgery centre, said: "There's nothing scientific to discuss here. Whole eye transplants are not possible today."

But Prof Muldashev acknowledges that impossibility; it is why he has dubbed his operation "combined eye tranplantation" in which 70% of the restored eye is regenerated tissue stimulated by a biomaterial treatment called Alloplant, which he and his colleagues in Ufa developed in the 1970s and have been refining ever since.

Alloplant is manufactured from the tissue of fresh corpses. In Russia, legislation allows any organs to be taken from a body unless the person expressly proscribed such an action while alive.

Prof Muldashev said that he took the donor's eye and extracted the cornea and the retina. He removed Ms Gorbacheva's atrophied eyeball, and laid the Alloplant - dead tissue - at the base of the eye. The retina and cornea were transplanted onto the Alloplant, a process requiring a total of 200 stitches. He claims the eye then effectively rebuilt itself. "It's like eye-cloning, self-regeneration," said Prof Muldashev. "This has never been done before and honestly we don't fully understand what's happened here."

He estimated the cost of the surgery at $100,000 (£64,000). The All Russian Eye Clinic performs some 3,000 operations a year on patients from around the world.

Doctor with a vision of fusing east and west

His little office on the fourth floor of Hospital Number 10 in Ufa betrays the twin obsessions of Professor Ernst Muldashev: the human eye and the forbidding mountains of Tibet.

As well as a wall full of framed medical and patent certificates, the office contains souvenirs from Mount Kailas in western Tibet - holy to millions of Buddhists, Hindus, and Jainists.

The chain-smoking ophthalmologist is not only a medic, but a bit of a mystic. He spent two months last summer trekking in the Himalayas, his fourth such expedition, and a month at the 22,000ft Mt Kailas, after his four-man expedition persuaded the Chinese authorities to allow them access as "pilgrims."

Colleagues say Prof Muldashev, who describes himself as a very religious man of no particular faith, is studying ancient Tibetan medicine with a view to fusing eastern and western traditions. He claims that the "laws" governing time, energy, information fields, and holograms that he witnessed in Tibet are as applicable to medicine and micro-surgery as to religion.

Despite the chain-smoking, he the 52-year-old is physically well-equipped for the rigours of months at high altitude. In the former Soviet Union, he was national orienteering champion three times.

Prof Muldashev's work has proved controversial. In the late 1970s, after a row with the authorities his medical qualifications were withdrawn for a time, during which he worked as a reindeer herdsman in Siberia.

The Bashkortostani government is building him an eye surgery centre and the Russian health ministry is also considering giving him a new clinic in Moscow.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Swiss banks let researchers in
fields.body:
Swiss banks let researchers in

Two Swiss banks plan to let researchers examine more than 2m Nazi-era bank accounts so that they can check claims by Holocaust survivors, breaking a deadlock over the number of accounts to be opened.

Sources said yesterday that Credit Suisse Group and UBS AG were expected to propose the solution at a meeting with a US district court judge. The deal could pave the way for a £800m bank settlement.
Reuters, New York

Indonesian quake kills five

An earthquake rocked parts of central Indonesia yesterday, killing at least five people and toppling hundreds of houses.

The quake, which had a magnitude of 6.5, was centred beneath the Molucca sea, 65 miles off Peleng island.
AP, Jakarta

Ex-Belgian PM to run for mayor

Former Belgian prime minister Jean-Luc Dehaene confirmed yesterday that he plans to return to party politics by running for mayor in his home town.

Mr Dehaene, who resigned last June after his party's election defeat, said he would be a Christian Democrat candidate in Vilvoorde.
Reuters, Brussels

Hostages held in TV protest

A 39-year-old jobless man protesting against US programmes on television was arrested yesterday after taking five hostages in Sergiyev Posad, north of Moscow, police said.

Police commandos raided the building after Pavel Kostyakin threatened the women in his mother's home with an axe and a knife.
AP, Moscow

Internet cheats outwit teachers

More than a third of Swedish teachers say pupils are using their IT wizardry to pass off homework downloaded from the internet as their own. The teachers are aware of the problem but lack the children's computer know-how in order to stop it, according to a survey published yesterday.
Reuters, Stockholm

Wash day for cat and dogs

Inventor Angel Segura unveiled an automatic washing machine for dogs and cats during a trade fair in Silleda, northwest Spain, the festival's committee said yesterday.

Pets are put in the box and sprayed with soap and water before being dried by air jets.
AP, Madrid

webTitle: Thinktank foresees rift between EU and Nato

fields.headline: Thinktank foresees rift between EU and Nato
fields.trailText: Europe must pull more weight on defence and security issues at a time when a lame-duck US president heads an administration that cannot be expected to launch significant foreign policy initiatives, a respected thinktank said yesterday.
fields.body:
Europe must pull more weight on defence and security issues at a time when a lame-duck US president heads an administration that cannot be expected to launch significant foreign policy initiatives, a respected thinktank said yesterday.

Unless Europe increased its defence capability "the widening gap is certain to generate more tension within the alliance and between Nato and the EU", the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS) said in an annual survey.

The EU's pledge to develop the capacity by 2003 to field 60,000 troops, able to deploy within 60 days, sustainable for at least a year "is not achievable merely by reallocating defence expenditure within existing budgets", John Chip man, the IISS director, said.

"Clinton has shown no more grasp than his many critics of how to shape the international order," the survey says. In a controversial passage, it finds "perplexing" the criticism by Hubert Védrine, the French foreign minister, of the US tendency to "hyperpowerdom".

"On balance, the United States ... looks more like a power which has had only modest success in defending its core interests than as an unconstrained power imposing its will unilaterally," the IISS says.

It says Europe should play a much bigger role in "defence diplomacy" for example, by helping the countries of central and eastern Europe restructure their armed forces and helping Russia to reprocess nuclear fuel and dismantle nuclear warheads.

webTitle: Sri Lankan government panics as fight for Jaffna reaches endgame

fields.headline: Sri Lankan government panics as fight for Jaffna reaches endgame
fields.standfirst: Cut off, demoralised troops face Tigers on the rampage
fields.trailText: They advanced silently across fields of waving coconut palms, to within a few hundred yards of where Captain Bandara Anussha was sheltering in a trench. The Tamil Tiger rebels then calmly moved their heavy artillery into position and the bombardment began - a relentless, three-day offensive, which turned the jungle floor into a sea of exploding shrapnel.
fields.body:
They advanced silently across fields of waving coconut palms, to within a few hundred yards of where Captain Bandara Anussha was sheltering in a trench. The Tamil Tiger rebels then calmly moved their heavy artillery into position and the bombardment began - a relentless, three-day offensive, which turned the jungle floor into a sea of exploding shrapnel.

"We were under siege. We were cut off from the other troops. We were exhausted and miserable," the captain said. As mortar shells continued to fall on the Sri Lankan government platoon, two of his soldiers were killed, and eight wounded.

After only two hours' sleep, supported by a radio with a flat battery, and only biscuits left to eat, Capt Anussha decided to call it a day. As he fled across the jungle, a bullet hit him. "I didn't know what had happened," he said. His fellow soldiers - those that had made it back from the battle at Pallai, which fell to the advancing rebels on Sunday - dumped him on a tractor.

Yesterday, sitting in a military hospital in Colombo, Capt Anussha was pondering what went wrong. "They have taken the most important tactical ground," he admitted, nursing his leg wound. "They know the territory. They use it better."

Across the Jaffna peninsula, Capt Anussha's story is being repeated. The army is retreating. Sri Lanka's government, headed by President Chandrika Kumaratunge, is in disarray, uncertain what to do. In a sign of desperation, the president yesterday introduced sweeping restrictions. She banned activities perceived as a threat to national security; brought in unlimited powers of arrest; invoked the right to close down troublesome newspapers. Foreign journalists must submit reports to a military censor. Criticism of the president has been banned.

India, meanwhile, has refused to evacuate some 28,000 troops trapped in the town of Jaffna.

After 17 years of brutal civil conflict in Sri Lanka, the war between the Tamil Tigers, who have been fighting for their own homeland, and government troops appears to be reaching a denouement. The Tigers are winning. A force of around 4,000 rebels - many of them women, some of them teenagers reared on a diet of Tiger propaganda and Rambo videos - is poised to defeat a well-equipped modern army of some 120,000 increasingly demoralised men.

Two weeks ago the Tigers stormed a key military base at Elephant Pass, the crucial gateway to the Jaffna peninsula. They killed 79 soldiers and took a huge cache of ammunition. Over the weekend they continued towards the town of Jaffna, capturing the town of Pallai and shooting Capt Anussha in the leg. The Tigers are now within 23 miles of the town they controlled until 1995, and have vowed to recapture it at any cost.

Although government troops held off an assault two days ago at the naval base of Kilaly, most analysts now believe it is only a matter of time before Jaffna falls. It could be days.

After a two-day pause the Tigers are expected to renew their assault, by attempting to shell the runway at Palalai, the government's only functioning air base. They need to advance only three miles more before the airstrip comes into range of Tiger heavy artillery. If the airport is destroyed, the government has little choice but to evacuate.

"It is a hopeless military situation. In such a situation there is no choice but to withdraw," Iqbal Athas, Sri Lanka's most respected defence analyst, said yesterday."They can't hold it. The troops have been fighting for 11 days. They are exhausted." Others analysts demur, and suggest the Tigers face the prospect of massive casualties as they advance across increasingly flat terrain against an army which has nowhere to flee.

Sitting in Colombo military hospital yesterday, surrounded by fellow officers in striped blue pyjamas, most of them with shattered limbs, Lieutenant Chaminda Pushpakumara described how many of his fellow soldiers died of dehydration in the retreat from Pallai. The plight of the soldiers was made worse by the fact that they were ordered to flee through the jungle wearing heavy flak jackets. Senior army officials had expected the attack to come from the south of the peninsula. In fact, a seaborne division of rebels landed on the north, crossing a lagoon by canoe before capturing part of the main supply road between Jaffna and Elephant Pass. The manoeuvre left Lt Pushpakumara and his troops without supplies.

The Tigers use of heavy artillery in recent months has proved devastating, military sources admit. Major Dhammika Wijesooriya, whose leg was almost blown off by a mortar on March 27, conceded the Tigers had a strategic advantage. "We study the maps and after that go for an offensive. It is easier for them because they know the territory. They also use small children motivated to fight. It is incorrect," he said.

The deepening crisis in the north has prompted Sri Lanka's government to seek help from outside, and to embark on a desperate quest for more heavy weaponry. Diplomatic relations were hastily resumed with Israel yesterday, a country which has supplied Sri Lanka with helicopter gunships. But crucial naval assistance from India has not been forthcoming.

Sri Lanka's foreign minister Lakshman Kadirgamar, who had flown to New Delhi to meet the prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, left empty-handed. India's refusal to intervene is hardly surprising. webTitle: How perfidious Albion may have poisoned Napoleon

fields.headline: How perfidious Albion may have poisoned Napoleon
fields.standfirst: New DNA tests rewrite history's verdict on death of French emperor
fields.trailText: Over a three-course lunch, the French senate grappled yesterday with the indigestible and diplomatically tricky notion that Napoleon Bonaparte died not of stomach cancer but because he was poisoned - with the complicity of his British captors.
fields.body:
Over a three-course lunch, the French senate grappled yesterday with the indigestible and diplomatically tricky notion that Napoleon Bonaparte died not of stomach cancer but because he was poisoned - with the complicity of his British captors.

The lunch, organised by the International Napoleonic Society, was an attempt to convince sceptical French historians and politicians of new scientific evidence showing that the French emperor did not die of natural causes on May 5 1821, after being banished to the remote Atlantic island of St Helena.

A dozen eminent French toxicologists, coroners, cancer specialists and police forensic scientists were on hand to explain that the history books were wrong to say that Napoleon died of cancer.

"There seems to be something of a problem in blaming a cancer for Napoleon's death when there is not the slightest symptom to indicate it," said Jean-Marie Andrieu, a leading cancer specialist who attended the debate. "What's more, the evidence in favour of arsenic poisoning is beginning to look very strong indeed."

The principal advocate of the arsenic-poisoning theory is Ben Weider, a French-Canadian historian, who started questioning the stomach cancer story after realising that unlike most cancer victims, Napoleon was noticeably fat when he died.

Other evidence also indicated poisoning. None of the five doctors present on St Helena at Napoleon's death could say with certainty what had caused it, and when examined closely the memoirs of his valet revealed a gradual decline in his health consistent with poisoning.

Moreover, when his remains were brought back to France in 1840 prior to ceremonial burial in Les Invalides, his body appeared perfectly preserved. At the time it was seen as a miracle. Today scientists say the phenomenon is symptomatic of arsenic poisoning.

DNA analyses of alleged samples of Napoleon's hair appear to substantiate the theory. Laboratories, including those of the FBI, have found arsenic levels hundreds of times higher than normal in samples of the emperor's hair obtained from descendants of his valet, Louis Marchand.

Tests have also ruled out another theory: that the arsenic was applied after death to preserve the hair. Mr Weider said: "Both the FBI and Scotland Yard, confronted with the results of these tests, have said that if they came across similar results in the case of a recent victim, they would have no hesitation at all in opening a murder inquiry."

An aide, Charles de Montholon, is thought to have poisoned Napoleon because Louis XVIII feared the emperor could return from exile. But the British were in at the kill, according to Mr Weider and his supporters.

If Napoleon was poisoned slowly by arsenic, he was apparently finished off by a dose of bitter almonds and a mercury-rich compound, calomel, which were given to Montholon by the island's British governor, Hudson Lowe.

Perhaps wary of the consequences for Franco-British relations, some senior French historians and senators were still reluctant to endorse this view. Several said they would wait until France's leading authority on the era, Jean Tulard, had come to a conclusion.

"It would be stupid of me to say poisoning was impossible," said one historian, Jean-Paul Kauffman. "But I think Napoleon was poisoned by the ghosts of his past glory rather than by cyanides. And his legend needs enigmas, not certainties."
