fields.headline: Women's sex aid on prescription
fields.standfirst: Better sex c/o Uncle Sam
fields.trailText: For the first time, the United States government has officially licensed a sexual aid for women. The device will be available on prescription from today for women who suffer sexual arousal problems.
fields.body:
For the first time, the United States government has officially licensed a sexual aid for women. The device will be available on prescription from today for women who suffer sexual arousal problems.

While Viagra, the drug developed to help men who suffered from impotence, is now sold over the internet and has become a staple of the comedian's routine, sexual aids for women have not received the same public attention.

The manufacturers of the device called Eros CTD (clitoral therapy device) believe that there is an equally large market awaiting their product.

The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday that it had approved Eros, made by UroMetrics, a small private company in St Paul, Minnesota. It will cost $359 (£230) and will only be available on prescription - not because it is deemed to be dangerous or to have risky side effects but because the FDA believes it should only be used with a doctor's advice.

Eros is essentially a soft plastic cup that is placed over the clitoris and operated by a hand-held vacuum tube.

It is similar in principle to vacuum pumps used by men to achieve erections in that it stimulates the blood flow into the genital area. Viagra is used by many women but there has as yet not been significant research on its effects on women.

The National Institutes of Health estimate that about 40m American women suffer from "female sexual dysfunction".

Testing of Eros by the FDA showed that 80% of those using it experienced increased sexual satisfaction. Tests are now due to be carried out in France, Norway and Italy.

It is estimated that as many as 2m women will have been prescribed Eros within its first year of licensing in the US.

"This is not going to be a panacea," said Dr Diane Mitchell, the FDA gynaecologist responsible for the tests. "It does not help every woman."

It might not be effective for women whose sexual problems were of a psychological nature, she said.

Although Eros will initially be available only on prescription, it is possible that eventually it will be available over the counter.

A spokeswoman for UroMetrics said that they had developed the device after realising that although they had produced two sexual devices to help men, there were none in the marketplace for women.

webTitle: Teenager admits starting disco fire where 63 died

fields.headline: Teenager admits starting disco fire where 63 died
fields.trailText: A teenage defendant said yesterday that he had set fire to some paper at the scene of a discotheque blaze that killed 63 people in Sweden.
fields.body:
A teenage defendant said yesterday that he had set fire to some paper at the scene of a discotheque blaze that killed 63 people in Sweden.

Shoresh Kaveh, 19, said through his lawyer that he stuffed paper under a pile of chairs and then lit it because he felt that organisers of the Halloween dance in Gothenburg had mistreated him.

"His idea was to burn the chairs to give them aggravation," defence lawyer Goran Bergendahl told Gothenburg district court on the second day of the trial, adding that Mr Kaveh had not planned the fire in advance.

Mr Kaveh is accused of aggravated arson along with Housein Arsani, 19; Mohammad Mohammadamini, 21; and Meysam Mohammadyeh, 19, following Sweden's worst fire disaster in living memory. The four are all immigrants from Iran.

Their lawyers claim they are not guilty of aggravated arson, at least partly because they did not intend to cause the damage that happened.

"It was a very small fire and he didn't understand that this would cause a big fire," Mr Mohammadamini's lawyer, Anders Munck, said. "He himself lost several friends."

Most of the 63 people who died in the blaze in October 1998 were teenagers. Many came from immigrant families.

An inspection of the site of the fire took place yesterday as part of the trial. Many of the victims' relatives wept as they emerged from the tour, which included a look at the stairwell where the fire started.

"It must have been like hell in there," said Gilliar Javaherynasab, who lost her 14-year-old brother in the blaze.

"It was very hard and there were a lot of emotions," she said, adding that many women were wailing and yelling the names of their children who died.

Meanwhile, representatives of some of the 500 survivors and relatives who are co-plaintiffs, complained that they were being denied the right to follow the case.

Because of the numbers and the need to interpret simultaneously into 13 languages, the co-plaintiffs are watching coverage of the case in a hall at Gothenburg's exhibition centre, in the same building as the trial. The coverage is live but the picture is indistinct.

"These people have the right to be present at the trial," their representative, Thomas Bodstrom, said.

"You cannot follow what's going on because the picture is not clear enough, and when the proceedings are translated, the spectators hear the same person's voice all the time so they don't know who is speaking," Mr Bodstrom said.

The trial is due to end on May 19, with the verdict expected one or two weeks later.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Date set for last Maze releases
fields.body:
Date set for last Maze releases

The remaining 80 paramilitary prisoners to be freed early under the terms of the Good Friday agreement will walk out of the Maze jail on July 28, it was revealed yesterday. A report said arrangements had yet to be made for the 17 prisoners who would be left behind, but the jail, in Co Antrim, would be shut by the end of the financial year.

Student bailed in Greer case

Bath university student Karen Burke, 19, of Wollaton near Nottingham, was bailed by Harlow magistrates yesterday accused of assaulting and unlawfully detaining author and academic Germaine Greer. Ms Greer, 61, was not hurt in the incident at her home near Saffron Walden, Essex, on Monday last week.

Cruelty claims 'a conspiracy'

A nursery owner accused of abusing children in her care told Merthyr Tydfil crown court yesterday that she was the victim of "an elaborate conspiracy" by staff and some parents at the nursery she ran for more than six years in Brecon, south Wales. Margaret Gloria Price, 58, who denies 13 charges of child cruelty, said: "These women have deliberately concocted this witches' brew against me." The case continues.

Flower show mark-up row

Some ticket agencies are charging double the recommended price for tickets to this year's Chelsea Flower Show, the Royal Horticul tural Society claimed yesterday. It said customers had reported agencies charging up to £65 a ticket for this month's event, a mark-up of more than 150% on the official price. Tickets sold direct by the RHS cost £12 to £27.

Prince stranded for second day

The Prince of Wales was "stranded" by bad weather for a second day yesterday at an all-male monastic community. He was unable to rejoin his yacht in the Aegean sea and spent his time visiting monasteries on Mount Athos in Greece.

Second fire on death trawler
Experts are investigating why two fires have broken out on board a trawler in less than six months. A man died in the first fire, and four fishermen were rescued from a blaze on the 38-tonne Zuider Kruis as she left Grimsby on Tuesday.

"I can make many dreams come true but that's too difficult," says the wizard, "so wish for something easier."

"I've got this friend, Frank Dobson," the man replies, "can you make him mayor of London?"

"Let's have another look at that leg."

The joke, told against Frank Dobson by a member of his own campaign team, underlined how far his star waned during a disastrous eight-month bid to be mayor of London.

The former health secretary started out a political heavyweight who enjoyed telling dirty stories. He ended a figure of fun, the butt of a thousand bad quips.

Bookies stopped taking bets on the outcome of the race a fortnight ago and, though Dobson put on the brave face worn by all candidates, even his closest allies yesterday said he would not win.

Recriminations started last night before the polls closed in the capital and the result was known. Inquests by Labour's national executive committee and the Greater London party could make the "blame game" one of the best free shows in town. The emergence in second place during the last opinion polls of the Tory Steve Norris added to Dobson's woes and left him needing a miracle.

Downing Street is pointing the finger at Millbank and Dobson; Millbank is complaining about Dobson and No 10; Dobson feels let down by both.

His supporters believe he was let down by the prime minister, with Tony Blair not appearing with him in public until early April - just four weeks before the polls.

The Ken Livingstone supporters who branded Dobson a puppet of No 10 also accused him of lacking Downing Street support. He could not win.

"He was a lame duck from day one and his campaign never got past first base," said a Labour bankbencher.

"Frank," said a minister, "was never given the support he needed and because they feared he would lose, prominent figures did not want to get too close."

A Millbank official said: "We did everything we could. He can have no complaints." Another said: "This is a disaster made in Downing Street. Blair made a fundamental political error by creating a job without first deciding who would fill it."

Sympathetic Westminster colleagues conceded that Dobson's campaign was poor and never really got going.

Overtures

After months of dismissing those who claimed he would stand as "fancy nancys" and in one case "liars", Dobson agreed 10 days before last September's Labour conference in Bournemouth to put his name forward.

Downing Street had identified him as a favoured candidate as early as February 1998, nearly 20 months earlier, but he had resisted the overtures.

His reluctance was to prove damaging twice over: valuable time was lost to erode Livingstone's huge poll lead and it looked as if he had been strong-armed into running, allowing rivals to paint him as No 10's stooge.

Even when he decided to go for it, Dobson delayed again - opting not to announce his intentions until after the conference. Blair and Dobson did not want the London mayor issue to dominate the conference but they missed an opportunity to use it as a platform to launch his campaign. He had second thoughts midweek during the conference and considered using his speech as health secretary to make his plans clear but at the last minute pulled back, instead denying rumours he would stand.

Clive Soley, the chairman of the parliamentary Labour party and a London MP, said: "If Frank loses it was because he was in a very difficult position from the start. He had very little time to establish himself as the main candidate. Ken Livingstone had been running his campaign for a year or two and Frank, quite honestly, never caught up."

Some in the Stop Livingstone camp maintain that Millbank's decision to delay the Labour selection process from December to February was crucial because it did not give the former GLC leader enough rope to hang himself.

His independent campaign only recently started falling apart, and another minister said: "The defection of Mark Goddard [the Livingstone aide who quit in disgust] this week was just the start. A few more Goddards and people would have been saying this guy is a shyster."

In private Blair expressed the naive hope that a businessman, someone above party but basically New Labour - a Richard Branson or Bob Ayling - would step forward.

The prime minister's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, touted Mo Mowlam, whose role in the Irish peace process talks he had come close to superseding at times. Ms Mowlam did not fancy it and, as with Dobson, no direct appeal was made by Blair. Key aides - including Sally Morgan at No 10 and Margaret McDonagh at Millbank - and the press were used as a sounding board.

When Ms Mowlam changed her mind in the autumn, it was too late. Both she and Dobson had helped to botch last July's reshuffle-that-never-was by refusing to move. But Dobson had come under repeated "only you can save us from Ken, Frank" pleas from friends in the Labour movement in London.

Glenda Jackson had tried, but failed, to create a bandwagon - "no good at wholesale politics, not voter-friendly enough" was the verdict on an Oscar-winning star too shy for real pavement politicking. Trevor Phillips was equally bold but lacked political clout.

Tony Banks, who quit the government that July, wanted No 10's support before he would declare while Downing Street wanted him to declare and prove his worth first.

Nick Raynsford, the minister for London, did see Blair. He asked for six weeks of campaigning to see if he could beat Livingstone in a ballot. If he could not, Millbank would still have the option of blocking Livingstone from the shortlist, exposing him as an independent for two vital months, from December. Had the electoral college been imposed Raynsford would have quit.

As it was he had three days of campaigning before Dobson finally threw his hat into the ring, forcing Raynsford to swiftly withdraw.

Hollow

But Livingstone's repeated opinion poll leads panicked Downing Street and Millbank as both feared Dobson could not win a one-member, one-vote ballot of the party's 68,000 London members even if it was delayed until the spring.

An electoral college based on the discredited model used in Wales, including trade union block votes, was devised to stop Livingstone and deliver victory for Dobson.

It was to be a hollow victory. The blatant rigging of the result, together with the "will he-won't he?" saga of whether Livingstone would be allowed to stand, killed off Dobson's already slim prospects.

The former health secretary maintains that he would have won a one-member, one-vote contest. We will never know. What we do know is the two-to-one majority among party members left Dobson not a lame duck but a dead duck.

Many members refused to campaign for him in protest at the result and Livingstone, who had pledged never to quit the party, went back on his word and stood as an independent.

One activist in east London, no Livingstone supporter, locked a box of Dobson leaflets in his car. Others refused to deliver leaflets with his name on them. Most just stayed at home, refusing to put up posters let alone knock on doors.

Bumping along on around 15% while Livingstone was basking in ratings of plus-50%, Dobson resorted to negative tactics and repeatedly attacked his rival. Livingstone was an extremist; Livingstone would set up "checkpoint charlies" to charge motorists £100 a month to drive into London; Livingstone would cost business millions of pounds.

Dobson's own policies - to appoint named police officers for every household, to appoint his own health tsar, to plant 100,000 trees to let London bloom - were secondary. The future of London Underground was the only real issue in a contest dominated by personalities and even here, Dobson's support for the government's private-public partnership was harder to sell than Livingstone's anti-privatisation line.

And there were the gaffes. When well-know media figures were caught up in the Millennium Dome fiasco on New Year's Eve, Dobson laughed at "toffee-nosed people" and had to apologise when it emerged that disabled, young and elderly people were also caught in the huge queues.

When the TV and radio star Chris Evans pledged £100,000 to Livingstone's campaign, Dobson said his mother had warned him never to trust redheads. Evans vowed to doubled his donation and £200,000 and brunettes everywhere were said to be outraged.

Downing Street appeared to acknowledge the game was up at the end of March when the pollster Philip Gould reported that focus groups showed Livingstone would easily collect most first preferences. The focus of the campaign, said an insider, switched to attempting to secure second place for their man in the faint hope that he would pick up an avalanche of second preferences in the shoot-out.

A "Frank and to the point" advertising drive, featuring Dobson's handwriting, was devised but appeared to have little impact.

It was not only the opinion polls that were writing him off as a loser. A straw poll at a British chambers of commerce conference in London put him fourth with just 15 votes, behind the Liberal Democrat, Susan Kramer, on 77 with Livingstone on 140 and Norris on 141.

A friend of Dobson yesterday said he was bitter at his treatment by the party and media. Giving up a job he loved, running the NHS, he has faced constant flak in the race to be mayor.

"Frank wanted to be health secretary until the election and was happy filling the shoes of Nye Bevan," said a minister. "He gave it up, stood and has a horrid time. It has been terrible for him."

Before his mayoral ordeal, when Dobson rang close friends, the York-born politician would announce "Dick Whittington here" to start the chat with a joke.

The real Dick Whittington travelled from York to London and was lord mayor twice; Dobson never looked like pulling it off once.

His friends are divided over what he will do next. Speculation that he could return to the cabinet has been played down by No 10 while rumours of a peerage may prove premature. All Dobson will say is that he would be honoured to remain Labour MP for Holborn and St Pancras.

His colleagues in the parliamentary Labour party believe he has been badly treated, said a minister, and would rebel if an inquest blamed him for not winning.

But Dobson, whose humour will probably emerge grittier than ever, knows politics can be a cruel business.

Knock knock Who's there? Frank Frank who?

fields.headline: Making of a mayor
fields.standfirst:
Rise and fall of the candidates

The London mayor: special report
fields.body:
1997

July 29 Deputy prime minister John Prescott unveils green paper for London mayor and assembly

1998

March 25 Greater London authority (referendum) bill white paper published, detailed proposals for mayor and assembly

April 28 Tories announce one-member, one-vote ballot of 38,000 London members

May 7 referendum on London mayor and assembly sees 72% yes vote and 28% no, on a turnout of only 34%

Aug 3 Ken Livingstone launches his manifesto, stressing transport as the "immediate problem"

Nov 10 Labour announces electoral college with selection panel to choose candidate

1999

Jan 19 London's 14 new super-constituencies announced

Jan 29 Livingstone promises to be a loyal mayor and accept party manifesto

Feb 8 Livingstone launches campaign to persuade Labour leadership to allow him to stand for Labour nomination

Feb 26 Government chooses South Bank site for new £20m home of GLA

March 14 Broadcaster Trevor Phillips announces he will run for Labour nomination

May 5 GLA bill cleared by the Commons. An opposition bid to block the bill's third reading defeated by a majority of 160

June 16 Phillips accuses Livingstone of racism after being offered deputy job

July 23 Tory shortlist of eight, including Lord Archer and Steve Norris, announced

July 28 Glenda Jackson stands down from government to run for Labour nomination

August 10 Archer says black women not as fat and badly dressed as they used to be

Aug 12 Susan Kramer selected as Liberal Democrat candidate after winning ballot of the party's 10,000 London members

Aug 29 Baroness Thatcher endorses Archer as Tory nominee

Sept 3 Blair approves 10-point loyalty test for Labour candidates

Sept 6 Tory electoral college interviews candidates

Sept 7 Livingstone officially launches his campaign for Labour nomination

Sept 14 Tory hustings to select a shortlist of two - Lord Archer and Steve Norris

Sept 30 Nick Raynsford steps down as minister for London to run for Labour nomination

Oct 1 Lord Archer wins the Tory postal ballot of 39,000 party members, to become 7-4 favourite to win the post

Oct 4 Frank Dobson announces candidacy for Labour nomination. He stands down as health secretary a week later

Oct 12 Labour announces an electoral college system to pick its candidate

Oct 20 Phillips drops out of mayoral race to stand as Dobson's running mate and deputy on the GLA

Oct 27 Tony Blair gives first public endorsement for Dobson as Livingstone appeals in newspaper adverts for campaign funds

Oct 28 Complaints that Dobson's campaign has been given a centrally-held list of Labour's 68,000-strong London membership

Oct 31 Prescott backs Glenda Jackson as Labour candidate

Nov 5 Data protection registrar announces investigation into the use of Labour membership lists by Dobson's campaign team

Nov 9 GLA bill clears the Lords and gets royal assent two days later

Nov 16 Labour candidates interviewed by party's mayoral selection panel

Nov 17 Dobson warns Blair he will quit the mayoral race if Livingstone is not allowed to stand

Nov 18 Dobson, Jackson and Livingstone (after a lengthy second interview) are shortlisted for Labour nomination. Businessman Ken Baldry is not

Nov 21 Archer quits mayoral race after the News of the World reveals he asked a friend to provide him with a false alibi before his 1987 Daily Star libel trial. Tory selection board decides to re-run the contest, refusing to hand the nomination to second place Norris

Dec 5 Norris announces he will run again

Dec 6 Dobson denies rumours that he is "depressed" and "heading for breakdown"

Dec 11 Norris is thrown off the Tory shortlist after party officials complain about his extra-marital affairs

Dec 14 Norris wins right to stand in the Tory hustings, after Hague steps in

2000

Jan 5 Jackson and Livingstone given copies of Labour's London membership list

Jan 17 Norris wins Tory nomination, beating businessman Andrew Boff

Feb 20 Dobson narrowly wins Labour nomination. Livingstone says result is "tainted" and urges Dobson to stand down

Feb 23 Labour releases letters Livingstone wrote to party chairman Vernon Hince in January, in which he promises never to run as an independent

Feb 24 Dobson announces an independent panel on the future of the tube

Feb 28 Livingstone meets deputy prime minister John Prescott for two hours of talks

March 2 Government agrees to give a free mailshot for mayoral candidates

March 3 Dobson and Livingstone clash on BBC's Question Time, when Dobson tells Livingstone to "make my day"

March 6 Livingstone announces he will stand as an independent and is suspended from the Labour party

March 7 Guardian/ICM poll gives Livingstone 68% of the vote, and Dobson 13%

March 19 DJ Chris Evans pledges £100,000 to Livingstone's campaign, later doubled after Dobson says his mother advised him to "steer clear of redheads"

March 20 Livingstone apologises to MPs for breaking Commons rules on registering his earnings from journalism and public speaking

April 4 Nominations close for mayoral candidates. Labour expels Livingstone from the party

April 12 Tony Blair makes first personal appearance supporting Dobson

April 13 ICM/Evening Standard opinion poll puts Dobson third, on 15% behind Norris on 16% and Livingstone on 49%

April 17 Livingstone publishes independent manifesto, opposing government plans for a partial sell-off of the Tube

April 19 Livingstone tells his supporters to vote Green for the "top-up" list in the GLA elections

April 24 Bookmakers stop taking bets on "unbeatable" Livingstone

April 27 Early polling booths open for the first time

April 28 Livingstone announces he will apply to rejoin Labour party after election

May 2 Livingstone attacked by fellow candidates over his perceived support for direct action after May Day riots.

webTitle: Boy, 11, fights for life after being set alight

fields.headline: Boy, 11, fights for life after being set alight
fields.standfirst: Police question 12-year-old about schoolboy suffering 70% burns in petrol incident  Friend injured putting out flames hailed as hero
fields.trailText: A schoolboy who was doused in petrol and set alight as he played near his home was last night in a critical condition after more than nine hours of emergency surgery.
fields.body:
A schoolboy who was doused in petrol and set alight as he played near his home was last night in a critical condition after more than nine hours of emergency surgery.

Alfred Page, aged 11, from Gillingham, Kent, received 70% burns to his body when he was engulfed in flames in the attack on Wednesday evening. Last night Kent police were continuing to hold a 12-year-old boy in connection with the incident.

Detectives are understood to be trying to establish whether Alfred, known as Podgy by family and friends, was the victim of a premeditated attack or an unwitting participant in a game that went wrong.

The family of the injured boy described two of his friends, Aaron Trotter and Desmond Jefford, both 13, as heroes for raising the alarm and trying to save him. Aaron suffered burns to his hands as he tried to put out the flames.

Emergency crews were called to Christmas Street in Gillingham just before 8pm on Wednesday after residents heard the boy's screams from an area of wasteland.

He was taken to Medway maritime hospital with third degree burns. Doctors decided he needed specialist treatment and he was transferred to the special burns unit at Broomfield hospital at Chelmsford, Essex. A team of nine surgeons began operating on the 11-year-old at 9am yesterday, removing damaged tissue.

Jim Frame, a consultant plastic surgeon, said Alfred had suffered 70% full thickness skin burn. "It's very serious," he said.

Police cordoned off the area of wasteland where the incident took place as detectives sifted through the grass and scrub looking for forensic evidence.

The injured boy's aunt, Debbie Page, 37, said moments after her nephew was set alight the boy suspected of carrying out the attack knocked on her door and said: "You'd better go - Podgy's on fire."

"I rushed up there and Podgy's friend Aaron had already put the fire out but Podgy was wearing a raincoat and his clothes had melted to him."

David Hall, 53, was in the Green Dragon pub when his son ran in and told him what had happened. He found Alfred stumbling down the street, his clothes hanging off him. "I saw a boy walking towards me. I got someone to put a blanket over him and called the ambulance. On his legs all the skin was hanging off the back from his muscles. He just said: 'Can you help me?'

"He was dazed and by the time the ambulance came he was in shock. His jeans were all burnt and hanging from him but his clothes on his top half were still there."

Edward Lovell, 50, an uncle of the injured boy, arrived on the scene to find Alfred in the house of one of his neighbours. "I went with him to hospital in the ambulance. He was remarkably good spirited for somebody who had been through what he had. He really was remarkably plucky; the ambulance men said so."

A family friend of Aaron Trotter said: "The poor lad is in a dreadful state but he was very brave. If it wasn't for him Podgy may not still be alive."

webTitle: Andrew hints at a royal remarriage

fields.headline: Andrew hints at a royal remarriage
fields.trailText: The Duke of York appears to have wrong-footed the royal family with an admission that he may remarry Sarah Ferguson, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The Duke of York appears to have wrong-footed the royal family with an admission that he may remarry Sarah Ferguson, it emerged last night.

Although the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh were forewarned that he intended to speak to Tatler magazine, the exact nature of the questions and answers was not approved in advance. Palace insiders indicated yesterday that the frank interview does not signal a warming of the royal family towards the idea of a remarriage.

In a wide-ranging interview, Prince Andrew said he had found new happiness living with his ex-wife and their two daughters and admitted: "We are not just doing it for the children. We are doing it for our own benefit too."

He added: "I don't rule remarriage out and I certainly don't rule it in. If ever the op portunity arose, I do not know what I would do, as it is not in the plan."

Prince Andrew and the duchess, both 40, divorced in 1996, but three years ago she returned to Sunninghill, Berkshire, along with the two girls, Beatrice, 11, and Eugenie, 10.

The prince, who gave the interview to publicise the NSPCC Full Stop campaign, of which he is chairman, said: "The fact is that we got married and had a wonderful time but it did not work out, for whatever reason."

He said he and his former wife were determined "not to make a nonsense of it again".

The duchess told Geordie Greig, the editor of Tatler: "There has been no discussion on remarriage or reconciliation or any other such word ... I simply say if it should happen, great. It is not in, nor is it ruled out."

She added: "The love is still very much there, just in a different form ... Our situation at Sunninghill is quite extraordinary and very original."

The family is pictured in the magazine under the heading: "We Are Family".

Prince Andrew revealed that he blamed himself for not understanding "the cries for help" until it was too late to halt their marriage breakdown.

He also dismissed reported romances with the model Caprice and French golfer Audrey Raimbault.

The bookmakers William Hill cut the odds on the couple remarrying within a year from 33/1 to 3/1.

Mr Greig said he was surprised by the prince's comments on possible remarriage.

"They are still very good friends. They talk a lot to each other, are very supportive and to a large extent rely on each other.

"This is not unusual, for a couple who have children to become friends again. What is unusual is for them to share a house and for them to contemplate remarriage.

"He was being absolutely straight and saying it is not ruled in, it's not ruled out. He is not in a position to say anything closer or revealing about it at the moment."

Mr Greig said the prince was also sensitive to his reputation as a "cack-handed, blonde-dating oaf", adding he had found him politically aware, contemporary and "sensitive to the nuances of the way he has been portrayed".

During the interview, the prince also offered a rare glimpse of his childhood relationship with his father and confessed that he was picked on at school because he was a royal.

On family life, he added: "My childhood was somewhat military. Things always turned up on time and I remember well that if I didn't turn up to breakfast within five minutes of the appointed time there would be none.

"To this day, I can't have breakfast later than half past eight simply because of the way I was taught. I was frightened that it might have gone by the time I got there."

Speaking of his "perfect" childhood, he added: "My parents made huge efforts to make sure they were with us a lot. That meant a huge sacrifice for them. I remember my mother would look after Edward and me in the evenings in the palace, alone, quite happily. It was a proper family."

fields.headline: Oh happy days
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Yes, yes, yes, oh, YEEESSSS! He's IN! At long last, Kenneth Robert Livingstone - "Ken" to you and me and the vast majority of ordinary, decent people in this great city - has been duly elected mayor of London.
fields.body:
Yes, yes, yes, oh, YEEESSSS! He's IN! At long last, Kenneth Robert Livingstone - "Ken" to you and me and the vast majority of ordinary, decent people in this great city - has been duly elected mayor of London.

Nope, this time the Tory and New Labour smear campaigns didn't pay off. The ordinary, decent Londoner - and, believe me, there's no-one more brilliantly canny than your average cockney - refused to be taken in by the smear machines. So let's nail these Six Great Smears for once and for all.

Smear 1: We were told that Ken is on the far left and once supported the IRA. The Plain Truth: Ken is an extremist only in his commitment to the well being of the people of this great city. He rarely, if ever, thinks about "politics", and believes terrorism should be practised only when strictly necessary.

Smear 2: We were told that Ken is a political opportunist, who will say whatever people want to hear in order to get elected. The Plain Truth: When I voiced these worries to Ken, he placed his hand gently on my shoulder, looked me straight in the eye and assured me personally that it wasn't true.

Smear 3: We were told that, way back in the 1980s, Ken once had a moustache. The Plain Truth: Ken has always been clean-shaven. Photographs of him wearing a moustache have been circulating in the media for many years now, but these have been widely discredited by photographic experts as highly skilled M15 forgeries, many of them studio shots of Private Walker, the spiv character in the long-running TV series Dad's Army.

Smear 4: We were told that Ken has never been liked by his parliamentary colleagues. The Plain Truth: Ken's popularity in the House of Commons is legendary. The reason they never want to sit anywhere near him is purely because they don't want to seem to be "sucking up" to such a charismatic political star.

Smear 5: We were told that Ken will use the mayoralty to promote old political cronies. The Plain Truth: Ken has pledged to pick his colleagues from right across the political spectrum. He has already offered his fellow Labour candidates key posts, but Glenda Jackson refused a senior catering position while Frank Dobson snootily refused out of hand the prestigious post of deputy mayor with special responsibility for toilet facilities in underground car parks.

Smear 6: We were told that London under Ken Livingstone's GLC wasn't all it has since been cracked up to be. The Plain Truth: Under Ken Livingstone, London in 1980s became a socialist paradise. Thanks to Ken's revolutionary Fares Fair policy. There were no traffic jams whatsoever, smoked salmon "eats" were served at peak hours on the underground, and the uncrowded streets were full of goodwill and merriment, neighbours sharing nutritious scraps with one another, while folk of all colours and creeds performed impromptu ballads in praise of their unmoustachioed liberator.

But now let's look to the future. Those of us who have stuck with Ken through thick and thin are fully aware what kind of miracles the guy is capable of. By the end of May, for instance, he will have largely sorted out London's current traffic nightmare. Out will go the private cars with their noxious fumes and irate single-person drivers. In will come luxurious door-to-door buses and coaches, all expertly driven by cheerful cockneys, many of them bona fide pearly kings and queens, with a choice of soft drinks, plus delicious freshly made baguettes and a full range of tempting pastries all "on the house".

Out will go tardy, grubby tube trains. In will come a fully integrated mixed-media underground transport system. Out will go the notorious Circle line, disastrously designed so that the traveller who gets on at, say South Kensington, emerges over an hour later in the very same place. In will come a vivid and hugely exciting new Sur Cool line redesigned by award-winning BritArtist Tracey Emin (widely tipped to be the new deputy mayor), which will transport jaded commuters on a magical mystery tour of light, colour and shade, eventually dropping them at West Acton, within easy reach of a handy connection for the District line.

With the happy loss of so much road traffic, many of London's busiest highways will be grassed over and transformed into premium picnic areas, where ordinary, decent Londoners - the best home-cooks in the world, incidentally - will be only too pleased to share their hampers with the homeless and downtrodden.

And those are just the plans until June! Hurrah for Ken! He's the guy who'll make us all happy once more! And one thing's for sure: he'll never disappoint us.

webTitle: Scots firm counts cost of lost MoD order

fields.headline: Scots firm counts cost of lost MoD order
fields.trailText: British troops are to be kitted out by Bavarian and Belgian clothiers after they undercut a Scottish manufacturer to win a £5.5m Ministry of Defence uniform order.
fields.body:
British troops are to be kitted out by Bavarian and Belgian clothiers after they undercut a Scottish manufacturer to win a £5.5m Ministry of Defence uniform order.

Edward Macbean of Cumbernauld had been bidding to make 140,000 pieces of waterproof combat clothing for British soldiers but lost out to an outfitter in Belgium and the Bavarian company Feuchter. Officials from Macbean said the deal would have safeguarded the future of its Lanarkshire plant, which has made British army outfits since 1998.

The news is the second such blow to Scottish industry, fol lowing widespread speculation that a £1bn MoD ferry order will go to a German shipyard and not the Govan yard on the Clyde - a move critics say may spell the end of Scottish shipbuilding.

Confirming the clothing contracts had gone abroad, a MoD spokesman said yesterday: "Two contracts worth a total of £5.5m were awarded to Feuchter and a Belgian company in December 1999 for the supply of army waterproof clothing as a result of a competition."

It is understood Feuchter had offered to make each item of clothing £4 cheaper than the Macbean bid. The Bavarian firm recently won a £1m contract to make anoraks for the navy. Macbean's chief executive, Jim Hunter, said he may have to lay off staff after losing the order.

"We've just invested £100,000 in the latest technology, we have a custom-built factory here. I may have to let people go," he said.

Mr Hunter said he was furstrated because it appeared Britain was the only country playing fair under EU competitive tendering rules. "Would you see the French military wearing Scottish made or British made uniforms? I don't think so."

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said: "Shamefully this is another example of cuts first, people last. The government is undermin ing quality in its quest to keep down costs."

But the MoD insisted it had made the right decision. A spokesman said: "We do everything we can to encourage and support our own domestic industry but in just a few cases, in open and fair competition, other manufacturers are able to provide the quality we require at a more favourable price.

"The latest available figures show that in the first six months of this financial year 92% of MoD clothing contracts were awarded to UK companies. The total value of these contracts was £43.3m. Our manufacturing companies export to Europe - it's a two-way street."

webTitle: Japan seeks to hunt more whales

fields.headline: Japan seeks to hunt more whales
fields.standfirst: Protests at plan to kill more species for 'scientific research' into diet
fields.trailText: Wildlife campaigners yesterday warned that Japan wants to hunt more whale species.
fields.body:
Wildlife campaigners yesterday warned that Japan wants to hunt more whale species.

The proposal was lodged last month with the Cambridge-based International Whaling Commission by Minoru Morimoto, Japan's IWC commissioner, it has emerged.

This draft research plan to extend Japan's "scientific whaling" is to be considered at meetings of the IWC in Adelaide, Australia, next month.

Although the IWC can be expected to oppose the proposal, Japan looks set to continue regardless.

The plan is reported to say that 100 minke whales, 50 Bryde's whales and 10 sperm whales will be killed to investigate their diet.

Japan has previously claimed that whales eat huge quantities of fish and therefore threaten commercial fisheries and the stability of marine eco-systems.

The West Country based Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society said up until now Japan's "scientific" hunt, which is carried out in defiance of a 14-year ban on commercial hunting, has targeted minke whales.

This latest development will further anger many countries and outrage environmentalists worldwide.

Sue Fisher, WDCS cam paigns manager said: "It also clearly shows that Japan is in no mood for any compromise on whaling. Scientific whaling provides meat to the Japanese markets and is no more than a thin disguise for a commercial hunt.

"The two larger whale species that Japan now identifies as targets for a spurious scientific study are, in fact, better economic targets for them".

She added: "Bigger whales yield more meat for much the same effort as smaller ones."

In 1982 the countries that are parties to the IWC agreed a ban on commercial whaling.

Norway and Japan have never abided by this - choosing instead to use legal loopholes to continue their commercial takes.

Two weeks ago, at the conference of parties to the Convention in Trade in Endangered Species (Cites), four proposals from Norway and Japan to resume international trade in products from three minke whale and one gray whale population were rejected.

The Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society said if the Cites parties had known at the time that Japan also intended to start hunting Bryde's and sperm whales, the opposition would have been even fiercer.

webTitle: Prisoners' accounts of struggle ending in jail death 'unreliable'

fields.headline: Prisoners' accounts of struggle ending in jail death 'unreliable'
fields.standfirst: Deaths in custody: special report
fields.trailText: Prisoner witnesses were accused in the high court yesterday of giving inconsistent and unreliable evidence in the case of an inmate who died during a struggle with prison officers in a privatised jail.
fields.body:
Prisoner witnesses were accused in the high court yesterday of giving inconsistent and unreliable evidence in the case of an inmate who died during a struggle with prison officers in a privatised jail.

Counsel for the director of public prosecutions said the evidence provided "no positive basis" for launching manslaughter charges against any officer involved in the death of the remand prisoner Alton Manning.

Manning, 33, from Birmingham, died in Blakenhurst prison in Worcestershire in December 1995. He suffocated in a struggle with officers after he was asked to squat naked for a strip search for drugs.

His sisters, Patricia Manning and Elizabeth Melbourne, also from Birmingham, were applying to the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, sitting with Mr Justice Morison, for a judicial review after the DPP and crown prosecution service refused to bring "unlawful act" manslaughter charges.

Nicholas Blake QC, for the family, said prisoners had given evidence at an inquest that one officer, unit manager David Nicholson, was holding Manning in a neck lock at the time he died. "There was clear evidence of restraint that was unreasonable, and therefore unlawful, being applied."

In March 1998 a unanimous verdict that Manning, who was black, had been unlawfully killed was recorded at Kidderminster coroner's court.

Mr Blake said the decision not to launch a criminal prosecution in view of the evidence was "irrational and perverse". The case raised important legal issues and was racially sensitive. In seven cases where inquests had found prisoners to have been unlawfully killed in prison or police custody, and no prosecutions had been brought, six involved black prisoners.

James Turner QC, for the DPP, said the decision not to launch manslaughter charges in Manning's case was beyond challenge. The CPS lawyer John Western had been entitled to conclude there was "no realistic prospect" of securing a conviction against Mr Nicholson in the face of a defence that the death was an accident.

"The prisoner accounts are inconsistent, some of them internally and some with each other," said Mr Turner. Lord Bingham reserved judgment.

fields.headline: Catholic bishops attack 'emotive' asylum language
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
Politicians accused of stirring up social divisions
fields.trailText: The Catholic bishops of England and Wales came close to urging their parishioners not to vote for William Hague yesterday as they issued their strongest attack yet on politicians of all parties for stirring up social divisions over asylum seekers.
fields.body:
The Catholic bishops of England and Wales came close to urging their parishioners not to vote for William Hague yesterday as they issued their strongest attack yet on politicians of all parties for stirring up social divisions over asylum seekers.

In a statement after a meeting in London, they accused politicians and some in the media of damaging community relations and giving rise to hostility and fear by attacks on refugees.

The bishops were concerned that the debate on asylum in the UK "is being conducted in a way that is damaging to community relations. In some instances this has given rise to hostility, alarm and fear".

Although insisting their message was not political and that it applied to all politicians as well as national newspapers which have criticised asylum seekers, the bishops' spokesman pointedly singled out expressions used by senior Tories for condemnation.

The Tory manifesto for yesterday's local government elections spoke of a flood of bogus asylum seekers, and Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary and a leading lay Catholic, has described Britain as becoming a soft touch for a massive influx.

The Conservative leadership has repeatedly refused to tone down its language despite condemnation from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the Commission for Racial Equality.

Bishop Patrick O'Donoghue suggested that Catholics should consult their bibles and the teaching of the church before deciding whether to vote for candidates promulgating such messages.

The bishop, whose diocese covers west London and who was speaking on behalf of his colleagues, said: "What we are calling for is compassion, understanding, respect, justice and love and all of these are at the heart of the Christian faith.

"It is regrettable that we cannot speak about asylum seekers without using emotive language. You hear again and again about scroungers, bogus, flood, aggressive beggars - awful statements.

"We are greatly concerned about this negative tone which is beginning to provoke hostility, alarm and fear in some communities.

"I am saying to William Hague that he should talk about love, compassion and understanding. Asylum seekers can be scapegoated and I am looking to politicians for leadership at a time of difficulty when we need a great deal of sensitivity to the issues involved.

"This is not simply addressed to William Hague and Ann Widdecombe but also to the government and other politicians and the media."

In the statement the bishops said: "[Our] concern stems from the Christian belief that we are bound to do what we can to welcome and help the stranger in need."

It called on politicians to educate the public about the conditions from which many asylum-seekers had fled.

It sought a balanced approach from politicians and the media to ensure asylum seekers were treated with compassion and dignity.

Although the statement came too late to affect voting in the elections, it may yet discomfort Mr Hague, who made a play for the Christian vote in the campaign, addressing a conference of Protestant evanglicals and calling for them to become more involved in politics.

fields.headline: Call for baby walkers ban
fields.trailText: Physiotherapists last night voted to lobby for a ban on baby walkers they claim are responsible for injuring thousands of children and hindering development.
fields.body:
Physiotherapists last night voted to lobby for a ban on baby walkers they claim are responsible for injuring thousands of children and hindering development.

Delegates at the Chartered Society of Physiotherapists conference in Eastbourne voted overwhelmingly in favour of the move.

They intend to work with other health organisations in calling for the popular walkers, used by more than 250,000 babies in the UK, to be outlawed.

According to research, the baby walkers are responsible for injuring as many as 4,000 children a year.

Children's walking and visual skills are believed to be affected because babies in the walkers cannot explore their surroundings properly or learn how their bodies work.

Babies put in the walkers are also thought to be slower to develop mentally.

A spokeswoman for the society said: "There is overwhelming support for this motion. Delegate after delegate was telling the conference how they had seen children's development hindered and delayed by these walkers."

Lynda Rowe, who proposed the motion, said: "Parents buy baby walkers because they believe they will keep their children safe and help them to learn to walk.

"Physiotherapists know this is not the case."

Mothercare, which manufactures some baby walkers, said: "Mothercare has always emphasised that the environment in which baby walkers are used is fundamental to their safety.

"They should only be used on a smooth surface and for a limited period as they are not a training aid."

webTitle: Gun lobby claims it would 'work out of President Bush's office'

fields.headline: Gun lobby claims it would 'work out of President Bush's office'
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The Republican presidential contender, George W Bush, was yesterday trying to fend off the over-zealous embrace of one of his closest allies after a National Rifle Association official said that if Mr Bush won, the NRA could set up office in the White House.
fields.body:
The Republican presidential contender, George W Bush, was yesterday trying to fend off the over-zealous embrace of one of his closest allies after a National Rifle Association official said that if Mr Bush won, the NRA could set up office in the White House.

The embarrassing claim emerged in a leaked video of a closed NRA meeting in Los Angeles in which the gun lobby's second-in-command, Kayne Robinson, declared that this year's presidential race could prove pivotal for the or ganisation's future.

In the video, which is being broadcast by a gun control advocacy group, Mr Robinson told NRA members: "If we win, we'll have a president where we work out of their office - unbelievably friendly relations."

Mr Robinson acknowledged yesterday that he had been talking about Mr Bush. He got to know the candidate during the recent primary election campaign, when Mr Robinson was serving in his other role as the head of the Republican's Iowa branch. But the NRA vice-president was unapologetic over his fulsome remarks at the February meeting. Under the Clinton administration, he said, advocates of gun control had had "unlimited access to the White House".

Mr Robinson's comments are likely to play into the hands of Mr Bush's Democratic opponent, Vice-president Al Gore who intends to make gun-control a central issue of his campaign. The Bush campaign headquarters did not return calls yesterday but a spokesman, Scott McClellan, was quoted in yesterday's Washington Post attempting to distance the Republican contender from Mr Robinson's claim.

"Neither the NRA nor any special interest sets the governor's agenda," Mr McClellan said. "Governor Bush sets his agenda based on his priorities and principles."

The video has surfaced at a time when guns are one of the most emotive "hot-button" issues in the election. The NRA has so far donated more than $500,000 (£325,000) in campaign funds directly to the Republican Party, and plans to spend up to £10m.

For the gunmakers, the stakes could not be higher. They are fighting off 31 local government initiatives aimed at suing them for the costs caused by gun-violence.

Meanwhile a series of measures are awaiting votes in Congress which would require stricter checks on would-be gun-buyers and require weapons manufacturers to install gun-locks.

It is an issue on which the two presidential contenders are on opposite ends of the spectrum. Mr Gore has been demonised by the NRA for casting a deciding vote last year on a law to require background checks on buyers at weekend gun-shows.

The NRA has meanwhile warmly endorsed Mr Bush as a "strong pro-gun candidate". Soon after becoming Texas governor in 1994, he signed a bill allowing Texans to carry concealed weapons for the first time in 125 years.

Last year he backed legislation which banned Texan cities from suing gunmakers. "Governor Bush is going to have a lot of explaining to do to defend his atrocious record on guns to the American people - the majority of whom overwhelmingly support new common-sense gun control laws," said Michael Barnes, the president of Handgun Control, which is using the Robinson video in its political advertising.

However, the Bush camp points out that he differs from the NRA on several issues. He supports raising the minimum age for gun-owners from 18 to 21, and banning the import of high-capacity ammunition magazines for machine guns.

The work, which was commissioned by the Royal Armouries, is a reworking of the 15th-century melody L'Homme Armé, on which Dufay, Ockeghem, Josquin and Palestrina based settings of the Mass.

fields.headline: Diary  Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: •A powerful champion steps forward to support nature in its unending battle with nurture. Sun football reporter Steven Howard is the son, we learn, of that noblest of English film actors, Trevor Howard. Few in the effete world of tabloid sports hackery, where Steven's cut-glass accent has caused bafflement, are aware of this.
fields.body:
A powerful champion steps forward to support nature in its unending battle with nurture. Sun football reporter Steven Howard is the son, we learn, of that noblest of English film actors, Trevor Howard. Few in the effete world of tabloid sports hackery, where Steven's cut-glass accent has caused bafflement, are aware of this. And yet who reading Steven's account of this week's Arsenal v West Ham game ("the pressure-cooker could take it no more and the game exploded in its normal crazy direction - straight into the stratosphere") can fail to be reminded of the tightly-coiled emotion of his late father's performance in Brief Encounter. Playing the GP who falls in love with Celia Johnson in a railway canteen but takes a job abroad to save her respectability may have been Trevor's best known role, but intriguingly - and isn't this spooky - he also starred in the 1956 Nazis in the jungle-style romp, Run To The Sun. Alas, Steven is less keen to run to the phone, and declines to return any of our calls. The strong, silent type, then. Just like his dad.

Members of the GMB in Middlesbrough receive an enticing offer, headed: "North East region constituency trip to Brussels", from political officer Kevan Jones. "Please find enclosed a draft itinerary for an up and coming GMB trip to Strasbourg, Brussels, on Saturday June 10-Friday 16 June 2000. The cost of the trip to each delegate is only £50." Wow. It sounds tremendous, the route taking in Dover, Rheims, Strasbourg, a tour of the Alsace wine region, Paris, Calais and home. Kevan's spiel makes all the places in Brussels sound so good that one half wonders whether he may not have a future as a travel agent.

Following a rebuff when the Rover press office's phone went unanswered - press attache Elaine Winterburn was on holiday looking after her two children (but then you really must take advantage when things are quiet, because there's bound to be trouble ahead), negotiations about the loan of top of the range Rover 75 move quickly. Already Elaine has promised to lend us a luxury 2.5 litre model with an on-the-road value of £27,730. We are pleased to accept, with one small rider: in the past, we have consented to return vehicles after a week, however in this case, as a mark of the Diary's confidence in Rover, it's probably best to hang on to it until the long-term future of Longbridge is secured.

Concern mounts that Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke has lost his drive. Hodder & Stoughton's catalogue of forthcoming books mentions only two works by his reverence: Jesus Never Said - Discovering the Real Jesus ("based on his fascinating series in Christianity magazine") in December, and in August the Parent-talk Guide to Your Child and Sex ("a must for any parent who wants to help their child in a world of sexual pressure": Eamonn Holmes). We hope to discuss these works with Steve as soon as he is forgiven for signing a letter to the Daily Telegraph without permission.

I am intrigued by a polemical piece in the Daily Star by Dominik Diamond, who rails against products of the middle-class brats affecting to be down with da kids. Mr Diamond, who used to present a football phone-in on Radio 5 Live in the confused style of a jingle-besotted early 1970s Radio 1 DJ with pretensions to being a class warrior (barbed comments about "posh" sports are popular) forgets that he went to Strathallan, one of Scotland's most expensive public schools. Very odd.

My thanks to Mrs LP Azaouzi and Mrs H Malik from Her Majesty's customs and excise for visiting me at home yesterday for a "VAT comfort visit". A pleasure to meet you both. I may well be going away shortly to spend time in another region of Her Majesty's sprawling empire, but I'm very glad they enjoyed their coffee.

fields.headline: Royal Bank of Scotland
fields.trailText: If the £18bn tussle over NatWest was a distraction for the board of Royal Bank of Scotland, it does not appear to have pushed the troops off course. Despite the five-month war, the Royal Bank's profits for the period to March 31 show that pre-tax profits rose by 35% to £715m or by 25% to £671m if exceptional items are excluded.
fields.body:
If the £18bn tussle over NatWest was a distraction for the board of Royal Bank of Scotland, it does not appear to have pushed the troops off course. Despite the five-month war, the Royal Bank's profits for the period to March 31 show that pre-tax profits rose by 35% to £715m or by 25% to £671m if exceptional items are excluded.

In its largest area, the boring business of UK banking, profits rose by 22% while Citizens, the US bank run by the expensive Larry Fish, achieved an 18% rise.

Now that it owns NatWest, Royal Bank is changing its year-end to match that of the big British banks, the main reason why it did not make any presentations to analysts or the media yesterday as it will be releasing six months results, including NatWest's contribution, on August 1.

Direct Line, the bank's little red phone operation, was saying more than its parent yesterday. Its phones are busier than ever with 2.8m motorists insuring their cars with the operation which was ground- breaking when it was launched a decade ago. Direct Line, which reorganised itself into five new business divisions yesterday, is planning to lead what it sees as the next revolution for insurance - on the in ternet. It is spending £50m to create "the UK's leading motoring site".

It said directline.com is already smashing through its targets and boasted that its aim of selling 15% of motor insurance online by 2003 "looks within easy reach". It has 40% share of the online motor insurance market, compared with its market share for private car insurance of 15%.

While Royal Bank may have managed to keep churning out the profits during the battle, its real job now is to convince the market it can achieve the cost savings and revenue enhancements it promised as a result of the deal. Hugh Pye, banking analyst at Flemings, said the share price, at £10.17 yesterday, was not factoring in progress. "If they deliver, the shares should go up," he said.

fields.headline: Mr Cook's last throw
fields.standfirst:
Britain has little left to say to Mr Mugabe

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: In the Zimbabwe crisis, the government has made its last throw. It is out of ammo. Robin Cook's announcement that Britain is suspending all military-related exports leaves the locker almost bare. fields.body:
In the Zimbabwe crisis, the government has made its last throw. It is out of ammo. Robin Cook's announcement that Britain is suspending all military-related exports leaves the locker almost bare. Since President Robert Mugabe launched his campaign of intimidation against his own people last February, Britain has tried diplomacy; it has tried high-level talks; it has offered money for land reform and its good offices in facilitating a resumption of international lending and aid. Mr Cook has withdrawn Britain's high commissioner, and then sent him back again; he has resisted Tory calls for broad, unfocused sanctions, and for the seizure of Mr Mugabe's personal assets. He has attempted a conciliatory approach. But it has all come to nought. Mr Mugabe is unchecked and rudely unbowed.

Perhaps Malcolm Rifkind, the former foreign secretary, was correct yesterday when he claimed the Foreign Office had unwisely allowed Mr Mugabe to portray the crisis as a struggle with Britain. But it is difficult to see how else Mr Cook could have acted. Now, hope of a peaceful resolution rests with Don McKinnon, the Commonwealth secretary-general, who is to visit Zimbabwe, with Commonwealth and EU monitoring of the Zimbabwe general election which must be held by August, and with continuing international pressure on Mr Mugabe.

With Britain having exhausted what little leverage it possessed to no measurable effect, Zimbabwe could go any one of three ways. Under the first scenario, Mr Mugabe and Zanu-PF will intensify their harassment and denunciation of supporters of Morgan Tsvangirai's opposition Movement for Democratic Change in general, and of white Zimbabweans in particular. When Mr Mugabe feels he has worked up enough momentum, and has inspired enough fear, the elections will finally be held; but in crucial rural areas, where the monitors will be stretched thin, they will be ruthlessly rigged. Mr Mugabe will then declare a famous victory - and unless overall fraud can be proven, instantly, and beyond any doubt, it is probable that the outside world will expediently (and depressingly) go along with the result.

The second possibility is that the MDC, despite everything, will win at the polls. For some in southern Africa and the west, this is a truly frightening prospect. For it is highly unlikely, on present form, that the panjandrums, hacks, thugs, placemen and time-servers of Zanu-PF would accept electoral defeat and sweetly depart for retirement on their newly expropriated country estates. Ironically, an MDC victory could thus bring the very civil war, mass exodus, and economic ruination which so many already fear at Mr Mugabe's hands. This is not to say that an opposition victory is undesirable. Far from it. But the consequences may be dire.

The last possibility is that, against expectations, the one man who still has real influence and economic leverage to exercise over Mr Mugabe - the president of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki - will resolve to put them to use to enforce fair play. So far, it is not apparent that Mr Mbeki has yet understood that what is happening in Zimbabwe could one day happen too in his country, where many of the same pressures exist. The demeaning of democracy, the degradation of respect for the law, and the usurpation of the people's will are not precedents which serve anybody's best interest. And South Africa is first in the firing line. With others like Britain now demonstrably powerless, Mr Mbeki has a responsibility to act quickly.

fields.headline: Philippine rebels split up hostages
fields.trailText: Islamic rebels have split their 21 mainly foreign hostages into five groups and each group is trying to break through a cordon of troops around their jungle hideout, leading to sporadic gun battles, Philippine officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
Islamic rebels have split their 21 mainly foreign hostages into five groups and each group is trying to break through a cordon of troops around their jungle hideout, leading to sporadic gun battles, Philippine officials said yesterday.

Orlando Mercado, the defence secretary, said that all the hostages kidnapped by the Abu Sayyaf (Father of the Sword) group from a Malaysian holiday resort on Easter Sunday were alive but still captive, discounting radio reports that two may have escaped or that some may have died in fighting around the rebel base on Jolo island, 600 miles south of Manila.

In a separate drama, another Abu Sayyaf unit sprayed gunfire on a group of Filipino hostages, including a priest, after tying their hands behind their backs when troops closed in on them on Wednesday, officials said.

Four of the 27 Filipino hostages taken on March 20 - schoolchildren, their teachers and the priest - were killed on Basilan island, near Jolo. Fifteen hostages were freed by the military, although five, including three children, were wounded. Eight hostages were unaccounted for.

"They sprayed them with gunfire before [the other hostages] started running," the army's commander in the south, Diomedio Villanueva, said, adding that many of the victims were bound before being killed. Police said the victims were also attacked with scythes.

"We will not be satisfied until those devils, the Abu Sayyaf, are killed," Leoncia Democrito, the pregnant wife of one of those killed, said as she wept over his coffin.

Colleagues of Father Ruel Gallardo said that the 34-year-old priest had his nails pulled out and suffered daily beatings during his captivity. The Pope expressed his sorrow at the priest's death yesterday.

Meanwhile the government's chief negotiator, Nur Misuari, was meeting his staff to discuss a resumption of contacts with the rebels to free the Jolo hostages. Informal talks were disrupted on Wednesday after fighting erupted between the rebels and troops. Radio reports said nine guerrillas died in the clash, but the rebels said they lost one dead.

"The incidents are a consequence of [the rebel groups and captives] being broken up into five groups," Mr Mercado said. "There was also an attempt to probe and get people out, but they found that the cordon is tight and we have reinforced the cordon."

Some 2,000 troops are spread around the hills of Jolo to cut off rebel escape routes.

The Jolo hostages are 10 Malaysians, three Germans, two French nationals, two South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese and a Filipina.

Germany yesterday added to growing pressure on Manila to end the crisis without bloodshed. The chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said in Berlin that he had urged the Philippines president, Joseph Estrada, to put the lives of the hostages above any other aim. France has made similar pleas.

Abu Sayyaf is one of two groups fighting for an Islamic state in the mainly Catholic Philippines. The larger rebel group is the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (Milf).

On the main Mindanao island, where the Milf also unleashed a wave of violence on Wednesday, there was only sporadic fighting yesterday.

Military and radio reports said 35 people died on Wednesday when the Milf clashed with soldiers in five places, launched grenades at an airport and exploded bombs in a seaport town. It took about 100 hostages during the fighting, but withdrew overnight, leaving its hostages behind.

The violence racking the southern Philippines is the worst since another separatist group agreed to a peace deal with Manila in 1996.

Mindanao is home to most of the 5m Muslims in the country's 74m population.
Reuters

fields.headline: Nora Swinburne
fields.standfirst: She brought beauty, grace and charm to an age of theatrical escapism
fields.trailText: Whatever she did on the West End stage - and her career spanned more than 60 years - the actress Nora Swinburne, who has died aged 97, did with grace and poise. Here was a profile of striking beauty: a touch haughty, perhaps, but with a hint of that silent command to which playgoers and filmgoers were content to be subject in the heyday of light comedy. She was also intelligent enough to enliven the most routine dramaturgy - and between the wars it could indeed be mechanical.
fields.body:
Whatever she did on the West End stage - and her career spanned more than 60 years - the actress Nora Swinburne, who has died aged 97, did with grace and poise. Here was a profile of striking beauty: a touch haughty, perhaps, but with a hint of that silent command to which playgoers and filmgoers were content to be subject in the heyday of light comedy. She was also intelligent enough to enliven the most routine dramaturgy - and between the wars it could indeed be mechanical.

How many other actresses knew how to twirl three rows of pearls as expertly and expressively as to make James Agate doubt, in Daphne du Maurier's The Years Between (1947), whether - in her supposed widowhood as a woman of parliamentary ambition - Swinburne would care "twopence whether working-class houses are provided with baths or not?" Who could more effectively lighten a dark scene of marital strife, or keep the home fires burning more brightly, even down to the handling of the drawing-room tongs (when, by rare chance, no servant was there to do it)?

Nearly all of Swinburne's plays were set amid the middle or upper-middle classes, with her caressing voice to smooth many a troubled male brow, or her beguiling feminity to bestow consolation on an anxious husband. If she did not dominate all the stage drawing-rooms of the period, her gracious presence brought dignity and a dry wit to scores of forgotten farces.

Is it ill-mannered now to wonder why she seemed so often, and for so long, to have played the same kind of ladylike part? To wonder, in a word, why she never developed into a more powerful actress? The short answer may be that Swinburne's attractive art flourished in an era when drawing-room comedy, however silly, pleased. Audiences could be sure of seeing, without envy or disdain, their social betters leading sometimes lurid lives of graceful and secure splendour, so unlike the lives of most spectators. It was a distraction from reality.

So, for the stage-struck daughter of a west country toy manufacturer, who trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and, at 14, got her first West End chance in something called Paddly Pools, the spirit of the age was on her side. When the troops who survived the trenches came home on leave, they crowded those theatres playing revues and musical comedy. By then, the young Elinore Johnson (she soon changed her name) was part of Clive Currie's Young Players learning the ropes.

Swinburne would appear in up to three West End plays every season. And even when the demand for floozies and flappers in such trivial-sounding shows as This And That, Yes, It's You I Want, Lovers' Leap, and Married For Money began to dwindle in the 1940s, her theatrical presence was such that no playgoer felt able to miss it. Even the sternest critics said she never bored them, however boring her part.

The upshot was two or three more decades on stage, including two stints with the '69 Theatre, Manchester, playing Violet in TS Eliot's The Family Reunion (1973) and Julia Shuttleworth in The Cocktail Party (1975). Then she retired.

Meanwhile, since 1919, there had been a less intense career both in silent cinema and the talkies. Her films ranged from Branded (1920) to Up The Chastity Belt (1971). Quarter (1948), drawn from Maugham short stories, was perhaps the best. But Swinburne's heart was always in the theatre. Between the wars, she sailed twice to Broadway; and in 1938 went successfully into management with Peter Blackmore's Lot's Wife, in which she played the title role.

In Turgenev's A Month In The Country (1943), Swinburne took over the role of Nathalia Petrovna from Valerie Taylor, and from Diana Wynyard in Lillian Hellman's Watch On The Rhine. Later stage credits included Mrs Arbuthnot in Wilde's A Woman Of No Importance (1953), Peter Coke's Fool's Paradise (1959), in which she co-starred with Cicely Courtneidge, and Donald Howarth's All Good Children (1964). Her television roles included Aunt Hester in the Forsyte Saga (1967).

There was a walkover look about much of her acting. But when it looks easy it seldom is. In the name part of Maugham's Caroline (Arts Theatre, 1949), for example, Swinburne played the siren, as Harold Hobson remarked, "gently and charmingly". It was a familiar role for her to be "an object of desire".

Nora Swinburne was thrice married and twice divorced; her first husband was the actor Francis Lister; her second was Edward Ashley-Cooper; and her third was the actor Esmond Knight, who died in 1987.

She leaves her son Francis, from her first marriage.

Nora Swinburne, actress, born July 24 1902; died May 1 2000

fields.headline: Cardinal John O'Connor
fields.standfirst: US cleric whose cheerful humility ensured his popularity despite conservative views
fields.trailText: Cardinal John O'Connor, the Catholic Archbishop of New York, who has died at the age of 80, was one of America's staunchest conservative voices. Throughout his career, he battled against most of the social changes of the 20th century - artificial contraception, abortion, the acceptance of homosexuality, and the ordination of women. His opposition went as far as issuing a veiled warning to senior Catholic politicians that they risked excommunication if they persisted in their support of abortion.
fields.body:
Cardinal John O'Connor, the Catholic Archbishop of New York, who has died at the age of 80, was one of America's staunchest conservative voices. Throughout his career, he battled against most of the social changes of the 20th century - artificial contraception, abortion, the acceptance of homosexuality, and the ordination of women. His opposition went as far as issuing a veiled warning to senior Catholic politicians that they risked excommunication if they persisted in their support of abortion.

But there was growing evidence that he was out of tune with large segments of his national congregation. Last year, a survey by the National Catholic Reporter found that up to a quarter of America's 60m Catholics were wholly inactive, that even more rejected the church's teachings on sexual conduct, and that only 37% attended Mass each week, a sharp decline from 10 years earlier.

Despite this, O'Connor's cheerful humility ensured that he was held in high personal regard. His working-class Philadelphia back- ground never quite left him. Startled by the likely bill for vestments when he became archbishop in 1984, he briskly instructed that his predecessor's robes be adapted to fit him. Through out his life, he fought against poverty, and was a staunch advocate of trade union rights; he once ordered a television crew out of a press conference when he learned it had crossed a picket line to get there.

His life closely parallelled that of Pope John Paul II, with whom he developed an exceptionally close relationship: "I want a man just like me in New York," the pontiff was reported as saying when appointing O'Connor head of the archdiocese. Only four months apart in age, they had taken up the priesthood within a year of one another.

However, after his ordination in 1945, O'Connor broke with tradition by moving to Georgetown University, in Washington, to embrace two subjects far removed from theology - clinical psychology and political science. He graduated with a PhD and a reputation as one of the college's brightest alumni.

Rather than take over a local parish, he chose the US navy in 1952, in response to a call for more chaplains during the Korean war, retiring after 27 years with the rank of rear admiral, and in charge of all navy chaplains.

Created bishop of Scranton, Pennsylvania, in 1983, he was soon involved in the sort of political controversy that marked the rest of his priesthood. His military experience left him moderate on foreign policy issues: among his targets was the Reagan administration's burgeoning defence spending and its clandestine support for anti-government forces in central America. Then, to the considerable surprise of his fellows, he was chosen by the Pope to succeed Cardinal Terence Cooke in the New York see.

Even before his arrival, O'Connor had managed to anger the city's large Jewish population by ineptly commenting that the Holocaust was "Judaism's gift to the world", and comparing deaths from abortion with the Nazis' campaign of racial murder. What he apparently meant to convey was sympathy for the unbearable wartime suffering of the Jews. The argument that his tongue, rather than his outlook, was at fault was eventually sustained by his subsequent campaigns against anti-semitism, and his successful efforts to improve relations between the Vatican and Israel.

As archbishop, he soon adapted to New York's high-profile approach to life, establishing a weekly news conference after his Sunday morning Mass to expound his views on current issues. He was quickly at odds with the city authorities over such matters as municipal leaflets about contraceptive facilities and bylaws protecting the employment rights of homosexuals, though he later developed a close friendship with his former adversary Mayor Ed Koch. They eventually collaborated on a book, His Eminence And Hizzoner (1989), and offered each other encouragement during their illnesses.

O'Connor's personal behaviour did not always square with his public pronouncements in other respects. In 1987, for example, he denounced proposals by Catholic bishops to start educational programmes on the dangers of Aids. Behind the scenes, meanwhile, he was helping to care for Aids patients in a local hospice. He also sank his political disagreements with Mayor David Dinkins and appeared with him on the streets of Washington Heights to calm explosive racial tensions.

Towards the end of his life, O'Connor wondered whether his readiness to engage in so much noisy controversy had really served its purpose. As he commented wryly in one interview: "Time after time, I have to ask myself if the church would be better off if I had just become a silent servant of the people."

But, as he surveyed the increasing secularisation of American life, O'Connor's deeply conservative views were not easily held in check. They were also reinforced throughout his incumbency by his monthly flights to the Vatican to consult with his equally conservative leader.

But the doctrinal pronouncements emerging from these discussions seemed to have less and less impact on America's increasingly radicalised Roman Catholic clergy and sceptical laity. The rules laid down so uncompromisingly by the archbishop no longer seemed as relevant to what his congregation could see around them.

O'Connor is survived by his brother and two sisters.
John Joseph O'Connor, cleric, born January 15 1920; died May 3 2000
