As he commented wryly in one interview: "Time after time, I have to ask myself if the church would be better off if I had just become a silent servant of the people." But, as he surveyed the increasing secularisation of American life, O'Connor's deeply conservative views were not easily held in check. They were also reinforced throughout his incumbency by his monthly flights to the Vatican to consult with his equally conservative leader. But the doctrinal pronouncements emerging from these discussions seemed to have less and less impact on America's increasingly radicalised Roman Catholic clergy and sceptical laity. The rules laid down so uncompromisingly by the archbishop no longer seemed as relevant to what his congregation could see around them. O'Connor is survived by his brother and two sisters. John Joseph O'Connor, cleric, born January 15 1920; died May 3 2000

fields.headline: Rail raptors
fields.trailText: Raptors are not as uncommon on the Underground as Peter Mellor (Letters, May 3) assumes. A network-wide survey of biodiversity by the London Ecology Unit in 1999 indicated kestrels habitually frequent areas on and around the railway, and often hunt over train depots ... perhaps in search of electrocuted mice.
fields.body:
Raptors are not as uncommon on the Underground as Peter Mellor (Letters, May 3) assumes. A network-wide survey of biodiversity by the London Ecology Unit in 1999 indicated kestrels habitually frequent areas on and around the railway, and often hunt over train depots ... perhaps in search of electrocuted mice.

Sparrowhawks have also been spotted and visitors to North Greenwich station at the Dome may spot Wayne Davies and his Harris hawk, Hamish, keeping the less desirable avian species, such as the ubiquitous feral pigeon, at bay. Those anticipating aerial violence may be disappointed, however. Unlike Mr Mellor's proposed golden eagle, Hamish acts as a deterrent rather than a terminator.

Ed Gillespie
London Underground
Edgarlesty@talk21.com

fields.headline: Speechless
fields.trailText:
Last weekend the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology hosted a three-day conference on translation, attended by participants from (almost) all over the world. The Foreign Office, however, refused to grant a visa to attend the conference to Dr Alya' MH Ahmad Al-Rubai'i, who was due to speak in a session on non-western approaches to translation studies.

Derek Boothman
fields.body:

The Foreign Office, however, refused to grant a visa to attend the conference to Dr Alya' MH Ahmad Al-Rubai'i, who was due to speak in a session on non-western approaches to translation studies.

Derek Boothman

Dr Al-Rubai'i's sin appears to be that she is on the staff of one of the Middle East's most highly regarded academic centres, the Al-Mustansiriyya University, which has the misfortune to be located in Baghdad. Through this action, Robin Cook's department is not isolating Saddam Hussein so much as erecting a barrier between a part of the Iraqi academic community professionally interested in furthering dialogue and the outside world. Could the foreign secretary justify to conference participants and to electors how this fits in with his ethical foreign policy?

Silvia Bernardini

University of Bologna, Italy
boothman@sslmit.unibo.it

fields.headline: The dirt on asthma jabs
fields.trailText: I nip to the supermarket during my lunch hour to grab the anti-bacterial clingfilm and kill-all-germs-dead disinfectant that I need to clean my oh-so-sterile house. I just have time to get it all done before I pick up my daughter from the nursery because she's due for her bacteria inoculations to replace the common dirt that historically kept her fit and healthy (Bacteria inoculation for babies could curb asthma, May 3).

I just have time to get it all done before I pick up my daughter from the nursery because she's due for her bacteria inoculations to replace the common dirt that historically kept her fit and healthy (Bacteria inoculation for babies could curb asthma, May 3).

I'm far too tired to think straight but, as I hang out in the waiting room, reading the latest articles on Brain Food for Your Child and Computer Courses for Toddlers, I can't help feeling that there must be some easier way.

Fiona Clarke
Plymouth
finndeni@reverse.freeserve. co.uk

 What use is the inoculation strategy if we all still drink chlorinated water, and eat food full of antibiotics? The inoculated germs will be killed off in no time. Our immune systems are being profoundly damaged by our way of life. This is why cancer, like asthma, is increasing so terrifyingly fast.

Sara Neill
Tunbridge Wells, Kent
sara.neill@zoom.co.uk

 I will be conducting a parallel investigation to the inoculation programme. For the next decade I will refrain from all washing-up and sweeping while monitoring young children in the vicinity. It will be interesting to compare the costs and benefits.

Ben Lane
 Bristol
ben_lane@ecolane.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: What makes films bomb
fields.trailText: I am concerned that your article on the British film industry may encourage the view that films with poor box office receipts are ipso facto poor films (Help for film makers taking on Hollywood, May 2).
fields.body:
I am concerned that your article on the British film industry may encourage the view that films with poor box office receipts are ipso facto poor films (Help for film makers taking on Hollywood, May 2).

I am the writer and director of A Kind Of Hush, one of a number of films to have received public money and described in your article as a "lottery loser". A Kind Of Hush has been in the main competitions of six European film festivals, received three major prizes and a vastly positive response from critics generally. Indeed, when the film opened in London last September, your weekly round-up of critics' ratings put the film in equal first place with Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut. Your critic was one of very few negative voices.

I suggest that the reason the film did not do well at the box office was not because the film was no good, but because of an almost total lack of promotional machine behind it. As the cinema manager said at the time: "You just cannot open a film in the West End without publicity."

The truth is that the commercial life or death of a film depends more on the quality of the distribution it receives than the quality of the work itself. If we are to judge films only by box office success then cinema will be the loser.

Brian Stirner
Writer/director, A Kind Of Hush

Newton Poppleford, Devon
pursuit@eurobell.co.uk

fields.headline: African education tests its benefactors
fields.trailText: Your coverage of the World Education Forum in Dakar has been very odd (Promises come in for Education and associated leader, May 1). Your suggestion that the UK government is isolated or backward is completely false.
fields.body:
Your coverage of the World Education Forum in Dakar has been very odd (Promises come in for Education and associated leader, May 1). Your suggestion that the UK government is isolated or backward is completely false.

We strongly support governments who are building sustainable primary education systems. We have committed £300m in the last three years and will do more. But this requires long-term partnerships to build and support commitment to educating all children, including girls.

Partnerships for development mean investment in helping countries build their own capacity to provide sustainable services for their people. This requires good management of public finances, and economic poli cies which ensure that the economy grows so that quality education systems can be maintained.

The call by Oxfam, which was supported by the Guardian, for a separate aid fund for primary education is a very old-fashioned approach to development. It leads to donors bypassing the local systems and creating centres of excellence. Then when the aid funds cease, the new systems crumble. This is why we, most southern NG0s and those who are working to ensure that we get all children, including the girls, into primary education by 2015, are opposed to the demand for a separate aid fund. It will not lead to sustainable development.
Clare Short MP
Secretary of state for international development

 Contrary to John Vidal's claim (World summit clash on education of poor, April 26) that public outlays on education under IMF-supported programs have generally declined, the most recent data for Africa show that, since 1985, these outlays have gone up, on average, by 1.4% per person (after adjusting for inflation).

Even more important is that these countries are also experiencing real gains in education. Illiteracy rates have declined by 2.4% per year, while female enrolment rates in primary education have gone up by 1.1% per year. In secondary education, enrolment rates have increased by 3.1 %.

Sanjeev Gupta
International Monetary Fund,
Washington, US

fields.headline: How did Napoleon die?
fields.standfirst: Was he poisoned? A brouhaha threatens
fields.trailText: The French and English never have far to go to find reason for a good contretemps. The ongoing débcle over BSE comes quickly to mind. But yesterday, the French Senate was plunging back nearly 200 years into history to mull over other iniquities of the perfidious Albion.
fields.body:
The French and English never have far to go to find reason for a good contretemps. The ongoing débcle over BSE comes quickly to mind. But yesterday, the French Senate was plunging back nearly 200 years into history to mull over other iniquities of the perfidious Albion.

The subject on the menu - quite literally - was the poisoning of Napoleon, the b te noire of our entente cordiale. No figure is more emblematic of Anglo-French rivalry: to the French, he was the great moderniser, but to the English, he was an absurd figure with a penchant for starting, and winning wars. Now his manner of death has all the potential for a cause célèbre. While the English have always maintained that Napoleon died of cancer in 1821 while imprisoned on the island of St Helena, French senators heard over their guinea-fowl lunch yesterday that the emperor was poisoned with arsenic.

Scientists have analysed the DNA of a lock of Napoleon's hair taken at the time of his death and have concluded that the results are consistent with gradual poisoning. FBI investigators confirmed their findings. Previously neglected autopsies indicated no weight loss (thus ruling out cancer). Over the main course, the question was debated and, finally, between the removal of the plates and the serving of coffee, senators were allowed to address questions to the toxicologists, cancerologists, criminal investigators and other experts giving evidence.

All of this appears to confirm long-held suspicions that a shadowy and perhaps somewhat outré character called Monthalon, a Frenchman imprisoned alongside Napoleon, was in the pay of the English and, directed by the English governor of St Helena, Hudson Lowe, supplied the emperor with bitter almonds laced with arsenic. Yesterday's lunchtime discussions were billed as a relative soufflé, but such revelations of our poisoning past will do little to ease our beef into the mouths of French consumers.

webTitle: Who wants to be a scientist?

fields.headline: Who wants to be a scientist?
fields.trailText: Would Carol Vorderman be vilified in the same way if she had fluffed a question on science, mathematics or engineering (Letters, May 4)? Probably not. Would a better knowledge of Shakespeare have saved Rover cars? Or the rest of British manufacturing industry? Will such knowledge fuel our ambition to be at the forefront of new technology and innovation? Of course not. A greater awareness of science in the boardroom, and in society in general, might though.
fields.body:
Would Carol Vorderman be vilified in the same way if she had fluffed a question on science, mathematics or engineering (Letters, May 4)? Probably not. Would a better knowledge of Shakespeare have saved Rover cars? Or the rest of British manufacturing industry? Will such knowledge fuel our ambition to be at the forefront of new technology and innovation? Of course not. A greater awareness of science in the boardroom, and in society in general, might though.

Shakespeare is not the problem, it is merely a symptom. It is the pseudo-intellectual bias of the likes of Jeremy Paxman and John Sutherland (From bard to worse, G2, May 3) who perpetuate the dubious virtues of a classical education that is at the root of this country's industrial decline. They denigrate Ms Vorderman's intellect, while forgetting that most students who plump for English literature and the arts do so because they find mathematics and the sciences too difficult. But then, it's not as if students of Eng lish literature are particularly revered on the majority of our university campuses. Certainly, my recollection is that they were generally considered to reside somewhere between spirogyra and other pond-life in the intellectual hierarchy at Cambridge. Perhaps this was what Ms Vorderman was alluding to?

Dr Adrian Potts
University of Southampton
ap@ecs.soton.ac.uk

 In my humble opinion, two of the greatest-ever Englishmen were Isaac Newton and Michael Faraday. Perhaps Ms Vorderman and I should set some "easy" questions on calculus or electromagnetic theory for Messrs Sutherland and Billington. Would their inability to answer qualify them for a career in television, politics, journalism?

John Caley
Crowthorne, Berks

 Of course it is perfectly OK in this country to say that maths is boring.

Ricky Gilby
Hull
ricky@towerhouse.karoo.co.uk

 Carol Vorderman fails to answer a Shakespeare question and the Guardian does a two-page feature about it. I hope if Kirsty Young had failed to answer the question "what is the chance of rolling a six on a dice?" you would have devoted two pages to the public's lack of understanding of everyday maths.

Rob Eastaway
 London
Rob@eastaway.demon.co.uk

 The rationale for making A-level maths harder appears to ignore the fact that maths at A-level is not designed exclusively to train mathematicians and scientists (A-level maths to be made harder, May 1). If we want a single maths A-level to provide a reasonable mathematical grounding for those entering a range of disciplines and professions, then making the subject more difficult is counterproductive.

In any case, maths is the A-level subject with the best range of opportunities for further advancement. The modular system attacked by Mr Tate's proposals actually facilitates delving deeper into the subject. I shall go to Cambridge next year to study maths with two and a half A-levels' worth of maths modules (maths, further maths and further maths (additional AS)and valuable experience competing in the British Mathematical Olympiad.

A single maths A-level may be inadequate training for a mathematician, but this is no reason to penalise those who take it for broader reasons. There are many opportunities for deeper mathematical study at secondary school level - provided there are enough qualified maths teachers.

Edward Wallace
London
TheWallaces@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Common sense prevails
fields.standfirst: Interest rates are unchanged. Just as well
fields.trailText: Denis Healey, who had plenty of form when it came to crisis management, once said that if you were in a hole the smart move was to stop digging. The Bank of England, thankfully, did just that yesterday when it left interest rates on hold at 6%, much to the relief of what remains of Britain's manufacturing base.
fields.body:
Denis Healey, who had plenty of form when it came to crisis management, once said that if you were in a hole the smart move was to stop digging. The Bank of England, thankfully, did just that yesterday when it left interest rates on hold at 6%, much to the relief of what remains of Britain's manufacturing base. But if the first rule of holes is to stop digging, the second is to haul yourself out. This may prove more difficult, because the economy, make no mistake, is in a very deep hole indeed. There is plenty of surface glitter, but beneath the carapace there is a severe dislocation between manufacturing and services, between north and south and between the protected domestic firms and those facing the full blast of international competition.

Coping with this problem would be hard at the best of times. As it is, the dark side of operational independence for the Bank means that it has a single policy objective - to keep inflation at 2.5% - and a single policy instrument to achieve it, the manipulation of short-term interest rates. The members of the MPC know that the obvious cure for the travails of manufacturing in Sheffield, a substantial cut in base rates, will also result in higher house prices in Surbiton.

So is there a way for policy-makers to clamber out of the hole? One answer, advanced in his new freedom by Michael Heseltine, is for the government simply to announce that it wants to join the euro at a lower rate than today's. In truth, there is no guarantee, given the capital flight out of euroland, that a stated intention to join the euro would bring down the exchange rate, even in the unlikely event of the rest of the euro-11 agreeing to such a plan.

The real need at present is for some joined-up economic thinking. Interest rates could be cut, but only if the government is prepared to use fiscal policy more aggressively to curb demand in the economy's hotspots. A more progressive local property tax would be a good start. At a structural level, it makes little sense to be giving the go-ahead for new housing developments in the south-east, nor to allow high-tech facilities to be moved from the north-west to the golden triangle of Oxford, Cambridge and London. But, with an election perhaps only a year away, joined-up thinking comes second to votes in marginals, and the upshot of the high pound for those not working in manufacturing is low inflation and rising real incomes. At least for now.

As it is, the dark side of operational independence for the Bank means that it has a single policy objective - to keep inflation at 2.5% - and a single policy instrument to achieve it, the manipulation of short-term interest rates. The members of the MPC know that the obvious cure for the travails of manufacturing in Sheffield, a substantial cut in base rates, will also result in higher house prices in Surbiton. So is there a way for policy-makers to clamber out of the hole? One answer, advanced in his new freedom by Michael Heseltine, is for the government simply to announce that it wants to join the euro at a lower rate than today's. In truth, there is no guarantee, given the capital flight out of euroland, that a stated intention to join the euro would bring down the exchange rate, even in the unlikely event of the rest of the euro-11 agreeing to such a plan. The real need at present is for some joined-up economic thinking. Interest rates could be cut, but only if the government is prepared to use fiscal policy more aggressively to curb demand in the economy's hotspots. A more progressive local property tax would be a good start. At a structural level, it makes little sense to be giving the go-ahead for new housing developments in the south-east, nor to allow high-tech facilities to be moved from the north-west to the golden triangle of Oxford, Cambridge and London. But, with an election perhaps only a year away, joined-up thinking comes second to votes in marginals, and the upshot of the high pound for those not working in manufacturing is low inflation and rising real incomes. At least for now.

fields.headline: Looted abbey
fields.standfirst: Search for the missing stones
fields.trailText: Friends of an 800-year-old Cistercian abbey are seeking ancient stones which may help to complete the picture of monastic life among the lonely hills of north Wales.
fields.body:
Friends of an 800-year-old Cistercian abbey are seeking ancient stones which may help to complete the picture of monastic life among the lonely hills of north Wales.

They are searching for masonry, including rare carvings, looted from Valle Crucis (Valley of the Cross) abbey near Llangollen since the dissolution of the monasteries in 1536.

They also hope to be able to find materials taken during the last 20 years by visitors looking for stylish additions to their homes and patios.

The abbey, in the kind of remote setting preferred by Cistercians in their wish to escape the ways of the world, was established in 1200 on land given by a prince of Powys to monks at Strata Marcella in mid-Wales.

At its peak there would have been about 15 monks plus lay brothers farming the surrounding fields.

But by the time Henry VIII wreaked havoc only about five monks remained.

The ruins now lie in pastures and include a west front with a richly carved doorway, rose window, rib-vaulted chapter house and inscription recording that in the 14th century "Abbot Adams carried out this work; may he rest in peace".

David Crane, secretary of the friends of the abbey, set up to support Cadw, the Welsh heritage agency, said: "After the dissolution, the abbey became a source of stone.

"It would have gone into houses and garden walls and much of it would be plain stone which would be impossible to identify.

"But other pieces - carved or worked - could be more significant and we would love to see them. We are not necessarily asking for them back.

"But we would like to find those stones, identify and record and see what they can tell us about the abbey."

The friends are also keen to discover what happened to artefacts excavated by a clergyman between 1890 and 1900. These included a silver seal, a rosary, a copy of the Koran found sealed up in a wall, Roman coins and stained glass.

fields.headline: Computer scandal 'cover-up'
fields.trailText: The former welfare minister, Frank Field, is to report his old department to parliament's financial watchdog for "covering up" millions of pounds of wasted cash on a computer system which was supposed to crack down on benefit overpayments.
fields.body:
The former welfare minister, Frank Field, is to report his old department to parliament's financial watchdog for "covering up" millions of pounds of wasted cash on a computer system which was supposed to crack down on benefit overpayments.

Mr Field is to ask Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, to investigate the Department of Social Security's mishandling of a computerised debt accounting and management system and the overpayment of 112,000 income support claimants by the Texas company, Electronic Data Systems.

It comes as Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, is planning to give the American firm a £1bn contract to take over the ministry's benefit payment system.

Mr Darling has compounded the scandal by declaring the lost taxpayers' cash a state secret, using Jack Straw's planned ban on the release of commercial information under the draft freedom of information bill to refuse to disclose how much money has been wasted. The ministry justifies this as essential to protect competitive commercial contracts signed by EDS.

Mr Field said yesterday: "I have decided the only people who could investigate this properly is the national audit office - particularly as EDS now holds 70% of all government information technology contracts. I am very worried about who is in control at the ministry."

The scandal is disclosed in today's Computing Weekly magazine, which reveals that an internal department of social security review has cleared the company and any officials of responsibility for the mess. The ministry said that the benefit system was found to be too complicated to monitor all overpayments without substantial additional expense. Officials had managed to trace two thirds of a missing £10.5m in overpayments - leaving £3m still to be collected.

webTitle: New phone code brings Heathrow to Bodmin

fields.headline: New phone code brings Heathrow to Bodmin
fields.trailText: When Dorothy Dearsley first stumbled downstairs in the night in Cornwall to answer a call for a business centre in Heathrow she shrugged it off as one of life's minor irritations: a wrong number.
fields.body:
When Dorothy Dearsley first stumbled downstairs in the night in Cornwall to answer a call for a business centre in Heathrow she shrugged it off as one of life's minor irritations: a wrong number.

However, less than a fortnight after the Big Number change, Mrs Dearsley, 62, has had hundreds of callers who have dialled 01208, the code for Bodmin, instead of 020 8, the new outer London number.

Others have had the same problem, particularly those whose numbers are the same as the first 10 digits of Heathrow airport departments and hotels. One Bodmin shopkeeper has been inundated with confidential faxes on asylum seekers intended for the immigration office at Heathrow, while a press operator has received more than 70 calls for the Radisson Edwardian hotel.

But it is Mrs Dearsley and her husband, John, 63, a toolmaker, who have been the worst affected. "We've had literally hundreds of calls since the changes were announced last autumn," she said.

"Last month we had 142 in two weeks. At its worst, we've averaged 20 a day, and since March 22 I've had 79 calls for the Sheraton hotel, 39 for the Park, 10 for the Apollo, five for the Thistle and four for Hertz cars. It's making my life a misery."

The couple's case has been taken up by their MP, the Liberal Democrat Paul Tyler, who has written, demanding com pensation, to BT, the telecommunications watchdog Oftel, and the Big Number, the phone operators' organisation that oversaw the April 22 switch.

Calls to hotels tend to come from abroad and, according to the time zone, disrupt the couple's sleep. Some callers had been abusive, said Mrs Dearsley. "One woman ringing from Asia said 'You've taken your time to answer', and then rang five times on the trot after refusing to accept it was the wrong number."

Mr Tyler, MP for North Cornwall, said the situation was not only inconvenient for private households, but also expensive for local businesses. "My constituents are getting literally hundreds of misdialled calls, but those who have complained to BT have received a buck-passing answer, telling them they may have to change their number.

"That's totally irresponsible. This is a big mess but a foreseeable mess, and there's no way they should be asked to do that without compensation."

A BT spokesman said the number changes were imposed by Oftel on the whole industry and were not BT's responsibility. "The only permanent way of sorting out the problem is to change the customer's phone number," he said.

A spokesman for the Big Number also disclaimed responsibility: "There is not much we can do. The networks have been switched over successfully. This situation is to do with people misdialling, over which we have no control."

fields.headline: E coli warning over pets
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Domestic pets can carry the potentially fatal food poisoning bacteria E coli in their guts and pass it on to young children, new research suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
Domestic pets can carry the potentially fatal food poisoning bacteria E coli in their guts and pass it on to young children, new research suggested yesterday.

Although scientists have known for some time that the stomach bug can be carried by farm animals such as cattle and goats, the discovery that dogs and cats can also harbour it means toddlers are at risk of picking it up from faeces.

Mac Johnson, of the Royal Veterinary College, said parents of young children should follow hygiene procedures which would reduce the risk of E coli being passed on.

He stressed that the findings did not mean parents should avoid keeping pets altogether, but said: "The issue that has been raised by the findings is that parents - especially of children under five - should take good care. It's a question of doing things sensibly - having good hygiene around the food preparation areas.

"For example, should we allow cats to walk across the breakfast bar, even walk across plates the children are going to have their breakfast from?

"Should we allow a toddler to swing on the dog's tail then stick their thumb in their mouth?

"It's simple things like care, hand-washing and making sure they don't actually roll about in dog's droppings," he told BBC1 Breakfast News.

The bug was especially dangerous because it did not cause illness in animals, and so could not be easily recognised.

"It's a nasty bug, it doesn't need many organisms to cause the illness and certainly in the under-ones it's actually quite dangerous," he said.

fields.headline: US navy under fire
fields.standfirst: Marshals move in to end year-long protest at Puerto Rican military range
fields.trailText: The US military is expected to resume bombing a remote Caribbean island within days after protesters were cleared from target ranges in a dawn raid yesterday, halting - at least for now - a year of protests that has included politicians and the clergy.
fields.body:
The US military is expected to resume bombing a remote Caribbean island within days after protesters were cleared from target ranges in a dawn raid yesterday, halting - at least for now - a year of protests that has included politicians and the clergy.

"Puerto Rico has been invaded again," said a New York city council member, Jose Rivera, who was one of several politicians who joined the demonstrators on Vieques, a 21-mile long island eight miles east of the mainland. "I can promise you that tomorrow there will be civil disobedience all over the US."

Protests have been planned for cities from New York to San Francisco. But federal agents did their best to defuse the issue by removing about 160 people from beach camps and the main gate to the range without arrests.

The demonstrators have threatened to use wire cutters to get back on to land appropriated by the navy nearly 60 years ago. Two-thirds of the island's 52 square miles were taken over, leaving the population of 9,300 to live on a central strip.

Resentment at up to 198 days a year of bombardment came to a head 12 months ago when a stray missile killed a civilian security guard. Operations were suspended as protesters occupied beaches on the firing range littered with unexploded munitions.

The navy says that only Vieques - used to prepare for every conflict since the second world war - is suitable for simultaneous air and sea training using live ammunition. Admiral Jay Johnson, the chief of naval operations, said: "Vieques is an irreplaceable asset." But this claim is contradicted by a deal brokered by President Bill Clinton, under which the bombing will resume - though with dummy ordnance - until the people of Vieques vote next year on whether the military should stay permanently or go in 2003.

The islanders blame the navy for a cancer rate that is 27% higher than on the Puerto Rican mainland, stunted economic development, damage to the environment and to fishing grounds which, other than the tourism and service industries, provide the local employment opportunities.

Yesterday's raid had been expected for weeks. All the politicans who were removed are of Puerto Rican extraction. Congressman Luis Gutierrez of Illinois, who was taken away with two bishops and about 12 nuns, said of the federal agents: "They are trying to be extremely courteous, but I think they understand that they are wrong because they have lost any moral authority.

"They may remove us but there will be many others to follow."

webTitle: Study reveals teenage regrets over first sex

fields.headline: Study reveals teenage regrets over first sex
fields.trailText: Young people who have sex before they are 15 often regret it afterwards, according to the first large-scale study of the sexual behaviour of the age group.
fields.body:
Young people who have sex before they are 15 often regret it afterwards, according to the first large-scale study of the sexual behaviour of the age group.

The research took place in Scotland in 1996 and 1997, prompted by concerns that the proportion of young people having sex before the legal age of consent was increasing. Previous studies have found young people regret having sex too early, but have tended to canvass the views of older teenagers whose views might be coloured by the fact they are looking back a few years.

For this study Daniel Wight and colleagues from the MRC social and public health sciences unit in Glasgow took questionnaires into 24 state schools in east Scotland. Young people in their third year, aged 14 on average, filled them in under exam conditions with researchers but no teachers present. Consent was given by the young people themselves and their parents.

Writing in the British Medical Journal today, the researchers say they received 7,395 useable questionnaires, of which 3,665 were from boys and 3,730 from girls.

Some 18% of the girls (661) and 15.4% of the boys (576) said they had experienced sexual intercourse. Most of them (74.8%) said they first had sex after their 13th birthday. Most (60.2%) said they had used a condom, but 18.9% had not used contraception.

Two-fifths of the young people were happy to have had the experience, saying that first intercourse "was at about the right time", but a third of the girls (32%) and a slightly smaller proportion of the boys (27%) felt it had happened too early, while 13% of girls and 5% of boys stated that it should not have happened at all. There was no association between having regrets and either social class, family composition or condom use.

A fifth of the girls said they had been under some kind of pressure to have sex both the first time (19.8%) and most recent time (18.1%), compared with 7% and 9.1% respectively for boys.

Those boys who reported that they had put pressure on girls to have sex felt more regrets over the experience than the others. The girls who felt regret were more likely to have felt pressured and not to have planned sexual intercourse with their partner beforehand. They were also more likely to report a fairly high level of monitoring of their behaviour by their parents. "In short," say the researchers, "for young women, regret seemed to be related to lack of control."

They conclude that young people need more help to feel in control of their sexual activity. "Health promotion should aim to help young people to develop relationship and negotiation skills. Sexual health education focusing on such skills can increase control ... making young people aware of the potential emotional and relationship consequences of early sexual intercourse may delay first intercourse."

webTitle: Top cyclist died after driver 'was distracted'

fields.headline: Top cyclist died after driver 'was distracted'
fields.standfirst: Inventor of superbike was killed while training for record attempt
fields.trailText: World record breaking cyclist Bruce Bursford, 41, was killed on a training ride when a lorry driver was distracted by his mobile phone, an inquest in Norwich heard yesterday.
fields.body:
World record breaking cyclist Bruce Bursford, 41, was killed on a training ride when a lorry driver was distracted by his mobile phone, an inquest in Norwich heard yesterday.

Mr Bursford died on the day he had received a letter from Tony Blair praising his invention, the Ultimate Bike, a space-age racer for which he had secured an export deal in the United States. The inquest heard that the driver of the tipper truck, Darren Greenwood, 35, of Toftwood, Norfolk, said to police minutes after the collision: "I just took my eyes off the road and that was it. At the time my mobile phone was ringing in my holdall."

The crash happened on a dry, clear day in February on the A47 nine miles from Mr Bursford's home at Dereham, Norfolk. He was on a 40-mile training ride using a conventional bike, and was clearly visible to other road users in a red, white, and blue cycling top with UK Ultimate Bike Team emblazoned across it, the inquest was told. He was cycling at 20 to 25mph and the lorry was going at 60 mph.

The Norwich district coroner, William Armstrong, read out a statement by Shirley Holbrook, who was driving in a car behind the lorry: "The driver would have had the cyclist in his view for two or three minutes, and I cannot understand why he didn't see him."

The accident investigator, PC Nicholas Kett, also told the inquest he believed the driver had failed to see the cyclist, and said that he was to be prosecuted for driving without due care and attention.

The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, adding: "It is a tremendous tragedy that the life of Bruce, who had such a distinguished career, brought pleasure to many people and was held in such high regard, was cut short in this appalling way."

At the time of his death, Mr Bursford was in training for the world hour cycling endurance record to add to 10 world records he held. His invention of the space-age bicycle had gone virtually unnoticed until in 1995 he set a world record with it of 207.9mph on a "rolling road"; the next year he accelerated faster than a Ferrari to reach 210.2mph, and in 1998 he reached the absolute record for a solo cyclist of 212.48mph during TV's Tomorrow's World Live show in Birmingham. In 1999 he gained another world record cycling an average 39 mph over a five-minute period on a hilly Welsh road.

Mr Bursford left a wife, Tracey, who was not at the inquest, and daughters Samantha, 10, and Jade, six.

After the inquest it emerged that the letter to Mr Bursford from Mr Blair's office had congratulated him on designing his "world beating" cycle.

Mr Bursford had met the prime minister at a Millennium Dome event last December. The inventor had three of his products displayed in the dome, two Ultimate Bikes and a revolutionary cycling helmet that he had designed. He had read Mr Blair's letter before setting out on the fatal training ride.

His bicycle, which sells in the US at prices from £9,000 to £25,000, has wheel bearings of silicon nitride, as do bearings in Nasa space shuttles and in Exocet missiles, and a skin of a carbon-based epoxy resin used in the US Stealth bomber.

His invention of the space-age bicycle had gone virtually unnoticed until in 1995 he set a world record with it of 207.9mph on a "rolling road"; the next year he accelerated faster than a Ferrari to reach 210.2mph, and in 1998 he reached the absolute record for a solo cyclist of 212.48mph during TV's Tomorrow's World Live show in Birmingham. In 1999 he gained another world record cycling an average 39 mph over a five-minute period on a hilly Welsh road. Mr Bursford left a wife, Tracey, who was not at the inquest, and daughters Samantha, 10, and Jade, six. After the inquest it emerged that the letter to Mr Bursford from Mr Blair's office had congratulated him on designing his "world beating" cycle. Mr Bursford had met the prime minister at a Millennium Dome event last December. The inventor had three of his products displayed in the dome, two Ultimate Bikes and a revolutionary cycling helmet that he had designed. He had read Mr Blair's letter before setting out on the fatal training ride. His bicycle, which sells in the US at prices from £9,000 to £25,000, has wheel bearings of silicon nitride, as do bearings in Nasa space shuttles and in Exocet missiles, and a skin of a carbon-based epoxy resin used in the US Stealth bomber.

webTitle: Cricket seeks solace at the Bar

fields.headline: Cricket seeks solace at the Bar
fields.trailText: The man charged with overseeing cricket's clean-up campaign may be recruited from the Bar in London, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The man charged with overseeing cricket's clean-up campaign may be recruited from the Bar in London, it emerged yesterday.

Speaking in his first interview since this week's match-rigging conference, Malcolm Gray, the incoming president of the International Cricket Council, said it was looking for a dynamic and ambitious legal expert.

"We don't want the old retired person doing it on a grace and favour basis," said Gray. "We want a young, energetic person, someone like a top criminal barrister from the London Bar for instance, a forty-something who is driving a career."

According to Gray, the ICC is looking for quick action from its new anti-corruption investigation. He takes over from Jagmohan Dalmiya as president towards the end of June and yesterday he made clear that he wanted to see positive results in the next five months.

The 59-year-old former chairman of the Australian Cricket Board said the game was in a state of shock. "It's like being in the trenches," he said, "but that is when you pull together."

Gray realises though that it will be his job to ensure that the enthusiasm to root out corruption in the game is maintained, although he is keen that things will begin to move soon. "I hope it's five months rather than five years before we see something."

It was agreed to set up an independent anti-corruption investigation at this week's meeting of the ICC at Lord's.

The South African judge Justice Edwin King is to head the inquiry into the Hansie Cronje corruption affair, a spokeswoman for the United Cricket Board of South Africa said yesterday.

 Kapil Dev, India's coach and former captain, is to take legal action after allegations made by Inderjit Singh Bindra, the former president of the Board of Control for Cricket in India, in an interview with CNN.
